    53	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
    54	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStately, plump Buck Mulligan came from the stairhead, bearing a bowl of
    55	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlather on which a mirror and a razor lay crossed. A yellow dressinggown,
    56	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tungirdled, was sustained gently behind him on the mild morning air. He
    57	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theld the bowl aloft and intoned:
    58	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
    59	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Introibo ad altare Dei.
    60	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
    61	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHalted, he peered down the dark winding stairs and called out coarsely:
    62	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
    63	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Come up, Kinch! Come up, you fearful jesuit!
    64	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
    65	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSolemnly he came forward and mounted the round gunrest. He faced about
    66	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand blessed gravely thrice the tower, the surrounding land and the
    67	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tawaking mountains. Then, catching sight of Stephen Dedalus, he bent
    68	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttowards him and made rapid crosses in the air, gurgling in his throat
    69	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand shaking his head. Stephen Dedalus, displeased and sleepy, leaned
    70	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this arms on the top of the staircase and looked coldly at the shaking
    71	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgurgling face that blessed him, equine in its length, and at the light
    72	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tuntonsured hair, grained and hued like pale oak.
    73	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
    74	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan peeped an instant under the mirror and then covered the
    75	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbowl smartly.
    76	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
    77	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Back to barracks! he said sternly.
    78	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
    79	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe added in a preacher’s tone:
    80	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
    81	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—For this, O dearly beloved, is the genuine Christine: body and soul and
    82	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblood and ouns. Slow music, please. Shut your eyes, gents. One moment. A
    83	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlittle trouble about those white corpuscles. Silence, all.
    84	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
    85	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe peered sideways up and gave a long slow whistle of call, then paused
    86	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tawhile in rapt attention, his even white teeth glistening here and there
    87	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith gold points. Chrysostomos. Two strong shrill whistles answered
    88	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthrough the calm.
    89	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
    90	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Thanks, old chap, he cried briskly. That will do nicely. Switch off the
    91	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcurrent, will you?
    92	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
    93	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe skipped off the gunrest and looked gravely at his watcher, gathering
    94	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabout his legs the loose folds of his gown. The plump shadowed face and
    95	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsullen oval jowl recalled a prelate, patron of arts in the middle ages.
    96	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA pleasant smile broke quietly over his lips.
    97	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
    98	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The mockery of it! he said gaily. Your absurd name, an ancient Greek!
    99	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   100	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe pointed his finger in friendly jest and went over to the parapet,
   101	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlaughing to himself. Stephen Dedalus stepped up, followed him wearily
   102	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thalfway and sat down on the edge of the gunrest, watching him still as
   103	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the propped his mirror on the parapet, dipped the brush in the bowl and
   104	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlathered cheeks and neck.
   105	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   106	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan’s gay voice went on.
   107	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   108	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—My name is absurd too: Malachi Mulligan, two dactyls. But it has a
   109	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHellenic ring, hasn’t it? Tripping and sunny like the buck himself.
   110	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWe must go to Athens. Will you come if I can get the aunt to fork out
   111	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttwenty quid?
   112	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   113	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe laid the brush aside and, laughing with delight, cried:
   114	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   115	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Will he come? The jejune jesuit!
   116	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   117	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCeasing, he began to shave with care.
   118	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   119	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Tell me, Mulligan, Stephen said quietly.
   120	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   121	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, my love?
   122	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   123	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—How long is Haines going to stay in this tower?
   124	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   125	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan showed a shaven cheek over his right shoulder.
   126	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   127	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—God, isn’t he dreadful? he said frankly. A ponderous Saxon. He thinks
   128	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou’re not a gentleman. God, these bloody English! Bursting with money
   129	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand indigestion. Because he comes from Oxford. You know, Dedalus, you
   130	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thave the real Oxford manner. He can’t make you out. O, my name for you
   131	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis the best: Kinch, the knife-blade.
   132	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   133	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe shaved warily over his chin.
   134	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   135	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He was raving all night about a black panther, Stephen said. Where is
   136	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this guncase?
   137	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   138	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A woful lunatic! Mulligan said. Were you in a funk?
   139	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   140	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I was, Stephen said with energy and growing fear. Out here in the dark
   141	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith a man I don’t know raving and moaning to himself about shooting a
   142	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblack panther. You saved men from drowning. I’m not a hero, however. If
   143	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the stays on here I am off.
   144	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   145	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan frowned at the lather on his razorblade. He hopped down
   146	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom his perch and began to search his trouser pockets hastily.
   147	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   148	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Scutter! he cried thickly.
   149	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   150	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe came over to the gunrest and, thrusting a hand into Stephen’s upper
   151	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpocket, said:
   152	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   153	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Lend us a loan of your noserag to wipe my razor.
   154	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   155	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen suffered him to pull out and hold up on show by its corner a
   156	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdirty crumpled handkerchief. Buck Mulligan wiped the razorblade neatly.
   157	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThen, gazing over the handkerchief, he said:
   158	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   159	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The bard’s noserag! A new art colour for our Irish poets: snotgreen.
   160	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYou can almost taste it, can’t you?
   161	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   162	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe mounted to the parapet again and gazed out over Dublin bay, his fair
   163	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toakpale hair stirring slightly.
   164	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   165	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—God! he said quietly. Isn’t the sea what Algy calls it: a great sweet
   166	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmother? The snotgreen sea. The scrotumtightening sea. Epi oinopa ponton.
   167	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAh, Dedalus, the Greeks! I must teach you. You must read them in the
   168	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toriginal. Thalatta! Thalatta! She is our great sweet mother. Come and
   169	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlook.
   170	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   171	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen stood up and went over to the parapet. Leaning on it he looked
   172	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdown on the water and on the mailboat clearing the harbourmouth of
   173	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKingstown.
   174	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   175	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Our mighty mother! Buck Mulligan said.
   176	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   177	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe turned abruptly his grey searching eyes from the sea to Stephen’s
   178	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tface.
   179	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   180	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The aunt thinks you killed your mother, he said. That’s why she won’t
   181	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlet me have anything to do with you.
   182	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   183	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Someone killed her, Stephen said gloomily.
   184	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   185	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You could have knelt down, damn it, Kinch, when your dying mother asked
   186	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou, Buck Mulligan said. I’m hyperborean as much as you. But to think of
   187	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyour mother begging you with her last breath to kneel down and pray for
   188	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther. And you refused. There is something sinister in you....
   189	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   190	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe broke off and lathered again lightly his farther cheek. A tolerant
   191	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsmile curled his lips.
   192	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   193	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—But a lovely mummer! he murmured to himself. Kinch, the loveliest
   194	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmummer of them all!
   195	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   196	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe shaved evenly and with care, in silence, seriously.
   197	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   198	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen, an elbow rested on the jagged granite, leaned his palm against
   199	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this brow and gazed at the fraying edge of his shiny black coat-sleeve.
   200	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPain, that was not yet the pain of love, fretted his heart. Silently, in
   201	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta dream she had come to him after her death, her wasted body within its
   202	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tloose brown graveclothes giving off an odour of wax and rosewood, her
   203	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbreath, that had bent upon him, mute, reproachful, a faint odour of
   204	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twetted ashes. Across the threadbare cuffedge he saw the sea hailed as a
   205	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgreat sweet mother by the wellfed voice beside him. The ring of bay
   206	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand skyline held a dull green mass of liquid. A bowl of white china had
   207	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstood beside her deathbed holding the green sluggish bile which she had
   208	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttorn up from her rotting liver by fits of loud groaning vomiting.
   209	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   210	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan wiped again his razorblade.
   211	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   212	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ah, poor dogsbody! he said in a kind voice. I must give you a shirt and
   213	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta few noserags. How are the secondhand breeks?
   214	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   215	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—They fit well enough, Stephen answered.
   216	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   217	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan attacked the hollow beneath his underlip.
   218	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   219	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The mockery of it, he said contentedly. Secondleg they should be. God
   220	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknows what poxy bowsy left them off. I have a lovely pair with a hair
   221	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstripe, grey. You’ll look spiffing in them. I’m not joking, Kinch. You
   222	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlook damn well when you’re dressed.
   223	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   224	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Thanks, Stephen said. I can’t wear them if they are grey.
   225	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   226	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He can’t wear them, Buck Mulligan told his face in the mirror.
   227	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEtiquette is etiquette. He kills his mother but he can’t wear grey
   228	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttrousers.
   229	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   230	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe folded his razor neatly and with stroking palps of fingers felt the
   231	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsmooth skin.
   232	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   233	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen turned his gaze from the sea and to the plump face with its
   234	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsmokeblue mobile eyes.
   235	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   236	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That fellow I was with in the Ship last night, said Buck Mulligan, says
   237	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou have g. p. i. He’s up in Dottyville with Connolly Norman. General
   238	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tparalysis of the insane!
   239	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   240	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe swept the mirror a half circle in the air to flash the tidings abroad
   241	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin sunlight now radiant on the sea. His curling shaven lips laughed and
   242	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe edges of his white glittering teeth. Laughter seized all his strong
   243	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twellknit trunk.
   244	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   245	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Look at yourself, he said, you dreadful bard!
   246	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   247	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen bent forward and peered at the mirror held out to him, cleft by
   248	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta crooked crack. Hair on end. As he and others see me. Who chose this
   249	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tface for me? This dogsbody to rid of vermin. It asks me too.
   250	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   251	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I pinched it out of the skivvy’s room, Buck Mulligan said. It does her
   252	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall right. The aunt always keeps plainlooking servants for Malachi. Lead
   253	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim not into temptation. And her name is Ursula.
   254	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   255	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLaughing again, he brought the mirror away from Stephen’s peering eyes.
   256	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   257	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The rage of Caliban at not seeing his face in a mirror, he said. If
   258	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWilde were only alive to see you!
   259	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   260	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDrawing back and pointing, Stephen said with bitterness:
   261	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   262	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—It is a symbol of Irish art. The cracked lookingglass of a servant.
   263	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   264	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan suddenly linked his arm in Stephen’s and walked with him
   265	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tround the tower, his razor and mirror clacking in the pocket where he
   266	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thad thrust them.
   267	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   268	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—It’s not fair to tease you like that, Kinch, is it? he said kindly. God
   269	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknows you have more spirit than any of them.
   270	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   271	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tParried again. He fears the lancet of my art as I fear that of his. The
   272	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcold steel pen.
   273	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   274	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Cracked lookingglass of a servant! Tell that to the oxy chap downstairs
   275	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand touch him for a guinea. He’s stinking with money and thinks you’re
   276	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnot a gentleman. His old fellow made his tin by selling jalap to Zulus
   277	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tor some bloody swindle or other. God, Kinch, if you and I could only
   278	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twork together we might do something for the island. Hellenise it.
   279	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   280	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCranly’s arm. His arm.
   281	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   282	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And to think of your having to beg from these swine. I’m the only one
   283	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat knows what you are. Why don’t you trust me more? What have you
   284	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tup your nose against me? Is it Haines? If he makes any noise here I’ll
   285	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbring down Seymour and we’ll give him a ragging worse than they gave
   286	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tClive Kempthorpe.
   287	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   288	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYoung shouts of moneyed voices in Clive Kempthorpe’s rooms. Palefaces:
   289	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey hold their ribs with laughter, one clasping another. O, I shall
   290	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\texpire! Break the news to her gently, Aubrey! I shall die! With slit
   291	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tribbons of his shirt whipping the air he hops and hobbles round the
   292	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttable, with trousers down at heels, chased by Ades of Magdalen with the
   293	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttailor’s shears. A scared calf’s face gilded with marmalade. I don’t
   294	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twant to be debagged! Don’t you play the giddy ox with me!
   295	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   296	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShouts from the open window startling evening in the quadrangle. A deaf
   297	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgardener, aproned, masked with Matthew Arnold’s face, pushes his mower
   298	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton the sombre lawn watching narrowly the dancing motes of grasshalms.
   299	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   300	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTo ourselves... new paganism... omphalos.
   301	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   302	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Let him stay, Stephen said. There’s nothing wrong with him except at
   303	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnight.
   304	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   305	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Then what is it? Buck Mulligan asked impatiently. Cough it up. I’m
   306	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquite frank with you. What have you against me now?
   307	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   308	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey halted, looking towards the blunt cape of Bray Head that lay on the
   309	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twater like the snout of a sleeping whale. Stephen freed his arm quietly.
   310	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   311	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Do you wish me to tell you? he asked.
   312	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   313	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, what is it? Buck Mulligan answered. I don’t remember anything.
   314	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   315	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe looked in Stephen’s face as he spoke. A light wind passed his brow,
   316	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfanning softly his fair uncombed hair and stirring silver points of
   317	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanxiety in his eyes.
   318	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   319	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen, depressed by his own voice, said:
   320	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   321	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Do you remember the first day I went to your house after my mother’s
   322	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeath?
   323	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   324	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan frowned quickly and said:
   325	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   326	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What? Where? I can’t remember anything. I remember only ideas and
   327	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsensations. Why? What happened in the name of God?
   328	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   329	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You were making tea, Stephen said, and went across the landing to
   330	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tget more hot water. Your mother and some visitor came out of the
   331	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrawingroom. She asked you who was in your room.
   332	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   333	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes? Buck Mulligan said. What did I say? I forget.
   334	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   335	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You said, Stephen answered, O, it’s only Dedalus whose mother is
   336	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeastly dead.
   337	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   338	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA flush which made him seem younger and more engaging rose to Buck
   339	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMulligan’s cheek.
   340	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   341	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Did I say that? he asked. Well? What harm is that?
   342	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   343	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe shook his constraint from him nervously.
   344	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   345	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And what is death, he asked, your mother’s or yours or my own? You
   346	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaw only your mother die. I see them pop off every day in the Mater and
   347	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRichmond and cut up into tripes in the dissectingroom. It’s a beastly
   348	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthing and nothing else. It simply doesn’t matter. You wouldn’t kneel
   349	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdown to pray for your mother on her deathbed when she asked you. Why?
   350	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBecause you have the cursed jesuit strain in you, only it’s injected the
   351	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twrong way. To me it’s all a mockery and beastly. Her cerebral lobes
   352	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tare not functioning. She calls the doctor sir Peter Teazle and picks
   353	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbuttercups off the quilt. Humour her till it’s over. You crossed her
   354	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlast wish in death and yet you sulk with me because I don’t whinge like
   355	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsome hired mute from Lalouette’s. Absurd! I suppose I did say it. I
   356	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdidn’t mean to offend the memory of your mother.
   357	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   358	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe had spoken himself into boldness. Stephen, shielding the gaping
   359	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twounds which the words had left in his heart, said very coldly:
   360	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   361	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I am not thinking of the offence to my mother.
   362	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   363	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Of what then? Buck Mulligan asked.
   364	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   365	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Of the offence to me, Stephen answered.
   366	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   367	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan swung round on his heel.
   368	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   369	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, an impossible person! he exclaimed.
   370	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   371	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe walked off quickly round the parapet. Stephen stood at his post,
   372	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgazing over the calm sea towards the headland. Sea and headland now grew
   373	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdim. Pulses were beating in his eyes, veiling their sight, and he felt
   374	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe fever of his cheeks.
   375	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   376	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA voice within the tower called loudly:
   377	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   378	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Are you up there, Mulligan?
   379	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   380	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’m coming, Buck Mulligan answered.
   381	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   382	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe turned towards Stephen and said:
   383	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   384	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Look at the sea. What does it care about offences? Chuck Loyola, Kinch,
   385	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand come on down. The Sassenach wants his morning rashers.
   386	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   387	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis head halted again for a moment at the top of the staircase, level
   388	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith the roof:
   389	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   390	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Don’t mope over it all day, he said. I’m inconsequent. Give up the
   391	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmoody brooding.
   392	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   393	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis head vanished but the drone of his descending voice boomed out of
   394	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe stairhead:
   395	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   396	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     And no more turn aside and brood
   397	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Upon love’s bitter mystery
   398	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     For Fergus rules the brazen cars.
   399	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   400	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWoodshadows floated silently by through the morning peace from the
   401	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstairhead seaward where he gazed. Inshore and farther out the mirror of
   402	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twater whitened, spurned by lightshod hurrying feet. White breast of
   403	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe dim sea. The twining stresses, two by two. A hand plucking the
   404	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tharpstrings, merging their twining chords. Wavewhite wedded words
   405	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshimmering on the dim tide.
   406	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   407	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA cloud began to cover the sun slowly, wholly, shadowing the bay in
   408	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeeper green. It lay beneath him, a bowl of bitter waters. Fergus’ song:
   409	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI sang it alone in the house, holding down the long dark chords. Her
   410	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoor was open: she wanted to hear my music. Silent with awe and pity
   411	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI went to her bedside. She was crying in her wretched bed. For those
   412	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twords, Stephen: love’s bitter mystery.
   413	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   414	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhere now?
   415	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   416	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHer secrets: old featherfans, tasselled dancecards, powdered with musk,
   417	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta gaud of amber beads in her locked drawer. A birdcage hung in the sunny
   418	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twindow of her house when she was a girl. She heard old Royce sing in the
   419	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpantomime of Turko the Terrible and laughed with others when he sang:
   420	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   421	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     I am the boy
   422	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     That can enjoy
   423	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Invisibility.
   424	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   425	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPhantasmal mirth, folded away: muskperfumed.
   426	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   427	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd no more turn aside and brood.
   428	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   429	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFolded away in the memory of nature with her toys. Memories beset his
   430	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrooding brain. Her glass of water from the kitchen tap when she had
   431	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tapproached the sacrament. A cored apple, filled with brown sugar,
   432	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\troasting for her at the hob on a dark autumn evening. Her shapely
   433	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfingernails reddened by the blood of squashed lice from the children’s
   434	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshirts.
   435	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   436	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn a dream, silently, she had come to him, her wasted body within its
   437	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tloose graveclothes giving off an odour of wax and rosewood, her breath,
   438	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbent over him with mute secret words, a faint odour of wetted ashes.
   439	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   440	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHer glazing eyes, staring out of death, to shake and bend my soul. On me
   441	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\talone. The ghostcandle to light her agony. Ghostly light on the tortured
   442	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tface. Her hoarse loud breath rattling in horror, while all prayed on
   443	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir knees. Her eyes on me to strike me down. Liliata rutilantium te
   444	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconfessorum turma circumdet: iubilantium te virginum chorus excipiat.
   445	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   446	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGhoul! Chewer of corpses!
   447	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   448	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNo, mother! Let me be and let me live.
   449	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   450	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Kinch ahoy!
   451	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   452	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan’s voice sang from within the tower. It came nearer up the
   453	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstaircase, calling again. Stephen, still trembling at his soul’s cry,
   454	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theard warm running sunlight and in the air behind him friendly words.
   455	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   456	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Dedalus, come down, like a good mosey. Breakfast is ready. Haines is
   457	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tapologising for waking us last night. It’s all right.
   458	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   459	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’m coming, Stephen said, turning.
   460	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   461	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Do, for Jesus’ sake, Buck Mulligan said. For my sake and for all our
   462	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsakes.
   463	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   464	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis head disappeared and reappeared.
   465	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   466	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I told him your symbol of Irish art. He says it’s very clever. Touch
   467	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim for a quid, will you? A guinea, I mean.
   468	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   469	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I get paid this morning, Stephen said.
   470	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   471	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The school kip? Buck Mulligan said. How much? Four quid? Lend us one.
   472	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   473	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—If you want it, Stephen said.
   474	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   475	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Four shining sovereigns, Buck Mulligan cried with delight. We’ll have
   476	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta glorious drunk to astonish the druidy druids. Four omnipotent
   477	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsovereigns.
   478	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   479	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe flung up his hands and tramped down the stone stairs, singing out of
   480	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttune with a Cockney accent:
   481	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   482	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     O, won’t we have a merry time,
   483	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Drinking whisky, beer and wine!
   484	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     On coronation,
   485	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Coronation day!
   486	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     O, won’t we have a merry time
   487	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     On coronation day!
   488	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   489	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWarm sunshine merrying over the sea. The nickel shavingbowl shone,
   490	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tforgotten, on the parapet. Why should I bring it down? Or leave it there
   491	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall day, forgotten friendship?
   492	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   493	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe went over to it, held it in his hands awhile, feeling its coolness,
   494	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsmelling the clammy slaver of the lather in which the brush was stuck.
   495	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo I carried the boat of incense then at Clongowes. I am another now and
   496	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyet the same. A servant too. A server of a servant.
   497	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   498	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn the gloomy domed livingroom of the tower Buck Mulligan’s gowned form
   499	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmoved briskly to and fro about the hearth, hiding and revealing its
   500	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyellow glow. Two shafts of soft daylight fell across the flagged floor
   501	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom the high barbacans: and at the meeting of their rays a cloud of
   502	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcoalsmoke and fumes of fried grease floated, turning.
   503	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   504	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—We’ll be choked, Buck Mulligan said. Haines, open that door, will you?
   505	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   506	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen laid the shavingbowl on the locker. A tall figure rose from the
   507	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thammock where it had been sitting, went to the doorway and pulled open
   508	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe inner doors.
   509	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   510	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Have you the key? a voice asked.
   511	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   512	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Dedalus has it, Buck Mulligan said. Janey Mack, I’m choked!
   513	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   514	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe howled, without looking up from the fire:
   515	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   516	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Kinch!
   517	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   518	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—It’s in the lock, Stephen said, coming forward.
   519	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   520	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe key scraped round harshly twice and, when the heavy door had been
   521	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tset ajar, welcome light and bright air entered. Haines stood at the
   522	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoorway, looking out. Stephen haled his upended valise to the table and
   523	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsat down to wait. Buck Mulligan tossed the fry on to the dish beside
   524	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim. Then he carried the dish and a large teapot over to the table, set
   525	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem down heavily and sighed with relief.
   526	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   527	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’m melting, he said, as the candle remarked when... But, hush! Not a
   528	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tword more on that subject! Kinch, wake up! Bread, butter, honey. Haines,
   529	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcome in. The grub is ready. Bless us, O Lord, and these thy gifts.
   530	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhere’s the sugar? O, jay, there’s no milk.
   531	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   532	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen fetched the loaf and the pot of honey and the buttercooler from
   533	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe locker. Buck Mulligan sat down in a sudden pet.
   534	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   535	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What sort of a kip is this? he said. I told her to come after eight.
   536	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   537	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—We can drink it black, Stephen said thirstily. There’s a lemon in the
   538	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlocker.
   539	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   540	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, damn you and your Paris fads! Buck Mulligan said. I want Sandycove
   541	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmilk.
   542	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   543	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHaines came in from the doorway and said quietly:
   544	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   545	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That woman is coming up with the milk.
   546	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   547	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The blessings of God on you! Buck Mulligan cried, jumping up from his
   548	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchair. Sit down. Pour out the tea there. The sugar is in the bag. Here,
   549	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI can’t go fumbling at the damned eggs.
   550	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   551	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe hacked through the fry on the dish and slapped it out on three
   552	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplates, saying:
   553	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   554	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—In nomine Patris et Filii et Spiritus Sancti.
   555	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   556	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHaines sat down to pour out the tea.
   557	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   558	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’m giving you two lumps each, he said. But, I say, Mulligan, you do
   559	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmake strong tea, don’t you?
   560	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   561	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan, hewing thick slices from the loaf, said in an old woman’s
   562	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twheedling voice:
   563	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   564	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—When I makes tea I makes tea, as old mother Grogan said. And when I
   565	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmakes water I makes water.
   566	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   567	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—By Jove, it is tea, Haines said.
   568	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   569	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan went on hewing and wheedling:
   570	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   571	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—So I do, Mrs Cahill, says she. Begob, ma’am, says Mrs Cahill, God send
   572	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou don’t make them in the one pot.
   573	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   574	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe lunged towards his messmates in turn a thick slice of bread, impaled
   575	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton his knife.
   576	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   577	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That’s folk, he said very earnestly, for your book, Haines. Five
   578	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlines of text and ten pages of notes about the folk and the fishgods of
   579	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDundrum. Printed by the weird sisters in the year of the big wind.
   580	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   581	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe turned to Stephen and asked in a fine puzzled voice, lifting his
   582	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrows:
   583	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   584	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Can you recall, brother, is mother Grogan’s tea and water pot spoken of
   585	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the Mabinogion or is it in the Upanishads?
   586	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   587	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I doubt it, said Stephen gravely.
   588	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   589	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Do you now? Buck Mulligan said in the same tone. Your reasons, pray?
   590	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   591	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I fancy, Stephen said as he ate, it did not exist in or out of the
   592	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMabinogion. Mother Grogan was, one imagines, a kinswoman of Mary Ann.
   593	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   594	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan’s face smiled with delight.
   595	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   596	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Charming! he said in a finical sweet voice, showing his white teeth and
   597	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblinking his eyes pleasantly. Do you think she was? Quite charming!
   598	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   599	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThen, suddenly overclouding all his features, he growled in a hoarsened
   600	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trasping voice as he hewed again vigorously at the loaf:
   601	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   602	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     —For old Mary Ann
   603	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     She doesn’t care a damn.
   604	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     But, hising up her petticoats...
   605	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   606	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe crammed his mouth with fry and munched and droned.
   607	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   608	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe doorway was darkened by an entering form.
   609	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   610	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The milk, sir!
   611	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   612	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Come in, ma’am, Mulligan said. Kinch, get the jug.
   613	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   614	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAn old woman came forward and stood by Stephen’s elbow.
   615	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   616	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That’s a lovely morning, sir, she said. Glory be to God.
   617	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   618	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—To whom? Mulligan said, glancing at her. Ah, to be sure!
   619	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   620	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen reached back and took the milkjug from the locker.
   621	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   622	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The islanders, Mulligan said to Haines casually, speak frequently of
   623	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe collector of prepuces.
   624	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   625	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—How much, sir? asked the old woman.
   626	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   627	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A quart, Stephen said.
   628	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   629	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe watched her pour into the measure and thence into the jug rich white
   630	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmilk, not hers. Old shrunken paps. She poured again a measureful and
   631	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta tilly. Old and secret she had entered from a morning world, maybe
   632	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta messenger. She praised the goodness of the milk, pouring it out.
   633	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCrouching by a patient cow at daybreak in the lush field, a witch on her
   634	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoadstool, her wrinkled fingers quick at the squirting dugs. They lowed
   635	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabout her whom they knew, dewsilky cattle. Silk of the kine and poor old
   636	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twoman, names given her in old times. A wandering crone, lowly form of
   637	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tan immortal serving her conqueror and her gay betrayer, their common
   638	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcuckquean, a messenger from the secret morning. To serve or to upbraid,
   639	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhether he could not tell: but scorned to beg her favour.
   640	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   641	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—It is indeed, ma’am, Buck Mulligan said, pouring milk into their cups.
   642	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   643	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Taste it, sir, she said.
   644	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   645	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe drank at her bidding.
   646	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   647	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—If we could live on good food like that, he said to her somewhat
   648	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tloudly, we wouldn’t have the country full of rotten teeth and rotten
   649	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tguts. Living in a bogswamp, eating cheap food and the streets paved with
   650	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdust, horsedung and consumptives’ spits.
   651	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   652	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Are you a medical student, sir? the old woman asked.
   653	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   654	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I am, ma’am, Buck Mulligan answered.
   655	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   656	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Look at that now, she said.
   657	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   658	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen listened in scornful silence. She bows her old head to a voice
   659	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat speaks to her loudly, her bonesetter, her medicineman: me she
   660	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tslights. To the voice that will shrive and oil for the grave all there
   661	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis of her but her woman’s unclean loins, of man’s flesh made not in
   662	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGod’s likeness, the serpent’s prey. And to the loud voice that now bids
   663	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther be silent with wondering unsteady eyes.
   664	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   665	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Do you understand what he says? Stephen asked her.
   666	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   667	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Is it French you are talking, sir? the old woman said to Haines.
   668	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   669	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHaines spoke to her again a longer speech, confidently.
   670	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   671	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Irish, Buck Mulligan said. Is there Gaelic on you?
   672	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   673	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I thought it was Irish, she said, by the sound of it. Are you from the
   674	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twest, sir?
   675	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   676	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I am an Englishman, Haines answered.
   677	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   678	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He’s English, Buck Mulligan said, and he thinks we ought to speak Irish
   679	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin Ireland.
   680	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   681	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Sure we ought to, the old woman said, and I’m ashamed I don’t speak the
   682	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlanguage myself. I’m told it’s a grand language by them that knows.
   683	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   684	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Grand is no name for it, said Buck Mulligan. Wonderful entirely. Fill
   685	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tus out some more tea, Kinch. Would you like a cup, ma’am?
   686	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   687	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—No, thank you, sir, the old woman said, slipping the ring of the
   688	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmilkcan on her forearm and about to go.
   689	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   690	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHaines said to her:
   691	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   692	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Have you your bill? We had better pay her, Mulligan, hadn’t we?
   693	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   694	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen filled again the three cups.
   695	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   696	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Bill, sir? she said, halting. Well, it’s seven mornings a pint at
   697	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttwopence is seven twos is a shilling and twopence over and these three
   698	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmornings a quart at fourpence is three quarts is a shilling. That’s a
   699	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshilling and one and two is two and two, sir.
   700	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   701	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan sighed and, having filled his mouth with a crust thickly
   702	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbuttered on both sides, stretched forth his legs and began to search his
   703	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttrouser pockets.
   704	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   705	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Pay up and look pleasant, Haines said to him, smiling.
   706	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   707	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen filled a third cup, a spoonful of tea colouring faintly the
   708	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthick rich milk. Buck Mulligan brought up a florin, twisted it round in
   709	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this fingers and cried:
   710	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   711	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A miracle!
   712	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   713	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe passed it along the table towards the old woman, saying:
   714	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   715	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ask nothing more of me, sweet. All I can give you I give.
   716	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   717	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen laid the coin in her uneager hand.
   718	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   719	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—We’ll owe twopence, he said.
   720	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   721	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Time enough, sir, she said, taking the coin. Time enough. Good morning,
   722	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsir.
   723	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   724	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe curtseyed and went out, followed by Buck Mulligan’s tender chant:
   725	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   726	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     —Heart of my heart, were it more,
   727	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     More would be laid at your feet.
   728	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   729	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe turned to Stephen and said:
   730	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   731	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Seriously, Dedalus. I’m stony. Hurry out to your school kip and bring
   732	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tus back some money. Today the bards must drink and junket. Ireland
   733	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\texpects that every man this day will do his duty.
   734	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   735	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That reminds me, Haines said, rising, that I have to visit your
   736	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnational library today.
   737	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   738	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Our swim first, Buck Mulligan said.
   739	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   740	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe turned to Stephen and asked blandly:
   741	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   742	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Is this the day for your monthly wash, Kinch?
   743	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   744	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThen he said to Haines:
   745	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   746	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The unclean bard makes a point of washing once a month.
   747	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   748	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—All Ireland is washed by the gulfstream, Stephen said as he let honey
   749	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttrickle over a slice of the loaf.
   750	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   751	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHaines from the corner where he was knotting easily a scarf about the
   752	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tloose collar of his tennis shirt spoke:
   753	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   754	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I intend to make a collection of your sayings if you will let me.
   755	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   756	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSpeaking to me. They wash and tub and scrub. Agenbite of inwit.
   757	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tConscience. Yet here’s a spot.
   758	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   759	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That one about the cracked lookingglass of a servant being the symbol
   760	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof Irish art is deuced good.
   761	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   762	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan kicked Stephen’s foot under the table and said with warmth
   763	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof tone:
   764	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   765	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Wait till you hear him on Hamlet, Haines.
   766	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   767	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, I mean it, Haines said, still speaking to Stephen. I was just
   768	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthinking of it when that poor old creature came in.
   769	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   770	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Would I make any money by it? Stephen asked.
   771	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   772	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHaines laughed and, as he took his soft grey hat from the holdfast of
   773	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe hammock, said:
   774	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   775	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I don’t know, I’m sure.
   776	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   777	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe strolled out to the doorway. Buck Mulligan bent across to Stephen and
   778	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaid with coarse vigour:
   779	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   780	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You put your hoof in it now. What did you say that for?
   781	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   782	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well? Stephen said. The problem is to get money. From whom? From the
   783	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmilkwoman or from him. It’s a toss up, I think.
   784	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   785	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I blow him out about you, Buck Mulligan said, and then you come along
   786	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith your lousy leer and your gloomy jesuit jibes.
   787	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   788	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I see little hope, Stephen said, from her or from him.
   789	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   790	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan sighed tragically and laid his hand on Stephen’s arm.
   791	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   792	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—From me, Kinch, he said.
   793	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   794	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn a suddenly changed tone he added:
   795	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   796	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—To tell you the God’s truth I think you’re right. Damn all else they
   797	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tare good for. Why don’t you play them as I do? To hell with them all.
   798	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLet us get out of the kip.
   799	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   800	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe stood up, gravely ungirdled and disrobed himself of his gown, saying
   801	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tresignedly:
   802	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   803	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Mulligan is stripped of his garments.
   804	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   805	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe emptied his pockets on to the table.
   806	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   807	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—There’s your snotrag, he said.
   808	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   809	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd putting on his stiff collar and rebellious tie he spoke to them,
   810	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchiding them, and to his dangling watchchain. His hands plunged and
   811	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trummaged in his trunk while he called for a clean handkerchief. God,
   812	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twe’ll simply have to dress the character. I want puce gloves and
   813	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgreen boots. Contradiction. Do I contradict myself? Very well then, I
   814	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcontradict myself. Mercurial Malachi. A limp black missile flew out of
   815	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this talking hands.
   816	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   817	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And there’s your Latin quarter hat, he said.
   818	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   819	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen picked it up and put it on. Haines called to them from the
   820	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoorway:
   821	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   822	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Are you coming, you fellows?
   823	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   824	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’m ready, Buck Mulligan answered, going towards the door. Come out,
   825	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKinch. You have eaten all we left, I suppose. Resigned he passed out
   826	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith grave words and gait, saying, wellnigh with sorrow:
   827	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   828	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And going forth he met Butterly.
   829	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   830	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen, taking his ashplant from its leaningplace, followed them out
   831	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand, as they went down the ladder, pulled to the slow iron door and
   832	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlocked it. He put the huge key in his inner pocket.
   833	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   834	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAt the foot of the ladder Buck Mulligan asked:
   835	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   836	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Did you bring the key?
   837	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   838	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I have it, Stephen said, preceding them.
   839	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   840	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe walked on. Behind him he heard Buck Mulligan club with his heavy
   841	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbathtowel the leader shoots of ferns or grasses.
   842	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   843	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Down, sir! How dare you, sir!
   844	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   845	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHaines asked:
   846	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   847	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Do you pay rent for this tower?
   848	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   849	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Twelve quid, Buck Mulligan said.
   850	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   851	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—To the secretary of state for war, Stephen added over his shoulder.
   852	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   853	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey halted while Haines surveyed the tower and said at last:
   854	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   855	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Rather bleak in wintertime, I should say. Martello you call it?
   856	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   857	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Billy Pitt had them built, Buck Mulligan said, when the French were on
   858	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe sea. But ours is the omphalos.
   859	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   860	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What is your idea of Hamlet? Haines asked Stephen.
   861	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   862	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—No, no, Buck Mulligan shouted in pain. I’m not equal to Thomas Aquinas
   863	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand the fiftyfive reasons he has made out to prop it up. Wait till I
   864	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thave a few pints in me first.
   865	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   866	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe turned to Stephen, saying, as he pulled down neatly the peaks of his
   867	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprimrose waistcoat:
   868	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   869	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You couldn’t manage it under three pints, Kinch, could you?
   870	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   871	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—It has waited so long, Stephen said listlessly, it can wait longer.
   872	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   873	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You pique my curiosity, Haines said amiably. Is it some paradox?
   874	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   875	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Pooh! Buck Mulligan said. We have grown out of Wilde and paradoxes.
   876	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIt’s quite simple. He proves by algebra that Hamlet’s grandson is
   877	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShakespeare’s grandfather and that he himself is the ghost of his own
   878	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfather.
   879	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   880	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What? Haines said, beginning to point at Stephen. He himself?
   881	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   882	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan slung his towel stolewise round his neck and, bending in
   883	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tloose laughter, said to Stephen’s ear:
   884	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   885	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, shade of Kinch the elder! Japhet in search of a father!
   886	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   887	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—We’re always tired in the morning, Stephen said to Haines. And it is
   888	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trather long to tell.
   889	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   890	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan, walking forward again, raised his hands.
   891	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   892	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The sacred pint alone can unbind the tongue of Dedalus, he said.
   893	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   894	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I mean to say, Haines explained to Stephen as they followed, this tower
   895	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand these cliffs here remind me somehow of Elsinore. That beetles o’er
   896	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this base into the sea, isn’t it?
   897	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   898	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan turned suddenly for an instant towards Stephen but did not
   899	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspeak. In the bright silent instant Stephen saw his own image in cheap
   900	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdusty mourning between their gay attires.
   901	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   902	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—It’s a wonderful tale, Haines said, bringing them to halt again.
   903	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   904	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEyes, pale as the sea the wind had freshened, paler, firm and prudent.
   905	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe seas’ ruler, he gazed southward over the bay, empty save for the
   906	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsmokeplume of the mailboat vague on the bright skyline and a sail
   907	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttacking by the Muglins.
   908	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   909	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I read a theological interpretation of it somewhere, he said bemused.
   910	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe Father and the Son idea. The Son striving to be atoned with the
   911	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather.
   912	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   913	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan at once put on a blithe broadly smiling face. He looked
   914	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat them, his wellshaped mouth open happily, his eyes, from which he had
   915	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsuddenly withdrawn all shrewd sense, blinking with mad gaiety. He moved
   916	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta doll’s head to and fro, the brims of his Panama hat quivering, and
   917	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbegan to chant in a quiet happy foolish voice:
   918	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   919	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     —I’m the queerest young fellow that ever you heard.
   920	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     My mother’s a jew, my father’s a bird.
   921	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     With Joseph the joiner I cannot agree.
   922	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     So here’s to disciples and Calvary.
   923	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   924	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe held up a forefinger of warning.
   925	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   926	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     —If anyone thinks that I amn’t divine
   927	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     He’ll get no free drinks when I’m making the wine
   928	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     But have to drink water and wish it were plain
   929	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     That I make when the wine becomes water again.
   930	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   931	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe tugged swiftly at Stephen’s ashplant in farewell and, running forward
   932	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto a brow of the cliff, fluttered his hands at his sides like fins or
   933	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twings of one about to rise in the air, and chanted:
   934	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   935	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     —Goodbye, now, goodbye! Write down all I said
   936	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     And tell Tom, Dick and Harry I rose from the dead.
   937	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     What’s bred in the bone cannot fail me to fly
   938	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     And Olivet’s breezy... Goodbye, now, goodbye!
   939	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   940	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe capered before them down towards the fortyfoot hole, fluttering his
   941	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twinglike hands, leaping nimbly, Mercury’s hat quivering in the fresh
   942	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twind that bore back to them his brief birdsweet cries.
   943	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   944	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHaines, who had been laughing guardedly, walked on beside Stephen and
   945	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaid:
   946	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   947	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—We oughtn’t to laugh, I suppose. He’s rather blasphemous. I’m not a
   948	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeliever myself, that is to say. Still his gaiety takes the harm out of
   949	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit somehow, doesn’t it? What did he call it? Joseph the Joiner?
   950	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   951	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The ballad of joking Jesus, Stephen answered.
   952	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   953	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, Haines said, you have heard it before?
   954	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   955	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Three times a day, after meals, Stephen said drily.
   956	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   957	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You’re not a believer, are you? Haines asked. I mean, a believer in
   958	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe narrow sense of the word. Creation from nothing and miracles and a
   959	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpersonal God.
   960	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   961	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—There’s only one sense of the word, it seems to me, Stephen said.
   962	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   963	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHaines stopped to take out a smooth silver case in which twinkled a
   964	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgreen stone. He sprang it open with his thumb and offered it.
   965	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   966	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Thank you, Stephen said, taking a cigarette.
   967	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   968	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHaines helped himself and snapped the case to. He put it back in his
   969	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsidepocket and took from his waistcoatpocket a nickel tinderbox, sprang
   970	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit open too, and, having lit his cigarette, held the flaming spunk
   971	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttowards Stephen in the shell of his hands.
   972	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   973	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, of course, he said, as they went on again. Either you believe
   974	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tor you don’t, isn’t it? Personally I couldn’t stomach that idea of a
   975	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpersonal God. You don’t stand for that, I suppose?
   976	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   977	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You behold in me, Stephen said with grim displeasure, a horrible
   978	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\texample of free thought.
   979	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   980	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe walked on, waiting to be spoken to, trailing his ashplant by his
   981	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tside. Its ferrule followed lightly on the path, squealing at his heels.
   982	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMy familiar, after me, calling, Steeeeeeeeeeeephen! A wavering line
   983	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\talong the path. They will walk on it tonight, coming here in the dark.
   984	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe wants that key. It is mine. I paid the rent. Now I eat his salt
   985	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbread. Give him the key too. All. He will ask for it. That was in his
   986	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teyes.
   987	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   988	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—After all, Haines began...
   989	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   990	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen turned and saw that the cold gaze which had measured him was not
   991	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall unkind.
   992	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   993	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—After all, I should think you are able to free yourself. You are your
   994	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\town master, it seems to me.
   995	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   996	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I am a servant of two masters, Stephen said, an English and an Italian.
   997	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
   998	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Italian? Haines said.
   999	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1000	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA crazy queen, old and jealous. Kneel down before me.
  1001	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1002	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And a third, Stephen said, there is who wants me for odd jobs.
  1003	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1004	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Italian? Haines said again. What do you mean?
  1005	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1006	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The imperial British state, Stephen answered, his colour rising, and
  1007	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe holy Roman catholic and apostolic church.
  1008	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1009	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHaines detached from his underlip some fibres of tobacco before he
  1010	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspoke.
  1011	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1012	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I can quite understand that, he said calmly. An Irishman must think
  1013	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlike that, I daresay. We feel in England that we have treated you rather
  1014	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunfairly. It seems history is to blame.
  1015	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1016	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe proud potent titles clanged over Stephen’s memory the triumph of
  1017	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir brazen bells: et unam sanctam catholicam et apostolicam ecclesiam:
  1018	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe slow growth and change of rite and dogma like his own rare thoughts,
  1019	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta chemistry of stars. Symbol of the apostles in the mass for pope
  1020	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMarcellus, the voices blended, singing alone loud in affirmation: and
  1021	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbehind their chant the vigilant angel of the church militant disarmed
  1022	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand menaced her heresiarchs. A horde of heresies fleeing with mitres
  1023	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tawry: Photius and the brood of mockers of whom Mulligan was one, and
  1024	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tArius, warring his life long upon the consubstantiality of the Son
  1025	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith the Father, and Valentine, spurning Christ’s terrene body, and the
  1026	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsubtle African heresiarch Sabellius who held that the Father was Himself
  1027	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis own Son. Words Mulligan had spoken a moment since in mockery to the
  1028	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstranger. Idle mockery. The void awaits surely all them that weave the
  1029	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twind: a menace, a disarming and a worsting from those embattled angels
  1030	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the church, Michael’s host, who defend her ever in the hour of
  1031	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconflict with their lances and their shields.
  1032	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1033	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHear, hear! Prolonged applause. Zut! Nom de Dieu!
  1034	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1035	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Of course I’m a Britisher, Haines’s voice said, and I feel as one. I
  1036	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdon’t want to see my country fall into the hands of German jews either.
  1037	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThat’s our national problem, I’m afraid, just now.
  1038	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1039	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTwo men stood at the verge of the cliff, watching: businessman, boatman.
  1040	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1041	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—She’s making for Bullock harbour.
  1042	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1043	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe boatman nodded towards the north of the bay with some disdain.
  1044	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1045	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—There’s five fathoms out there, he said. It’ll be swept up that way
  1046	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhen the tide comes in about one. It’s nine days today.
  1047	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1048	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe man that was drowned. A sail veering about the blank bay waiting
  1049	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor a swollen bundle to bob up, roll over to the sun a puffy face,
  1050	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaltwhite. Here I am.
  1051	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1052	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey followed the winding path down to the creek. Buck Mulligan stood on
  1053	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta stone, in shirtsleeves, his unclipped tie rippling over his shoulder.
  1054	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA young man clinging to a spur of rock near him, moved slowly frogwise
  1055	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this green legs in the deep jelly of the water.
  1056	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1057	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Is the brother with you, Malachi?
  1058	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1059	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Down in Westmeath. With the Bannons.
  1060	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1061	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Still there? I got a card from Bannon. Says he found a sweet young
  1062	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthing down there. Photo girl he calls her.
  1063	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1064	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Snapshot, eh? Brief exposure.
  1065	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1066	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan sat down to unlace his boots. An elderly man shot up near
  1067	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe spur of rock a blowing red face. He scrambled up by the stones,
  1068	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twater glistening on his pate and on its garland of grey hair, water
  1069	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trilling over his chest and paunch and spilling jets out of his black
  1070	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsagging loincloth.
  1071	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1072	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan made way for him to scramble past and, glancing at Haines
  1073	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand Stephen, crossed himself piously with his thumbnail at brow and lips
  1074	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand breastbone.
  1075	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1076	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Seymour’s back in town, the young man said, grasping again his spur of
  1077	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trock. Chucked medicine and going in for the army.
  1078	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1079	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ah, go to God! Buck Mulligan said.
  1080	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1081	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Going over next week to stew. You know that red Carlisle girl, Lily?
  1082	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1083	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes.
  1084	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1085	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Spooning with him last night on the pier. The father is rotto with
  1086	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmoney.
  1087	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1088	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Is she up the pole?
  1089	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1090	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Better ask Seymour that.
  1091	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1092	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Seymour a bleeding officer! Buck Mulligan said.
  1093	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1094	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe nodded to himself as he drew off his trousers and stood up, saying
  1095	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttritely:
  1096	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1097	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Redheaded women buck like goats.
  1098	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1099	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe broke off in alarm, feeling his side under his flapping shirt.
  1100	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1101	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—My twelfth rib is gone, he cried. I’m the Übermensch. Toothless Kinch
  1102	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand I, the supermen.
  1103	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1104	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe struggled out of his shirt and flung it behind him to where his
  1105	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tclothes lay.
  1106	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1107	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Are you going in here, Malachi?
  1108	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1109	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes. Make room in the bed.
  1110	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1111	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe young man shoved himself backward through the water and reached
  1112	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe middle of the creek in two long clean strokes. Haines sat down on a
  1113	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstone, smoking.
  1114	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1115	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Are you not coming in? Buck Mulligan asked.
  1116	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1117	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Later on, Haines said. Not on my breakfast.
  1118	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1119	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen turned away.
  1120	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1121	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’m going, Mulligan, he said.
  1122	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1123	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Give us that key, Kinch, Buck Mulligan said, to keep my chemise flat.
  1124	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1125	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen handed him the key. Buck Mulligan laid it across his heaped
  1126	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tclothes.
  1127	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1128	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And twopence, he said, for a pint. Throw it there.
  1129	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1130	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen threw two pennies on the soft heap. Dressing, undressing. Buck
  1131	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMulligan erect, with joined hands before him, said solemnly:
  1132	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1133	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He who stealeth from the poor lendeth to the Lord. Thus spake
  1134	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tZarathustra.
  1135	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  1137	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  1139	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand smiling at wild Irish.
  1140	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1141	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHorn of a bull, hoof of a horse, smile of a Saxon.
  1142	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1143	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The Ship, Buck Mulligan cried. Half twelve.
  1144	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1145	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Good, Stephen said.
  1146	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
