  1148	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1149	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Liliata rutilantium.
  1150	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Turma circumdet.
  1151	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Iubilantium te virginum.
  1152	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1153	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe priest’s grey nimbus in a niche where he dressed discreetly. I will
  1154	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnot sleep here tonight. Home also I cannot go.
  1155	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1156	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA voice, sweettoned and sustained, called to him from the sea. Turning
  1157	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe curve he waved his hand. It called again. A sleek brown head, a
  1158	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseal’s, far out on the water, round.
  1159	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1160	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tUsurper.
  1161	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1162	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1163	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1164	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1165	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1166	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t[ 2 ]
  1167	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1168	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You, Cochrane, what city sent for him?
  1169	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1170	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Tarentum, sir.
  1171	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1172	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Very good. Well?
  1173	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1174	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—There was a battle, sir.
  1175	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1176	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Very good. Where?
  1177	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1178	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe boy’s blank face asked the blank window.
  1179	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1180	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFabled by the daughters of memory. And yet it was in some way if not as
  1181	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmemory fabled it. A phrase, then, of impatience, thud of Blake’s wings
  1182	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof excess. I hear the ruin of all space, shattered glass and toppling
  1183	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmasonry, and time one livid final flame. What’s left us then?
  1184	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1185	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I forget the place, sir. 279 B. C.
  1186	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1187	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Asculum, Stephen said, glancing at the name and date in the gorescarred
  1188	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbook.
  1189	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1190	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, sir. And he said: Another victory like that and we are done for.
  1191	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1192	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThat phrase the world had remembered. A dull ease of the mind. From
  1193	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta hill above a corpsestrewn plain a general speaking to his officers,
  1194	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tleaned upon his spear. Any general to any officers. They lend ear.
  1195	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1196	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You, Armstrong, Stephen said. What was the end of Pyrrhus?
  1197	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1198	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—End of Pyrrhus, sir?
  1199	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1200	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I know, sir. Ask me, sir, Comyn said.
  1201	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1202	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Wait. You, Armstrong. Do you know anything about Pyrrhus?
  1203	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1204	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA bag of figrolls lay snugly in Armstrong’s satchel. He curled them
  1205	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbetween his palms at whiles and swallowed them softly. Crumbs adhered to
  1206	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe tissue of his lips. A sweetened boy’s breath. Welloff people, proud
  1207	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat their eldest son was in the navy. Vico road, Dalkey.
  1208	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1209	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Pyrrhus, sir? Pyrrhus, a pier.
  1210	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1211	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAll laughed. Mirthless high malicious laughter. Armstrong looked round
  1212	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat his classmates, silly glee in profile. In a moment they will laugh
  1213	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmore loudly, aware of my lack of rule and of the fees their papas pay.
  1214	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1215	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Tell me now, Stephen said, poking the boy’s shoulder with the book,
  1216	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhat is a pier.
  1217	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1218	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A pier, sir, Armstrong said. A thing out in the water. A kind of a
  1219	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbridge. Kingstown pier, sir.
  1220	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1221	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSome laughed again: mirthless but with meaning. Two in the back bench
  1222	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhispered. Yes. They knew: had never learned nor ever been innocent.
  1223	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAll. With envy he watched their faces: Edith, Ethel, Gerty, Lily. Their
  1224	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlikes: their breaths, too, sweetened with tea and jam, their bracelets
  1225	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttittering in the struggle.
  1226	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1227	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Kingstown pier, Stephen said. Yes, a disappointed bridge.
  1228	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1229	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe words troubled their gaze.
  1230	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1231	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—How, sir? Comyn asked. A bridge is across a river.
  1232	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1233	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFor Haines’s chapbook. No-one here to hear. Tonight deftly amid wild
  1234	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrink and talk, to pierce the polished mail of his mind. What then? A
  1235	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjester at the court of his master, indulged and disesteemed, winning a
  1236	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tclement master’s praise. Why had they chosen all that part? Not wholly
  1237	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor the smooth caress. For them too history was a tale like any other
  1238	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoo often heard, their land a pawnshop.
  1239	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1240	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHad Pyrrhus not fallen by a beldam’s hand in Argos or Julius Caesar not
  1241	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeen knifed to death. They are not to be thought away. Time has
  1242	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbranded them and fettered they are lodged in the room of the infinite
  1243	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpossibilities they have ousted. But can those have been possible seeing
  1244	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat they never were? Or was that only possible which came to pass?
  1245	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWeave, weaver of the wind.
  1246	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1247	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Tell us a story, sir.
  1248	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1249	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, do, sir. A ghoststory.
  1250	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1251	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Where do you begin in this? Stephen asked, opening another book.
  1252	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1253	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Weep no more, Comyn said.
  1254	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1255	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Go on then, Talbot.
  1256	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1257	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And the story, sir?
  1258	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1259	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—After, Stephen said. Go on, Talbot.
  1260	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1261	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA swarthy boy opened a book and propped it nimbly under the breastwork
  1262	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof his satchel. He recited jerks of verse with odd glances at the text:
  1263	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1264	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     —Weep no more, woful shepherds, weep no more
  1265	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     For Lycidas, your sorrow, is not dead,
  1266	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Sunk though he be beneath the watery floor...
  1267	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1268	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIt must be a movement then, an actuality of the possible as possible.
  1269	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAristotle’s phrase formed itself within the gabbled verses and floated
  1270	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tout into the studious silence of the library of Saint Genevieve where he
  1271	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thad read, sheltered from the sin of Paris, night by night. By his elbow
  1272	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta delicate Siamese conned a handbook of strategy. Fed and feeding brains
  1273	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabout me: under glowlamps, impaled, with faintly beating feelers: and
  1274	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin my mind’s darkness a sloth of the underworld, reluctant, shy of
  1275	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrightness, shifting her dragon scaly folds. Thought is the thought of
  1276	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthought. Tranquil brightness. The soul is in a manner all that is: the
  1277	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsoul is the form of forms. Tranquility sudden, vast, candescent: form of
  1278	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tforms.
  1279	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1280	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTalbot repeated:
  1281	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1282	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     —Through the dear might of Him that walked the waves,
  1283	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Through the dear might...
  1284	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1285	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Turn over, Stephen said quietly. I don’t see anything.
  1286	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1287	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What, sir? Talbot asked simply, bending forward.
  1288	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1289	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis hand turned the page over. He leaned back and went on again, having
  1290	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjust remembered. Of him that walked the waves. Here also over these
  1291	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcraven hearts his shadow lies and on the scoffer’s heart and lips and
  1292	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton mine. It lies upon their eager faces who offered him a coin of the
  1293	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttribute. To Caesar what is Caesar’s, to God what is God’s. A long
  1294	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlook from dark eyes, a riddling sentence to be woven and woven on the
  1295	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchurch’s looms. Ay.
  1296	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1297	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Riddle me, riddle me, randy ro.
  1298	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     My father gave me seeds to sow.
  1299	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1300	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTalbot slid his closed book into his satchel.
  1301	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1302	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Have I heard all? Stephen asked.
  1303	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1304	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, sir. Hockey at ten, sir.
  1305	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1306	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Half day, sir. Thursday.
  1307	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1308	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who can answer a riddle? Stephen asked.
  1309	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1310	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey bundled their books away, pencils clacking, pages rustling.
  1311	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCrowding together they strapped and buckled their satchels, all gabbling
  1312	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgaily:
  1313	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1314	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A riddle, sir? Ask me, sir.
  1315	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1316	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, ask me, sir.
  1317	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1318	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A hard one, sir.
  1319	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1320	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—This is the riddle, Stephen said:
  1321	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1322	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     The cock crew,
  1323	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     The sky was blue:
  1324	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     The bells in heaven
  1325	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Were striking eleven.
  1326	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     ‘Tis time for this poor soul
  1327	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     To go to heaven.
  1328	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1329	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat is that?
  1330	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1331	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What, sir?
  1332	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1333	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Again, sir. We didn’t hear.
  1334	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1335	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTheir eyes grew bigger as the lines were repeated. After a silence
  1336	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCochrane said:
  1337	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1338	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What is it, sir? We give it up.
  1339	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1340	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen, his throat itching, answered:
  1341	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1342	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The fox burying his grandmother under a hollybush.
  1343	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1344	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe stood up and gave a shout of nervous laughter to which their cries
  1345	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\techoed dismay.
  1346	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1347	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA stick struck the door and a voice in the corridor called:
  1348	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1349	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Hockey!
  1350	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1351	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey broke asunder, sidling out of their benches, leaping them. Quickly
  1352	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey were gone and from the lumberroom came the rattle of sticks and
  1353	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tclamour of their boots and tongues.
  1354	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1355	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSargent who alone had lingered came forward slowly, showing an open
  1356	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcopybook. His tangled hair and scraggy neck gave witness of unreadiness
  1357	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand through his misty glasses weak eyes looked up pleading. On his
  1358	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcheek, dull and bloodless, a soft stain of ink lay, dateshaped, recent
  1359	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand damp as a snail’s bed.
  1360	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1361	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe held out his copybook. The word Sums was written on the headline.
  1362	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBeneath were sloping figures and at the foot a crooked signature with
  1363	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblind loops and a blot. Cyril Sargent: his name and seal.
  1364	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1365	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Mr Deasy told me to write them out all again, he said, and show them to
  1366	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou, sir.
  1367	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1368	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen touched the edges of the book. Futility.
  1369	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1370	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Do you understand how to do them now? he asked.
  1371	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1372	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Numbers eleven to fifteen, Sargent answered. Mr Deasy said I was to
  1373	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcopy them off the board, sir.
  1374	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1375	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Can you do them yourself? Stephen asked.
  1376	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1377	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—No, sir.
  1378	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1379	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tUgly and futile: lean neck and tangled hair and a stain of ink, a
  1380	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsnail’s bed. Yet someone had loved him, borne him in her arms and in
  1381	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther heart. But for her the race of the world would have trampled him
  1382	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunderfoot, a squashed boneless snail. She had loved his weak watery
  1383	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblood drained from her own. Was that then real? The only true thing
  1384	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin life? His mother’s prostrate body the fiery Columbanus in holy zeal
  1385	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbestrode. She was no more: the trembling skeleton of a twig burnt in
  1386	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe fire, an odour of rosewood and wetted ashes. She had saved him from
  1387	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeing trampled underfoot and had gone, scarcely having been. A poor soul
  1388	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgone to heaven: and on a heath beneath winking stars a fox, red reek
  1389	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof rapine in his fur, with merciless bright eyes scraped in the earth,
  1390	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlistened, scraped up the earth, listened, scraped and scraped.
  1391	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1392	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSitting at his side Stephen solved out the problem. He proves by algebra
  1393	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat Shakespeare’s ghost is Hamlet’s grandfather. Sargent peered askance
  1394	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthrough his slanted glasses. Hockeysticks rattled in the lumberroom: the
  1395	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thollow knock of a ball and calls from the field.
  1396	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1397	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAcross the page the symbols moved in grave morrice, in the mummery of
  1398	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir letters, wearing quaint caps of squares and cubes. Give hands,
  1399	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttraverse, bow to partner: so: imps of fancy of the Moors. Gone too from
  1400	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe world, Averroes and Moses Maimonides, dark men in mien and movement,
  1401	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tflashing in their mocking mirrors the obscure soul of the world, a
  1402	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdarkness shining in brightness which brightness could not comprehend.
  1403	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1404	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Do you understand now? Can you work the second for yourself?
  1405	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1406	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, sir.
  1407	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1408	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn long shaky strokes Sargent copied the data. Waiting always for a word
  1409	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof help his hand moved faithfully the unsteady symbols, a faint hue
  1410	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof shame flickering behind his dull skin. Amor matris: subjective and
  1411	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tobjective genitive. With her weak blood and wheysour milk she had fed
  1412	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim and hid from sight of others his swaddling bands.
  1413	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1414	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLike him was I, these sloping shoulders, this gracelessness. My
  1415	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchildhood bends beside me. Too far for me to lay a hand there once or
  1416	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlightly. Mine is far and his secret as our eyes. Secrets, silent, stony
  1417	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsit in the dark palaces of both our hearts: secrets weary of their
  1418	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttyranny: tyrants, willing to be dethroned.
  1419	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1420	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe sum was done.
  1421	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1422	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—It is very simple, Stephen said as he stood up.
  1423	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1424	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, sir. Thanks, Sargent answered.
  1425	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1426	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe dried the page with a sheet of thin blottingpaper and carried his
  1427	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcopybook back to his bench.
  1428	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1429	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You had better get your stick and go out to the others, Stephen said as
  1430	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the followed towards the door the boy’s graceless form.
  1431	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1432	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, sir.
  1433	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1434	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn the corridor his name was heard, called from the playfield.
  1435	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1436	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Sargent!
  1437	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1438	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Run on, Stephen said. Mr Deasy is calling you.
  1439	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1440	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe stood in the porch and watched the laggard hurry towards the scrappy
  1441	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfield where sharp voices were in strife. They were sorted in teams and
  1442	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Deasy came away stepping over wisps of grass with gaitered feet. When
  1443	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the had reached the schoolhouse voices again contending called to him. He
  1444	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tturned his angry white moustache.
  1445	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1446	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What is it now? he cried continually without listening.
  1447	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1448	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Cochrane and Halliday are on the same side, sir, Stephen said.
  1449	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1450	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Will you wait in my study for a moment, Mr Deasy said, till I restore
  1451	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\torder here.
  1452	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1453	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd as he stepped fussily back across the field his old man’s voice
  1454	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcried sternly:
  1455	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1456	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What is the matter? What is it now?
  1457	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1458	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTheir sharp voices cried about him on all sides: their many forms closed
  1459	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tround him, the garish sunshine bleaching the honey of his illdyed head.
  1460	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1461	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStale smoky air hung in the study with the smell of drab abraded leather
  1462	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof its chairs. As on the first day he bargained with me here. As it was
  1463	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the beginning, is now. On the sideboard the tray of Stuart coins,
  1464	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbase treasure of a bog: and ever shall be. And snug in their spooncase
  1465	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof purple plush, faded, the twelve apostles having preached to all the
  1466	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgentiles: world without end.
  1467	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1468	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA hasty step over the stone porch and in the corridor. Blowing out his
  1469	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trare moustache Mr Deasy halted at the table.
  1470	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1471	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—First, our little financial settlement, he said.
  1472	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1473	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe brought out of his coat a pocketbook bound by a leather thong. It
  1474	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tslapped open and he took from it two notes, one of joined halves, and
  1475	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlaid them carefully on the table.
  1476	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1477	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Two, he said, strapping and stowing his pocketbook away.
  1478	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1479	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd now his strongroom for the gold. Stephen’s embarrassed hand moved
  1480	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tover the shells heaped in the cold stone mortar: whelks and money
  1481	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcowries and leopard shells: and this, whorled as an emir’s turban, and
  1482	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthis, the scallop of saint James. An old pilgrim’s hoard, dead treasure,
  1483	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thollow shells.
  1484	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1485	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA sovereign fell, bright and new, on the soft pile of the tablecloth.
  1486	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1487	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Three, Mr Deasy said, turning his little savingsbox about in his hand.
  1488	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThese are handy things to have. See. This is for sovereigns. This is for
  1489	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshillings. Sixpences, halfcrowns. And here crowns. See.
  1490	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1491	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe shot from it two crowns and two shillings.
  1492	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1493	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Three twelve, he said. I think you’ll find that’s right.
  1494	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1495	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Thank you, sir, Stephen said, gathering the money together with shy
  1496	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thaste and putting it all in a pocket of his trousers.
  1497	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1498	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—No thanks at all, Mr Deasy said. You have earned it.
  1499	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1500	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen’s hand, free again, went back to the hollow shells. Symbols too
  1501	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof beauty and of power. A lump in my pocket: symbols soiled by greed and
  1502	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmisery.
  1503	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1504	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Don’t carry it like that, Mr Deasy said. You’ll pull it out somewhere
  1505	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand lose it. You just buy one of these machines. You’ll find them very
  1506	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thandy.
  1507	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1508	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnswer something.
  1509	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1510	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Mine would be often empty, Stephen said.
  1511	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1512	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe same room and hour, the same wisdom: and I the same. Three times
  1513	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnow. Three nooses round me here. Well? I can break them in this instant
  1514	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tif I will.
  1515	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1516	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Because you don’t save, Mr Deasy said, pointing his finger. You don’t
  1517	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknow yet what money is. Money is power. When you have lived as long as I
  1518	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thave. I know, I know. If youth but knew. But what does Shakespeare say?
  1519	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPut but money in thy purse.
  1520	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1521	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Iago, Stephen murmured.
  1522	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1523	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe lifted his gaze from the idle shells to the old man’s stare.
  1524	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1525	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He knew what money was, Mr Deasy said. He made money. A poet, yes, but
  1526	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tan Englishman too. Do you know what is the pride of the English? Do you
  1527	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknow what is the proudest word you will ever hear from an Englishman’s
  1528	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmouth?
  1529	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1530	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe seas’ ruler. His seacold eyes looked on the empty bay: it seems
  1531	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thistory is to blame: on me and on my words, unhating.
  1532	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1533	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That on his empire, Stephen said, the sun never sets.
  1534	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1535	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ba! Mr Deasy cried. That’s not English. A French Celt said that. He
  1536	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttapped his savingsbox against his thumbnail.
  1537	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1538	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I will tell you, he said solemnly, what is his proudest boast. I paid
  1539	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmy way.
  1540	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1541	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGood man, good man.
  1542	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1543	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I paid my way. I never borrowed a shilling in my life. Can you feel
  1544	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat? I owe nothing. Can you?
  1545	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1546	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMulligan, nine pounds, three pairs of socks, one pair brogues, ties.
  1547	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCurran, ten guineas. McCann, one guinea. Fred Ryan, two shillings.
  1548	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTemple, two lunches. Russell, one guinea, Cousins, ten shillings, Bob
  1549	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tReynolds, half a guinea, Koehler, three guineas, Mrs MacKernan, five
  1550	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tweeks’ board. The lump I have is useless.
  1551	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1552	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—For the moment, no, Stephen answered.
  1553	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1554	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Deasy laughed with rich delight, putting back his savingsbox.
  1555	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1556	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I knew you couldn’t, he said joyously. But one day you must feel it. We
  1557	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tare a generous people but we must also be just.
  1558	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1559	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I fear those big words, Stephen said, which make us so unhappy.
  1560	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1561	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Deasy stared sternly for some moments over the mantelpiece at the
  1562	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshapely bulk of a man in tartan fillibegs: Albert Edward, prince of
  1563	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWales.
  1564	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1565	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You think me an old fogey and an old tory, his thoughtful voice said.
  1566	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI saw three generations since O’Connell’s time. I remember the famine in
  1567	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t‘46. Do you know that the orange lodges agitated for repeal of the
  1568	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunion twenty years before O’Connell did or before the prelates of your
  1569	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcommunion denounced him as a demagogue? You fenians forget some things.
  1570	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1571	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGlorious, pious and immortal memory. The lodge of Diamond in Armagh the
  1572	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsplendid behung with corpses of papishes. Hoarse, masked and armed, the
  1573	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplanters’ covenant. The black north and true blue bible. Croppies lie
  1574	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdown.
  1575	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1576	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen sketched a brief gesture.
  1577	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1578	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I have rebel blood in me too, Mr Deasy said. On the spindle side. But I
  1579	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tam descended from sir John Blackwood who voted for the union. We are all
  1580	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIrish, all kings’ sons.
  1581	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1582	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Alas, Stephen said.
  1583	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1584	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Per vias rectas, Mr Deasy said firmly, was his motto. He voted for it
  1585	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand put on his topboots to ride to Dublin from the Ards of Down to do
  1586	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tso.
  1587	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1588	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Lal the ral the ra
  1589	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     The rocky road to Dublin.
  1590	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1591	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA gruff squire on horseback with shiny topboots. Soft day, sir John!
  1592	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSoft day, your honour!... Day!... Day!... Two topboots jog dangling on
  1593	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto Dublin. Lal the ral the ra. Lal the ral the raddy.
  1594	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1595	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That reminds me, Mr Deasy said. You can do me a favour, Mr Dedalus,
  1596	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith some of your literary friends. I have a letter here for the press.
  1597	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSit down a moment. I have just to copy the end.
  1598	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1599	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe went to the desk near the window, pulled in his chair twice and read
  1600	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toff some words from the sheet on the drum of his typewriter.
  1601	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1602	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Sit down. Excuse me, he said over his shoulder, the dictates of common
  1603	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsense. Just a moment.
  1604	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1605	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe peered from under his shaggy brows at the manuscript by his elbow
  1606	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand, muttering, began to prod the stiff buttons of the keyboard slowly,
  1607	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsometimes blowing as he screwed up the drum to erase an error.
  1608	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1609	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen seated himself noiselessly before the princely presence. Framed
  1610	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taround the walls images of vanished horses stood in homage, their meek
  1611	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theads poised in air: lord Hastings’ Repulse, the duke of Westminster’s
  1612	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShotover, the duke of Beaufort’s Ceylon, prix de Paris, 1866. Elfin
  1613	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\triders sat them, watchful of a sign. He saw their speeds, backing king’s
  1614	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcolours, and shouted with the shouts of vanished crowds.
  1615	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1616	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Full stop, Mr Deasy bade his keys. But prompt ventilation of this
  1617	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tallimportant question...
  1618	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1619	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhere Cranly led me to get rich quick, hunting his winners among the
  1620	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmudsplashed brakes, amid the bawls of bookies on their pitches and reek
  1621	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the canteen, over the motley slush. Even money Fair Rebel. Ten to one
  1622	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe field. Dicers and thimbleriggers we hurried by after the hoofs, the
  1623	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvying caps and jackets and past the meatfaced woman, a butcher’s dame,
  1624	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnuzzling thirstily her clove of orange.
  1625	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1626	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShouts rang shrill from the boys’ playfield and a whirring whistle.
  1627	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1628	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAgain: a goal. I am among them, among their battling bodies in a medley,
  1629	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe joust of life. You mean that knockkneed mother’s darling who seems
  1630	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto be slightly crawsick? Jousts. Time shocked rebounds, shock by shock.
  1631	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJousts, slush and uproar of battles, the frozen deathspew of the slain,
  1632	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta shout of spearspikes baited with men’s bloodied guts.
  1633	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1634	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Now then, Mr Deasy said, rising.
  1635	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1636	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe came to the table, pinning together his sheets. Stephen stood up.
  1637	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1638	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I have put the matter into a nutshell, Mr Deasy said. It’s about
  1639	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe foot and mouth disease. Just look through it. There can be no two
  1640	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\topinions on the matter.
  1641	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1642	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMay I trespass on your valuable space. That doctrine of laissez faire
  1643	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhich so often in our history. Our cattle trade. The way of all our old
  1644	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tindustries. Liverpool ring which jockeyed the Galway harbour scheme.
  1645	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEuropean conflagration. Grain supplies through the narrow waters of
  1646	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe channel. The pluterperfect imperturbability of the department of
  1647	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tagriculture. Pardoned a classical allusion. Cassandra. By a woman who
  1648	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas no better than she should be. To come to the point at issue.
  1649	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1650	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I don’t mince words, do I? Mr Deasy asked as Stephen read on.
  1651	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1652	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFoot and mouth disease. Known as Koch’s preparation. Serum and virus.
  1653	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPercentage of salted horses. Rinderpest. Emperor’s horses at Mürzsteg,
  1654	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlower Austria. Veterinary surgeons. Mr Henry Blackwood Price. Courteous
  1655	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toffer a fair trial. Dictates of common sense. Allimportant question. In
  1656	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tevery sense of the word take the bull by the horns. Thanking you for the
  1657	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thospitality of your columns.
  1658	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1659	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I want that to be printed and read, Mr Deasy said. You will see at the
  1660	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnext outbreak they will put an embargo on Irish cattle. And it can
  1661	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbe cured. It is cured. My cousin, Blackwood Price, writes to me it is
  1662	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tregularly treated and cured in Austria by cattledoctors there. They
  1663	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toffer to come over here. I am trying to work up influence with
  1664	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe department. Now I’m going to try publicity. I am surrounded by
  1665	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdifficulties, by... intrigues by... backstairs influence by...
  1666	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1667	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe raised his forefinger and beat the air oldly before his voice spoke.
  1668	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1669	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Mark my words, Mr Dedalus, he said. England is in the hands of the
  1670	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjews. In all the highest places: her finance, her press. And they are
  1671	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe signs of a nation’s decay. Wherever they gather they eat up the
  1672	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnation’s vital strength. I have seen it coming these years. As sure
  1673	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tas we are standing here the jew merchants are already at their work of
  1674	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdestruction. Old England is dying.
  1675	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1676	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe stepped swiftly off, his eyes coming to blue life as they passed a
  1677	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbroad sunbeam. He faced about and back again.
  1678	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1679	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Dying, he said again, if not dead by now.
  1680	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1681	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     The harlot’s cry from street to street
  1682	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Shall weave old England’s windingsheet.
  1683	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1684	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis eyes open wide in vision stared sternly across the sunbeam in which
  1685	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the halted.
  1686	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1687	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A merchant, Stephen said, is one who buys cheap and sells dear, jew or
  1688	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgentile, is he not?
  1689	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1690	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—They sinned against the light, Mr Deasy said gravely. And you can see
  1691	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe darkness in their eyes. And that is why they are wanderers on the
  1692	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tearth to this day.
  1693	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1694	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOn the steps of the Paris stock exchange the goldskinned men quoting
  1695	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprices on their gemmed fingers. Gabble of geese. They swarmed loud,
  1696	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tuncouth about the temple, their heads thickplotting under maladroit silk
  1697	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thats. Not theirs: these clothes, this speech, these gestures. Their full
  1698	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tslow eyes belied the words, the gestures eager and unoffending, but
  1699	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknew the rancours massed about them and knew their zeal was vain. Vain
  1700	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpatience to heap and hoard. Time surely would scatter all. A hoard
  1701	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theaped by the roadside: plundered and passing on. Their eyes knew their
  1702	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyears of wandering and, patient, knew the dishonours of their flesh.
  1703	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1704	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who has not? Stephen said.
  1705	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1706	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What do you mean? Mr Deasy asked.
  1707	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1708	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe came forward a pace and stood by the table. His underjaw fell
  1709	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsideways open uncertainly. Is this old wisdom? He waits to hear from me.
  1710	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1711	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—History, Stephen said, is a nightmare from which I am trying to awake.
  1712	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1713	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFrom the playfield the boys raised a shout. A whirring whistle: goal.
  1714	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat if that nightmare gave you a back kick?
  1715	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1716	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The ways of the Creator are not our ways, Mr Deasy said. All human
  1717	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thistory moves towards one great goal, the manifestation of God.
  1718	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1719	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen jerked his thumb towards the window, saying:
  1720	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1721	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That is God.
  1722	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1723	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHooray! Ay! Whrrwhee!
  1724	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1725	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What? Mr Deasy asked.
  1726	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1727	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A shout in the street, Stephen answered, shrugging his shoulders.
  1728	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1729	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Deasy looked down and held for awhile the wings of his nose tweaked
  1730	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbetween his fingers. Looking up again he set them free.
  1731	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1732	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I am happier than you are, he said. We have committed many errors and
  1733	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmany sins. A woman brought sin into the world. For a woman who was no
  1734	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbetter than she should be, Helen, the runaway wife of Menelaus, ten
  1735	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyears the Greeks made war on Troy. A faithless wife first brought the
  1736	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstrangers to our shore here, MacMurrough’s wife and her leman, O’Rourke,
  1737	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprince of Breffni. A woman too brought Parnell low. Many errors, many
  1738	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfailures but not the one sin. I am a struggler now at the end of my
  1739	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdays. But I will fight for the right till the end.
  1740	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1741	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     For Ulster will fight
  1742	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     And Ulster will be right.
  1743	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1744	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen raised the sheets in his hand.
  1745	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1746	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, sir, he began.
  1747	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1748	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I foresee, Mr Deasy said, that you will not remain here very long at
  1749	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthis work. You were not born to be a teacher, I think. Perhaps I am
  1750	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twrong.
  1751	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1752	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A learner rather, Stephen said.
  1753	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1754	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd here what will you learn more?
  1755	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1756	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Deasy shook his head.
  1757	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1758	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who knows? he said. To learn one must be humble. But life is the great
  1759	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tteacher.
  1760	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1761	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen rustled the sheets again.
  1762	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1763	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—As regards these, he began.
  1764	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1765	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, Mr Deasy said. You have two copies there. If you can have them
  1766	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpublished at once.
  1767	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1768	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTelegraph. Irish Homestead.
  1769	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1770	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I will try, Stephen said, and let you know tomorrow. I know two editors
  1771	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tslightly.
  1772	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1773	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That will do, Mr Deasy said briskly. I wrote last night to Mr Field,
  1774	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tM.P. There is a meeting of the cattletraders’ association today at the
  1775	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCity Arms hotel. I asked him to lay my letter before the meeting. You
  1776	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsee if you can get it into your two papers. What are they?
  1777	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1778	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The Evening Telegraph...
  1779	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1780	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That will do, Mr Deasy said. There is no time to lose. Now I have to
  1781	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanswer that letter from my cousin.
  1782	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1783	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Good morning, sir, Stephen said, putting the sheets in his pocket.
  1784	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThank you.
  1785	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1786	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Not at all, Mr Deasy said as he searched the papers on his desk. I like
  1787	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto break a lance with you, old as I am.
  1788	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1789	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Good morning, sir, Stephen said again, bowing to his bent back.
  1790	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1791	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe went out by the open porch and down the gravel path under the trees,
  1792	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thearing the cries of voices and crack of sticks from the playfield.
  1793	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe lions couchant on the pillars as he passed out through the gate:
  1794	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoothless terrors. Still I will help him in his fight. Mulligan will dub
  1795	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tme a new name: the bullockbefriending bard.
  1796	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1797	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Mr Dedalus!
  1798	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1799	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRunning after me. No more letters, I hope.
  1800	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1801	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Just one moment.
  1802	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1803	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, sir, Stephen said, turning back at the gate.
  1804	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1805	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Deasy halted, breathing hard and swallowing his breath.
  1806	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1807	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I just wanted to say, he said. Ireland, they say, has the honour of
  1808	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeing the only country which never persecuted the jews. Do you know
  1809	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat? No. And do you know why?
  1810	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1811	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe frowned sternly on the bright air.
  1812	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1813	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Why, sir? Stephen asked, beginning to smile.
  1814	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1815	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Because she never let them in, Mr Deasy said solemnly.
  1816	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1817	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA coughball of laughter leaped from his throat dragging after it a
  1818	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trattling chain of phlegm. He turned back quickly, coughing, laughing,
  1819	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this lifted arms waving to the air.
  1820	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1821	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—She never let them in, he cried again through his laughter as he
  1822	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstamped on gaitered feet over the gravel of the path. That’s why.
  1823	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1824	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOn his wise shoulders through the checkerwork of leaves the sun flung
  1825	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspangles, dancing coins.
  1826	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1827	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1828	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1829	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1830	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1831	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t[ 3 ]
  1832	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1833	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIneluctable modality of the visible: at least that if no more, thought
  1834	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthrough my eyes. Signatures of all things I am here to read, seaspawn
  1835	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand seawrack, the nearing tide, that rusty boot. Snotgreen, bluesilver,
  1836	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trust: coloured signs. Limits of the diaphane. But he adds: in bodies.
  1837	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThen he was aware of them bodies before of them coloured. How? By
  1838	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknocking his sconce against them, sure. Go easy. Bald he was and a
  1839	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmillionaire, maestro di color che sanno. Limit of the diaphane in. Why
  1840	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin? Diaphane, adiaphane. If you can put your five fingers through it it
  1841	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis a gate, if not a door. Shut your eyes and see.
  1842	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1843	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen closed his eyes to hear his boots crush crackling wrack and
  1844	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshells. You are walking through it howsomever. I am, a stride at a time.
  1845	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA very short space of time through very short times of space. Five, six:
  1846	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe nacheinander. Exactly: and that is the ineluctable modality of the
  1847	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taudible. Open your eyes. No. Jesus! If I fell over a cliff that beetles
  1848	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\to’er his base, fell through the nebeneinander ineluctably! I am getting
  1849	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton nicely in the dark. My ash sword hangs at my side. Tap with it: they
  1850	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdo. My two feet in his boots are at the ends of his legs, nebeneinander.
  1851	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSounds solid: made by the mallet of Los Demiurgos. Am I walking into
  1852	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teternity along Sandymount strand? Crush, crack, crick, crick. Wild sea
  1853	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmoney. Dominie Deasy kens them a’.
  1854	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1855	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      Won’t you come to Sandymount,
  1856	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      Madeline the mare?
  1857	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1858	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRhythm begins, you see. I hear. A catalectic tetrameter of iambs
  1859	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmarching. No, agallop: deline the mare.
  1860	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1861	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOpen your eyes now. I will. One moment. Has all vanished since? If I
  1862	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\topen and am for ever in the black adiaphane. Basta! I will see if I can
  1863	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsee.
  1864	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1865	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSee now. There all the time without you: and ever shall be, world
  1866	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twithout end.
  1867	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1868	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey came down the steps from Leahy’s terrace prudently, Frauenzimmer:
  1869	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand down the shelving shore flabbily, their splayed feet sinking in
  1870	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe silted sand. Like me, like Algy, coming down to our mighty mother.
  1871	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNumber one swung lourdily her midwife’s bag, the other’s gamp poked in
  1872	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe beach. From the liberties, out for the day. Mrs Florence MacCabe,
  1873	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trelict of the late Patk MacCabe, deeply lamented, of Bride Street. One
  1874	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof her sisterhood lugged me squealing into life. Creation from nothing.
  1875	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat has she in the bag? A misbirth with a trailing navelcord, hushed
  1876	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin ruddy wool. The cords of all link back, strandentwining cable of
  1877	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall flesh. That is why mystic monks. Will you be as gods? Gaze in your
  1878	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tomphalos. Hello. Kinch here. Put me on to Edenville. Aleph, alpha:
  1879	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnought, nought, one.
  1880	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1881	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSpouse and helpmate of Adam Kadmon: Heva, naked Eve. She had no navel.
  1882	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGaze. Belly without blemish, bulging big, a buckler of taut vellum,
  1883	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tno, whiteheaped corn, orient and immortal, standing from everlasting to
  1884	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teverlasting. Womb of sin.
  1885	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  1886	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWombed in sin darkness I was too, made not begotten. By them, the man
  1887	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith my voice and my eyes and a ghostwoman with ashes on her breath.
  1888	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey clasped and sundered, did the coupler’s will. From before the ages

  2155	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNore. Goes like this. O, O. He takes me, Napper Tandy, by the hand.

  2158	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Kilkenny...

  2160	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWeak wasting hand on mine. They have forgotten Kevin Egan, not he them.
  2161	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRemembering thee, O Sion.
  2162	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2163	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe had come nearer the edge of the sea and wet sand slapped his boots.
  2164	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe new air greeted him, harping in wild nerves, wind of wild air of
  2165	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseeds of brightness. Here, I am not walking out to the Kish lightship,
  2166	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tam I? He stood suddenly, his feet beginning to sink slowly in the
  2167	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquaking soil. Turn back.
  2168	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2169	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTurning, he scanned the shore south, his feet sinking again slowly
  2170	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin new sockets. The cold domed room of the tower waits. Through the
  2171	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbarbacans the shafts of light are moving ever, slowly ever as my
  2172	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfeet are sinking, creeping duskward over the dial floor. Blue dusk,
  2173	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnightfall, deep blue night. In the darkness of the dome they wait,
  2174	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir pushedback chairs, my obelisk valise, around a board of abandoned
  2175	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplatters. Who to clear it? He has the key. I will not sleep there when
  2176	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthis night comes. A shut door of a silent tower, entombing their blind
  2177	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbodies, the panthersahib and his pointer. Call: no answer. He lifted his
  2178	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfeet up from the suck and turned back by the mole of boulders. Take
  2179	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall, keep all. My soul walks with me, form of forms. So in the moon’s
  2180	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmidwatches I pace the path above the rocks, in sable silvered, hearing
  2181	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tElsinore’s tempting flood.
  2182	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2183	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe flood is following me. I can watch it flow past from here. Get back
  2184	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthen by the Poolbeg road to the strand there. He climbed over the sedge
  2185	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand eely oarweeds and sat on a stool of rock, resting his ashplant in a
  2186	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgrike.
  2187	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2188	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA bloated carcass of a dog lay lolled on bladderwrack. Before him the
  2189	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgunwale of a boat, sunk in sand. Un coche ensablé Louis Veuillot called
  2190	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGautier’s prose. These heavy sands are language tide and wind have
  2191	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsilted here. And these, the stoneheaps of dead builders, a warren of
  2192	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tweasel rats. Hide gold there. Try it. You have some. Sands and stones.
  2193	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHeavy of the past. Sir Lout’s toys. Mind you don’t get one bang on the
  2194	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tear. I’m the bloody well gigant rolls all them bloody well boulders,

  2198	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA point, live dog, grew into sight running across the sweep of sand.
  2199	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLord, is he going to attack me? Respect his liberty. You will not
  2200	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbe master of others or their slave. I have my stick. Sit tight. From
  2201	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfarther away, walking shoreward across from the crested tide, figures,
  2202	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttwo. The two maries. They have tucked it safe mong the bulrushes.
  2203	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPeekaboo. I see you. No, the dog. He is running back to them. Who?
  2204	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2205	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGalleys of the Lochlanns ran here to beach, in quest of prey, their

  2207	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttorcs of tomahawks aglitter on their breasts when Malachi wore the
  2208	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcollar of gold. A school of turlehide whales stranded in hot noon,
  2209	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspouting, hobbling in the shallows. Then from the starving cagework city
  2210	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta horde of jerkined dwarfs, my people, with flayers’ knives, running,
  2211	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tscaling, hacking in green blubbery whalemeat. Famine, plague and
  2212	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tslaughters. Their blood is in me, their lusts my waves. I moved among
  2213	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem on the frozen Liffey, that I, a changeling, among the spluttering
  2214	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tresin fires. I spoke to no-one: none to me.
  2215	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2216	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe dog’s bark ran towards him, stopped, ran back. Dog of my enemy.
  2217	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI just simply stood pale, silent, bayed about. Terribilia meditans. A
  2218	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprimrose doublet, fortune’s knave, smiled on my fear. For that are you
  2219	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpining, the bark of their applause? Pretenders: live their lives. The
  2220	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBruce’s brother, Thomas Fitzgerald, silken knight, Perkin Warbeck,
  2221	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYork’s false scion, in breeches of silk of whiterose ivory, wonder of
  2222	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta day, and Lambert Simnel, with a tail of nans and sutlers, a scullion
  2223	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcrowned. All kings’ sons. Paradise of pretenders then and now. He saved
  2224	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmen from drowning and you shake at a cur’s yelping. But the courtiers
  2225	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twho mocked Guido in Or san Michele were in their own house. House of...
  2226	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWe don’t want any of your medieval abstrusiosities. Would you do what
  2227	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the did? A boat would be near, a lifebuoy. Natürlich, put there for you.
  2228	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWould you or would you not? The man that was drowned nine days ago off
  2229	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMaiden’s rock. They are waiting for him now. The truth, spit it out. I
  2230	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twould want to. I would try. I am not a strong swimmer. Water cold soft.
  2231	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhen I put my face into it in the basin at Clongowes. Can’t see! Who’s
  2232	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbehind me? Out quickly, quickly! Do you see the tide flowing quickly in
  2233	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton all sides, sheeting the lows of sand quickly, shellcocoacoloured? If
  2234	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI had land under my feet. I want his life still to be his, mine to be

  2237	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbitter death: lost.

  2241	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTheir dog ambled about a bank of dwindling sand, trotting, sniffing on
  2242	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall sides. Looking for something lost in a past life. Suddenly he made
  2243	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toff like a bounding hare, ears flung back, chasing the shadow of a
  2244	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlowskimming gull. The man’s shrieked whistle struck his limp ears. He

  2250	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplashing, from far, from farther out, waves and waves.

  2255	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treared up at them with mute bearish fawning. Unheeded he kept by them as
  2256	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey came towards the drier sand, a rag of wolf’s tongue redpanting from
  2257	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this jaws. His speckled body ambled ahead of them and then loped off at a

  2259	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tround it, brother, nosing closer, went round it, sniffling rapidly like
  2260	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta dog all over the dead dog’s bedraggled fell. Dogskull, dogsniff, eyes

  2271	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquick short at an unsmelt rock. The simple pleasures of the poor. His
  2272	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thindpaws then scattered the sand: then his forepaws dabbled and delved.

  2310	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsword, to the west, trekking to evening lands. She trudges, schlepps,

  2331	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis shadow lay over the rocks as he bent, ending. Why not endless till
  2332	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe farthest star? Darkly they are there behind this light, darkness
  2333	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshining in the brightness, delta of Cassiopeia, worlds. Me sits there
  2334	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith his augur’s rod of ash, in borrowed sandals, by day beside a livid
  2335	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsea, unbeheld, in violet night walking beneath a reign of uncouth stars.

  2337	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEndless, would it be mine, form of my form? Who watches me here? Who
  2338	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tever anywhere will read these written words? Signs on a white field.
  2339	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSomewhere to someone in your flutiest voice. The good bishop of Cloyne
  2340	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttook the veil of the temple out of his shovel hat: veil of space with
  2341	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcoloured emblems hatched on its field. Hold hard. Coloured on a flat:
  2342	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyes, that’s right. Flat I see, then think distance, near, far, flat
  2343	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI see, east, back. Ah, see now! Falls back suddenly, frozen in
  2344	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstereoscope. Click does the trick. You find my words dark. Darkness is
  2345	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin our souls do you not think? Flutier. Our souls, shamewounded by our
  2346	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsins, cling to us yet more, a woman to her lover clinging, the more the
  2347	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmore.

  2351	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe ineluctable visuality. She, she, she. What she? The virgin at Hodges

  2357	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyellow stockings, darned with lumpy wool. Talk about apple dumplings,
  2358	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpiuttosto. Where are your wits?

  2362	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSad too. Touch, touch me.

  2365	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnote and pencil into a pocket, his hat tilted down on his eyes. That
  2366	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis Kevin Egan’s movement I made, nodding for his nap, sabbath sleep. Et
  2367	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvidit Deus. Et erant valde bona. Alo! Bonjour. Welcome as the flowers
  2368	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin May. Under its leaf he watched through peacocktwittering lashes the
  2369	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsouthing sun. I am caught in this burning scene. Pan’s hour, the faunal
  2370	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnoon. Among gumheavy serpentplants, milkoozing fruits, where on the
  2371	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttawny waters leaves lie wide. Pain is far.
