  2376	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnebeneinander. He counted the creases of rucked leather wherein
  2377	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanother’s foot had nested warm. The foot that beat the ground in
  2378	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttripudium, foot I dislove. But you were delighted when Esther Osvalt’s
  2379	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshoe went on you: girl I knew in Paris. Tiens, quel petit pied! Staunch
  2380	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfriend, a brother soul: Wilde’s love that dare not speak its name. His
  2381	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tarm: Cranly’s arm. He now will leave me. And the blame? As I am. As I
  2382	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tam. All or not at all.
  2383	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2384	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn long lassoes from the Cock lake the water flowed full, covering
  2385	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgreengoldenly lagoons of sand, rising, flowing. My ashplant will float
  2386	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taway. I shall wait. No, they will pass on, passing, chafing against the
  2387	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlow rocks, swirling, passing. Better get this job over quick. Listen: a
  2388	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfourworded wavespeech: seesoo, hrss, rsseeiss, ooos. Vehement breath of
  2389	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twaters amid seasnakes, rearing horses, rocks. In cups of rocks it slops:
  2390	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tflop, slop, slap: bounded in barrels. And, spent, its speech ceases. It
  2391	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tflows purling, widely flowing, floating foampool, flower unfurling.
  2392	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2393	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tUnder the upswelling tide he saw the writhing weeds lift languidly and
  2394	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsway reluctant arms, hising up their petticoats, in whispering water
  2395	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tswaying and upturning coy silver fronds. Day by day: night by night:
  2396	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlifted, flooded and let fall. Lord, they are weary; and, whispered to,
  2397	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey sigh. Saint Ambrose heard it, sigh of leaves and waves, waiting,
  2398	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tawaiting the fullness of their times, diebus ac noctibus iniurias
  2399	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpatiens ingemiscit. To no end gathered; vainly then released,
  2400	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tforthflowing, wending back: loom of the moon. Weary too in sight of
  2401	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlovers, lascivious men, a naked woman shining in her courts, she draws a
  2402	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoil of waters.
  2403	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2404	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFive fathoms out there. Full fathom five thy father lies. At one, he
  2405	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaid. Found drowned. High water at Dublin bar. Driving before it a loose
  2406	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrift of rubble, fanshoals of fishes, silly shells. A corpse rising
  2407	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaltwhite from the undertow, bobbing a pace a pace a porpoise landward.
  2408	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThere he is. Hook it quick. Pull. Sunk though he be beneath the watery
  2409	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfloor. We have him. Easy now.
  2410	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2411	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBag of corpsegas sopping in foul brine. A quiver of minnows, fat of a
  2412	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspongy titbit, flash through the slits of his buttoned trouserfly.
  2413	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGod becomes man becomes fish becomes barnacle goose becomes featherbed
  2414	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmountain. Dead breaths I living breathe, tread dead dust, devour a
  2415	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\turinous offal from all dead. Hauled stark over the gunwale he breathes
  2416	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tupward the stench of his green grave, his leprous nosehole snoring to
  2417	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe sun.
  2418	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2419	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA seachange this, brown eyes saltblue. Seadeath, mildest of all deaths
  2420	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknown to man. Old Father Ocean. Prix de Paris: beware of imitations.
  2421	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJust you give it a fair trial. We enjoyed ourselves immensely.
  2422	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2423	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCome. I thirst. Clouding over. No black clouds anywhere, are there?
  2424	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThunderstorm. Allbright he falls, proud lightning of the intellect,
  2425	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLucifer, dico, qui nescit occasum. No. My cockle hat and staff and hismy
  2426	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsandal shoon. Where? To evening lands. Evening will find itself.
  2427	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2428	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe took the hilt of his ashplant, lunging with it softly, dallying
  2429	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstill. Yes, evening will find itself in me, without me. All days make
  2430	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir end. By the way next when is it Tuesday will be the longest
  2431	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tday. Of all the glad new year, mother, the rum tum tiddledy tum. Lawn
  2432	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTennyson, gentleman poet. Già. For the old hag with the yellow teeth.
  2433	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd Monsieur Drumont, gentleman journalist. Già. My teeth are very bad.
  2434	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhy, I wonder. Feel. That one is going too. Shells. Ought I go to a
  2435	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdentist, I wonder, with that money? That one. This. Toothless Kinch, the
  2436	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsuperman. Why is that, I wonder, or does it mean something perhaps?
  2437	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2438	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMy handkerchief. He threw it. I remember. Did I not take it up?
  2439	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2440	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis hand groped vainly in his pockets. No, I didn’t. Better buy one.
  2441	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2442	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe laid the dry snot picked from his nostril on a ledge of rock,
  2443	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcarefully. For the rest let look who will.
  2444	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2445	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBehind. Perhaps there is someone.
  2446	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2447	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe turned his face over a shoulder, rere regardant. Moving through the
  2448	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tair high spars of a threemaster, her sails brailed up on the crosstrees,
  2449	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thoming, upstream, silently moving, a silent ship.
  2450	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2451	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2452	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2453	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2454	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2455	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t— II —
  2456	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2457	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2458	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2459	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2460	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2461	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t[ 4 ]
  2462	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2463	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Leopold Bloom ate with relish the inner organs of beasts and fowls.
  2464	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe liked thick giblet soup, nutty gizzards, a stuffed roast heart,
  2465	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tliverslices fried with crustcrumbs, fried hencods’ roes. Most of all
  2466	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the liked grilled mutton kidneys which gave to his palate a fine tang of
  2467	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfaintly scented urine.
  2468	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2469	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKidneys were in his mind as he moved about the kitchen softly, righting
  2470	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther breakfast things on the humpy tray. Gelid light and air were in the
  2471	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tkitchen but out of doors gentle summer morning everywhere. Made him feel
  2472	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta bit peckish.
  2473	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2474	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe coals were reddening.
  2475	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2476	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnother slice of bread and butter: three, four: right. She didn’t like
  2477	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther plate full. Right. He turned from the tray, lifted the kettle off
  2478	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe hob and set it sideways on the fire. It sat there, dull and squat,
  2479	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tits spout stuck out. Cup of tea soon. Good. Mouth dry. The cat walked
  2480	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstiffly round a leg of the table with tail on high.
  2481	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2482	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Mkgnao!
  2483	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2484	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, there you are, Mr Bloom said, turning from the fire.
  2485	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2486	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe cat mewed in answer and stalked again stiffly round a leg of the
  2487	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttable, mewing. Just how she stalks over my writingtable. Prr. Scratch my
  2488	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thead. Prr.
  2489	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2490	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Bloom watched curiously, kindly the lithe black form. Clean to see:
  2491	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe gloss of her sleek hide, the white button under the butt of her
  2492	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttail, the green flashing eyes. He bent down to her, his hands on his
  2493	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknees.
  2494	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2495	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Milk for the pussens, he said.
  2496	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2497	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Mrkgnao! the cat cried.
  2498	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2499	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey call them stupid. They understand what we say better than we
  2500	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunderstand them. She understands all she wants to. Vindictive too.
  2501	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCruel. Her nature. Curious mice never squeal. Seem to like it. Wonder
  2502	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhat I look like to her. Height of a tower? No, she can jump me.
  2503	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2504	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Afraid of the chickens she is, he said mockingly. Afraid of the
  2505	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchookchooks. I never saw such a stupid pussens as the pussens.
  2506	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2507	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Mrkrgnao! the cat said loudly.
  2508	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2509	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe blinked up out of her avid shameclosing eyes, mewing plaintively
  2510	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand long, showing him her milkwhite teeth. He watched the dark eyeslits
  2511	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnarrowing with greed till her eyes were green stones. Then he went to
  2512	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe dresser, took the jug Hanlon’s milkman had just filled for him,
  2513	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoured warmbubbled milk on a saucer and set it slowly on the floor.
  2514	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2515	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Gurrhr! she cried, running to lap.
  2516	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2517	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe watched the bristles shining wirily in the weak light as she tipped
  2518	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthree times and licked lightly. Wonder is it true if you clip them they
  2519	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcan’t mouse after. Why? They shine in the dark, perhaps, the tips. Or
  2520	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tkind of feelers in the dark, perhaps.
  2521	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2522	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe listened to her licking lap. Ham and eggs, no. No good eggs with this
  2523	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrouth. Want pure fresh water. Thursday: not a good day either for a
  2524	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmutton kidney at Buckley’s. Fried with butter, a shake of pepper. Better
  2525	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta pork kidney at Dlugacz’s. While the kettle is boiling. She lapped
  2526	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tslower, then licking the saucer clean. Why are their tongues so rough?
  2527	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTo lap better, all porous holes. Nothing she can eat? He glanced round
  2528	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim. No.
  2529	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2530	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOn quietly creaky boots he went up the staircase to the hall, paused by
  2531	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe bedroom door. She might like something tasty. Thin bread and butter
  2532	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshe likes in the morning. Still perhaps: once in a way.
  2533	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2534	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe said softly in the bare hall:
  2535	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2536	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’m going round the corner. Be back in a minute.
  2537	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2538	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd when he had heard his voice say it he added:
  2539	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2540	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You don’t want anything for breakfast?
  2541	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2542	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA sleepy soft grunt answered:
  2543	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2544	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Mn.
  2545	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2546	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNo. She didn’t want anything. He heard then a warm heavy sigh, softer,
  2547	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tas she turned over and the loose brass quoits of the bedstead jingled.
  2548	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMust get those settled really. Pity. All the way from Gibraltar.
  2549	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tForgotten any little Spanish she knew. Wonder what her father gave for
  2550	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit. Old style. Ah yes! of course. Bought it at the governor’s auction.
  2551	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGot a short knock. Hard as nails at a bargain, old Tweedy. Yes, sir. At
  2552	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPlevna that was. I rose from the ranks, sir, and I’m proud of it.
  2553	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStill he had brains enough to make that corner in stamps. Now that was
  2554	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfarseeing.
  2555	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2556	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis hand took his hat from the peg over his initialled heavy overcoat
  2557	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand his lost property office secondhand waterproof. Stamps: stickyback
  2558	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpictures. Daresay lots of officers are in the swim too. Course they do.
  2559	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe sweated legend in the crown of his hat told him mutely: Plasto’s
  2560	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thigh grade ha. He peeped quickly inside the leather headband. White slip
  2561	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof paper. Quite safe.
  2562	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2563	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOn the doorstep he felt in his hip pocket for the latchkey. Not there.
  2564	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn the trousers I left off. Must get it. Potato I have. Creaky wardrobe.
  2565	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNo use disturbing her. She turned over sleepily that time. He pulled
  2566	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe halldoor to after him very quietly, more, till the footleaf dropped
  2567	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgently over the threshold, a limp lid. Looked shut. All right till I
  2568	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcome back anyhow.
  2569	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2570	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe crossed to the bright side, avoiding the loose cellarflap of number
  2571	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseventyfive. The sun was nearing the steeple of George’s church. Be a
  2572	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twarm day I fancy. Specially in these black clothes feel it more. Black
  2573	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconducts, reflects, (refracts is it?), the heat. But I couldn’t go in
  2574	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat light suit. Make a picnic of it. His eyelids sank quietly often as
  2575	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the walked in happy warmth. Boland’s breadvan delivering with trays our
  2576	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdaily but she prefers yesterday’s loaves turnovers crisp crowns hot.
  2577	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMakes you feel young. Somewhere in the east: early morning: set off at
  2578	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdawn. Travel round in front of the sun, steal a day’s march on him. Keep
  2579	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit up for ever never grow a day older technically. Walk along a strand,
  2580	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstrange land, come to a city gate, sentry there, old ranker too, old
  2581	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTweedy’s big moustaches, leaning on a long kind of a spear. Wander
  2582	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthrough awned streets. Turbaned faces going by. Dark caves of carpet
  2583	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshops, big man, Turko the terrible, seated crosslegged, smoking a coiled
  2584	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpipe. Cries of sellers in the streets. Drink water scented with fennel,
  2585	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsherbet. Dander along all day. Might meet a robber or two. Well,
  2586	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmeet him. Getting on to sundown. The shadows of the mosques among the
  2587	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpillars: priest with a scroll rolled up. A shiver of the trees, signal,
  2588	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe evening wind. I pass on. Fading gold sky. A mother watches me from
  2589	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther doorway. She calls her children home in their dark language. High
  2590	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twall: beyond strings twanged. Night sky, moon, violet, colour of Molly’s
  2591	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnew garters. Strings. Listen. A girl playing one of those instruments
  2592	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhat do you call them: dulcimers. I pass.
  2593	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2594	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tProbably not a bit like it really. Kind of stuff you read: in the track
  2595	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the sun. Sunburst on the titlepage. He smiled, pleasing himself.
  2596	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat Arthur Griffith said about the headpiece over the Freeman leader: a
  2597	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thomerule sun rising up in the northwest from the laneway behind the bank
  2598	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof Ireland. He prolonged his pleased smile. Ikey touch that: homerule
  2599	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsun rising up in the northwest.
  2600	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2601	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe approached Larry O’Rourke’s. From the cellar grating floated up the
  2602	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tflabby gush of porter. Through the open doorway the bar squirted out
  2603	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhiffs of ginger, teadust, biscuitmush. Good house, however: just the
  2604	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tend of the city traffic. For instance M’Auley’s down there: n. g. as
  2605	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tposition. Of course if they ran a tramline along the North Circular from
  2606	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe cattlemarket to the quays value would go up like a shot.
  2607	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2608	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBaldhead over the blind. Cute old codger. No use canvassing him for an
  2609	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tad. Still he knows his own business best. There he is, sure enough, my
  2610	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbold Larry, leaning against the sugarbin in his shirtsleeves watching
  2611	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe aproned curate swab up with mop and bucket. Simon Dedalus takes him
  2612	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toff to a tee with his eyes screwed up. Do you know what I’m going to
  2613	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttell you? What’s that, Mr O’Rourke? Do you know what? The Russians,
  2614	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey’d only be an eight o’clock breakfast for the Japanese.
  2615	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2616	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStop and say a word: about the funeral perhaps. Sad thing about poor
  2617	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDignam, Mr O’Rourke.
  2618	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2619	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTurning into Dorset street he said freshly in greeting through the
  2620	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoorway:
  2621	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2622	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Good day, Mr O’Rourke.
  2623	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2624	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Good day to you.
  2625	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2626	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Lovely weather, sir.
  2627	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2628	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—‘Tis all that.
  2629	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2630	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhere do they get the money? Coming up redheaded curates from the county
  2631	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLeitrim, rinsing empties and old man in the cellar. Then, lo and behold,
  2632	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey blossom out as Adam Findlaters or Dan Tallons. Then think of the
  2633	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcompetition. General thirst. Good puzzle would be cross Dublin without
  2634	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpassing a pub. Save it they can’t. Off the drunks perhaps. Put down
  2635	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthree and carry five. What is that, a bob here and there, dribs and
  2636	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrabs. On the wholesale orders perhaps. Doing a double shuffle with the
  2637	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttown travellers. Square it you with the boss and we’ll split the job,
  2638	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsee?
  2639	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2640	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHow much would that tot to off the porter in the month? Say ten barrels
  2641	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof stuff. Say he got ten per cent off. O more. Fifteen. He passed Saint
  2642	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJoseph’s National school. Brats’ clamour. Windows open. Fresh air
  2643	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thelps memory. Or a lilt. Ahbeesee defeegee kelomen opeecue rustyouvee
  2644	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoubleyou. Boys are they? Yes. Inishturk. Inishark. Inishboffin. At
  2645	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir joggerfry. Mine. Slieve Bloom.
  2646	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2647	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe halted before Dlugacz’s window, staring at the hanks of sausages,
  2648	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpolonies, black and white. Fifteen multiplied by. The figures whitened
  2649	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin his mind, unsolved: displeased, he let them fade. The shiny links,
  2650	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpacked with forcemeat, fed his gaze and he breathed in tranquilly the
  2651	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlukewarm breath of cooked spicy pigs’ blood.
  2652	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2653	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA kidney oozed bloodgouts on the willowpatterned dish: the last. He
  2654	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstood by the nextdoor girl at the counter. Would she buy it too, calling
  2655	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe items from a slip in her hand? Chapped: washingsoda. And a pound and
  2656	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta half of Denny’s sausages. His eyes rested on her vigorous hips.
  2657	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWoods his name is. Wonder what he does. Wife is oldish. New blood.
  2658	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNo followers allowed. Strong pair of arms. Whacking a carpet on the
  2659	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tclothesline. She does whack it, by George. The way her crooked skirt
  2660	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tswings at each whack.
  2661	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2662	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe ferreteyed porkbutcher folded the sausages he had snipped off with
  2663	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblotchy fingers, sausagepink. Sound meat there: like a stallfed heifer.
  2664	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2665	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe took a page up from the pile of cut sheets: the model farm at
  2666	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKinnereth on the lakeshore of Tiberias. Can become ideal winter
  2667	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsanatorium. Moses Montefiore. I thought he was. Farmhouse, wall round
  2668	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit, blurred cattle cropping. He held the page from him: interesting:
  2669	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tread it nearer, the title, the blurred cropping cattle, the page
  2670	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trustling. A young white heifer. Those mornings in the cattlemarket, the
  2671	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeasts lowing in their pens, branded sheep, flop and fall of dung, the
  2672	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbreeders in hobnailed boots trudging through the litter, slapping a palm
  2673	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton a ripemeated hindquarter, there’s a prime one, unpeeled switches in
  2674	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir hands. He held the page aslant patiently, bending his senses and
  2675	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this will, his soft subject gaze at rest. The crooked skirt swinging,
  2676	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhack by whack by whack.
  2677	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2678	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe porkbutcher snapped two sheets from the pile, wrapped up her prime
  2679	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsausages and made a red grimace.
  2680	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2681	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Now, my miss, he said.
  2682	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2683	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe tendered a coin, smiling boldly, holding her thick wrist out.
  2684	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2685	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Thank you, my miss. And one shilling threepence change. For you,
  2686	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplease?
  2687	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2688	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Bloom pointed quickly. To catch up and walk behind her if she went
  2689	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tslowly, behind her moving hams. Pleasant to see first thing in the
  2690	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmorning. Hurry up, damn it. Make hay while the sun shines. She stood
  2691	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toutside the shop in sunlight and sauntered lazily to the right. He
  2692	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsighed down his nose: they never understand. Sodachapped hands. Crusted
  2693	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoenails too. Brown scapulars in tatters, defending her both ways.
  2694	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe sting of disregard glowed to weak pleasure within his breast. For
  2695	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanother: a constable off duty cuddling her in Eccles’ Lane. They like
  2696	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem sizeable. Prime sausage. O please, Mr Policeman, I’m lost in the
  2697	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twood.
  2698	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2699	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Threepence, please.
  2700	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2701	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis hand accepted the moist tender gland and slid it into a sidepocket.
  2702	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThen it fetched up three coins from his trousers’ pocket and laid them
  2703	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton the rubber prickles. They lay, were read quickly and quickly slid,
  2704	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdisc by disc, into the till.
  2705	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2706	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Thank you, sir. Another time.
  2707	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2708	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA speck of eager fire from foxeyes thanked him. He withdrew his gaze
  2709	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tafter an instant. No: better not: another time.
  2710	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2711	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Good morning, he said, moving away.
  2712	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2713	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Good morning, sir.
  2714	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2715	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNo sign. Gone. What matter?
  2716	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2717	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe walked back along Dorset street, reading gravely. Agendath Netaim:
  2718	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplanters’ company. To purchase waste sandy tracts from Turkish
  2719	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgovernment and plant with eucalyptus trees. Excellent for shade, fuel
  2720	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand construction. Orangegroves and immense melonfields north of Jaffa.
  2721	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYou pay eighty marks and they plant a dunam of land for you with olives,
  2722	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toranges, almonds or citrons. Olives cheaper: oranges need artificial
  2723	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tirrigation. Every year you get a sending of the crop. Your name entered
  2724	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor life as owner in the book of the union. Can pay ten down and the
  2725	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbalance in yearly instalments. Bleibtreustrasse 34, Berlin, W. 15.
  2726	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2727	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNothing doing. Still an idea behind it.
  2728	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2729	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe looked at the cattle, blurred in silver heat. Silverpowdered
  2730	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tolivetrees. Quiet long days: pruning, ripening. Olives are packed in
  2731	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjars, eh? I have a few left from Andrews. Molly spitting them out. Knows
  2732	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe taste of them now. Oranges in tissue paper packed in crates. Citrons
  2733	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoo. Wonder is poor Citron still in Saint Kevin’s parade. And Mastiansky
  2734	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith the old cither. Pleasant evenings we had then. Molly in Citron’s
  2735	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbasketchair. Nice to hold, cool waxen fruit, hold in the hand, lift it
  2736	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto the nostrils and smell the perfume. Like that, heavy, sweet, wild
  2737	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tperfume. Always the same, year after year. They fetched high prices too,
  2738	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMoisel told me. Arbutus place: Pleasants street: pleasant old times.
  2739	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMust be without a flaw, he said. Coming all that way: Spain, Gibraltar,
  2740	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMediterranean, the Levant. Crates lined up on the quayside at Jaffa,
  2741	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchap ticking them off in a book, navvies handling them barefoot in
  2742	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsoiled dungarees. There’s whatdoyoucallhim out of. How do you? Doesn’t
  2743	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsee. Chap you know just to salute bit of a bore. His back is like that
  2744	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNorwegian captain’s. Wonder if I’ll meet him today. Watering cart. To
  2745	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprovoke the rain. On earth as it is in heaven.
  2746	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2747	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA cloud began to cover the sun slowly, wholly. Grey. Far.
  2748	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2749	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNo, not like that. A barren land, bare waste. Vulcanic lake, the dead
  2750	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsea: no fish, weedless, sunk deep in the earth. No wind could lift those
  2751	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twaves, grey metal, poisonous foggy waters. Brimstone they called it
  2752	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\training down: the cities of the plain: Sodom, Gomorrah, Edom. All dead
  2753	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnames. A dead sea in a dead land, grey and old. Old now. It bore the
  2754	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toldest, the first race. A bent hag crossed from Cassidy’s, clutching a
  2755	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnaggin bottle by the neck. The oldest people. Wandered far away over
  2756	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall the earth, captivity to captivity, multiplying, dying, being born
  2757	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teverywhere. It lay there now. Now it could bear no more. Dead: an old
  2758	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twoman’s: the grey sunken cunt of the world.
  2759	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2760	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDesolation.
  2761	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2762	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGrey horror seared his flesh. Folding the page into his pocket he turned
  2763	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinto Eccles street, hurrying homeward. Cold oils slid along his veins,
  2764	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchilling his blood: age crusting him with a salt cloak. Well, I am here
  2765	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnow. Yes, I am here now. Morning mouth bad images. Got up wrong side of
  2766	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe bed. Must begin again those Sandow’s exercises. On the hands down.
  2767	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBlotchy brown brick houses. Number eighty still unlet. Why is that?
  2768	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tValuation is only twentyeight. Towers, Battersby, North, MacArthur:
  2769	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tparlour windows plastered with bills. Plasters on a sore eye. To smell
  2770	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe gentle smoke of tea, fume of the pan, sizzling butter. Be near her
  2771	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tample bedwarmed flesh. Yes, yes.
  2772	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2773	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tQuick warm sunlight came running from Berkeley road, swiftly, in slim
  2774	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsandals, along the brightening footpath. Runs, she runs to meet me, a
  2775	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgirl with gold hair on the wind.
  2776	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2777	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTwo letters and a card lay on the hallfloor. He stooped and gathered
  2778	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem. Mrs Marion Bloom. His quickened heart slowed at once. Bold hand.
  2779	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMrs Marion.
  2780	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2781	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Poldy!
  2782	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2783	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEntering the bedroom he halfclosed his eyes and walked through warm
  2784	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyellow twilight towards her tousled head.
  2785	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2786	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who are the letters for?
  2787	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2788	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe looked at them. Mullingar. Milly.
  2789	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2790	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A letter for me from Milly, he said carefully, and a card to you. And a
  2791	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tletter for you.
  2792	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  2794	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknees.
  2795	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  2798	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLetting the blind up by gentle tugs halfway his backward eye saw her
  2799	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tglance at the letter and tuck it under her pillow.
  2800	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2801	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That do? he asked, turning.
  2802	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2803	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe was reading the card, propped on her elbow.
  2804	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  2806	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  2808	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tslowly with a snug sigh.
  2809	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  2811	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2812	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The kettle is boiling, he said.
  2813	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  2815	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlinen: and lifted all in an armful on to the foot of the bed.
  2816	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  2818	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  2820	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2821	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What?
  2822	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2823	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Scald the teapot.
  2824	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2825	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOn the boil sure enough: a plume of steam from the spout. He scalded and
  2826	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trinsed out the teapot and put in four full spoons of tea, tilting the
  2827	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tkettle then to let the water flow in. Having set it to draw he took off
  2828	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe kettle, crushed the pan flat on the live coals and watched the lump
  2829	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof butter slide and melt. While he unwrapped the kidney the cat mewed
  2830	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thungrily against him. Give her too much meat she won’t mouse. Say they
  2831	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twon’t eat pork. Kosher. Here. He let the bloodsmeared paper fall to
  2832	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther and dropped the kidney amid the sizzling butter sauce. Pepper. He
  2833	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsprinkled it through his fingers ringwise from the chipped eggcup.
  2834	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2835	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThen he slit open his letter, glancing down the page and over. Thanks:
  2836	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnew tam: Mr Coghlan: lough Owel picnic: young student: Blazes Boylan’s
  2837	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseaside girls.
  2838	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  2840	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsmiling. Silly Milly’s birthday gift. Only five she was then. No, wait:
  2841	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfour. I gave her the amberoid necklace she broke. Putting pieces of
  2842	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfolded brown paper in the letterbox for her. He smiled, pouring.
  2843	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2844	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     O, Milly Bloom, you are my darling.
  2845	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     You are my lookingglass from night to morning.
  2846	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     I’d rather have you without a farthing
  2847	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Than Katey Keogh with her ass and garden.
  2848	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2849	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPoor old professor Goodwin. Dreadful old case. Still he was a courteous
  2850	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\told chap. Oldfashioned way he used to bow Molly off the platform. And
  2851	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe little mirror in his silk hat. The night Milly brought it into
  2852	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe parlour. O, look what I found in professor Goodwin’s hat! All we
  2853	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlaughed. Sex breaking out even then. Pert little piece she was.

  2856	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tteapot on the tray. Its hump bumped as he took it up. Everything on
  2857	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit? Bread and butter, four, sugar, spoon, her cream. Yes. He carried it
  2858	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tupstairs, his thumb hooked in the teapot handle.

  2861	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe chair by the bedhead.

  2866	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe pillow. He looked calmly down on her bulk and between her large soft

  2868	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof her couched body rose on the air, mingling with the fragrance of the
  2869	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttea she poured.

  2875	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  2879	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  2881	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2882	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Là ci darem with J. C. Doyle, she said, and Love’s Old Sweet Song.
  2883	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2884	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHer full lips, drinking, smiled. Rather stale smell that incense leaves
  2885	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnext day. Like foul flowerwater.
  2886	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  2890	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  2892	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2893	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Eleven, I think, he answered. I didn’t see the paper.
  2894	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2895	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFollowing the pointing of her finger he took up a leg of her soiled
  2896	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrawers from the bed. No? Then, a twisted grey garter looped round a
  2897	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstocking: rumpled, shiny sole.
  2898	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2899	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—No: that book.
  2900	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2901	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOther stocking. Her petticoat.
  2902	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2903	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—It must have fell down, she said.
  2904	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2905	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe felt here and there. Voglio e non vorrei. Wonder if she pronounces
  2906	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat right: voglio. Not in the bed. Must have slid down. He stooped and
  2907	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlifted the valance. The book, fallen, sprawled against the bulge of the
  2908	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\torangekeyed chamberpot.
  2909	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2910	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Show here, she said. I put a mark in it. There’s a word I wanted to ask
  2911	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou.
  2912	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2913	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe swallowed a draught of tea from her cup held by nothandle and,
  2914	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thaving wiped her fingertips smartly on the blanket, began to search the
  2915	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttext with the hairpin till she reached the word.
  2916	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2917	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Met him what? he asked.
  2918	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2919	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Here, she said. What does that mean?
  2920	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2921	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe leaned downward and read near her polished thumbnail.
  2922	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2923	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Metempsychosis?
  2924	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2925	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes. Who’s he when he’s at home?
  2926	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2927	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Metempsychosis, he said, frowning. It’s Greek: from the Greek. That
  2928	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmeans the transmigration of souls.
  2929	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2930	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, rocks! she said. Tell us in plain words.
  2931	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2932	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe smiled, glancing askance at her mocking eyes. The same young eyes.
  2933	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe first night after the charades. Dolphin’s Barn. He turned over the
  2934	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsmudged pages. Ruby: the Pride of the Ring. Hello. Illustration. Fierce
  2935	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tItalian with carriagewhip. Must be Ruby pride of the on the floor naked.
  2936	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSheet kindly lent. The monster Maffei desisted and flung his victim
  2937	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom him with an oath. Cruelty behind it all. Doped animals. Trapeze at
  2938	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHengler’s. Had to look the other way. Mob gaping. Break your neck
  2939	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand we’ll break our sides. Families of them. Bone them young so they
  2940	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmetamspychosis. That we live after death. Our souls. That a man’s soul
  2941	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tafter he dies. Dignam’s soul...
  2942	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2943	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Did you finish it? he asked.
  2944	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2945	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, she said. There’s nothing smutty in it. Is she in love with the
  2946	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfirst fellow all the time?
  2947	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2948	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Never read it. Do you want another?
  2949	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2950	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes. Get another of Paul de Kock’s. Nice name he has.
  2951	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2952	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe poured more tea into her cup, watching it flow sideways.
  2953	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2954	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMust get that Capel street library book renewed or they’ll write to
  2955	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKearney, my guarantor. Reincarnation: that’s the word.
  2956	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2957	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Some people believe, he said, that we go on living in another body
  2958	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tafter death, that we lived before. They call it reincarnation. That
  2959	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twe all lived before on the earth thousands of years ago or some other
  2960	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplanet. They say we have forgotten it. Some say they remember their past
  2961	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlives.
  2962	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2963	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe sluggish cream wound curdling spirals through her tea. Better remind
  2964	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther of the word: metempsychosis. An example would be better. An example?
  2965	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2966	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe Bath of the Nymph over the bed. Given away with the Easter number of
  2967	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPhoto Bits: Splendid masterpiece in art colours. Tea before you put milk
  2968	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin. Not unlike her with her hair down: slimmer. Three and six I gave
  2969	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor the frame. She said it would look nice over the bed. Naked nymphs:
  2970	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGreece: and for instance all the people that lived then.
  2971	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2972	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe turned the pages back.
  2973	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2974	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Metempsychosis, he said, is what the ancient Greeks called it. They
  2975	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tused to believe you could be changed into an animal or a tree, for
  2976	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinstance. What they called nymphs, for example.
  2977	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2978	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHer spoon ceased to stir up the sugar. She gazed straight before her,
  2979	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinhaling through her arched nostrils.
  2980	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2981	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—There’s a smell of burn, she said. Did you leave anything on the fire?
  2982	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2983	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The kidney! he cried suddenly.
  2984	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2985	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe fitted the book roughly into his inner pocket and, stubbing his toes
  2986	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tagainst the broken commode, hurried out towards the smell, stepping
  2987	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thastily down the stairs with a flurried stork’s legs. Pungent smoke shot
  2988	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tup in an angry jet from a side of the pan. By prodding a prong of the
  2989	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfork under the kidney he detached it and turned it turtle on its back.
  2990	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOnly a little burnt. He tossed it off the pan on to a plate and let the
  2991	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tscanty brown gravy trickle over it.
  2992	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  2993	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCup of tea now. He sat down, cut and buttered a slice of the loaf.
  2994	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe shore away the burnt flesh and flung it to the cat. Then he put a
  2995	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tforkful into his mouth, chewing with discernment the toothsome pliant
  2996	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmeat. Done to a turn. A mouthful of tea. Then he cut away dies of bread,
  2997	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsopped one in the gravy and put it in his mouth. What was that about
  2998	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsome young student and a picnic? He creased out the letter at his side,
  2999	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treading it slowly as he chewed, sopping another die of bread in the
  3000	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgravy and raising it to his mouth.
  3001	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3002	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDearest Papli
  3003	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3004	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThanks ever so much for the lovely birthday present. It suits me
  3005	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsplendid. Everyone says I am quite the belle in my new tam. I got
  3006	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmummy’s lovely box of creams and am writing. They are lovely. I am
  3007	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgetting on swimming in the photo business now. Mr Coghlan took one of me
  3008	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand Mrs. Will send when developed. We did great biz yesterday. Fair day
  3009	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand all the beef to the heels were in. We are going to lough Owel on
  3010	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMonday with a few friends to make a scrap picnic. Give my love to
  3011	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmummy and to yourself a big kiss and thanks. I hear them at the piano
  3012	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdownstairs. There is to be a concert in the Greville Arms on Saturday.
  3013	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThere is a young student comes here some evenings named Bannon his
  3014	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcousins or something are big swells and he sings Boylan’s (I was on the
  3015	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpop of writing Blazes Boylan’s) song about those seaside girls. Tell him
  3016	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsilly Milly sends my best respects. I must now close with fondest love
  3017	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3018	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYour fond daughter

  3025	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3026	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFifteen yesterday. Curious, fifteenth of the month too. Her first
  3027	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbirthday away from home. Separation. Remember the summer morning she
  3028	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas born, running to knock up Mrs Thornton in Denzille street. Jolly old
  3029	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twoman. Lot of babies she must have helped into the world. She knew from
  3030	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe first poor little Rudy wouldn’t live. Well, God is good, sir. She
  3031	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknew at once. He would be eleven now if he had lived.
  3032	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3033	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis vacant face stared pityingly at the postscript. Excuse bad writing.
  3034	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHurry. Piano downstairs. Coming out of her shell. Row with her in the
  3035	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tXL Café about the bracelet. Wouldn’t eat her cakes or speak or look.
  3036	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSaucebox. He sopped other dies of bread in the gravy and ate piece after
  3037	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpiece of kidney. Twelve and six a week. Not much. Still, she might do
  3038	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tworse. Music hall stage. Young student. He drank a draught of cooler tea
  3039	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto wash down his meal. Then he read the letter again: twice.
  3040	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3041	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tO, well: she knows how to mind herself. But if not? No, nothing has
  3042	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thappened. Of course it might. Wait in any case till it does. A wild
  3043	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpiece of goods. Her slim legs running up the staircase. Destiny.
  3044	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRipening now. Vain: very.
  3045	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3046	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe smiled with troubled affection at the kitchen window. Day I caught
  3047	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther in the street pinching her cheeks to make them red. Anemic a little.
  3048	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWas given milk too long. On the Erin’s King that day round the Kish.
  3049	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDamned old tub pitching about. Not a bit funky. Her pale blue scarf

  3067	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA soft qualm, regret, flowed down his backbone, increasing. Will happen,
  3068	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyes. Prevent. Useless: can’t move. Girl’s sweet light lips. Will happen
  3069	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoo. He felt the flowing qualm spread over him. Useless to move now.
  3070	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLips kissed, kissing, kissed. Full gluey woman’s lips.
  3071	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3072	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBetter where she is down there: away. Occupy her. Wanted a dog to pass
  3073	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe time. Might take a trip down there. August bank holiday, only two
  3074	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand six return. Six weeks off, however. Might work a press pass. Or
  3075	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthrough M’Coy.

  3077	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe cat, having cleaned all her fur, returned to the meatstained paper,
  3078	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnosed at it and stalked to the door. She looked back at him, mewing.
  3079	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWants to go out. Wait before a door sometime it will open. Let her wait.
  3080	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHas the fidgets. Electric. Thunder in the air. Was washing at her ear
  3081	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith her back to the fire too.

  3084	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tundoing the waistband of his trousers. The cat mewed to him.
  3085	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  3096	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbounds. Ah, wanted to go upstairs, curl up in a ball on the bed.

  3102	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe went out through the backdoor into the garden: stood to listen
  3103	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttowards the next garden. No sound. Perhaps hanging clothes out to dry.
  3104	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe maid was in the garden. Fine morning.
  3105	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3106	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe bent down to regard a lean file of spearmint growing by the wall.
  3107	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMake a summerhouse here. Scarlet runners. Virginia creepers. Want to
  3108	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmanure the whole place over, scabby soil. A coat of liver of sulphur.
  3109	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAll soil like that without dung. Household slops. Loam, what is this
  3110	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat is? The hens in the next garden: their droppings are very good top
  3111	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdressing. Best of all though are the cattle, especially when they are
  3112	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfed on those oilcakes. Mulch of dung. Best thing to clean ladies’ kid
  3113	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgloves. Dirty cleans. Ashes too. Reclaim the whole place. Grow peas in
  3114	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat corner there. Lettuce. Always have fresh greens then. Still gardens
  3115	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thave their drawbacks. That bee or bluebottle here Whitmonday.
  3116	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  3118	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpeg. Or hanging up on the floor. Funny I don’t remember that. Hallstand
  3119	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoo full. Four umbrellas, her raincloak. Picking up the letters.
  3120	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDrago’s shopbell ringing. Queer I was just thinking that moment. Brown
  3121	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrillantined hair over his collar. Just had a wash and brushup. Wonder
  3122	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thave I time for a bath this morning. Tara street. Chap in the paybox
  3123	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthere got away James Stephens, they say. O’Brien.

  3126	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEnthusiast.

  3128	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe kicked open the crazy door of the jakes. Better be careful not to get
  3129	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthese trousers dirty for the funeral. He went in, bowing his head

  3131	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlimewash and stale cobwebs he undid his braces. Before sitting down he
  3132	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpeered through a chink up at the nextdoor windows. The king was in his

  3136	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton his bared knees. Something new and easy. No great hurry. Keep it
  3137	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta bit. Our prize titbit: Matcham’s Masterstroke. Written by Mr Philip
  3138	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBeaufoy, Playgoers’ Club, London. Payment at the rate of one guinea
  3139	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta column has been made to the writer. Three and a half. Three pounds
  3140	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthree. Three pounds, thirteen and six.
  3141	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3142	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tQuietly he read, restraining himself, the first column and, yielding but
  3143	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tresisting, began the second. Midway, his last resistance yielding, he
  3144	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tallowed his bowels to ease themselves quietly as he read, reading still
  3145	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpatiently that slight constipation of yesterday quite gone. Hope it’s
  3146	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnot too big bring on piles again. No, just right. So. Ah! Costive. One
  3147	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttabloid of cascara sagrada. Life might be so. It did not move or touch
  3148	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim but it was something quick and neat. Print anything now. Silly
  3149	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseason. He read on, seated calm above his own rising smell. Neat
  3150	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcertainly. Matcham often thinks of the masterstroke by which he won the
  3151	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlaughing witch who now. Begins and ends morally. Hand in hand. Smart. He
  3152	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tglanced back through what he had read and, while feeling his water flow
  3153	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquietly, he envied kindly Mr Beaufoy who had written it and received
  3154	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpayment of three pounds, thirteen and six.
  3155	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3156	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMight manage a sketch. By Mr and Mrs L. M. Bloom. Invent a story for
  3157	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsome proverb. Which? Time I used to try jotting down on my cuff what she
  3158	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaid dressing. Dislike dressing together. Nicked myself shaving. Biting
  3159	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther nether lip, hooking the placket of her skirt. Timing her. 9.15.
  3160	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDid Roberts pay you yet? 9.20. What had Gretta Conroy on? 9.23. What
  3161	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpossessed me to buy this comb? 9.24. I’m swelled after that cabbage. A
  3162	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspeck of dust on the patent leather of her boot.
  3163	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3164	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRubbing smartly in turn each welt against her stockinged calf. Morning
  3165	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tafter the bazaar dance when May’s band played Ponchielli’s dance of the
  3166	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thours. Explain that: morning hours, noon, then evening coming on, then
  3167	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnight hours. Washing her teeth. That was the first night. Her head
  3168	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdancing. Her fansticks clicking. Is that Boylan well off? He has money.
  3169	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhy? I noticed he had a good rich smell off his breath dancing. No use
  3170	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thumming then. Allude to it. Strange kind of music that last night. The
  3171	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmirror was in shadow. She rubbed her handglass briskly on her woollen
  3172	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvest against her full wagging bub. Peering into it. Lines in her eyes.
  3173	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIt wouldn’t pan out somehow.
  3174	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3175	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEvening hours, girls in grey gauze. Night hours then: black with daggers
  3176	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand eyemasks. Poetical idea: pink, then golden, then grey, then black.
  3177	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStill, true to life also. Day: then the night.
  3178	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3179	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe tore away half the prize story sharply and wiped himself with it.

  3181	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tback the jerky shaky door of the jakes and came forth from the gloom
  3182	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinto the air.

  3186	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis the funeral? Better find out in the paper.

  3206	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBy lorries along sir John Rogerson’s quay Mr Bloom walked soberly, past
  3207	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWindmill lane, Leask’s the linseed crusher, the postal telegraph office.
  3208	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCould have given that address too. And past the sailors’ home. He turned
  3209	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom the morning noises of the quayside and walked through Lime street.
  3210	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBy Brady’s cottages a boy for the skins lolled, his bucket of offal
  3211	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlinked, smoking a chewed fagbutt. A smaller girl with scars of eczema
  3212	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton her forehead eyed him, listlessly holding her battered caskhoop. Tell
  3213	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim if he smokes he won’t grow. O let him! His life isn’t such a bed of
  3214	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\troses. Waiting outside pubs to bring da home. Come home to ma, da.
  3215	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSlack hour: won’t be many there. He crossed Townsend street, passed
  3216	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe frowning face of Bethel. El, yes: house of: Aleph, Beth. And past
  3217	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNichols’ the undertaker. At eleven it is. Time enough. Daresay Corny
  3218	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKelleher bagged the job for O’Neill’s. Singing with his eyes shut.
  3219	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCorny. Met her once in the park. In the dark. What a lark. Police tout.
  3220	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHer name and address she then told with my tooraloom tooraloom tay.
  3221	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tO, surely he bagged it. Bury him cheap in a whatyoumaycall. With my
  3222	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttooraloom, tooraloom, tooraloom, tooraloom.
  3223	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3224	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn Westland row he halted before the window of the Belfast and Oriental
  3225	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTea Company and read the legends of leadpapered packets: choice blend,
  3226	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfinest quality, family tea. Rather warm. Tea. Must get some from Tom
  3227	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKernan. Couldn’t ask him at a funeral, though. While his eyes still read
  3228	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblandly he took off his hat quietly inhaling his hairoil and sent his
  3229	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tright hand with slow grace over his brow and hair. Very warm morning.
  3230	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tUnder their dropped lids his eyes found the tiny bow of the leather
  3231	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theadband inside his high grade ha. Just there. His right hand came down
  3232	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinto the bowl of his hat. His fingers found quickly a card behind the
  3233	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theadband and transferred it to his waistcoat pocket.
  3234	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3235	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo warm. His right hand once more more slowly went over his brow and
  3236	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thair. Then he put on his hat again, relieved: and read again: choice
  3237	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblend, made of the finest Ceylon brands. The far east. Lovely spot it
  3238	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmust be: the garden of the world, big lazy leaves to float about on,
  3239	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcactuses, flowery meads, snaky lianas they call them. Wonder is it like
  3240	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat. Those Cinghalese lobbing about in the sun in dolce far niente, not
  3241	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoing a hand’s turn all day. Sleep six months out of twelve. Too hot to
  3242	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquarrel. Influence of the climate. Lethargy. Flowers of idleness. The
  3243	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tair feeds most. Azotes. Hothouse in Botanic gardens. Sensitive plants.
  3244	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWaterlilies. Petals too tired to. Sleeping sickness in the air. Walk on
  3245	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\troseleaves. Imagine trying to eat tripe and cowheel. Where was the chap
  3246	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI saw in that picture somewhere? Ah yes, in the dead sea floating on his
  3247	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tback, reading a book with a parasol open. Couldn’t sink if you tried: so
  3248	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthick with salt. Because the weight of the water, no, the weight of
  3249	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe body in the water is equal to the weight of the what? Or is it the
  3250	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvolume is equal to the weight? It’s a law something like that. Vance in
  3251	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHigh school cracking his fingerjoints, teaching. The college curriculum.
  3252	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCracking curriculum. What is weight really when you say the weight?
  3253	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThirtytwo feet per second per second. Law of falling bodies: per second
  3254	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tper second. They all fall to the ground. The earth. It’s the force of
  3255	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgravity of the earth is the weight.
  3256	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3257	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe turned away and sauntered across the road. How did she walk with her
  3258	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsausages? Like that something. As he walked he took the folded Freeman
  3259	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom his sidepocket, unfolded it, rolled it lengthwise in a baton and
  3260	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttapped it at each sauntering step against his trouserleg. Careless air:
  3261	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjust drop in to see. Per second per second. Per second for every second
  3262	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit means. From the curbstone he darted a keen glance through the door of
  3263	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe postoffice. Too late box. Post here. No-one. In.
  3264	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3265	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe handed the card through the brass grill.
  3266	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3267	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Are there any letters for me? he asked.
  3268	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3269	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhile the postmistress searched a pigeonhole he gazed at the recruiting
  3270	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tposter with soldiers of all arms on parade: and held the tip of his
  3271	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbaton against his nostrils, smelling freshprinted rag paper. No answer
  3272	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprobably. Went too far last time.
  3273	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3274	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe postmistress handed him back through the grill his card with a
  3275	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tletter. He thanked her and glanced rapidly at the typed envelope.
  3276	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3277	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      Henry Flower Esq,
  3278	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t         c/o P. O. Westland Row,
  3279	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t            City.
  3280	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3281	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnswered anyhow. He slipped card and letter into his sidepocket,
  3282	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treviewing again the soldiers on parade. Where’s old Tweedy’s regiment?
  3283	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCastoff soldier. There: bearskin cap and hackle plume. No, he’s a
  3284	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgrenadier. Pointed cuffs. There he is: royal Dublin fusiliers. Redcoats.
  3285	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tToo showy. That must be why the women go after them. Uniform. Easier to
  3286	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tenlist and drill. Maud Gonne’s letter about taking them off O’Connell
  3287	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstreet at night: disgrace to our Irish capital. Griffith’s paper is on
  3288	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe same tack now: an army rotten with venereal disease: overseas or
  3289	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thalfseasover empire. Half baked they look: hypnotised like. Eyes front.
  3290	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMark time. Table: able. Bed: ed. The King’s own. Never see him dressed
  3291	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tup as a fireman or a bobby. A mason, yes.
  3292	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3293	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe strolled out of the postoffice and turned to the right. Talk: as if
  3294	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat would mend matters. His hand went into his pocket and a forefinger
  3295	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfelt its way under the flap of the envelope, ripping it open in jerks.
  3296	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWomen will pay a lot of heed, I don’t think. His fingers drew forth the
  3297	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tletter the letter and crumpled the envelope in his pocket. Something
  3298	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpinned on: photo perhaps. Hair? No.

  3301	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou.

  3320	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3321	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA photo it isn’t. A badge maybe.

  3327	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  3330	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Bloom gazed across the road at the outsider drawn up before the door

  3332	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstood still, waiting, while the man, husband, brother, like her,
  3333	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsearched his pockets for change. Stylish kind of coat with that roll
  3334	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcollar, warm for a day like this, looks like blanketcloth. Careless
  3335	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstand of her with her hands in those patch pockets. Like that haughty
  3336	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcreature at the polo match. Women all for caste till you touch the spot.
  3337	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHandsome is and handsome does. Reserved about to yield. The honourable
  3338	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMrs and Brutus is an honourable man. Possess her once take the starch
  3339	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tout of her.

  3445	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcould. Well, tolloll. Just C. P. M’Coy will do.

  3448	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3449	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDidn’t catch me napping that wheeze. The quick touch. Soft mark. I’d
  3450	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlike my job. Valise I have a particular fancy for. Leather. Capped
  3451	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcorners, rivetted edges, double action lever lock. Bob Cowley lent him
  3452	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this for the Wicklow regatta concert last year and never heard tidings of
  3453	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit from that good day to this.

  3456	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgot an. Reedy freckled soprano. Cheeseparing nose. Nice enough in its
  3457	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tway: for a little ballad. No guts in it. You and me, don’t you know:
  3458	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the same boat. Softsoaping. Give you the needle that would. Can’t
  3459	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the hear the difference? Think he’s that way inclined a bit. Against
  3460	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmy grain somehow. Thought that Belfast would fetch him. I hope that
  3461	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsmallpox up there doesn’t get worse. Suppose she wouldn’t let herself be
  3462	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvaccinated again. Your wife and my wife.

  3467	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thoardings. Cantrell and Cochrane’s Ginger Ale (Aromatic). Clery’s Summer
  3468	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSale. No, he’s going on straight. Hello. Leah tonight. Mrs Bandmann
  3469	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPalmer. Like to see her again in that. Hamlet she played last night.
  3470	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMale impersonator. Perhaps he was a woman. Why Ophelia committed
  3471	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsuicide. Poor papa! How he used to talk of Kate Bateman in that. Outside
  3472	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe Adelphi in London waited all the afternoon to get in. Year before
  3473	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI was born that was: sixtyfive. And Ristori in Vienna. What is this the
  3474	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tright name is? By Mosenthal it is. Rachel, is it? No. The scene he was
  3475	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\talways talking about where the old blind Abraham recognises the voice
  3476	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand puts his fingers on his face.

  3479	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfather to die of grief and misery in my arms, who left the house of his
  3480	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfather and left the God of his father.
  3481	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  3485	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tface. That day! O, dear! O, dear! Ffoo! Well, perhaps it was best for

  3488	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Bloom went round the corner and passed the drooping nags of the
  3489	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thazard. No use thinking of it any more. Nosebag time. Wish I hadn’t met
  3490	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat M’Coy fellow.
  3491	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3492	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe came nearer and heard a crunching of gilded oats, the gently champing
  3493	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tteeth. Their full buck eyes regarded him as he went by, amid the sweet
  3494	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toaten reek of horsepiss. Their Eldorado. Poor jugginses! Damn all they
  3495	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknow or care about anything with their long noses stuck in nosebags.
  3496	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tToo full for words. Still they get their feed all right and their doss.
  3497	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGelded too: a stump of black guttapercha wagging limp between their
  3498	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thaunches. Might be happy all the same that way. Good poor brutes they
  3499	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlook. Still their neigh can be very irritating.
  3500	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3501	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe drew the letter from his pocket and folded it into the newspaper he
  3502	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcarried. Might just walk into her here. The lane is safer.
  3503	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3504	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe passed the cabman’s shelter. Curious the life of drifting cabbies.
  3505	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAll weathers, all places, time or setdown, no will of their own. Voglio
  3506	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\te non. Like to give them an odd cigarette. Sociable. Shout a few flying
  3507	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsyllables as they pass. He hummed:
  3508	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3509	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Là ci darem la mano
  3510	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     La la lala la la.
  3511	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3512	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe turned into Cumberland street and, going on some paces, halted in the
  3513	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlee of the station wall. No-one. Meade’s timberyard. Piled balks. Ruins
  3514	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand tenements. With careful tread he passed over a hopscotch court with
  3515	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tits forgotten pickeystone. Not a sinner. Near the timberyard a squatted
  3516	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchild at marbles, alone, shooting the taw with a cunnythumb. A wise
  3517	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttabby, a blinking sphinx, watched from her warm sill. Pity to disturb
  3518	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem. Mohammed cut a piece out of his mantle not to wake her. Open it.
  3519	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd once I played marbles when I went to that old dame’s school. She
  3520	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tliked mignonette. Mrs Ellis’s. And Mr? He opened the letter within the
  3521	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnewspaper.
  3522	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3523	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA flower. I think it’s a. A yellow flower with flattened petals. Not
  3524	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tannoyed then? What does she say?
  3525	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3526	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDear Henry
  3527	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3528	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI got your last letter to me and thank you very much for it. I am sorry
  3529	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou did not like my last letter. Why did you enclose the stamps? I am
  3530	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tawfully angry with you. I do wish I could punish you for that. I called
  3531	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou naughty boy because I do not like that other world. Please tell me
  3532	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhat is the real meaning of that word? Are you not happy in your home
  3533	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou poor little naughty boy? I do wish I could do something for you.
  3534	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPlease tell me what you think of poor me. I often think of the beautiful
  3535	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tname you have. Dear Henry, when will we meet? I think of you so often
  3536	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou have no idea. I have never felt myself so much drawn to a man as
  3537	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou. I feel so bad about. Please write me a long letter and tell me
  3538	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmore. Remember if you do not I will punish you. So now you know what I
  3539	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twill do to you, you naughty boy, if you do not wrote. O how I long to
  3540	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmeet you. Henry dear, do not deny my request before my patience are
  3541	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\texhausted. Then I will tell you all. Goodbye now, naughty darling, I
  3542	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thave such a bad headache. today. and write by return to your longing
  3543	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3544	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMartha
  3545	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3546	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tP. S. Do tell me what kind of perfume does your wife use. I want to
  3547	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknow.
  3548	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3549	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe tore the flower gravely from its pinhold smelt its almost no smell
  3550	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand placed it in his heart pocket. Language of flowers. They like it
  3551	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbecause no-one can hear. Or a poison bouquet to strike him down. Then
  3552	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twalking slowly forward he read the letter again, murmuring here and
  3553	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthere a word. Angry tulips with you darling manflower punish your cactus
  3554	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tif you don’t please poor forgetmenot how I long violets to dear roses
  3555	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhen we soon anemone meet all naughty nightstalk wife Martha’s perfume.
  3556	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHaving read it all he took it from the newspaper and put it back in his
  3557	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsidepocket.
  3558	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  3559	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWeak joy opened his lips. Changed since the first letter. Wonder did she
  3560	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twrote it herself. Doing the indignant: a girl of good family like me,
  3561	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trespectable character. Could meet one Sunday after the rosary. Thank
  3562	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou: not having any. Usual love scrimmage. Then running round corners.
  3563	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBad as a row with Molly. Cigar has a cooling effect. Narcotic. Go
  3564	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfurther next time. Naughty boy: punish: afraid of words, of course.
  3565	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBrutal, why not? Try it anyhow. A bit at a time.
  3566	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  3568	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCommon pin, eh? He threw it on the road. Out of her clothes somewhere:
  3569	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpinned together. Queer the number of pins they always have. No roses
  3570	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twithout thorns.
