  4400	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4401	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe tapped his chest sadly.
  4402	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4403	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBlazing face: redhot. Too much John Barleycorn. Cure for a red nose.
  4404	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDrink like the devil till it turns adelite. A lot of money he spent
  4405	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcolouring it.
  4406	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4407	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Power gazed at the passing houses with rueful apprehension.
  4408	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4409	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He had a sudden death, poor fellow, he said.
  4410	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4411	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The best death, Mr Bloom said.
  4412	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4413	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTheir wide open eyes looked at him.
  4414	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4415	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—No suffering, he said. A moment and all is over. Like dying in sleep.
  4416	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4417	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNo-one spoke.
  4418	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4419	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDead side of the street this. Dull business by day, land agents,
  4420	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttemperance hotel, Falconer’s railway guide, civil service college,
  4421	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGill’s, catholic club, the industrious blind. Why? Some reason. Sun or
  4422	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twind. At night too. Chummies and slaveys. Under the patronage of the
  4423	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlate Father Mathew. Foundation stone for Parnell. Breakdown. Heart.
  4424	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4425	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhite horses with white frontlet plumes came round the Rotunda corner,
  4426	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgalloping. A tiny coffin flashed by. In a hurry to bury. A mourning
  4427	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcoach. Unmarried. Black for the married. Piebald for bachelors. Dun for
  4428	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta nun.
  4429	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4430	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Sad, Martin Cunningham said. A child.
  4431	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4432	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA dwarf’s face, mauve and wrinkled like little Rudy’s was. Dwarf’s body,
  4433	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tweak as putty, in a whitelined deal box. Burial friendly society
  4434	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpays. Penny a week for a sod of turf. Our. Little. Beggar. Baby. Meant
  4435	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnothing. Mistake of nature. If it’s healthy it’s from the mother. If not
  4436	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom the man. Better luck next time.
  4437	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4438	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Poor little thing, Mr Dedalus said. It’s well out of it.
  4439	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4440	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe carriage climbed more slowly the hill of Rutland square. Rattle his
  4441	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbones. Over the stones. Only a pauper. Nobody owns.
  4442	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4443	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—In the midst of life, Martin Cunningham said.
  4444	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4445	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—But the worst of all, Mr Power said, is the man who takes his own life.
  4446	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4447	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMartin Cunningham drew out his watch briskly, coughed and put it back.
  4448	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4449	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The greatest disgrace to have in the family, Mr Power added.
  4450	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4451	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Temporary insanity, of course, Martin Cunningham said decisively. We
  4452	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmust take a charitable view of it.
  4453	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4454	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—They say a man who does it is a coward, Mr Dedalus said.
  4455	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4456	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—It is not for us to judge, Martin Cunningham said.
  4457	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4458	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Bloom, about to speak, closed his lips again. Martin Cunningham’s
  4459	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlarge eyes. Looking away now. Sympathetic human man he is. Intelligent.
  4460	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLike Shakespeare’s face. Always a good word to say. They have no mercy
  4461	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton that here or infanticide. Refuse christian burial. They used to drive
  4462	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta stake of wood through his heart in the grave. As if it wasn’t broken
  4463	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\talready. Yet sometimes they repent too late. Found in the riverbed
  4464	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tclutching rushes. He looked at me. And that awful drunkard of a wife
  4465	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof his. Setting up house for her time after time and then pawning the
  4466	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfurniture on him every Saturday almost. Leading him the life of the
  4467	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdamned. Wear the heart out of a stone, that. Monday morning. Start
  4468	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tafresh. Shoulder to the wheel. Lord, she must have looked a sight
  4469	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat night Dedalus told me he was in there. Drunk about the place and
  4470	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcapering with Martin’s umbrella.
  4471	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4472	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     And they call me the jewel of Asia,
  4473	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Of Asia,
  4474	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     The geisha.
  4475	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4476	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe looked away from me. He knows. Rattle his bones.
  4477	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4478	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThat afternoon of the inquest. The redlabelled bottle on the table. The
  4479	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\troom in the hotel with hunting pictures. Stuffy it was. Sunlight through
  4480	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe slats of the Venetian blind. The coroner’s sunlit ears, big and
  4481	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thairy. Boots giving evidence. Thought he was asleep first. Then saw like
  4482	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyellow streaks on his face. Had slipped down to the foot of the bed.
  4483	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tVerdict: overdose. Death by misadventure. The letter. For my son
  4484	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLeopold.
  4485	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4486	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNo more pain. Wake no more. Nobody owns.
  4487	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4488	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe carriage rattled swiftly along Blessington street. Over the stones.
  4489	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4490	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—We are going the pace, I think, Martin Cunningham said.
  4491	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4492	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—God grant he doesn’t upset us on the road, Mr Power said.
  4493	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4494	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I hope not, Martin Cunningham said. That will be a great race tomorrow
  4495	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin Germany. The Gordon Bennett.
  4496	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4497	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, by Jove, Mr Dedalus said. That will be worth seeing, faith.
  4498	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4499	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAs they turned into Berkeley street a streetorgan near the Basin sent
  4500	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tover and after them a rollicking rattling song of the halls. Has anybody
  4501	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\there seen Kelly? Kay ee double ell wy. Dead March from Saul. He’s as
  4502	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbad as old Antonio. He left me on my ownio. Pirouette! The Mater
  4503	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMisericordiae. Eccles street. My house down there. Big place. Ward for
  4504	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tincurables there. Very encouraging. Our Lady’s Hospice for the dying.
  4505	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDeadhouse handy underneath. Where old Mrs Riordan died. They look
  4506	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tterrible the women. Her feeding cup and rubbing her mouth with the
  4507	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspoon. Then the screen round her bed for her to die. Nice young student
  4508	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat was dressed that bite the bee gave me. He’s gone over to the
  4509	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlying-in hospital they told me. From one extreme to the other.
  4510	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4511	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe carriage galloped round a corner: stopped.
  4512	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4513	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What’s wrong now?
  4514	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4515	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA divided drove of branded cattle passed the windows, lowing, slouching
  4516	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby on padded hoofs, whisking their tails slowly on their clotted bony
  4517	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcroups. Outside them and through them ran raddled sheep bleating their
  4518	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfear.
  4519	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4520	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Emigrants, Mr Power said.
  4521	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4522	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Huuuh! the drover’s voice cried, his switch sounding on their flanks.
  4523	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHuuuh! out of that!
  4524	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4525	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThursday, of course. Tomorrow is killing day. Springers. Cuffe sold them
  4526	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabout twentyseven quid each. For Liverpool probably. Roastbeef for old
  4527	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEngland. They buy up all the juicy ones. And then the fifth quarter
  4528	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlost: all that raw stuff, hide, hair, horns. Comes to a big thing in a
  4529	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyear. Dead meat trade. Byproducts of the slaughterhouses for tanneries,
  4530	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsoap, margarine. Wonder if that dodge works now getting dicky meat off
  4531	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe train at Clonsilla.
  4532	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4533	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe carriage moved on through the drove.
  4534	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4535	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I can’t make out why the corporation doesn’t run a tramline from the
  4536	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tparkgate to the quays, Mr Bloom said. All those animals could be taken
  4537	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin trucks down to the boats.
  4538	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4539	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Instead of blocking up the thoroughfare, Martin Cunningham said. Quite
  4540	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tright. They ought to.
  4541	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4542	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, Mr Bloom said, and another thing I often thought, is to have
  4543	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmunicipal funeral trams like they have in Milan, you know. Run the line
  4544	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tout to the cemetery gates and have special trams, hearse and carriage
  4545	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand all. Don’t you see what I mean?
  4546	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4547	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, that be damned for a story, Mr Dedalus said. Pullman car and saloon
  4548	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdiningroom.
  4549	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4550	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A poor lookout for Corny, Mr Power added.
  4551	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4552	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Why? Mr Bloom asked, turning to Mr Dedalus. Wouldn’t it be more decent
  4553	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthan galloping two abreast?
  4554	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4555	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, there’s something in that, Mr Dedalus granted.
  4556	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4557	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And, Martin Cunningham said, we wouldn’t have scenes like that when the
  4558	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thearse capsized round Dunphy’s and upset the coffin on to the road.
  4559	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4560	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That was terrible, Mr Power’s shocked face said, and the corpse fell
  4561	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabout the road. Terrible!
  4562	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4563	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—First round Dunphy’s, Mr Dedalus said, nodding. Gordon Bennett cup.
  4564	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4565	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Praises be to God! Martin Cunningham said piously.
  4566	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4567	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBom! Upset. A coffin bumped out on to the road. Burst open. Paddy Dignam
  4568	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshot out and rolling over stiff in the dust in a brown habit too large
  4569	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor him. Red face: grey now. Mouth fallen open. Asking what’s up now.
  4570	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tQuite right to close it. Looks horrid open. Then the insides decompose
  4571	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquickly. Much better to close up all the orifices. Yes, also. With wax.
  4572	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe sphincter loose. Seal up all.
  4573	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4574	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Dunphy’s, Mr Power announced as the carriage turned right.
  4575	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4576	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDunphy’s corner. Mourning coaches drawn up, drowning their grief. A
  4577	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpause by the wayside. Tiptop position for a pub. Expect we’ll pull up
  4578	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\there on the way back to drink his health. Pass round the consolation.
  4579	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tElixir of life.
  4580	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4581	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBut suppose now it did happen. Would he bleed if a nail say cut him
  4582	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the knocking about? He would and he wouldn’t, I suppose. Depends on
  4583	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhere. The circulation stops. Still some might ooze out of an artery. It
  4584	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twould be better to bury them in red: a dark red.
  4585	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4586	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn silence they drove along Phibsborough road. An empty hearse trotted
  4587	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby, coming from the cemetery: looks relieved.
  4588	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4589	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCrossguns bridge: the royal canal.
  4590	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4591	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWater rushed roaring through the sluices. A man stood on his
  4592	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdropping barge, between clamps of turf. On the towpath by the lock a
  4593	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tslacktethered horse. Aboard of the Bugabu.
  4594	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4595	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTheir eyes watched him. On the slow weedy waterway he had floated on his
  4596	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\traft coastward over Ireland drawn by a haulage rope past beds of
  4597	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treeds, over slime, mudchoked bottles, carrion dogs. Athlone, Mullingar,
  4598	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMoyvalley, I could make a walking tour to see Milly by the canal. Or
  4599	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcycle down. Hire some old crock, safety. Wren had one the other day at
  4600	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe auction but a lady’s. Developing waterways. James M’Cann’s hobby
  4601	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto row me o’er the ferry. Cheaper transit. By easy stages. Houseboats.
  4602	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCamping out. Also hearses. To heaven by water. Perhaps I will without
  4603	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twriting. Come as a surprise, Leixlip, Clonsilla. Dropping down lock by
  4604	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlock to Dublin. With turf from the midland bogs. Salute. He lifted his
  4605	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrown straw hat, saluting Paddy Dignam.
  4606	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4607	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey drove on past Brian Boroimhe house. Near it now.
  4608	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4609	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I wonder how is our friend Fogarty getting on, Mr Power said.
  4610	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4611	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Better ask Tom Kernan, Mr Dedalus said.
  4612	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4613	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—How is that? Martin Cunningham said. Left him weeping, I suppose?
  4614	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4615	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Though lost to sight, Mr Dedalus said, to memory dear.
  4616	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4617	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe carriage steered left for Finglas road.
  4618	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4619	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe stonecutter’s yard on the right. Last lap. Crowded on the spit of
  4620	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tland silent shapes appeared, white, sorrowful, holding out calm hands,
  4621	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknelt in grief, pointing. Fragments of shapes, hewn. In white silence:
  4622	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tappealing. The best obtainable. Thos. H. Dennany, monumental builder and
  4623	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsculptor.
  4624	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4625	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPassed.
  4626	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4627	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOn the curbstone before Jimmy Geary, the sexton’s, an old tramp sat,
  4628	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgrumbling, emptying the dirt and stones out of his huge dustbrown
  4629	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyawning boot. After life’s journey.
  4630	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4631	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGloomy gardens then went by: one by one: gloomy houses.
  4632	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4633	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Power pointed.
  4634	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4635	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That is where Childs was murdered, he said. The last house.
  4636	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4637	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—So it is, Mr Dedalus said. A gruesome case. Seymour Bushe got him off.
  4638	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMurdered his brother. Or so they said.
  4639	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4640	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The crown had no evidence, Mr Power said.
  4641	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4642	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Only circumstantial, Martin Cunningham added. That’s the maxim of the
  4643	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlaw. Better for ninetynine guilty to escape than for one innocent person
  4644	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto be wrongfully condemned.
  4645	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4646	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey looked. Murderer’s ground. It passed darkly. Shuttered, tenantless,
  4647	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunweeded garden. Whole place gone to hell. Wrongfully condemned. Murder.
  4648	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe murderer’s image in the eye of the murdered. They love reading about
  4649	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit. Man’s head found in a garden. Her clothing consisted of. How she met
  4650	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther death. Recent outrage. The weapon used. Murderer is still at large.
  4651	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tClues. A shoelace. The body to be exhumed. Murder will out.
  4652	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4653	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCramped in this carriage. She mightn’t like me to come that way without
  4654	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tletting her know. Must be careful about women. Catch them once with
  4655	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir pants down. Never forgive you after. Fifteen.
  4656	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4657	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe high railings of Prospect rippled past their gaze. Dark poplars,
  4658	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trare white forms. Forms more frequent, white shapes thronged amid the
  4659	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttrees, white forms and fragments streaming by mutely, sustaining vain
  4660	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgestures on the air.
  4661	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4662	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe felly harshed against the curbstone: stopped. Martin Cunningham put
  4663	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tout his arm and, wrenching back the handle, shoved the door open with
  4664	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this knee. He stepped out. Mr Power and Mr Dedalus followed.
  4665	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4666	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tChange that soap now. Mr Bloom’s hand unbuttoned his hip pocket swiftly
  4667	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand transferred the paperstuck soap to his inner handkerchief pocket.
  4668	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe stepped out of the carriage, replacing the newspaper his other hand
  4669	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstill held.
  4670	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4671	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPaltry funeral: coach and three carriages. It’s all the same.
  4672	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPallbearers, gold reins, requiem mass, firing a volley. Pomp of death.
  4673	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBeyond the hind carriage a hawker stood by his barrow of cakes and
  4674	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfruit. Simnel cakes those are, stuck together: cakes for the dead.
  4675	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDogbiscuits. Who ate them? Mourners coming out.
  4676	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4677	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe followed his companions. Mr Kernan and Ned Lambert followed, Hynes
  4678	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twalking after them. Corny Kelleher stood by the opened hearse and took
  4679	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tout the two wreaths. He handed one to the boy.
  4680	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4681	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhere is that child’s funeral disappeared to?
  4682	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4683	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA team of horses passed from Finglas with toiling plodding tread,
  4684	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdragging through the funereal silence a creaking waggon on which lay a
  4685	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgranite block. The waggoner marching at their head saluted.
  4686	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4687	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCoffin now. Got here before us, dead as he is. Horse looking round at it
  4688	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith his plume skeowways. Dull eye: collar tight on his neck, pressing
  4689	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton a bloodvessel or something. Do they know what they cart out here
  4690	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tevery day? Must be twenty or thirty funerals every day. Then Mount
  4691	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJerome for the protestants. Funerals all over the world everywhere every
  4692	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tminute. Shovelling them under by the cartload doublequick. Thousands
  4693	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tevery hour. Too many in the world.
  4694	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4695	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMourners came out through the gates: woman and a girl. Leanjawed harpy,
  4696	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thard woman at a bargain, her bonnet awry. Girl’s face stained with dirt
  4697	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand tears, holding the woman’s arm, looking up at her for a sign to cry.
  4698	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFish’s face, bloodless and livid.
  4699	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4700	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe mutes shouldered the coffin and bore it in through the gates. So
  4701	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmuch dead weight. Felt heavier myself stepping out of that bath. First
  4702	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe stiff: then the friends of the stiff. Corny Kelleher and the
  4703	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tboy followed with their wreaths. Who is that beside them? Ah, the
  4704	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrother-in-law.
  4705	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4706	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAll walked after.
  4707	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4708	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMartin Cunningham whispered:
  4709	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4710	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I was in mortal agony with you talking of suicide before Bloom.
  4711	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4712	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What? Mr Power whispered. How so?
  4713	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4714	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—His father poisoned himself, Martin Cunningham whispered. Had the
  4715	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tQueen’s hotel in Ennis. You heard him say he was going to Clare.
  4716	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnniversary.
  4717	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4718	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O God! Mr Power whispered. First I heard of it. Poisoned himself?
  4719	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4720	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe glanced behind him to where a face with dark thinking eyes followed
  4721	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttowards the cardinal’s mausoleum. Speaking.
  4722	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4723	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Was he insured? Mr Bloom asked.
  4724	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4725	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I believe so, Mr Kernan answered. But the policy was heavily mortgaged.
  4726	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMartin is trying to get the youngster into Artane.
  4727	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4728	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—How many children did he leave?
  4729	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4730	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Five. Ned Lambert says he’ll try to get one of the girls into Todd’s.
  4731	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4732	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A sad case, Mr Bloom said gently. Five young children.
  4733	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4734	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A great blow to the poor wife, Mr Kernan added.
  4735	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4736	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Indeed yes, Mr Bloom agreed.
  4737	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4738	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHas the laugh at him now.
  4739	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4740	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe looked down at the boots he had blacked and polished. She had
  4741	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toutlived him. Lost her husband. More dead for her than for me. One must
  4742	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toutlive the other. Wise men say. There are more women than men in the
  4743	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tworld. Condole with her. Your terrible loss. I hope you’ll soon follow
  4744	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim. For Hindu widows only. She would marry another. Him? No. Yet who
  4745	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknows after. Widowhood not the thing since the old queen died. Drawn on
  4746	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta guncarriage. Victoria and Albert. Frogmore memorial mourning. But
  4747	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the end she put a few violets in her bonnet. Vain in her heart of
  4748	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thearts. All for a shadow. Consort not even a king. Her son was the
  4749	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsubstance. Something new to hope for not like the past she wanted back,
  4750	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twaiting. It never comes. One must go first: alone, under the ground: and
  4751	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlie no more in her warm bed.
  4752	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4753	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—How are you, Simon? Ned Lambert said softly, clasping hands. Haven’t
  4754	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseen you for a month of Sundays.
  4755	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4756	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Never better. How are all in Cork’s own town?
  4757	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4758	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I was down there for the Cork park races on Easter Monday, Ned Lambert
  4759	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaid. Same old six and eightpence. Stopped with Dick Tivy.
  4760	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4761	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And how is Dick, the solid man?
  4762	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4763	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Nothing between himself and heaven, Ned Lambert answered.
  4764	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4765	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—By the holy Paul! Mr Dedalus said in subdued wonder. Dick Tivy bald?
  4766	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4767	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Martin is going to get up a whip for the youngsters, Ned Lambert said,
  4768	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpointing ahead. A few bob a skull. Just to keep them going till the
  4769	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinsurance is cleared up.
  4770	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4771	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, yes, Mr Dedalus said dubiously. Is that the eldest boy in front?
  4772	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4773	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, Ned Lambert said, with the wife’s brother. John Henry Menton is
  4774	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbehind. He put down his name for a quid.
  4775	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4776	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’ll engage he did, Mr Dedalus said. I often told poor Paddy he ought
  4777	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto mind that job. John Henry is not the worst in the world.
  4778	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4779	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—How did he lose it? Ned Lambert asked. Liquor, what?
  4780	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4781	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Many a good man’s fault, Mr Dedalus said with a sigh.
  4782	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4783	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey halted about the door of the mortuary chapel. Mr Bloom stood behind
  4784	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe boy with the wreath looking down at his sleekcombed hair and at the
  4785	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tslender furrowed neck inside his brandnew collar. Poor boy! Was he there
  4786	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhen the father? Both unconscious. Lighten up at the last moment
  4787	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand recognise for the last time. All he might have done. I owe three
  4788	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshillings to O’Grady. Would he understand? The mutes bore the coffin
  4789	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinto the chapel. Which end is his head?
  4790	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4791	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAfter a moment he followed the others in, blinking in the screened
  4792	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlight. The coffin lay on its bier before the chancel, four tall yellow
  4793	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcandles at its corners. Always in front of us. Corny Kelleher, laying a
  4794	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twreath at each fore corner, beckoned to the boy to kneel. The mourners
  4795	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknelt here and there in prayingdesks. Mr Bloom stood behind near the
  4796	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfont and, when all had knelt, dropped carefully his unfolded newspaper
  4797	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom his pocket and knelt his right knee upon it. He fitted his black
  4798	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\that gently on his left knee and, holding its brim, bent over piously.
  4799	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4800	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA server bearing a brass bucket with something in it came out through a
  4801	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoor. The whitesmocked priest came after him, tidying his stole with one
  4802	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thand, balancing with the other a little book against his toad’s belly.
  4803	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWho’ll read the book? I, said the rook.
  4804	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4805	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey halted by the bier and the priest began to read out of his book
  4806	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith a fluent croak.
  4807	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4808	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Coffey. I knew his name was like a coffin. Dominenamine. Bully
  4809	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabout the muzzle he looks. Bosses the show. Muscular christian. Woe
  4810	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbetide anyone that looks crooked at him: priest. Thou art Peter. Burst
  4811	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsideways like a sheep in clover Dedalus says he will. With a belly on
  4812	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim like a poisoned pup. Most amusing expressions that man finds. Hhhn:
  4813	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tburst sideways.
  4814	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4815	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Non intres in judicium cum servo tuo, Domine.
  4816	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4817	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMakes them feel more important to be prayed over in Latin. Requiem mass.
  4818	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCrape weepers. Blackedged notepaper. Your name on the altarlist. Chilly
  4819	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplace this. Want to feed well, sitting in there all the morning in the
  4820	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgloom kicking his heels waiting for the next please. Eyes of a toad too.
  4821	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat swells him up that way? Molly gets swelled after cabbage. Air of
  4822	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe place maybe. Looks full up of bad gas. Must be an infernal lot
  4823	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof bad gas round the place. Butchers, for instance: they get like raw
  4824	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeefsteaks. Who was telling me? Mervyn Browne. Down in the vaults of
  4825	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaint Werburgh’s lovely old organ hundred and fifty they have to bore a
  4826	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thole in the coffins sometimes to let out the bad gas and burn it. Out it
  4827	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trushes: blue. One whiff of that and you’re a goner.
  4828	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4829	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMy kneecap is hurting me. Ow. That’s better.
  4830	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4831	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe priest took a stick with a knob at the end of it out of the boy’s
  4832	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbucket and shook it over the coffin. Then he walked to the other end and
  4833	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshook it again. Then he came back and put it back in the bucket. As you
  4834	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twere before you rested. It’s all written down: he has to do it.
  4835	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4836	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Et ne nos inducas in tentationem.
  4837	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4838	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe server piped the answers in the treble. I often thought it would be
  4839	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbetter to have boy servants. Up to fifteen or so. After that, of course
  4840	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t...
  4841	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4842	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHoly water that was, I expect. Shaking sleep out of it. He must be fed
  4843	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tup with that job, shaking that thing over all the corpses they trot up.
  4844	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat harm if he could see what he was shaking it over. Every mortal
  4845	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tday a fresh batch: middleaged men, old women, children, women dead in
  4846	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchildbirth, men with beards, baldheaded businessmen, consumptive girls
  4847	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith little sparrows’ breasts. All the year round he prayed the same
  4848	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthing over them all and shook water on top of them: sleep. On Dignam
  4849	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnow.
  4850	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4851	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—In paradisum.
  4852	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4853	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSaid he was going to paradise or is in paradise. Says that over
  4854	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teverybody. Tiresome kind of a job. But he has to say something.
  4855	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4856	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe priest closed his book and went off, followed by the server. Corny
  4857	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKelleher opened the sidedoors and the gravediggers came in, hoisted the
  4858	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcoffin again, carried it out and shoved it on their cart. Corny Kelleher
  4859	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgave one wreath to the boy and one to the brother-in-law. All followed
  4860	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem out of the sidedoors into the mild grey air. Mr Bloom came last
  4861	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfolding his paper again into his pocket. He gazed gravely at the ground
  4862	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttill the coffincart wheeled off to the left. The metal wheels ground the
  4863	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgravel with a sharp grating cry and the pack of blunt boots followed the
  4864	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttrundled barrow along a lane of sepulchres.
  4865	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4866	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe ree the ra the ree the ra the roo. Lord, I mustn’t lilt here.
  4867	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4868	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The O’Connell circle, Mr Dedalus said about him.
  4869	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4870	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Power’s soft eyes went up to the apex of the lofty cone.
  4871	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4872	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He’s at rest, he said, in the middle of his people, old Dan O’. But his
  4873	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theart is buried in Rome. How many broken hearts are buried here, Simon!
  4874	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4875	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Her grave is over there, Jack, Mr Dedalus said. I’ll soon be stretched
  4876	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeside her. Let Him take me whenever He likes.
  4877	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4878	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBreaking down, he began to weep to himself quietly, stumbling a little
  4879	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin his walk. Mr Power took his arm.
  4880	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4881	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—She’s better where she is, he said kindly.
  4882	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4883	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I suppose so, Mr Dedalus said with a weak gasp. I suppose she is in
  4884	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theaven if there is a heaven.
  4885	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4886	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCorny Kelleher stepped aside from his rank and allowed the mourners to
  4887	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplod by.
  4888	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4889	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Sad occasions, Mr Kernan began politely.
  4890	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4891	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Bloom closed his eyes and sadly twice bowed his head.
  4892	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4893	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The others are putting on their hats, Mr Kernan said. I suppose we can
  4894	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdo so too. We are the last. This cemetery is a treacherous place.
  4895	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4896	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey covered their heads.
  4897	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4898	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The reverend gentleman read the service too quickly, don’t you think?
  4899	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Kernan said with reproof.
  4900	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4901	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Bloom nodded gravely looking in the quick bloodshot eyes. Secret
  4902	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teyes, secretsearching. Mason, I think: not sure. Beside him again. We
  4903	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tare the last. In the same boat. Hope he’ll say something else.
  4904	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4905	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Kernan added:
  4906	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4907	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The service of the Irish church used in Mount Jerome is simpler, more
  4908	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\timpressive I must say.
  4909	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4910	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Bloom gave prudent assent. The language of course was another thing.
  4911	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4912	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Kernan said with solemnity:
  4913	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4914	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I am the resurrection and the life. That touches a man’s inmost heart.
  4915	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4916	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—It does, Mr Bloom said.
  4917	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4918	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYour heart perhaps but what price the fellow in the six feet by two
  4919	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith his toes to the daisies? No touching that. Seat of the affections.
  4920	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBroken heart. A pump after all, pumping thousands of gallons of blood
  4921	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tevery day. One fine day it gets bunged up: and there you are. Lots of
  4922	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem lying around here: lungs, hearts, livers. Old rusty pumps: damn
  4923	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe thing else. The resurrection and the life. Once you are dead you are
  4924	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdead. That last day idea. Knocking them all up out of their graves. Come
  4925	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tforth, Lazarus! And he came fifth and lost the job. Get up! Last day!
  4926	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThen every fellow mousing around for his liver and his lights and the
  4927	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trest of his traps. Find damn all of himself that morning. Pennyweight of
  4928	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpowder in a skull. Twelve grammes one pennyweight. Troy measure.
  4929	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4930	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCorny Kelleher fell into step at their side.
  4931	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4932	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Everything went off A1, he said. What?

  4935	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyour tooraloom tooraloom.
  4936	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4937	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—As it should be, Mr Kernan said.

  4940	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4941	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Kernan assured him.

  4944	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknow his face.
  4945	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  4947	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4948	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Bloom, he said, Madame Marion Tweedy that was, is, I mean, the soprano.
  4949	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe’s his wife.
  4950	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4951	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, to be sure, John Henry Menton said. I haven’t seen her for some
  4952	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttime. She was a finelooking woman. I danced with her, wait, fifteen
  4953	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseventeen golden years ago, at Mat Dillon’s in Roundtown. And a good
  4954	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tarmful she was.
  4955	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4956	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe looked behind through the others.
  4957	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4958	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What is he? he asked. What does he do? Wasn’t he in the stationery
  4959	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tline? I fell foul of him one evening, I remember, at bowls.
  4960	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4961	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNed Lambert smiled.
  4962	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4963	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, he was, he said, in Wisdom Hely’s. A traveller for blottingpaper.
  4964	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4965	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—In God’s name, John Henry Menton said, what did she marry a coon like
  4966	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat for? She had plenty of game in her then.
  4967	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4968	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Has still, Ned Lambert said. He does some canvassing for ads.
  4969	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4970	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJohn Henry Menton’s large eyes stared ahead.
  4971	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4972	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe barrow turned into a side lane. A portly man, ambushed among the
  4973	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgrasses, raised his hat in homage. The gravediggers touched their caps.
  4974	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4975	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—John O’Connell, Mr Power said pleased. He never forgets a friend.
  4976	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4977	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr O’Connell shook all their hands in silence. Mr Dedalus said:
  4978	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4979	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I am come to pay you another visit.
  4980	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4981	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—My dear Simon, the caretaker answered in a low voice. I don’t want your
  4982	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcustom at all.
  4983	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  4985	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCunningham’s side puzzling two long keys at his back.
  4986	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4987	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Did you hear that one, he asked them, about Mulcahy from the Coombe?
  4988	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4989	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I did not, Martin Cunningham said.
  4990	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4991	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey bent their silk hats in concert and Hynes inclined his ear. The
  4992	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcaretaker hung his thumbs in the loops of his gold watchchain and spoke
  4993	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin a discreet tone to their vacant smiles.
  4994	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  4995	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—They tell the story, he said, that two drunks came out here one foggy
  4996	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tevening to look for the grave of a friend of theirs. They asked for
  4997	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMulcahy from the Coombe and were told where he was buried. After
  4998	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttraipsing about in the fog they found the grave sure enough. One of the
  4999	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrunks spelt out the name: Terence Mulcahy. The other drunk was blinking
  5000	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tup at a statue of Our Saviour the widow had got put up.
  5001	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5002	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe caretaker blinked up at one of the sepulchres they passed. He
  5003	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tresumed:
  5004	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5005	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And, after blinking up at the sacred figure, Not a bloody bit like the
  5006	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tman, says he. That’s not Mulcahy, says he, whoever done it.
  5007	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5008	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRewarded by smiles he fell back and spoke with Corny Kelleher, accepting
  5009	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe dockets given him, turning them over and scanning them as he walked.
  5010	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5011	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That’s all done with a purpose, Martin Cunningham explained to Hynes.
  5012	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5013	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I know, Hynes said. I know that.
  5014	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5015	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—To cheer a fellow up, Martin Cunningham said. It’s pure
  5016	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgoodheartedness: damn the thing else.
  5017	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5018	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Bloom admired the caretaker’s prosperous bulk. All want to be on good
  5019	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tterms with him. Decent fellow, John O’Connell, real good sort. Keys:
  5020	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlike Keyes’s ad: no fear of anyone getting out. No passout checks.
  5021	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHabeas corpus. I must see about that ad after the funeral. Did I write
  5022	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBallsbridge on the envelope I took to cover when she disturbed me
  5023	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twriting to Martha? Hope it’s not chucked in the dead letter office. Be
  5024	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe better of a shave. Grey sprouting beard. That’s the first sign when
  5025	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe hairs come out grey. And temper getting cross. Silver threads among
  5026	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe grey. Fancy being his wife. Wonder he had the gumption to propose to
  5027	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tany girl. Come out and live in the graveyard. Dangle that before her.
  5028	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIt might thrill her first. Courting death. Shades of night hovering
  5029	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\there with all the dead stretched about. The shadows of the tombs when
  5030	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchurchyards yawn and Daniel O’Connell must be a descendant I suppose
  5031	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twho is this used to say he was a queer breedy man great catholic all the
  5032	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsame like a big giant in the dark. Will o’ the wisp. Gas of graves.
  5033	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWant to keep her mind off it to conceive at all. Women especially are so
  5034	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttouchy. Tell her a ghost story in bed to make her sleep. Have you ever
  5035	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseen a ghost? Well, I have. It was a pitchdark night. The clock was on
  5036	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe stroke of twelve. Still they’d kiss all right if properly keyed up.
  5037	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhores in Turkish graveyards. Learn anything if taken young. You might
  5038	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpick up a young widow here. Men like that. Love among the tombstones.
  5039	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRomeo. Spice of pleasure. In the midst of death we are in life. Both
  5040	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tends meet. Tantalising for the poor dead. Smell of grilled beefsteaks to
  5041	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe starving. Gnawing their vitals. Desire to grig people. Molly wanting
  5042	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto do it at the window. Eight children he has anyway.
  5043	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5044	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe has seen a fair share go under in his time, lying around him field
  5045	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tafter field. Holy fields. More room if they buried them standing.
  5046	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSitting or kneeling you couldn’t. Standing? His head might come up some
  5047	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tday above ground in a landslip with his hand pointing. All honeycombed
  5048	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe ground must be: oblong cells. And very neat he keeps it too: trim
  5049	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgrass and edgings. His garden Major Gamble calls Mount Jerome. Well,
  5050	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tso it is. Ought to be flowers of sleep. Chinese cemeteries with giant
  5051	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoppies growing produce the best opium Mastiansky told me. The Botanic
  5052	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGardens are just over there. It’s the blood sinking in the earth gives
  5053	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnew life. Same idea those jews they said killed the christian boy. Every
  5054	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tman his price. Well preserved fat corpse, gentleman, epicure, invaluable
  5055	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor fruit garden. A bargain. By carcass of William Wilkinson, auditor
  5056	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand accountant, lately deceased, three pounds thirteen and six. With
  5057	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthanks.
  5058	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5059	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI daresay the soil would be quite fat with corpsemanure, bones, flesh,
  5060	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnails. Charnelhouses. Dreadful. Turning green and pink decomposing. Rot
  5061	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquick in damp earth. The lean old ones tougher. Then a kind of a tallowy
  5062	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tkind of a cheesy. Then begin to get black, black treacle oozing out of
  5063	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem. Then dried up. Deathmoths. Of course the cells or whatever they
  5064	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tare go on living. Changing about. Live for ever practically. Nothing to
  5065	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfeed on feed on themselves.
  5066	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5067	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBut they must breed a devil of a lot of maggots. Soil must be simply
  5068	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tswirling with them. Your head it simply swurls. Those pretty little
  5069	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseaside gurls. He looks cheerful enough over it. Gives him a sense of
  5070	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpower seeing all the others go under first. Wonder how he looks at life.
  5071	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCracking his jokes too: warms the cockles of his heart. The one about
  5072	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe bulletin. Spurgeon went to heaven 4 a.m. this morning. 11 p.m.
  5073	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(closing time). Not arrived yet. Peter. The dead themselves the men
  5074	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanyhow would like to hear an odd joke or the women to know what’s in
  5075	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfashion. A juicy pear or ladies’ punch, hot, strong and sweet. Keep
  5076	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tout the damp. You must laugh sometimes so better do it that way.
  5077	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGravediggers in Hamlet. Shows the profound knowledge of the human heart.
  5078	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDaren’t joke about the dead for two years at least. De mortuis nil nisi
  5079	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprius. Go out of mourning first. Hard to imagine his funeral. Seems a
  5080	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsort of a joke. Read your own obituary notice they say you live longer.
  5081	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGives you second wind. New lease of life.
  5082	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5083	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—How many have you for tomorrow? the caretaker asked.
  5084	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5085	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Two, Corny Kelleher said. Half ten and eleven.
  5086	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5087	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe caretaker put the papers in his pocket. The barrow had ceased to
  5088	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttrundle. The mourners split and moved to each side of the hole, stepping
  5089	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith care round the graves. The gravediggers bore the coffin and set its
  5090	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnose on the brink, looping the bands round it.
  5091	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5092	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBurying him. We come to bury Cæsar. His ides of March or June. He
  5093	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoesn’t know who is here nor care. Now who is that lankylooking galoot
  5094	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tover there in the macintosh? Now who is he I’d like to know? Now I’d
  5095	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgive a trifle to know who he is. Always someone turns up you never
  5096	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdreamt of. A fellow could live on his lonesome all his life. Yes, he
  5097	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcould. Still he’d have to get someone to sod him after he died though he
  5098	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcould dig his own grave. We all do. Only man buries. No, ants too. First
  5099	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthing strikes anybody. Bury the dead. Say Robinson Crusoe was true to
  5100	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlife. Well then Friday buried him. Every Friday buries a Thursday if you
  5101	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcome to look at it.
  5102	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5103	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     O, poor Robinson Crusoe!
  5104	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     How could you possibly do so?
  5105	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5106	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPoor Dignam! His last lie on the earth in his box. When you think of
  5107	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem all it does seem a waste of wood. All gnawed through. They could
  5108	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinvent a handsome bier with a kind of panel sliding, let it down that
  5109	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tway. Ay but they might object to be buried out of another fellow’s.
  5110	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey’re so particular. Lay me in my native earth. Bit of clay from
  5111	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe holy land. Only a mother and deadborn child ever buried in the one
  5112	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcoffin. I see what it means. I see. To protect him as long as possible
  5113	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teven in the earth. The Irishman’s house is his coffin. Embalming in
  5114	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcatacombs, mummies the same idea.
  5115	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5116	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Bloom stood far back, his hat in his hand, counting the bared heads.
  5117	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTwelve. I’m thirteen. No. The chap in the macintosh is thirteen. Death’s
  5118	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnumber. Where the deuce did he pop out of? He wasn’t in the chapel, that
  5119	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI’ll swear. Silly superstition that about thirteen.
  5120	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5121	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNice soft tweed Ned Lambert has in that suit. Tinge of purple. I had
  5122	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tone like that when we lived in Lombard street west. Dressy fellow he was
  5123	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tonce. Used to change three suits in the day. Must get that grey suit
  5124	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof mine turned by Mesias. Hello. It’s dyed. His wife I forgot he’s not
  5125	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmarried or his landlady ought to have picked out those threads for him.
  5126	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5127	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe coffin dived out of sight, eased down by the men straddled on the
  5128	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgravetrestles. They struggled up and out: and all uncovered. Twenty.
  5129	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5130	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPause.
  5131	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5132	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIf we were all suddenly somebody else.
  5133	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5134	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFar away a donkey brayed. Rain. No such ass. Never see a dead one, they
  5135	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsay. Shame of death. They hide. Also poor papa went away.
  5136	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5137	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGentle sweet air blew round the bared heads in a whisper. Whisper. The
  5138	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tboy by the gravehead held his wreath with both hands staring quietly in
  5139	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe black open space. Mr Bloom moved behind the portly kindly caretaker.
  5140	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWellcut frockcoat. Weighing them up perhaps to see which will go next.
  5141	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWell, it is a long rest. Feel no more. It’s the moment you feel. Must be
  5142	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdamned unpleasant. Can’t believe it at first. Mistake must be: someone
  5143	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\telse. Try the house opposite. Wait, I wanted to. I haven’t yet. Then
  5144	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdarkened deathchamber. Light they want. Whispering around you. Would you
  5145	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlike to see a priest? Then rambling and wandering. Delirium all you hid
  5146	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall your life. The death struggle. His sleep is not natural. Press his
  5147	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlower eyelid. Watching is his nose pointed is his jaw sinking are the
  5148	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsoles of his feet yellow. Pull the pillow away and finish it off on the
  5149	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfloor since he’s doomed. Devil in that picture of sinner’s death showing
  5150	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim a woman. Dying to embrace her in his shirt. Last act of Lucia. Shall
  5151	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI nevermore behold thee? Bam! He expires. Gone at last. People talk
  5152	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabout you a bit: forget you. Don’t forget to pray for him. Remember
  5153	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim in your prayers. Even Parnell. Ivy day dying out. Then they follow:
  5154	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdropping into a hole, one after the other.
  5155	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5156	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWe are praying now for the repose of his soul. Hoping you’re well and
  5157	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnot in hell. Nice change of air. Out of the fryingpan of life into the
  5158	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfire of purgatory.
  5159	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5160	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDoes he ever think of the hole waiting for himself? They say you do when
  5161	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou shiver in the sun. Someone walking over it. Callboy’s warning. Near
  5162	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou. Mine over there towards Finglas, the plot I bought. Mamma, poor
  5163	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmamma, and little Rudy.
  5164	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5165	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe gravediggers took up their spades and flung heavy clods of clay in
  5166	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton the coffin. Mr Bloom turned away his face. And if he was alive all
  5167	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe time? Whew! By jingo, that would be awful! No, no: he is dead, of
  5168	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcourse. Of course he is dead. Monday he died. They ought to have
  5169	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsome law to pierce the heart and make sure or an electric clock or
  5170	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta telephone in the coffin and some kind of a canvas airhole. Flag of
  5171	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdistress. Three days. Rather long to keep them in summer. Just as well
  5172	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto get shut of them as soon as you are sure there’s no.
  5173	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5174	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe clay fell softer. Begin to be forgotten. Out of sight, out of mind.
  5175	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5176	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe caretaker moved away a few paces and put on his hat. Had enough of
  5177	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit. The mourners took heart of grace, one by one, covering themselves
  5178	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twithout show. Mr Bloom put on his hat and saw the portly figure make its
  5179	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tway deftly through the maze of graves. Quietly, sure of his ground, he
  5180	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttraversed the dismal fields.
  5181	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5182	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHynes jotting down something in his notebook. Ah, the names. But he
  5183	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknows them all. No: coming to me.
  5184	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5185	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I am just taking the names, Hynes said below his breath. What is your
  5186	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchristian name? I’m not sure.
  5187	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5188	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—L, Mr Bloom said. Leopold. And you might put down M’Coy’s name too. He
  5189	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tasked me to.
  5190	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5191	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Charley, Hynes said writing. I know. He was on the Freeman once.
  5192	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5193	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo he was before he got the job in the morgue under Louis Byrne. Good
  5194	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tidea a postmortem for doctors. Find out what they imagine they know.
  5195	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe died of a Tuesday. Got the run. Levanted with the cash of a few ads.
  5196	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCharley, you’re my darling. That was why he asked me to. O well, does
  5197	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tno harm. I saw to that, M’Coy. Thanks, old chap: much obliged. Leave him
  5198	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunder an obligation: costs nothing.
  5199	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  5213	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  5215	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe. Has anybody here seen? Kay ee double ell. Become invisible. Good
  5216	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLord, what became of him?
  5217	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5218	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA seventh gravedigger came beside Mr Bloom to take up an idle spade.
  5219	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5220	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, excuse me!
  5221	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5222	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe stepped aside nimbly.
  5223	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5224	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tClay, brown, damp, began to be seen in the hole. It rose. Nearly over.
  5225	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA mound of damp clods rose more, rose, and the gravediggers rested their
  5226	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspades. All uncovered again for a few instants. The boy propped
  5227	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this wreath against a corner: the brother-in-law his on a lump. The
  5228	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgravediggers put on their caps and carried their earthy spades towards
  5229	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe barrow. Then knocked the blades lightly on the turf: clean. One bent
  5230	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto pluck from the haft a long tuft of grass. One, leaving his mates,
  5231	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twalked slowly on with shouldered weapon, its blade blueglancing.
  5232	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSilently at the gravehead another coiled the coffinband. His navelcord.
  5233	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe brother-in-law, turning away, placed something in his free hand.
  5234	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThanks in silence. Sorry, sir: trouble. Headshake. I know that. For
  5235	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyourselves just.
  5236	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5237	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe mourners moved away slowly without aim, by devious paths, staying at
  5238	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhiles to read a name on a tomb.
  5239	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5240	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Let us go round by the chief’s grave, Hynes said. We have time.
  5241	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5242	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Let us, Mr Power said.
  5243	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5244	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey turned to the right, following their slow thoughts. With awe Mr
  5245	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPower’s blank voice spoke:
  5246	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5247	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Some say he is not in that grave at all. That the coffin was filled
  5248	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith stones. That one day he will come again.
  5249	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5250	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHynes shook his head.
  5251	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5252	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Parnell will never come again, he said. He’s there, all that was mortal
  5253	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof him. Peace to his ashes.
  5254	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5255	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Bloom walked unheeded along his grove by saddened angels, crosses,
  5256	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbroken pillars, family vaults, stone hopes praying with upcast eyes,
  5257	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\told Ireland’s hearts and hands. More sensible to spend the money on some
  5258	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcharity for the living. Pray for the repose of the soul of. Does anybody
  5259	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treally? Plant him and have done with him. Like down a coalshoot. Then
  5260	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlump them together to save time. All souls’ day. Twentyseventh I’ll be
  5261	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat his grave. Ten shillings for the gardener. He keeps it free of weeds.
  5262	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOld man himself. Bent down double with his shears clipping. Near death’s
  5263	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoor. Who passed away. Who departed this life. As if they did it of
  5264	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir own accord. Got the shove, all of them. Who kicked the
  5265	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbucket. More interesting if they told you what they were. So and So,
  5266	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twheelwright. I travelled for cork lino. I paid five shillings in the
  5267	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpound. Or a woman’s with her saucepan. I cooked good Irish stew.
  5268	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEulogy in a country churchyard it ought to be that poem of whose is it
  5269	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWordsworth or Thomas Campbell. Entered into rest the protestants put it.
  5270	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOld Dr Murren’s. The great physician called him home. Well it’s God’s
  5271	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tacre for them. Nice country residence. Newly plastered and painted.
  5272	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIdeal spot to have a quiet smoke and read the Church Times. Marriage
  5273	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tads they never try to beautify. Rusty wreaths hung on knobs, garlands of
  5274	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbronzefoil. Better value that for the money. Still, the flowers are more
  5275	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoetical. The other gets rather tiresome, never withering. Expresses
  5276	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnothing. Immortelles.
  5277	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5278	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA bird sat tamely perched on a poplar branch. Like stuffed. Like the
  5279	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twedding present alderman Hooper gave us. Hoo! Not a budge out of him.
  5280	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKnows there are no catapults to let fly at him. Dead animal even sadder.
  5281	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSilly-Milly burying the little dead bird in the kitchen matchbox, a
  5282	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdaisychain and bits of broken chainies on the grave.
  5283	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5284	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe Sacred Heart that is: showing it. Heart on his sleeve. Ought to be
  5285	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsideways and red it should be painted like a real heart. Ireland was
  5286	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdedicated to it or whatever that. Seems anything but pleased. Why this
  5287	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinfliction? Would birds come then and peck like the boy with the basket
  5288	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof fruit but he said no because they ought to have been afraid of the
  5289	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tboy. Apollo that was.
  5290	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5291	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHow many! All these here once walked round Dublin. Faithful departed. As
  5292	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou are now so once were we.
  5293	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5294	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBesides how could you remember everybody? Eyes, walk, voice. Well, the
  5295	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvoice, yes: gramophone. Have a gramophone in every grave or keep it in
  5296	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe house. After dinner on a Sunday. Put on poor old greatgrandfather.
  5297	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKraahraark! Hellohellohello amawfullyglad kraark awfullygladaseeagain
  5298	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thellohello amawf krpthsth. Remind you of the voice like the photograph
  5299	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treminds you of the face. Otherwise you couldn’t remember the face after
  5300	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfifteen years, say. For instance who? For instance some fellow that died
  5301	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhen I was in Wisdom Hely’s.
  5302	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5303	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRtststr! A rattle of pebbles. Wait. Stop!
  5304	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5305	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe looked down intently into a stone crypt. Some animal. Wait. There he
  5306	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgoes.
  5307	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5308	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAn obese grey rat toddled along the side of the crypt, moving the
  5309	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpebbles. An old stager: greatgrandfather: he knows the ropes. The grey
  5310	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\talive crushed itself in under the plinth, wriggled itself in under it.
  5311	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGood hidingplace for treasure.
  5312	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5313	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWho lives there? Are laid the remains of Robert Emery. Robert Emmet was
  5314	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tburied here by torchlight, wasn’t he? Making his rounds.
  5315	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5316	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTail gone now.
  5317	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5318	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOne of those chaps would make short work of a fellow. Pick the bones
  5319	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tclean no matter who it was. Ordinary meat for them. A corpse is meat
  5320	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgone bad. Well and what’s cheese? Corpse of milk. I read in that
  5321	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tVoyages in China that the Chinese say a white man smells like a corpse.
  5322	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCremation better. Priests dead against it. Devilling for the other firm.
  5323	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWholesale burners and Dutch oven dealers. Time of the plague. Quicklime
  5324	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfeverpits to eat them. Lethal chamber. Ashes to ashes. Or bury at sea.
  5325	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhere is that Parsee tower of silence? Eaten by birds. Earth, fire,
  5326	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twater. Drowning they say is the pleasantest. See your whole life in a
  5327	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tflash. But being brought back to life no. Can’t bury in the air however.
  5328	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOut of a flying machine. Wonder does the news go about whenever a fresh
  5329	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tone is let down. Underground communication. We learned that from them.
  5330	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWouldn’t be surprised. Regular square feed for them. Flies come before
  5331	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the’s well dead. Got wind of Dignam. They wouldn’t care about the smell
  5332	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof it. Saltwhite crumbling mush of corpse: smell, taste like raw white
  5333	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tturnips.
  5334	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5335	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe gates glimmered in front: still open. Back to the world again.
  5336	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEnough of this place. Brings you a bit nearer every time. Last time I
  5337	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas here was Mrs Sinico’s funeral. Poor papa too. The love that kills.
  5338	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd even scraping up the earth at night with a lantern like that case
  5339	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI read of to get at fresh buried females or even putrefied with running
  5340	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgravesores. Give you the creeps after a bit. I will appear to you after
  5341	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeath. You will see my ghost after death. My ghost will haunt you after
  5342	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeath. There is another world after death named hell. I do not like that
  5343	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tother world she wrote. No more do I. Plenty to see and hear and feel
  5344	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyet. Feel live warm beings near you. Let them sleep in their maggoty
  5345	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeds. They are not going to get me this innings. Warm beds: warm
  5346	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfullblooded life.
  5347	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5348	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMartin Cunningham emerged from a sidepath, talking gravely.
  5349	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5350	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSolicitor, I think. I know his face. Menton, John Henry, solicitor,
  5351	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcommissioner for oaths and affidavits. Dignam used to be in his office.
  5352	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMat Dillon’s long ago. Jolly Mat. Convivial evenings. Cold fowl, cigars,
  5353	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe Tantalus glasses. Heart of gold really. Yes, Menton. Got his rag out
  5354	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat evening on the bowlinggreen because I sailed inside him. Pure fluke
  5355	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof mine: the bias. Why he took such a rooted dislike to me. Hate
  5356	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat first sight. Molly and Floey Dillon linked under the lilactree,
  5357	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlaughing. Fellow always like that, mortified if women are by.
  5358	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5359	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGot a dinge in the side of his hat. Carriage probably.
  5360	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  5383	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcould wind a sappyhead like that round his little finger, without his

  5500	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNannetti’s reading closet. WITH UNFEIGNED REGRET IT IS WE ANNOUNCE THE

  5505	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto atoms if they got him caught. Rule the world today. His machineries
  5506	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tare pegging away too. Like these, got out of hand: fermenting. Working
  5507	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taway, tearing away. And that old grey rat tearing to get in. HOW A GREAT
  5508	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDAILY ORGAN IS TURNED OUT

  5511	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcrown.
  5512	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5513	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStrange he never saw his real country. Ireland my country. Member for
  5514	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCollege green. He boomed that workaday worker tack for all it was worth.
  5515	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIt’s the ads and side features sell a weekly, not the stale news in the
  5516	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tofficial gazette. Queen Anne is dead. Published by authority in the year
  5517	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tone thousand and. Demesne situate in the townland of Rosenallis, barony
  5518	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof Tinnahinch. To all whom it may concern schedule pursuant to statute
  5519	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshowing return of number of mules and jennets exported from Ballina.
  5520	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNature notes. Cartoons. Phil Blake’s weekly Pat and Bull story. Uncle
  5521	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tToby’s page for tiny tots. Country bumpkin’s queries. Dear Mr Editor,
  5522	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhat is a good cure for flatulence? I’d like that part. Learn a lot
  5523	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tteaching others. The personal note. M. A. P. Mainly all pictures.
  5524	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShapely bathers on golden strand. World’s biggest balloon. Double
  5525	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmarriage of sisters celebrated. Two bridegrooms laughing heartily at
  5526	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teach other. Cuprani too, printer. More Irish than the Irish.
  5527	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  5528	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe machines clanked in threefour time. Thump, thump, thump. Now if he
  5529	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgot paralysed there and no-one knew how to stop them they’d clank on and
  5530	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton the same, print it over and over and up and back. Monkeydoodle the
  5531	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhole thing. Want a cool head.
