  8179	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  8180	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, it’s a fine order, Nosey Flynn said. They stick to you when you’re
  8181	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdown. I know a fellow was trying to get into it. But they’re as close as
  8182	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdamn it. By God they did right to keep the women out of it.
  8183	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  8184	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDavy Byrne smiledyawnednodded all in one:
  8185	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  8186	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Iiiiiichaaaaaaach!
  8187	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  8189	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tout what they do be doing. But be damned but they smelt her out and
  8190	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tswore her in on the spot a master mason. That was one of the saint
  8191	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLegers of Doneraile.
  8192	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  8194	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  8196	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI never once saw him—you know, over the line.
  8197	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  8199	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toff when the fun gets too hot. Didn’t you see him look at his watch? Ah,
  8200	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou weren’t there. If you ask him to have a drink first thing he does
  8201	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the outs with the watch to see what he ought to imbibe. Declare to God he
  8202	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoes.

  8401	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDublin he must have, tapping his way round by the stones. Could he walk
  8402	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin a beeline if he hadn’t that cane? Bloodless pious face like a fellow
  8403	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgoing in to be a priest.

  8407	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLook at all the things they can learn to do. Read with their fingers.
  8408	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTune pianos. Or we are surprised they have any brains. Why we think a
  8409	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeformed person or a hunchback clever if he says something we might say.
  8410	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOf course the other senses are more. Embroider. Plait baskets. People
  8411	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tought to help. Workbasket I could buy for Molly’s birthday. Hates
  8412	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsewing. Might take an objection. Dark men they call them.
  8413	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  8414	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSense of smell must be stronger too. Smells on all sides, bunched
  8415	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttogether. Each street different smell. Each person too. Then the spring,
  8416	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe summer: smells. Tastes? They say you can’t taste wines with your
  8417	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teyes shut or a cold in the head. Also smoke in the dark they say get no
  8418	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpleasure.

  8457	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta magnum. Tales of the bench and assizes and annals of the bluecoat
  8458	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tschool. I sentenced him to ten years. I suppose he’d turn up his nose
  8459	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat that stuff I drank. Vintage wine for them, the year marked on a
  8460	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdusty bottle. Has his own ideas of justice in the recorder’s court.
  8461	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWellmeaning old man. Police chargesheets crammed with cases get their
  8462	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpercentage manufacturing crime. Sends them to the rightabout. The devil
  8463	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton moneylenders. Gave Reuben J a great strawcalling. Now he’s really
  8464	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhat they call a dirty jew. Power those judges have. Crusty old topers
  8465	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin wigs. Bear with a sore paw. And may the Lord have mercy on your soul.

  8478	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe right.

  8480	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIs it? Almost certain. Won’t look. Wine in my face. Why did I? Too
  8481	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theady. Yes, it is. The walk. Not see. Get on.
  8482	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  8484	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHandsome building. Sir Thomas Deane designed. Not following me?
  8485	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  8486	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDidn’t see me perhaps. Light in his eyes.
  8487	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  8489	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstatues: quiet there. Safe in a minute.
  8490	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  8491	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNo. Didn’t see me. After two. Just at the gate.

  8591	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshadow. I mean, whether Hamlet is Shakespeare or James I or Essex.
  8592	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tClergymen’s discussions of the historicity of Jesus. Art has to reveal
  8593	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto us ideas, formless spiritual essences. The supreme question about a
  8594	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twork of art is out of how deep a life does it spring. The painting of
  8595	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGustave Moreau is the painting of ideas. The deepest poetry of Shelley,
  8596	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe words of Hamlet bring our minds into contact with the eternal
  8597	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twisdom, Plato’s world of ideas. All the rest is the speculation of
  8598	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tschoolboys for schoolboys.

  8733	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What is a ghost? Stephen said with tingling energy. One who has faded

  8735	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmanners. Elizabethan London lay as far from Stratford as corrupt Paris
  8736	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlies from virgin Dublin. Who is the ghost from limbo patrum, returning
  8737	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto the world that has forgotten him? Who is King Hamlet?

  8740	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  8744	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tswift glance their hearing. The flag is up on the playhouse by the
  8745	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbankside. The bear Sackerson growls in the pit near it, Paris garden.
  8746	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCanvasclimbers who sailed with Drake chew their sausages among the

  8751	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Shakespeare has left the huguenot’s house in Silver street and walks by
  8752	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe swanmews along the riverbank. But he does not stay to feed the pen
  8753	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchivying her game of cygnets towards the rushes. The swan of Avon has
  8754	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tother thoughts.
  8755	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  8756	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tComposition of place. Ignatius Loyola, make haste to help me!
  8757	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  8758	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The play begins. A player comes on under the shadow, made up in the
  8759	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcastoff mail of a court buck, a wellset man with a bass voice. It is the
  8760	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tghost, the king, a king and no king, and the player is Shakespeare who
  8761	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thas studied Hamlet all the years of his life which were not vanity in
  8762	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\torder to play the part of the spectre. He speaks the words to Burbage,
  8763	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe young player who stands before him beyond the rack of cerecloth,
  8764	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcalling him by a name:
  8765	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  8766	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHamlet, I am thy father’s spirit,
  8767	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  8768	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbidding him list. To a son he speaks, the son of his soul, the prince,
  8769	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyoung Hamlet and to the son of his body, Hamnet Shakespeare, who has
  8770	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdied in Stratford that his namesake may live for ever.
  8771	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  8772	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIs it possible that that player Shakespeare, a ghost by absence, and in
  8773	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe vesture of buried Denmark, a ghost by death, speaking his own words
  8774	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto his own son’s name (had Hamnet Shakespeare lived he would have been
  8775	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprince Hamlet’s twin), is it possible, I want to know, or probable that
  8776	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the did not draw or foresee the logical conclusion of those premises: you
  8777	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tare the dispossessed son: I am the murdered father: your mother is the
  8778	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tguilty queen, Ann Shakespeare, born Hathaway?
  8779	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  8780	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—But this prying into the family life of a great man, Russell began
  8781	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\timpatiently.
  8782	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  8783	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tArt thou there, truepenny?
  8784	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  8785	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Interesting only to the parish clerk. I mean, we have the plays. I
  8786	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmean when we read the poetry of King Lear what is it to us how the poet
  8787	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlived? As for living our servants can do that for us, Villiers de l’Isle
  8788	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thas said. Peeping and prying into greenroom gossip of the day, the
  8789	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoet’s drinking, the poet’s debts. We have King Lear: and it is
  8790	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\timmortal.

  8869	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSocratididion’s Epipsychidion, no man, not a woman, will ever know. But

  8882	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe girl I left behind me. If the earthquake did not time it we should

  8890	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof men. But his boywomen are the women of a boy. Their life, thought,

  9011	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the won to him, tender people, a whore of Babylon, ladies of justices,

  9028	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe possible as possible: things not known: what name Achilles bore when
  9029	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the lived among women.
  9030	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9031	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCoffined thoughts around me, in mummycases, embalmed in spice of words.
  9032	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThoth, god of libraries, a birdgod, moonycrowned. And I heard the voice
  9033	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof that Egyptian highpriest. In painted chambers loaded with tilebooks.
  9034	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9035	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey are still. Once quick in the brains of men. Still: but an itch of
  9036	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeath is in them, to tell me in my ear a maudlin tale, urge me to wreak
  9037	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir will.

  9041	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmuch. Others abide our question. A shadow hangs over all the rest.

  9045	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta button, don’t you know, who is killed or who is guilty...

  9049	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin mo shagart. Put beurla on it, littlejohn.

  9052	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9053	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I was prepared for paradoxes from what Malachi Mulligan told us but

  9056	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  9060	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twrinkled brows. A basilisk. E quando vede l’uomo l’attosca. Messer
  9061	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBrunetto, I thank thee for the word.
  9062	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9063	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—As we, or mother Dana, weave and unweave our bodies, Stephen said,
  9064	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom day to day, their molecules shuttled to and fro, so does the artist
  9065	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tweave and unweave his image. And as the mole on my right breast is where
  9066	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit was when I was born, though all my body has been woven of new stuff
  9067	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttime after time, so through the ghost of the unquiet father the image
  9068	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the unliving son looks forth. In the intense instant of imagination,
  9069	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhen the mind, Shelley says, is a fading coal, that which I was is that
  9070	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhich I am and that which in possibility I may come to be. So in the
  9071	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfuture, the sister of the past, I may see myself as I sit here now but
  9072	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby reflection from that which then I shall be.
  9073	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9074	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDrummond of Hawthornden helped you at that stile.
  9075	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9076	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, Mr Best said youngly. I feel Hamlet quite young. The bitterness
  9077	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmight be from the father but the passages with Ophelia are surely from
  9078	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe son.
  9079	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9080	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHas the wrong sow by the lug. He is in my father. I am in his son.
  9081	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9082	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That mole is the last to go, Stephen said, laughing.
  9083	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9084	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJohn Eglinton made a nothing pleasing mow.
  9085	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9086	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—If that were the birthmark of genius, he said, genius would be a
  9087	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrug in the market. The plays of Shakespeare’s later years which Renan
  9088	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tadmired so much breathe another spirit.
  9089	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9090	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The spirit of reconciliation, the quaker librarian breathed.
  9091	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9092	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—There can be no reconciliation, Stephen said, if there has not been a
  9093	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsundering.
  9094	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9095	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSaid that.
  9096	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9097	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—If you want to know what are the events which cast their shadow over
  9098	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe hell of time of King Lear, Othello, Hamlet, Troilus and Cressida,
  9099	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlook to see when and how the shadow lifts. What softens the heart of a
  9100	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tman, shipwrecked in storms dire, Tried, like another Ulysses, Pericles,
  9101	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprince of Tyre?
  9102	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9103	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHead, redconecapped, buffeted, brineblinded.
  9104	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9105	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A child, a girl, placed in his arms, Marina.
  9106	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9107	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The leaning of sophists towards the bypaths of apocrypha is a constant
  9108	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquantity, John Eglinton detected. The highroads are dreary but they lead
  9109	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto the town.
  9110	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9111	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGood Bacon: gone musty. Shakespeare Bacon’s wild oats. Cypherjugglers
  9112	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgoing the highroads. Seekers on the great quest. What town, good
  9113	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmasters? Mummed in names: A. E., eon: Magee, John Eglinton. East of the
  9114	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsun, west of the moon: Tir na n-og. Booted the twain and staved.
  9115	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9116	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      How many miles to Dublin?
  9117	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      Three score and ten, sir.
  9118	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      Will we be there by candlelight?

  9121	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tperiod.

  9127	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat which was lost. What was lost is given back to him: his daughter’s
  9128	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchild. My dearest wife, Pericles says, was like this maid. Will any man
  9129	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlove the daughter if he has not loved the mother?

  9141	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—His own image to a man with that queer thing genius is the standard of
  9142	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall experience, material and moral. Such an appeal will touch him. The
  9143	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\timages of other males of his blood will repel him. He will see in them
  9144	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgrotesque attempts of nature to foretell or to repeat himself.
  9145	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9146	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe benign forehead of the quaker librarian enkindled rosily with hope.
  9147	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9148	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I hope Mr Dedalus will work out his theory for the enlightenment of
  9149	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe public. And we ought to mention another Irish commentator, Mr George
  9150	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBernard Shaw. Nor should we forget Mr Frank Harris. His articles on
  9151	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShakespeare in the Saturday Review were surely brilliant. Oddly enough
  9152	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the too draws for us an unhappy relation with the dark lady of the
  9153	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsonnets. The favoured rival is William Herbert, earl of Pembroke. I own
  9154	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat if the poet must be rejected such a rejection would seem more in
  9155	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tharmony with—what shall I say?—our notions of what ought not to have
  9156	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeen.

  9162	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlove thy man?
  9163	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9164	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That may be too, Stephen said. There’s a saying of Goethe’s which Mr
  9165	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMagee likes to quote. Beware of what you wish for in youth because you
  9166	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twill get it in middle life. Why does he send to one who is a buonaroba,
  9167	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta bay where all men ride, a maid of honour with a scandalous girlhood, a
  9168	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlordling to woo for him? He was himself a lord of language and had made
  9169	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thimself a coistrel gentleman and he had written Romeo and Juliet.
  9170	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhy? Belief in himself has been untimely killed. He was overborne in a
  9171	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcornfield first (ryefield, I should say) and he will never be a victor
  9172	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin his own eyes after nor play victoriously the game of laugh and lie
  9173	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdown. Assumed dongiovannism will not save him. No later undoing will
  9174	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tundo the first undoing. The tusk of the boar has wounded him there where
  9175	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlove lies ableeding. If the shrew is worsted yet there remains to her
  9176	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twoman’s invisible weapon. There is, I feel in the words, some goad of
  9177	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe flesh driving him into a new passion, a darker shadow of the first,
  9178	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdarkening even his own understanding of himself. A like fate awaits him
  9179	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand the two rages commingle in a whirlpool.
  9180	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9181	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey list. And in the porches of their ears I pour.
  9182	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9183	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The soul has been before stricken mortally, a poison poured in the
  9184	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tporch of a sleeping ear. But those who are done to death in sleep cannot
  9185	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknow the manner of their quell unless their Creator endow their souls
  9186	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith that knowledge in the life to come. The poisoning and the beast
  9187	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith two backs that urged it King Hamlet’s ghost could not know of were
  9188	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the not endowed with knowledge by his creator. That is why the speech
  9189	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(his lean unlovely English) is always turned elsewhere, backward.
  9190	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRavisher and ravished, what he would but would not, go with him from
  9191	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLucrece’s bluecircled ivory globes to Imogen’s breast, bare, with its
  9192	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmole cinquespotted. He goes back, weary of the creation he has piled up
  9193	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto hide him from himself, an old dog licking an old sore. But, because
  9194	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tloss is his gain, he passes on towards eternity in undiminished
  9195	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpersonality, untaught by the wisdom he has written or by the laws he
  9196	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thas revealed. His beaver is up. He is a ghost, a shadow now, the wind by
  9197	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tElsinore’s rocks or what you will, the sea’s voice, a voice heard
  9198	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tonly in the heart of him who is the substance of his shadow, the son
  9199	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconsubstantial with the father.

  9222	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcrosstree, Who let Him bury, stood up, harrowed hell, fared into heaven

  9224	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOwn Self but yet shall come in the latter day to doom the quick and dead

  9380	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdark figure following his hasty heels.
  9381	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9382	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe door closed.
  9383	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9384	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The sheeny! Buck Mulligan cried.
  9385	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9386	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe jumped up and snatched the card.
  9387	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9388	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What’s his name? Ikey Moses? Bloom.
  9389	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9390	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe rattled on:
  9391	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9392	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Jehovah, collector of prepuces, is no more. I found him over in the
  9393	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmuseum where I went to hail the foamborn Aphrodite. The Greek mouth that
  9394	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thas never been twisted in prayer. Every day we must do homage to her.
  9395	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLife of life, thy lips enkindle.
  9396	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9397	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSuddenly he turned to Stephen:
  9398	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9399	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He knows you. He knows your old fellow. O, I fear me, he is Greeker
  9400	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthan the Greeks. His pale Galilean eyes were upon her mesial groove.
  9401	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tVenus Kallipyge. O, the thunder of those loins! The god pursuing the
  9402	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmaiden hid.
  9403	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9404	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—We want to hear more, John Eglinton decided with Mr Best’s approval. We
  9405	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbegin to be interested in Mrs S. Till now we had thought of her, if at
  9406	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall, as a patient Griselda, a Penelope stayathome.
  9407	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9408	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Antisthenes, pupil of Gorgias, Stephen said, took the palm of beauty
  9409	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom Kyrios Menelaus’ brooddam, Argive Helen, the wooden mare of Troy
  9410	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin whom a score of heroes slept, and handed it to poor Penelope. Twenty
  9411	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyears he lived in London and, during part of that time, he drew a salary
  9412	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tequal to that of the lord chancellor of Ireland. His life was rich. His
  9413	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tart, more than the art of feudalism as Walt Whitman called it, is the
  9414	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tart of surfeit. Hot herringpies, green mugs of sack, honeysauces, sugar
  9415	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof roses, marchpane, gooseberried pigeons, ringocandies. Sir Walter
  9416	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRaleigh, when they arrested him, had half a million francs on his
  9417	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tback including a pair of fancy stays. The gombeenwoman Eliza Tudor had
  9418	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunderlinen enough to vie with her of Sheba. Twenty years he dallied
  9419	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthere between conjugial love and its chaste delights and scortatory love
  9420	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand its foul pleasures. You know Manningham’s story of the burgher’s
  9421	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twife who bade Dick Burbage to her bed after she had seen him in Richard
  9422	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIII and how Shakespeare, overhearing, without more ado about nothing,
  9423	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttook the cow by the horns and, when Burbage came knocking at the gate,
  9424	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanswered from the capon’s blankets: William the conqueror came before
  9425	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRichard III. And the gay lakin, mistress Fitton, mount and cry O, and
  9426	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this dainty birdsnies, lady Penelope Rich, a clean quality woman is
  9427	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsuited for a player, and the punks of the bankside, a penny a time.
  9428	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9429	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCours la Reine. Encore vingt sous. Nous ferons de petites cochonneries.
  9430	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMinette? Tu veux?
  9431	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9432	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The height of fine society. And sir William Davenant of Oxford’s mother
  9433	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith her cup of canary for any cockcanary.
  9434	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9435	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan, his pious eyes upturned, prayed:
  9436	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  9438	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9439	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And Harry of six wives’ daughter. And other lady friends from neighbour
  9440	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseats as Lawn Tennyson, gentleman poet, sings. But all those twenty
  9441	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyears what do you suppose poor Penelope in Stratford was doing behind
  9442	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe diamond panes?
  9443	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9444	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDo and do. Thing done. In a rosery of Fetter lane of Gerard, herbalist,
  9445	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the walks, greyedauburn. An azured harebell like her veins. Lids of
  9446	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJuno’s eyes, violets. He walks. One life is all. One body. Do. But do.
  9447	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAfar, in a reek of lust and squalor, hands are laid on whiteness.
  9448	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  9455	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  9460	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9461	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOld wall where sudden lizards flash. At Charenton I watched them.

  9463	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—It seems so, Stephen said, when he wants to do for him, and for all

  9465	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstallion. Maybe, like Socrates, he had a midwife to mother as he had a
  9466	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshrew to wife. But she, the giglot wanton, did not break a bedvow. Two
  9467	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeeds are rank in that ghost’s mind: a broken vow and the dullbrained
  9468	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyokel on whom her favour has declined, deceased husband’s brother. Sweet
  9469	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnn, I take it, was hot in the blood. Once a wooer, twice a wooer.
  9470	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  9519	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Pretty countryfolk had few chattels then, John Eglinton observed, as

  9523	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlanded estate at Stratford and a house in Ireland yard, a capitalist

  9540	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdead wife and bids his friends be kind to an old mistress (don’t forget
  9541	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNell Gwynn Herpyllis) and let her live in his villa.

  9570	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And the sense of property, Stephen said. He drew Shylock out of his own
  9571	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlong pocket. The son of a maltjobber and moneylender he was himself a
  9572	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcornjobber and moneylender, with ten tods of corn hoarded in the famine
  9573	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\triots. His borrowers are no doubt those divers of worship mentioned
  9574	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby Chettle Falstaff who reported his uprightness of dealing. He sued a
  9575	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfellowplayer for the price of a few bags of malt and exacted his pound
  9576	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof flesh in interest for every money lent. How else could Aubrey’s
  9577	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tostler and callboy get rich quick? All events brought grist to his
  9578	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmill. Shylock chimes with the jewbaiting that followed the hanging and
  9579	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquartering of the queen’s leech Lopez, his jew’s heart being plucked
  9580	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tforth while the sheeny was yet alive: Hamlet and Macbeth with the coming
  9581	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto the throne of a Scotch philosophaster with a turn for witchroasting.
  9582	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe lost armada is his jeer in Love’s Labour Lost. His pageants,
  9583	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe histories, sail fullbellied on a tide of Mafeking enthusiasm.
  9584	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWarwickshire jesuits are tried and we have a porter’s theory of
  9585	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tequivocation. The Sea Venture comes home from Bermudas and the play
  9586	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRenan admired is written with Patsy Caliban, our American cousin.
  9587	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe sugared sonnets follow Sidney’s. As for fay Elizabeth, otherwise
  9588	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcarrotty Bess, the gross virgin who inspired The Merry Wives of Windsor,
  9589	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlet some meinherr from Almany grope his life long for deephid meanings
  9590	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the depths of the buckbasket.

  9593	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheolologicophilolological. Mingo, minxi, mictum, mingere.

  9620	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Saint Thomas, Stephen smiling said, whose gorbellied works I enjoy
  9621	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treading in the original, writing of incest from a standpoint different
  9622	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom that of the new Viennese school Mr Magee spoke of, likens it in his
  9623	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twise and curious way to an avarice of the emotions. He means that the
  9624	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlove so given to one near in blood is covetously withheld from some
  9625	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstranger who, it may be, hungers for it. Jews, whom christians tax with
  9626	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tavarice, are of all races the most given to intermarriage. Accusations
  9627	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tare made in anger. The christian laws which built up the hoards of the
  9628	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjews (for whom, as for the lollards, storm was shelter) bound their
  9629	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taffections too with hoops of steel. Whether these be sins or virtues old
  9630	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNobodaddy will tell us at doomsday leet. But a man who holds so tightly
  9631	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto what he calls his rights over what he calls his debts will hold
  9632	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttightly also to what he calls his rights over her whom he calls his
  9633	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twife. No sir smile neighbour shall covet his ox or his wife or his
  9634	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmanservant or his maidservant or his jackass.
  9635	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9636	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Or his jennyass, Buck Mulligan antiphoned.
  9637	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9638	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Gentle Will is being roughly handled, gentle Mr Best said gently.
  9639	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9640	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Which will? gagged sweetly Buck Mulligan. We are getting mixed.
  9641	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9642	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The will to live, John Eglinton philosophised, for poor Ann, Will’s
  9643	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twidow, is the will to die.
  9644	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9645	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Requiescat! Stephen prayed.
  9646	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9647	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     What of all the will to do?
  9648	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     It has vanished long ago...
  9649	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9650	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—She lies laid out in stark stiffness in that secondbest bed, the mobled
  9651	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tqueen, even though you prove that a bed in those days was as rare as a
  9652	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmotorcar is now and that its carvings were the wonder of seven parishes.
  9653	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn old age she takes up with gospellers (one stayed with her at New
  9654	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPlace and drank a quart of sack the town council paid for but in which
  9655	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbed he slept it skills not to ask) and heard she had a soul. She read
  9656	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tor had read to her his chapbooks preferring them to the Merry Wives and,
  9657	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tloosing her nightly waters on the jordan, she thought over Hooks and
  9658	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEyes for Believers’ Breeches and The most Spiritual Snuffbox to Make the
  9659	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMost Devout Souls Sneeze. Venus has twisted her lips in prayer. Agenbite
  9660	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof inwit: remorse of conscience. It is an age of exhausted whoredom
  9661	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgroping for its god.
  9662	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9663	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—History shows that to be true, inquit Eglintonus Chronolologos. The
  9664	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tages succeed one another. But we have it on high authority that a man’s
  9665	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tworst enemies shall be those of his own house and family. I feel that
  9666	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRussell is right. What do we care for his wife or father? I should say
  9667	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat only family poets have family lives. Falstaff was not a family man.
  9668	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI feel that the fat knight is his supreme creation.
  9669	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9670	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLean, he lay back. Shy, deny thy kindred, the unco guid. Shy, supping
  9671	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith the godless, he sneaks the cup. A sire in Ultonian Antrim bade it
  9672	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim. Visits him here on quarter days. Mr Magee, sir, there’s a gentleman
  9673	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto see you. Me? Says he’s your father, sir. Give me my Wordsworth. Enter
  9674	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMagee Mor Matthew, a rugged rough rugheaded kern, in strossers with
  9675	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta buttoned codpiece, his nether stocks bemired with clauber of ten
  9676	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tforests, a wand of wilding in his hand.
  9677	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9678	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYour own? He knows your old fellow. The widower.
  9679	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9680	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHurrying to her squalid deathlair from gay Paris on the quayside I
  9681	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttouched his hand. The voice, new warmth, speaking. Dr Bob Kenny is
  9682	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tattending her. The eyes that wish me well. But do not know me.
  9683	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9684	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A father, Stephen said, battling against hopelessness, is a necessary
  9685	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tevil. He wrote the play in the months that followed his father’s death.
  9686	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIf you hold that he, a greying man with two marriageable daughters,
  9687	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith thirtyfive years of life, nel mezzo del cammin di nostra vita, with
  9688	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfifty of experience, is the beardless undergraduate from Wittenberg then
  9689	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou must hold that his seventyyear old mother is the lustful queen. No.
  9690	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe corpse of John Shakespeare does not walk the night. From hour to
  9691	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thour it rots and rots. He rests, disarmed of fatherhood, having devised
  9692	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat mystical estate upon his son. Boccaccio’s Calandrino was the first
  9693	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand last man who felt himself with child. Fatherhood, in the sense of
  9694	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconscious begetting, is unknown to man. It is a mystical estate, an
  9695	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tapostolic succession, from only begetter to only begotten. On that
  9696	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmystery and not on the madonna which the cunning Italian intellect
  9697	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tflung to the mob of Europe the church is founded and founded irremovably
  9698	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbecause founded, like the world, macro and microcosm, upon the void.
  9699	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tUpon incertitude, upon unlikelihood. Amor matris, subjective and
  9700	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tobjective genitive, may be the only true thing in life. Paternity may be
  9701	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta legal fiction. Who is the father of any son that any son should love
  9702	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim or he any son?
  9703	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9704	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat the hell are you driving at?
  9705	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9706	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI know. Shut up. Blast you. I have reasons.
  9707	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9708	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAmplius. Adhuc. Iterum. Postea.
  9709	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9710	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAre you condemned to do this?
  9711	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9712	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—They are sundered by a bodily shame so steadfast that the criminal
  9713	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tannals of the world, stained with all other incests and bestialities,
  9714	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thardly record its breach. Sons with mothers, sires with daughters,
  9715	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlesbic sisters, loves that dare not speak their name, nephews with
  9716	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgrandmothers, jailbirds with keyholes, queens with prize bulls. The son
  9717	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunborn mars beauty: born, he brings pain, divides affection, increases
  9718	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcare. He is a new male: his growth is his father’s decline, his youth
  9719	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this father’s envy, his friend his father’s enemy.
  9720	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9721	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn rue Monsieur-le-Prince I thought it.
  9722	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9723	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What links them in nature? An instant of blind rut.
  9724	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9725	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAm I a father? If I were?
  9726	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9727	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShrunken uncertain hand.
  9728	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9729	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Sabellius, the African, subtlest heresiarch of all the beasts of the
  9730	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfield, held that the Father was Himself His Own Son. The bulldog of
  9731	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAquin, with whom no word shall be impossible, refutes him. Well: if
  9732	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe father who has not a son be not a father can the son who has not a
  9733	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfather be a son? When Rutlandbaconsouthamptonshakespeare or another poet
  9734	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the same name in the comedy of errors wrote Hamlet he was not the
  9735	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfather of his own son merely but, being no more a son, he was and felt
  9736	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thimself the father of all his race, the father of his own grandfather,
  9737	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe father of his unborn grandson who, by the same token, never was
  9738	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tborn, for nature, as Mr Magee understands her, abhors perfection.
  9739	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9740	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEglintoneyes, quick with pleasure, looked up shybrightly. Gladly
  9741	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tglancing, a merry puritan, through the twisted eglantine.
  9742	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

  9747	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplay’s the thing! Let me parturiate!

  9751	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—As for his family, Stephen said, his mother’s name lives in the
  9752	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tforest of Arden. Her death brought from him the scene with Volumnia in
  9753	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCoriolanus. His boyson’s death is the deathscene of young Arthur in King
  9754	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJohn. Hamlet, the black prince, is Hamnet Shakespeare. Who the girls in
  9755	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe Tempest, in Pericles, in Winter’s Tale are we know. Who Cleopatra,
  9756	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfleshpot of Egypt, and Cressid and Venus are we may guess. But there is
  9757	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanother member of his family who is recorded.

  9774	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tone time mass he did and he seen his brud Maister Wull the playwriter up
  9775	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin Lunnon in a wrastling play wud a man on’s back. The playhouse sausage
  9776	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfilled Gilbert’s soul. He is nowhere: but an Edmund and a Richard are
  9777	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trecorded in the works of sweet William.

  9801	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSTEPHEN: (Stringendo) He has hidden his own name, a fair name, William,
  9802	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the plays, a super here, a clown there, as a painter of old Italy
  9803	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tset his face in a dark corner of his canvas. He has revealed it in the
  9804	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsonnets where there is Will in overplus. Like John o’Gaunt his name is
  9805	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdear to him, as dear as the coat and crest he toadied for, on a bend
  9806	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsable a spear or steeled argent, honorificabilitudinitatibus, dearer
  9807	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthan his glory of greatest shakescene in the country. What’s in a name?
  9808	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThat is what we ask ourselves in childhood when we write the name that
  9809	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twe are told is ours. A star, a daystar, a firedrake, rose at his birth.
  9810	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIt shone by day in the heavens alone, brighter than Venus in the
  9811	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnight, and by night it shone over delta in Cassiopeia, the recumbent
  9812	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconstellation which is the signature of his initial among the stars. His
  9813	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teyes watched it, lowlying on the horizon, eastward of the bear, as
  9814	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the walked by the slumberous summer fields at midnight returning from
  9815	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShottery and from her arms.

  9891	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLapwing.

  9893	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI am tired of my voice, the voice of Esau. My kingdom for a drink.
  9894	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9895	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOn.
  9896	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9897	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You will say those names were already in the chronicles from which he
  9898	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttook the stuff of his plays. Why did he take them rather than others?
  9899	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRichard, a whoreson crookback, misbegotten, makes love to a widowed Ann
  9900	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(what’s in a name?), woos and wins her, a whoreson merry widow. Richard
  9901	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe conqueror, third brother, came after William the conquered. The
  9902	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tother four acts of that play hang limply from that first. Of all his
  9903	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tkings Richard is the only king unshielded by Shakespeare’s reverence,
  9904	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe angel of the world. Why is the underplot of King Lear in which
  9905	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEdmund figures lifted out of Sidney’s Arcadia and spatchcocked on to a
  9906	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCeltic legend older than history?
  9907	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9908	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That was Will’s way, John Eglinton defended. We should not now combine
  9909	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta Norse saga with an excerpt from a novel by George Meredith. Que
  9910	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvoulez-vous? Moore would say. He puts Bohemia on the seacoast and makes
  9911	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tUlysses quote Aristotle.
  9912	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9913	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Why? Stephen answered himself. Because the theme of the false or
  9914	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe usurping or the adulterous brother or all three in one is to
  9915	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShakespeare, what the poor are not, always with him. The note of
  9916	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbanishment, banishment from the heart, banishment from home, sounds
  9917	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tuninterruptedly from The Two Gentlemen of Verona onward till Prospero
  9918	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbreaks his staff, buries it certain fathoms in the earth and drowns his
  9919	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbook. It doubles itself in the middle of his life, reflects itself in
  9920	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanother, repeats itself, protasis, epitasis, catastasis, catastrophe.
  9921	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIt repeats itself again when he is near the grave, when his married
  9922	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdaughter Susan, chip of the old block, is accused of adultery. But it
  9923	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas the original sin that darkened his understanding, weakened his will
  9924	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand left in him a strong inclination to evil. The words are those of
  9925	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmy lords bishops of Maynooth. An original sin and, like original sin,
  9926	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcommitted by another in whose sin he too has sinned. It is between the
  9927	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlines of his last written words, it is petrified on his tombstone under
  9928	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhich her four bones are not to be laid. Age has not withered it. Beauty
  9929	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand peace have not done it away. It is in infinite variety everywhere
  9930	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the world he has created, in Much Ado about Nothing, twice in As you
  9931	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlike It, in The Tempest, in Hamlet, in Measure for Measure—and in all
  9932	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe other plays which I have not read.
  9933	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9934	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe laughed to free his mind from his mind’s bondage.
  9935	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9936	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJudge Eglinton summed up.
  9937	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9938	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The truth is midway, he affirmed. He is the ghost and the prince. He is
  9939	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall in all.
  9940	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9941	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He is, Stephen said. The boy of act one is the mature man of act five.
  9942	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAll in all. In Cymbeline, in Othello he is bawd and cuckold. He acts and
  9943	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis acted on. Lover of an ideal or a perversion, like José he kills the
  9944	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treal Carmen. His unremitting intellect is the hornmad Iago ceaselessly
  9945	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twilling that the moor in him shall suffer.
  9946	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9947	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Cuckoo! Cuckoo! Cuck Mulligan clucked lewdly. O word of fear!
  9948	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9949	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDark dome received, reverbed.
  9950	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9951	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And what a character is Iago! undaunted John Eglinton exclaimed.
  9952	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhen all is said Dumas fils (or is it Dumas père?) is right. After God
  9953	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShakespeare has created most.
  9954	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9955	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Man delights him not nor woman neither, Stephen said. He returns after
  9956	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta life of absence to that spot of earth where he was born, where he has
  9957	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\talways been, man and boy, a silent witness and there, his journey of
  9958	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlife ended, he plants his mulberrytree in the earth. Then dies. The
  9959	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmotion is ended. Gravediggers bury Hamlet père and Hamlet fils. A king
  9960	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand a prince at last in death, with incidental music. And, what though
  9961	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmurdered and betrayed, bewept by all frail tender hearts for, Dane or
  9962	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDubliner, sorrow for the dead is the only husband from whom they refuse
  9963	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto be divorced. If you like the epilogue look long on it: prosperous
  9964	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tProspero, the good man rewarded, Lizzie, grandpa’s lump of love, and
  9965	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnuncle Richie, the bad man taken off by poetic justice to the place
  9966	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhere the bad niggers go. Strong curtain. He found in the world without
  9967	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tas actual what was in his world within as possible. Maeterlinck says:
  9968	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIf Socrates leave his house today he will find the sage seated on his
  9969	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoorstep. If Judas go forth tonight it is to Judas his steps will tend.
  9970	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEvery life is many days, day after day. We walk through ourselves,
  9971	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmeeting robbers, ghosts, giants, old men, young men, wives, widows,
  9972	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrothers-in-love, but always meeting ourselves. The playwright who wrote
  9973	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe folio of this world and wrote it badly (He gave us light first and
  9974	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe sun two days later), the lord of things as they are whom the most
  9975	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRoman of catholics call dio boia, hangman god, is doubtless all in all
  9976	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin all of us, ostler and butcher, and would be bawd and cuckold too but
  9977	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat in the economy of heaven, foretold by Hamlet, there are no more
  9978	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmarriages, glorified man, an androgynous angel, being a wife unto
  9979	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thimself.
  9980	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9981	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Eureka! Buck Mulligan cried. Eureka!
  9982	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9983	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSuddenly happied he jumped up and reached in a stride John Eglinton’s
  9984	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdesk.
  9985	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9986	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—May I? he said. The Lord has spoken to Malachi.
  9987	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9988	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe began to scribble on a slip of paper.
  9989	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9990	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTake some slips from the counter going out.
  9991	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9992	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Those who are married, Mr Best, douce herald, said, all save one, shall
  9993	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlive. The rest shall keep as they are.
  9994	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9995	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe laughed, unmarried, at Eglinton Johannes, of arts a bachelor.
  9996	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
  9997	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tUnwed, unfancied, ware of wiles, they fingerponder nightly each his
  9998	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvariorum edition of The Taming of the Shrew.
  9999	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10000	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You are a delusion, said roundly John Eglinton to Stephen. You have
 10001	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrought us all this way to show us a French triangle. Do you believe
 10002	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyour own theory?
 10003	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10004	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—No, Stephen said promptly.
 10005	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10006	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Are you going to write it? Mr Best asked. You ought to make it a
 10007	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdialogue, don’t you know, like the Platonic dialogues Wilde wrote.
 10008	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10009	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJohn Eclecticon doubly smiled.
 10010	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10011	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, in that case, he said, I don’t see why you should expect payment
 10012	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor it since you don’t believe it yourself. Dowden believes there is
 10013	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsome mystery in Hamlet but will say no more. Herr Bleibtreu, the man
 10014	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPiper met in Berlin, who is working up that Rutland theory, believes
 10015	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat the secret is hidden in the Stratford monument. He is going to
 10016	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvisit the present duke, Piper says, and prove to him that his ancestor
 10017	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twrote the plays. It will come as a surprise to his grace. But he
 10018	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbelieves his theory.
 10019	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10020	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI believe, O Lord, help my unbelief. That is, help me to believe or help
 10021	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tme to unbelieve? Who helps to believe? Egomen. Who to unbelieve? Other
 10022	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchap.
 10023	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10024	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You are the only contributor to Dana who asks for pieces of silver.
 10025	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThen I don’t know about the next number. Fred Ryan wants space for an
 10026	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tarticle on economics.
 10027	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10028	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFraidrine. Two pieces of silver he lent me. Tide you over. Economics.
 10029	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10030	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—For a guinea, Stephen said, you can publish this interview.
 10031	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10032	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan stood up from his laughing scribbling, laughing: and then
 10033	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgravely said, honeying malice:
 10034	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10035	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I called upon the bard Kinch at his summer residence in upper
 10036	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMecklenburgh street and found him deep in the study of the Summa contra
 10037	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGentiles in the company of two gonorrheal ladies, Fresh Nelly and
 10038	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRosalie, the coalquay whore.
 10039	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10040	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe broke away.
 10041	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10042	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Come, Kinch. Come, wandering Ængus of the birds.
 10043	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10044	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCome, Kinch. You have eaten all we left. Ay. I will serve you your orts
 10045	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand offals.
 10046	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10047	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen rose.
 10048	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10049	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLife is many days. This will end.
 10050	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10051	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—We shall see you tonight, John Eglinton said. Notre ami Moore says
 10052	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMalachi Mulligan must be there.
 10053	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10054	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan flaunted his slip and panama.
 10055	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10056	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Monsieur Moore, he said, lecturer on French letters to the youth of
 10057	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIreland. I’ll be there. Come, Kinch, the bards must drink. Can you walk
 10058	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstraight?

 10060	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLaughing, he...

 10069	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlub back: I followed. I gall his kibe.

 10073	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tno thought.

 10104	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnew art for Europe like the Greeks or M. Maeterlinck. Abbey Theatre! I
 10105	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsmell the pubic sweat of monks.

 10110	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tleft the femme de trente ans. And why no other children born? And his
 10111	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfirst child a girl?

 10124	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     I hardly hear the purlieu cry

 10126	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Before my thoughts begin to run
 10127	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     On F. M’Curdy Atkinson,

 10140	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto be like nature. Only crows, priests and English coal are black.

 10146	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton the paper and then you go and slate her drivel to Jaysus. Couldn’t
 10147	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou do the Yeats touch?

 10189	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand mirthfully he told the shadows, souls of men:
 10190	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10191	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, the night in the Camden hall when the daughters of Erin had to
 10192	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlift their skirts to step over you as you lay in your mulberrycoloured,
 10193	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmulticoloured, multitudinous vomit!

 10196	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem.

 10200	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPart. The moment is now. Where then? If Socrates leave his house today,
 10201	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tif Judas go forth tonight. Why? That lies in space which I in time must
 10202	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcome to, ineluctably.
 10203	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10204	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMy will: his will that fronts me. Seas between.

 10210	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe portico.
 10211	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10212	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHere I watched the birds for augury. Ængus of the birds. They go, they
 10213	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcome. Last night I flew. Easily flew. Men wondered. Street of harlots
 10214	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tafter. A creamfruit melon he held to me. In. You will see.
 10215	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10216	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The wandering jew, Buck Mulligan whispered with clown’s awe. Did you
 10217	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsee his eye? He looked upon you to lust after you. I fear thee, ancient
 10218	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmariner. O, Kinch, thou art in peril. Get thee a breechpad.

 10221	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 10223	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10224	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA dark back went before them, step of a pard, down, out by the gateway,
 10225	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunder portcullis barbs.
 10226	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 10228	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10229	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOffend me still. Speak on.
 10230	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10231	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKind air defined the coigns of houses in Kildare street. No birds. Frail
 10232	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom the housetops two plumes of smoke ascended, pluming, and in a flaw
 10233	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof softness softly were blown.
 10234	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10235	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCease to strive. Peace of the druid priests of Cymbeline: hierophantic:
 10236	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom wide earth an altar.

 10239	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     And let our crooked smokes climb to their nostrils
