 10248	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe superior, the very reverend John Conmee S. J. reset his smooth watch
 10249	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin his interior pocket as he came down the presbytery steps. Five to
 10250	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthree. Just nice time to walk to Artane. What was that boy’s name again?
 10251	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDignam. Yes. Vere dignum et iustum est. Brother Swan was the person
 10252	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto see. Mr Cunningham’s letter. Yes. Oblige him, if possible. Good
 10253	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpractical catholic: useful at mission time.
 10254	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10255	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA onelegged sailor, swinging himself onward by lazy jerks of his
 10256	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcrutches, growled some notes. He jerked short before the convent of the
 10257	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsisters of charity and held out a peaked cap for alms towards the very
 10258	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treverend John Conmee S. J. Father Conmee blessed him in the sun for his
 10259	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpurse held, he knew, one silver crown.
 10260	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10261	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee crossed to Mountjoy square. He thought, but not for long,
 10262	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof soldiers and sailors, whose legs had been shot off by cannonballs,
 10263	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tending their days in some pauper ward, and of cardinal Wolsey’s words:
 10264	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIf I had served my God as I have served my king He would not have
 10265	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabandoned me in my old days. He walked by the treeshade of sunnywinking
 10266	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tleaves: and towards him came the wife of Mr David Sheehy M.P.
 10267	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10268	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Very well, indeed, father. And you, father?
 10269	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10270	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee was wonderfully well indeed. He would go to Buxton
 10271	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprobably for the waters. And her boys, were they getting on well at
 10272	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBelvedere? Was that so? Father Conmee was very glad indeed to hear that.
 10273	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd Mr Sheehy himself? Still in London. The house was still sitting, to
 10274	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbe sure it was. Beautiful weather it was, delightful indeed. Yes, it was
 10275	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvery probable that Father Bernard Vaughan would come again to preach. O,
 10276	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyes: a very great success. A wonderful man really.
 10277	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10278	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee was very glad to see the wife of Mr David Sheehy M.P.
 10279	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIooking so well and he begged to be remembered to Mr David Sheehy M.P.
 10280	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYes, he would certainly call.
 10281	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10282	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Good afternoon, Mrs Sheehy.
 10283	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10284	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee doffed his silk hat and smiled, as he took leave, at the
 10285	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjet beads of her mantilla inkshining in the sun. And smiled yet again,
 10286	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin going. He had cleaned his teeth, he knew, with arecanut paste.
 10287	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10288	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee walked and, walking, smiled for he thought on Father
 10289	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBernard Vaughan’s droll eyes and cockney voice.
 10290	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10291	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Pilate! Wy don’t you old back that owlin mob?
 10292	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10293	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA zealous man, however. Really he was. And really did great good in his
 10294	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tway. Beyond a doubt. He loved Ireland, he said, and he loved the Irish.
 10295	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOf good family too would one think it? Welsh, were they not?
 10296	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10297	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tO, lest he forget. That letter to father provincial.
 10298	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10299	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee stopped three little schoolboys at the corner of Mountjoy
 10300	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsquare. Yes: they were from Belvedere. The little house. Aha. And were
 10301	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey good boys at school? O. That was very good now. And what was his
 10302	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tname? Jack Sohan. And his name? Ger. Gallaher. And the other little man?
 10303	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis name was Brunny Lynam. O, that was a very nice name to have.
 10304	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10305	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee gave a letter from his breast to Master Brunny Lynam and
 10306	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpointed to the red pillarbox at the corner of Fitzgibbon street.
 10307	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10308	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—But mind you don’t post yourself into the box, little man, he said.
 10309	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10310	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe boys sixeyed Father Conmee and laughed:
 10311	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10312	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, sir.
 10313	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10314	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, let me see if you can post a letter, Father Conmee said.
 10315	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10316	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMaster Brunny Lynam ran across the road and put Father Conmee’s letter
 10317	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto father provincial into the mouth of the bright red letterbox. Father
 10318	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tConmee smiled and nodded and smiled and walked along Mountjoy square
 10319	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teast.
 10320	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10321	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Denis J Maginni, professor of dancing &c, in silk hat, slate
 10322	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrockcoat with silk facings, white kerchief tie, tight lavender
 10323	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttrousers, canary gloves and pointed patent boots, walking with grave
 10324	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeportment most respectfully took the curbstone as he passed lady
 10325	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMaxwell at the corner of Dignam’s court.
 10326	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10327	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWas that not Mrs M’Guinness?
 10328	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10329	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMrs M’Guinness, stately, silverhaired, bowed to Father Conmee from the
 10330	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfarther footpath along which she sailed. And Father Conmee smiled and
 10331	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaluted. How did she do?
 10332	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10333	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA fine carriage she had. Like Mary, queen of Scots, something. And to
 10334	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthink that she was a pawnbroker! Well, now! Such a... what should he
 10335	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsay?... such a queenly mien.
 10336	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10337	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee walked down Great Charles street and glanced at the shutup
 10338	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfree church on his left. The reverend T. R. Greene B.A. will (D.V.)
 10339	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspeak. The incumbent they called him. He felt it incumbent on him to say
 10340	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta few words. But one should be charitable. Invincible ignorance. They
 10341	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tacted according to their lights.
 10342	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10343	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee turned the corner and walked along the North Circular
 10344	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\troad. It was a wonder that there was not a tramline in such an important
 10345	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthoroughfare. Surely, there ought to be.
 10346	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10347	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA band of satchelled schoolboys crossed from Richmond street. All
 10348	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\traised untidy caps. Father Conmee greeted them more than once benignly.
 10349	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tChristian brother boys.
 10350	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10351	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee smelt incense on his right hand as he walked. Saint
 10352	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJoseph’s church, Portland row. For aged and virtuous females.
 10353	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee raised his hat to the Blessed Sacrament. Virtuous: but
 10354	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toccasionally they were also badtempered.
 10355	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10356	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNear Aldborough house Father Conmee thought of that spendthrift
 10357	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnobleman. And now it was an office or something.
 10358	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10359	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee began to walk along the North Strand road and was saluted
 10360	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby Mr William Gallagher who stood in the doorway of his shop. Father
 10361	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tConmee saluted Mr William Gallagher and perceived the odours that came
 10362	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom baconflitches and ample cools of butter. He passed Grogan’s the
 10363	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTobacconist against which newsboards leaned and told of a dreadful
 10364	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcatastrophe in New York. In America those things were continually
 10365	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thappening. Unfortunate people to die like that, unprepared. Still, an
 10366	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tact of perfect contrition.
 10367	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10368	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee went by Daniel Bergin’s publichouse against the window of
 10369	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhich two unlabouring men lounged. They saluted him and were saluted.
 10370	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10371	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee passed H. J. O’Neill’s funeral establishment where Corny
 10372	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKelleher totted figures in the daybook while he chewed a blade of hay.
 10373	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA constable on his beat saluted Father Conmee and Father Conmee saluted
 10374	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe constable. In Youkstetter’s, the porkbutcher’s, Father Conmee
 10375	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tobserved pig’s puddings, white and black and red, lie neatly curled in
 10376	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttubes.
 10377	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10378	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMoored under the trees of Charleville Mall Father Conmee saw a
 10379	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tturfbarge, a towhorse with pendent head, a bargeman with a hat of dirty
 10380	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstraw seated amidships, smoking and staring at a branch of poplar above
 10381	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim. It was idyllic: and Father Conmee reflected on the providence of
 10382	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe Creator who had made turf to be in bogs whence men might dig it
 10383	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tout and bring it to town and hamlet to make fires in the houses of poor
 10384	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpeople.
 10385	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10386	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOn Newcomen bridge the very reverend John Conmee S. J. of saint Francis
 10387	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tXavier’s church, upper Gardiner street, stepped on to an outward bound
 10388	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttram.
 10389	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10390	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOff an inward bound tram stepped the reverend Nicholas Dudley C. C. of
 10391	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaint Agatha’s church, north William street, on to Newcomen bridge.
 10392	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10393	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAt Newcomen bridge Father Conmee stepped into an outward bound tram for
 10394	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the disliked to traverse on foot the dingy way past Mud Island.
 10395	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10396	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee sat in a corner of the tramcar, a blue ticket tucked with
 10397	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcare in the eye of one plump kid glove, while four shillings, a sixpence
 10398	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand five pennies chuted from his other plump glovepalm into his purse.
 10399	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPassing the ivy church he reflected that the ticket inspector usually
 10400	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmade his visit when one had carelessly thrown away the ticket. The
 10401	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsolemnity of the occupants of the car seemed to Father Conmee excessive
 10402	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor a journey so short and cheap. Father Conmee liked cheerful decorum.
 10403	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10404	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIt was a peaceful day. The gentleman with the glasses opposite Father
 10405	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tConmee had finished explaining and looked down. His wife, Father Conmee
 10406	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsupposed. A tiny yawn opened the mouth of the wife of the gentleman with
 10407	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe glasses. She raised her small gloved fist, yawned ever so gently,
 10408	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttiptapping her small gloved fist on her opening mouth and smiled tinily,
 10409	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsweetly.
 10410	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10411	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee perceived her perfume in the car. He perceived also that
 10412	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe awkward man at the other side of her was sitting on the edge of the
 10413	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseat.
 10414	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10415	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee at the altarrails placed the host with difficulty in the
 10416	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmouth of the awkward old man who had the shaky head.
 10417	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10418	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAt Annesley bridge the tram halted and, when it was about to go, an old
 10419	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twoman rose suddenly from her place to alight. The conductor pulled the
 10420	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbellstrap to stay the car for her. She passed out with her basket and
 10421	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta marketnet: and Father Conmee saw the conductor help her and net and
 10422	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbasket down: and Father Conmee thought that, as she had nearly passed
 10423	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe end of the penny fare, she was one of those good souls who had
 10424	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\talways to be told twice bless you, my child, that they have been
 10425	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabsolved, pray for me. But they had so many worries in life, so many
 10426	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcares, poor creatures.
 10427	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10428	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFrom the hoardings Mr Eugene Stratton grimaced with thick niggerlips at
 10429	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee.
 10430	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10431	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee thought of the souls of black and brown and yellow men and
 10432	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof his sermon on saint Peter Claver S. J. and the African mission and of
 10433	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe propagation of the faith and of the millions of black and brown and
 10434	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyellow souls that had not received the baptism of water when their last
 10435	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thour came like a thief in the night. That book by the Belgian jesuit, Le
 10436	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNombre des Élus, seemed to Father Conmee a reasonable plea. Those were
 10437	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmillions of human souls created by God in His Own likeness to whom the
 10438	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfaith had not (D.V.) been brought. But they were God’s souls, created by
 10439	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGod. It seemed to Father Conmee a pity that they should all be lost, a
 10440	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twaste, if one might say.
 10441	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10442	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAt the Howth road stop Father Conmee alighted, was saluted by the
 10443	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconductor and saluted in his turn.
 10444	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10445	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe Malahide road was quiet. It pleased Father Conmee, road and name.
 10446	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe joybells were ringing in gay Malahide. Lord Talbot de Malahide,
 10447	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\timmediate hereditary lord admiral of Malahide and the seas adjoining.
 10448	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThen came the call to arms and she was maid, wife and widow in one day.
 10449	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThose were old worldish days, loyal times in joyous townlands, old times
 10450	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the barony.
 10451	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10452	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee, walking, thought of his little book Old Times in the
 10453	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBarony and of the book that might be written about jesuit houses and of
 10454	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMary Rochfort, daughter of lord Molesworth, first countess of Belvedere.
 10455	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10456	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA listless lady, no more young, walked alone the shore of lough Ennel,
 10457	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMary, first countess of Belvedere, listlessly walking in the evening,
 10458	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnot startled when an otter plunged. Who could know the truth? Not the
 10459	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjealous lord Belvedere and not her confessor if she had not committed
 10460	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tadultery fully, eiaculatio seminis inter vas naturale mulieris, with her
 10461	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thusband’s brother? She would half confess if she had not all sinned as
 10462	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twomen did. Only God knew and she and he, her husband’s brother.
 10463	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10464	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee thought of that tyrannous incontinence, needed however for
 10465	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tman’s race on earth, and of the ways of God which were not our ways.
 10466	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10467	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDon John Conmee walked and moved in times of yore. He was humane and
 10468	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thonoured there. He bore in mind secrets confessed and he smiled at
 10469	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsmiling noble faces in a beeswaxed drawingroom, ceiled with full fruit
 10470	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tclusters. And the hands of a bride and of a bridegroom, noble to noble,
 10471	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twere impalmed by Don John Conmee.
 10472	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10473	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIt was a charming day.
 10474	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10475	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe lychgate of a field showed Father Conmee breadths of cabbages,
 10476	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcurtseying to him with ample underleaves. The sky showed him a flock
 10477	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof small white clouds going slowly down the wind. Moutonner, the French
 10478	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaid. A just and homely word.
 10479	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10480	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee, reading his office, watched a flock of muttoning clouds
 10481	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tover Rathcoffey. His thinsocked ankles were tickled by the stubble of
 10482	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tClongowes field. He walked there, reading in the evening, and heard
 10483	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe cries of the boys’ lines at their play, young cries in the quiet
 10484	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tevening. He was their rector: his reign was mild.
 10485	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10486	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee drew off his gloves and took his rededged breviary out. An
 10487	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tivory bookmark told him the page.
 10488	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10489	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNones. He should have read that before lunch. But lady Maxwell had come.
 10490	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10491	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee read in secret Pater and Ave and crossed his breast. Deus
 10492	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin adiutorium.
 10493	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10494	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe walked calmly and read mutely the nones, walking and reading till he
 10495	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcame to Res in Beati immaculati: Principium verborum tuorum veritas: in
 10496	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teternum omnia iudicia iustitiæ tuæ.
 10497	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10498	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA flushed young man came from a gap of a hedge and after him came a
 10499	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyoung woman with wild nodding daisies in her hand. The young man raised
 10500	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this cap abruptly: the young woman abruptly bent and with slow care
 10501	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdetached from her light skirt a clinging twig.
 10502	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10503	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee blessed both gravely and turned a thin page of his
 10504	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbreviary. Sin: Principes persecuti sunt me gratis: et a verbis tuis
 10505	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tformidavit cor meum.
 10506	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10507	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCorny Kelleher closed his long daybook and glanced with his drooping eye
 10508	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat a pine coffinlid sentried in a corner. He pulled himself erect,
 10509	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twent to it and, spinning it on its axle, viewed its shape and brass
 10510	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfurnishings. Chewing his blade of hay he laid the coffinlid by and came
 10511	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto the doorway. There he tilted his hatbrim to give shade to his eyes
 10512	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand leaned against the doorcase, looking idly out.
 10513	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10514	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather John Conmee stepped into the Dollymount tram on Newcomen bridge.
 10515	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10516	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCorny Kelleher locked his largefooted boots and gazed, his hat
 10517	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdowntilted, chewing his blade of hay.
 10518	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10519	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tConstable 57C, on his beat, stood to pass the time of day.
 10520	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10521	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That’s a fine day, Mr Kelleher.
 10522	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10523	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ay, Corny Kelleher said.
 10524	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10525	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—It’s very close, the constable said.
 10526	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10527	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCorny Kelleher sped a silent jet of hayjuice arching from his mouth
 10528	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhile a generous white arm from a window in Eccles street flung forth a
 10529	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcoin.
 10530	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10531	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What’s the best news? he asked.
 10532	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10533	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I seen that particular party last evening, the constable said with
 10534	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbated breath.
 10535	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10536	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA onelegged sailor crutched himself round MacConnell’s corner, skirting
 10537	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRabaiotti’s icecream car, and jerked himself up Eccles street. Towards
 10538	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLarry O’Rourke, in shirtsleeves in his doorway, he growled unamiably:
 10539	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10540	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—For England...
 10541	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10542	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe swung himself violently forward past Katey and Boody Dedalus, halted
 10543	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand growled:
 10544	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10545	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—home and beauty.
 10546	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10547	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJ. J. O’Molloy’s white careworn face was told that Mr Lambert was in the
 10548	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twarehouse with a visitor.
 10549	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10550	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA stout lady stopped, took a copper coin from her purse and dropped it
 10551	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinto the cap held out to her. The sailor grumbled thanks, glanced sourly
 10552	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat the unheeding windows, sank his head and swung himself forward four
 10553	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstrides.
 10554	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10555	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe halted and growled angrily:
 10556	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10557	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—For England...
 10558	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10559	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTwo barefoot urchins, sucking long liquorice laces, halted near him,
 10560	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgaping at his stump with their yellowslobbered mouths.
 10561	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10562	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe swung himself forward in vigorous jerks, halted, lifted his head
 10563	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttowards a window and bayed deeply:
 10564	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10565	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—home and beauty.
 10566	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10567	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe gay sweet chirping whistling within went on a bar or two, ceased.
 10568	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe blind of the window was drawn aside. A card Unfurnished Apartments
 10569	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tslipped from the sash and fell. A plump bare generous arm shone, was
 10570	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseen, held forth from a white petticoatbodice and taut shiftstraps. A
 10571	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twoman’s hand flung forth a coin over the area railings. It fell on the
 10572	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpath.
 10573	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10574	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOne of the urchins ran to it, picked it up and dropped it into the
 10575	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tminstrel’s cap, saying:
 10576	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10577	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—There, sir.
 10578	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10579	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKatey and Boody Dedalus shoved in the door of the closesteaming kitchen.
 10580	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10581	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Did you put in the books? Boody asked.
 10582	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10583	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMaggy at the range rammed down a greyish mass beneath bubbling suds

 10814	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcouncil chamber of saint Mary’s abbey where silken Thomas proclaimed
 10815	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thimself a rebel in 1534. This is the most historic spot in all Dublin.

 10860	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 10871	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas inside. He mightn’t like it, though. What? God, I’ll tell him

 10907	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLawyers of the past, haughty, pleading, beheld pass from the
 10908	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconsolidated taxing office to Nisi Prius court Richie Goulding carrying
 10909	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe costbag of Goulding, Collis and Ward and heard rustling from the
 10910	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tadmiralty division of king’s bench to the court of appeal an elderly
 10911	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfemale with false teeth smiling incredulously and a black silk skirt of
 10912	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgreat amplitude.
 10913	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10914	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—See? he said. See now the last one I put in is over here: Turns Over.
 10915	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe impact. Leverage, see?
 10916	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10917	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe showed them the rising column of disks on the right.
 10918	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10919	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Smart idea, Nosey Flynn said, snuffling. So a fellow coming in late can
 10920	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsee what turn is on and what turns are over.
 10921	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10922	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—See? Tom Rochford said.
 10923	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10924	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe slid in a disk for himself: and watched it shoot, wobble, ogle, stop:
 10925	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfour. Turn Now On.
 10926	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10927	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’ll see him now in the Ormond, Lenehan said, and sound him. One good
 10928	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tturn deserves another.
 10929	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10930	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Do, Tom Rochford said. Tell him I’m Boylan with impatience.
 10931	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10932	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Goodnight, M’Coy said abruptly. When you two begin...
 10933	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10934	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNosey Flynn stooped towards the lever, snuffling at it.
 10935	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10936	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—But how does it work here, Tommy? he asked.
 10937	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10938	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Tooraloo, Lenehan said. See you later.
 10939	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10940	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe followed M’Coy out across the tiny square of Crampton court.
 10941	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10942	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He’s a hero, he said simply.
 10943	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10944	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I know, M’Coy said. The drain, you mean.
 10945	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10946	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Drain? Lenehan said. It was down a manhole.
 10947	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10948	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey passed Dan Lowry’s musichall where Marie Kendall, charming
 10949	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsoubrette, smiled on them from a poster a dauby smile.
 10950	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10951	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGoing down the path of Sycamore street beside the Empire musichall
 10952	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLenehan showed M’Coy how the whole thing was. One of those manholes like
 10953	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta bloody gaspipe and there was the poor devil stuck down in it, half
 10954	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchoked with sewer gas. Down went Tom Rochford anyhow, booky’s vest and
 10955	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall, with the rope round him. And be damned but he got the rope round
 10956	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe poor devil and the two were hauled up.
 10957	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10958	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The act of a hero, he said.
 10959	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10960	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAt the Dolphin they halted to allow the ambulance car to gallop past
 10961	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem for Jervis street.
 10962	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10963	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—This way, he said, walking to the right. I want to pop into Lynam’s
 10964	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto see Sceptre’s starting price. What’s the time by your gold watch and
 10965	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchain?
 10966	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10967	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tM’Coy peered into Marcus Tertius Moses’ sombre office, then at O’Neill’s
 10968	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tclock.
 10969	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10970	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—After three, he said. Who’s riding her?
 10971	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10972	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O. Madden, Lenehan said. And a game filly she is.
 10973	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10974	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhile he waited in Temple bar M’Coy dodged a banana peel with gentle
 10975	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpushes of his toe from the path to the gutter. Fellow might damn easy
 10976	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tget a nasty fall there coming along tight in the dark.
 10977	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10978	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe gates of the drive opened wide to give egress to the viceregal
 10979	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcavalcade.
 10980	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10981	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Even money, Lenehan said returning. I knocked against Bantam Lyons
 10982	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin there going to back a bloody horse someone gave him that hasn’t an
 10983	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tearthly. Through here.
 10984	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10985	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey went up the steps and under Merchants’ arch. A darkbacked figure
 10986	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tscanned books on the hawker’s cart.
 10987	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10988	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—There he is, Lenehan said.
 10989	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10990	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Wonder what he’s buying, M’Coy said, glancing behind.
 10991	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10992	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Leopoldo or the Bloom is on the Rye, Lenehan said.
 10993	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10994	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He’s dead nuts on sales, M’Coy said. I was with him one day and he
 10995	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbought a book from an old one in Liffey street for two bob. There were
 10996	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfine plates in it worth double the money, the stars and the moon and
 10997	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcomets with long tails. Astronomy it was about.
 10998	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 10999	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLenehan laughed.
 11000	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11001	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’ll tell you a damn good one about comets’ tails, he said. Come over
 11002	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the sun.
 11003	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11004	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey crossed to the metal bridge and went along Wellington quay by the
 11005	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\triverwall.
 11006	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11007	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMaster Patrick Aloysius Dignam came out of Mangan’s, late Fehrenbach’s,
 11008	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcarrying a pound and a half of porksteaks.
 11009	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11010	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—There was a long spread out at Glencree reformatory, Lenehan said
 11011	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teagerly. The annual dinner, you know. Boiled shirt affair. The lord
 11012	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmayor was there, Val Dillon it was, and sir Charles Cameron and Dan
 11013	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDawson spoke and there was music. Bartell d’Arcy sang and Benjamin
 11014	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDollard...
 11015	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11016	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I know, M’Coy broke in. My missus sang there once.
 11017	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11018	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Did she? Lenehan said.
 11019	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11020	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA card Unfurnished Apartments reappeared on the windowsash of number 7
 11021	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEccles street.
 11022	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11023	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe checked his tale a moment but broke out in a wheezy laugh.
 11024	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11025	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—But wait till I tell you, he said. Delahunt of Camden street had the
 11026	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcatering and yours truly was chief bottlewasher. Bloom and the wife were
 11027	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthere. Lashings of stuff we put up: port wine and sherry and curacao to
 11028	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhich we did ample justice. Fast and furious it was. After liquids came
 11029	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsolids. Cold joints galore and mince pies...
 11030	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11031	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I know, M’Coy said. The year the missus was there...
 11032	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11033	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLenehan linked his arm warmly.
 11034	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11035	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—But wait till I tell you, he said. We had a midnight lunch too after
 11036	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall the jollification and when we sallied forth it was blue o’clock the
 11037	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmorning after the night before. Coming home it was a gorgeous winter’s
 11038	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnight on the Featherbed Mountain. Bloom and Chris Callinan were on one
 11039	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tside of the car and I was with the wife on the other. We started singing
 11040	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tglees and duets: Lo, the early beam of morning. She was well primed
 11041	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith a good load of Delahunt’s port under her bellyband. Every jolt the
 11042	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbloody car gave I had her bumping up against me. Hell’s delights! She
 11043	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thas a fine pair, God bless her. Like that.
 11044	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11045	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe held his caved hands a cubit from him, frowning:
 11046	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11047	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I was tucking the rug under her and settling her boa all the time. Know
 11048	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhat I mean?
 11049	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11050	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis hands moulded ample curves of air. He shut his eyes tight in
 11051	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdelight, his body shrinking, and blew a sweet chirp from his lips.
 11052	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11053	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The lad stood to attention anyhow, he said with a sigh. She’s a gamey
 11054	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmare and no mistake. Bloom was pointing out all the stars and the comets
 11055	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the heavens to Chris Callinan and the jarvey: the great bear and
 11056	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHercules and the dragon, and the whole jingbang lot. But, by God, I was
 11057	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlost, so to speak, in the milky way. He knows them all, faith. At last
 11058	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshe spotted a weeny weeshy one miles away. And what star is that, Poldy?
 11059	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsays she. By God, she had Bloom cornered. That one, is it? says Chris
 11060	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCallinan, sure that’s only what you might call a pinprick. By God, he
 11061	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twasn’t far wide of the mark.
 11062	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11063	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLenehan stopped and leaned on the riverwall, panting with soft laughter.
 11064	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11065	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’m weak, he gasped.
 11066	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11067	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tM’Coy’s white face smiled about it at instants and grew grave. Lenehan
 11068	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twalked on again. He lifted his yachtingcap and scratched his hindhead
 11069	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trapidly. He glanced sideways in the sunlight at M’Coy.
 11070	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11071	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He’s a cultured allroundman, Bloom is, he said seriously. He’s not one
 11072	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof your common or garden... you know... There’s a touch of the artist
 11073	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabout old Bloom.
 11074	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11075	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Bloom turned over idly pages of The Awful Disclosures of Maria Monk,
 11076	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthen of Aristotle’s Masterpiece. Crooked botched print. Plates: infants
 11077	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcuddled in a ball in bloodred wombs like livers of slaughtered cows.
 11078	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLots of them like that at this moment all over the world. All butting
 11079	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith their skulls to get out of it. Child born every minute somewhere.
 11080	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMrs Purefoy.
 11081	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11082	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe laid both books aside and glanced at the third: Tales of the Ghetto
 11083	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby Leopold von Sacher Masoch.
 11084	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11085	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That I had, he said, pushing it by.
 11086	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11087	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe shopman let two volumes fall on the counter.
 11088	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11089	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Them are two good ones, he said.
 11090	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11091	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOnions of his breath came across the counter out of his ruined mouth.
 11092	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe bent to make a bundle of the other books, hugged them against his
 11093	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunbuttoned waistcoat and bore them off behind the dingy curtain.
 11094	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11095	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOn O’Connell bridge many persons observed the grave deportment and gay
 11096	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tapparel of Mr Denis J Maginni, professor of dancing &c.
 11097	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11098	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Bloom, alone, looked at the titles. Fair Tyrants by James Lovebirch.
 11099	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKnow the kind that is. Had it? Yes.
 11100	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11101	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe opened it. Thought so.
 11102	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11103	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA woman’s voice behind the dingy curtain. Listen: the man.
 11104	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11105	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNo: she wouldn’t like that much. Got her it once.
 11106	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11107	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe read the other title: Sweets of Sin. More in her line. Let us see.
 11108	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11109	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe read where his finger opened.
 11110	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11111	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—All the dollarbills her husband gave her were spent in the stores on
 11112	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twondrous gowns and costliest frillies. For him! For Raoul!
 11113	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11114	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYes. This. Here. Try.
 11115	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11116	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Her mouth glued on his in a luscious voluptuous kiss while his hands
 11117	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfelt for the opulent curves inside her déshabillé.
 11118	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11119	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYes. Take this. The end.
 11120	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11121	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You are late, he spoke hoarsely, eying her with a suspicious glare.
 11122	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11123	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe beautiful woman threw off her sabletrimmed wrap, displaying her
 11124	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tqueenly shoulders and heaving embonpoint. An imperceptible smile played
 11125	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tround her perfect lips as she turned to him calmly.
 11126	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11127	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Bloom read again: The beautiful woman.
 11128	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11129	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWarmth showered gently over him, cowing his flesh. Flesh yielded amply
 11130	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tamid rumpled clothes: whites of eyes swooning up. His nostrils arched
 11131	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthemselves for prey. Melting breast ointments (for him! For Raoul!).
 11132	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tArmpits’ oniony sweat. Fishgluey slime (her heaving embonpoint!). Feel!
 11133	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPress! Crished! Sulphur dung of lions!
 11134	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11135	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYoung! Young!
 11136	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11137	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAn elderly female, no more young, left the building of the courts of
 11138	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchancery, king’s bench, exchequer and common pleas, having heard in
 11139	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe lord chancellor’s court the case in lunacy of Potterton, in the
 11140	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tadmiralty division the summons, exparte motion, of the owners of the
 11141	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLady Cairns versus the owners of the barque Mona, in the court of appeal
 11142	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treservation of judgment in the case of Harvey versus the Ocean Accident
 11143	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand Guarantee Corporation.
 11144	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11145	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPhlegmy coughs shook the air of the bookshop, bulging out the dingy
 11146	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcurtains. The shopman’s uncombed grey head came out and his unshaven
 11147	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treddened face, coughing. He raked his throat rudely, puked phlegm on the
 11148	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfloor. He put his boot on what he had spat, wiping his sole along it,
 11149	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand bent, showing a rawskinned crown, scantily haired.
 11150	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11151	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Bloom beheld it.
 11152	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11153	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMastering his troubled breath, he said:
 11154	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11155	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’ll take this one.
 11156	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11157	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe shopman lifted eyes bleared with old rheum.
 11158	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11159	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Sweets of Sin, he said, tapping on it. That’s a good one.
 11160	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11161	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe lacquey by the door of Dillon’s auctionrooms shook his handbell
 11162	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttwice again and viewed himself in the chalked mirror of the cabinet.
 11163	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11164	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDilly Dedalus, loitering by the curbstone, heard the beats of the
 11165	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbell, the cries of the auctioneer within. Four and nine. Those lovely
 11166	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcurtains. Five shillings. Cosy curtains. Selling new at two guineas. Any
 11167	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tadvance on five shillings? Going for five shillings.
 11168	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11169	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe lacquey lifted his handbell and shook it:
 11170	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11171	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Barang!
 11172	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11173	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBang of the lastlap bell spurred the halfmile wheelmen to their sprint.
 11174	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJ. A. Jackson, W. E. Wylie, A. Munro and H. T. Gahan, their stretched
 11175	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnecks wagging, negotiated the curve by the College library.
 11176	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11177	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Dedalus, tugging a long moustache, came round from Williams’s row. He
 11178	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thalted near his daughter.
 11179	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11180	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—It’s time for you, she said.
 11181	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11182	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Stand up straight for the love of the lord Jesus, Mr Dedalus said.
 11183	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAre you trying to imitate your uncle John, the cornetplayer, head upon
 11184	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshoulder? Melancholy God!
 11185	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11186	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDilly shrugged her shoulders. Mr Dedalus placed his hands on them and
 11187	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theld them back.
 11188	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11189	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Stand up straight, girl, he said. You’ll get curvature of the spine. Do
 11190	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou know what you look like?
 11191	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11192	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe let his head sink suddenly down and forward, hunching his shoulders
 11193	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand dropping his underjaw.
 11194	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11195	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Give it up, father, Dilly said. All the people are looking at you.
 11196	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11197	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Dedalus drew himself upright and tugged again at his moustache.
 11198	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11199	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Did you get any money? Dilly asked.
 11200	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11201	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Where would I get money? Mr Dedalus said. There is no-one in Dublin
 11202	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twould lend me fourpence.
 11203	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11204	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You got some, Dilly said, looking in his eyes.
 11205	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11206	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—How do you know that? Mr Dedalus asked, his tongue in his cheek.
 11207	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11208	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Kernan, pleased with the order he had booked, walked boldly along
 11209	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJames’s street.
 11210	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11211	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I know you did, Dilly answered. Were you in the Scotch house now?
 11212	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11213	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I was not, then, Mr Dedalus said, smiling. Was it the little nuns
 11214	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttaught you to be so saucy? Here.
 11215	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11216	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe handed her a shilling.
 11217	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11218	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—See if you can do anything with that, he said.
 11219	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11220	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I suppose you got five, Dilly said. Give me more than that.
 11221	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11222	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Wait awhile, Mr Dedalus said threateningly. You’re like the rest of
 11223	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem, are you? An insolent pack of little bitches since your poor mother
 11224	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdied. But wait awhile. You’ll all get a short shrift and a long day from
 11225	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tme. Low blackguardism! I’m going to get rid of you. Wouldn’t care if I
 11226	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas stretched out stiff. He’s dead. The man upstairs is dead.
 11227	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11228	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe left her and walked on. Dilly followed quickly and pulled his coat.
 11229	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11230	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, what is it? he said, stopping.
 11231	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11232	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe lacquey rang his bell behind their backs.
 11233	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11234	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Barang!
 11235	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11236	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Curse your bloody blatant soul, Mr Dedalus cried, turning on him.
 11237	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11238	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe lacquey, aware of comment, shook the lolling clapper of his bell but
 11239	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfeebly:
 11240	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11241	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Bang!
 11242	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11243	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Dedalus stared at him.
 11244	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11245	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Watch him, he said. It’s instructive. I wonder will he allow us to
 11246	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttalk.
 11247	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11248	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You got more than that, father, Dilly said.
 11249	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11250	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’m going to show you a little trick, Mr Dedalus said. I’ll leave
 11251	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou all where Jesus left the jews. Look, there’s all I have. I got
 11252	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttwo shillings from Jack Power and I spent twopence for a shave for the
 11253	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfuneral.
 11254	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11255	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe drew forth a handful of copper coins, nervously.
 11256	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11257	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Can’t you look for some money somewhere? Dilly said.
 11258	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11259	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Dedalus thought and nodded.
 11260	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11261	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I will, he said gravely. I looked all along the gutter in O’Connell
 11262	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstreet. I’ll try this one now.
 11263	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11264	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You’re very funny, Dilly said, grinning.
 11265	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11266	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Here, Mr Dedalus said, handing her two pennies. Get a glass of milk for
 11267	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyourself and a bun or a something. I’ll be home shortly.
 11268	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11269	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe put the other coins in his pocket and started to walk on.
 11270	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11271	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe viceregal cavalcade passed, greeted by obsequious policemen, out of
 11272	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tParkgate.
 11273	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11274	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’m sure you have another shilling, Dilly said.
 11275	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11276	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe lacquey banged loudly.
 11277	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11278	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Dedalus amid the din walked off, murmuring to himself with a pursing
 11279	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmincing mouth gently:
 11280	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11281	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The little nuns! Nice little things! O, sure they wouldn’t do anything!
 11282	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tO, sure they wouldn’t really! Is it little sister Monica!
 11283	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11284	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFrom the sundial towards James’s gate walked Mr Kernan, pleased with the
 11285	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\torder he had booked for Pulbrook Robertson, boldly along James’s street,
 11286	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpast Shackleton’s offices. Got round him all right. How do you do, Mr
 11287	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCrimmins? First rate, sir. I was afraid you might be up in your other
 11288	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\testablishment in Pimlico. How are things going? Just keeping alive.
 11289	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLovely weather we’re having. Yes, indeed. Good for the country. Those
 11290	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfarmers are always grumbling. I’ll just take a thimbleful of your best
 11291	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgin, Mr Crimmins. A small gin, sir. Yes, sir. Terrible affair that
 11292	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGeneral Slocum explosion. Terrible, terrible! A thousand casualties. And
 11293	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theartrending scenes. Men trampling down women and children. Most brutal
 11294	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthing. What do they say was the cause? Spontaneous combustion. Most
 11295	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tscandalous revelation. Not a single lifeboat would float and the
 11296	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfirehose all burst. What I can’t understand is how the inspectors ever
 11297	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tallowed a boat like that... Now, you’re talking straight, Mr Crimmins.
 11298	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYou know why? Palm oil. Is that a fact? Without a doubt. Well now, look
 11299	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat that. And America they say is the land of the free. I thought we were
 11300	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbad here.
 11301	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11302	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI smiled at him. America, I said quietly, just like that. What is it?
 11303	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe sweepings of every country including our own. Isn’t that true?
 11304	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThat’s a fact.
 11305	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11306	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGraft, my dear sir. Well, of course, where there’s money going there’s
 11307	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\talways someone to pick it up.
 11308	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11309	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSaw him looking at my frockcoat. Dress does it. Nothing like a dressy
 11310	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tappearance. Bowls them over.
 11311	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11312	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Hello, Simon, Father Cowley said. How are things?
 11313	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11314	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Hello, Bob, old man, Mr Dedalus answered, stopping.
 11315	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11316	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Kernan halted and preened himself before the sloping mirror of Peter
 11317	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKennedy, hairdresser. Stylish coat, beyond a doubt. Scott of Dawson
 11318	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstreet. Well worth the half sovereign I gave Neary for it. Never built
 11319	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunder three guineas. Fits me down to the ground. Some Kildare street
 11320	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tclub toff had it probably. John Mulligan, the manager of the Hibernian
 11321	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbank, gave me a very sharp eye yesterday on Carlisle bridge as if he
 11322	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tremembered me.
 11323	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11324	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAham! Must dress the character for those fellows. Knight of the road.
 11325	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGentleman. And now, Mr Crimmins, may we have the honour of your custom
 11326	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tagain, sir. The cup that cheers but not inebriates, as the old saying
 11327	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thas it.
 11328	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11329	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNorth wall and sir John Rogerson’s quay, with hulls and anchorchains,
 11330	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsailing westward, sailed by a skiff, a crumpled throwaway, rocked on the
 11331	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tferrywash, Elijah is coming.
 11332	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11333	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Kernan glanced in farewell at his image. High colour, of course.
 11334	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGrizzled moustache. Returned Indian officer. Bravely he bore his stumpy
 11335	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbody forward on spatted feet, squaring his shoulders. Is that Ned
 11336	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLambert’s brother over the way, Sam? What? Yes. He’s as like it as damn
 11337	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit. No. The windscreen of that motorcar in the sun there. Just a flash
 11338	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlike that. Damn like him.
 11339	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11340	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAham! Hot spirit of juniper juice warmed his vitals and his breath. Good
 11341	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrop of gin, that was. His frocktails winked in bright sunshine to his
 11342	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfat strut.
 11343	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11344	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDown there Emmet was hanged, drawn and quartered. Greasy black rope.
 11345	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDogs licking the blood off the street when the lord lieutenant’s wife
 11346	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrove by in her noddy.
 11347	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11348	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBad times those were. Well, well. Over and done with. Great topers too.
 11349	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFourbottle men.
 11350	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11351	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLet me see. Is he buried in saint Michan’s? Or no, there was a midnight
 11352	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tburial in Glasnevin. Corpse brought in through a secret door in the
 11353	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twall. Dignam is there now. Went out in a puff. Well, well. Better turn
 11354	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdown here. Make a detour.
 11355	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11356	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Kernan turned and walked down the slope of Watling street by
 11357	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe corner of Guinness’s visitors’ waitingroom. Outside the Dublin
 11358	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDistillers Company’s stores an outside car without fare or jarvey stood,
 11359	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe reins knotted to the wheel. Damn dangerous thing. Some Tipperary
 11360	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbosthoon endangering the lives of the citizens. Runaway horse.
 11361	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11362	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDenis Breen with his tomes, weary of having waited an hour in John
 11363	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHenry Menton’s office, led his wife over O’Connell bridge, bound for the
 11364	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toffice of Messrs Collis and Ward.
 11365	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11366	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Kernan approached Island street.
 11367	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11368	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTimes of the troubles. Must ask Ned Lambert to lend me those
 11369	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treminiscences of sir Jonah Barrington. When you look back on it all
 11370	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnow in a kind of retrospective arrangement. Gaming at Daly’s. No
 11371	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcardsharping then. One of those fellows got his hand nailed to the table
 11372	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby a dagger. Somewhere here lord Edward Fitzgerald escaped from major
 11373	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSirr. Stables behind Moira house.
 11374	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11375	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDamn good gin that was.
 11376	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11377	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFine dashing young nobleman. Good stock, of course. That ruffian, that
 11378	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsham squire, with his violet gloves gave him away. Course they were
 11379	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton the wrong side. They rose in dark and evil days. Fine poem that
 11380	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis: Ingram. They were gentlemen. Ben Dollard does sing that ballad
 11381	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttouchingly. Masterly rendition.
 11382	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11383	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAt the siege of Ross did my father fall.
 11384	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11385	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA cavalcade in easy trot along Pembroke quay passed, outriders leaping,
 11386	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tleaping in their, in their saddles. Frockcoats. Cream sunshades.
 11387	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11388	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Kernan hurried forward, blowing pursily.
 11389	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11390	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis Excellency! Too bad! Just missed that by a hair. Damn it! What a
 11391	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpity!
 11392	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11393	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen Dedalus watched through the webbed window the lapidary’s fingers
 11394	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprove a timedulled chain. Dust webbed the window and the showtrays. Dust
 11395	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdarkened the toiling fingers with their vulture nails. Dust slept
 11396	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton dull coils of bronze and silver, lozenges of cinnabar, on rubies,
 11397	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tleprous and winedark stones.
 11398	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11399	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBorn all in the dark wormy earth, cold specks of fire, evil, lights
 11400	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshining in the darkness. Where fallen archangels flung the stars of
 11401	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir brows. Muddy swinesnouts, hands, root and root, gripe and wrest
 11402	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem.
 11403	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11404	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe dances in a foul gloom where gum bums with garlic. A sailorman,
 11405	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trustbearded, sips from a beaker rum and eyes her. A long and seafed
 11406	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsilent rut. She dances, capers, wagging her sowish haunches and her
 11407	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thips, on her gross belly flapping a ruby egg.
 11408	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11409	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOld Russell with a smeared shammy rag burnished again his gem, turned it
 11410	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand held it at the point of his Moses’ beard. Grandfather ape gloating
 11411	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton a stolen hoard.
 11412	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11413	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd you who wrest old images from the burial earth? The brainsick words
 11414	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof sophists: Antisthenes. A lore of drugs. Orient and immortal wheat
 11415	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstanding from everlasting to everlasting.
 11416	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11417	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTwo old women fresh from their whiff of the briny trudged through
 11418	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIrishtown along London bridge road, one with a sanded tired umbrella,
 11419	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tone with a midwife’s bag in which eleven cockles rolled.
 11420	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11421	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe whirr of flapping leathern bands and hum of dynamos from the
 11422	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpowerhouse urged Stephen to be on. Beingless beings. Stop! Throb always
 11423	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twithout you and the throb always within. Your heart you sing of. I
 11424	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbetween them. Where? Between two roaring worlds where they swirl, I.
 11425	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShatter them, one and both. But stun myself too in the blow. Shatter me
 11426	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou who can. Bawd and butcher were the words. I say! Not yet awhile. A
 11427	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlook around.
 11428	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11429	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYes, quite true. Very large and wonderful and keeps famous time. You say
 11430	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tright, sir. A Monday morning, ‘twas so, indeed.
 11431	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11432	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen went down Bedford row, the handle of the ash clacking against
 11433	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this shoulderblade. In Clohissey’s window a faded 1860 print of Heenan
 11434	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tboxing Sayers held his eye. Staring backers with square hats stood
 11435	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tround the roped prizering. The heavyweights in tight loincloths proposed

 11437	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thearts.
 11438	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11439	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe turned and halted by the slanted bookcart.
 11440	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11441	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Twopence each, the huckster said. Four for sixpence.
 11442	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11443	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTattered pages. The Irish Beekeeper. Life and Miracles of the Curé of
 11444	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tArs. Pocket Guide to Killarney.
 11445	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11446	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI might find here one of my pawned schoolprizes. Stephano Dedalo, alumno
 11447	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toptimo, palmam ferenti.
 11448	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11449	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conmee, having read his little hours, walked through the hamlet

 11451	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11452	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBinding too good probably. What is this? Eighth and ninth book of Moses.
 11453	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSecret of all secrets. Seal of King David. Thumbed pages: read and read.
 11454	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWho has passed here before me? How to soften chapped hands. Recipe for
 11455	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhite wine vinegar. How to win a woman’s love. For me this. Say the
 11456	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfollowing talisman three times with hands folded:
 11457	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11458	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Se el yilo nebrakada femininum! Amor me solo! Sanktus! Amen.
 11459	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11460	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWho wrote this? Charms and invocations of the most blessed abbot Peter
 11461	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSalanka to all true believers divulged. As good as any other abbot’s
 11462	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcharms, as mumbling Joachim’s. Down, baldynoddle, or we’ll wool your
 11463	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twool.
 11464	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11465	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What are you doing here, Stephen?
 11466	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11467	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDilly’s high shoulders and shabby dress.
 11468	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11469	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShut the book quick. Don’t let see.
 11470	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11471	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What are you doing? Stephen said.
 11472	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11473	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA Stuart face of nonesuch Charles, lank locks falling at its sides. It
 11474	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tglowed as she crouched feeding the fire with broken boots. I told her
