 11477	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11478	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What have you there? Stephen asked.
 11479	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11480	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I bought it from the other cart for a penny, Dilly said, laughing
 11481	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnervously. Is it any good?
 11482	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11483	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMy eyes they say she has. Do others see me so? Quick, far and daring.
 11484	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShadow of my mind.
 11485	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11486	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe took the coverless book from her hand. Chardenal’s French primer.
 11487	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11488	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What did you buy that for? he asked. To learn French?
 11489	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11490	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe nodded, reddening and closing tight her lips.
 11491	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11492	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShow no surprise. Quite natural.
 11493	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11494	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Here, Stephen said. It’s all right. Mind Maggy doesn’t pawn it on you.
 11495	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI suppose all my books are gone.
 11496	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11497	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Some, Dilly said. We had to.
 11498	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11499	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe is drowning. Agenbite. Save her. Agenbite. All against us. She will
 11500	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrown me with her, eyes and hair. Lank coils of seaweed hair around me,
 11501	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmy heart, my soul. Salt green death.
 11502	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11503	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWe.
 11504	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11505	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAgenbite of inwit. Inwit’s agenbite.
 11506	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11507	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMisery! Misery!
 11508	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11509	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Hello, Simon, Father Cowley said. How are things?
 11510	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11511	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Hello, Bob, old man, Mr Dedalus answered, stopping.
 11512	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11513	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey clasped hands loudly outside Reddy and Daughter’s. Father Cowley
 11514	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrushed his moustache often downward with a scooping hand.
 11515	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11516	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What’s the best news? Mr Dedalus said.
 11517	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11518	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Why then not much, Father Cowley said. I’m barricaded up, Simon, with
 11519	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttwo men prowling around the house trying to effect an entrance.
 11520	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11521	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Jolly, Mr Dedalus said. Who is it?
 11522	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11523	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, Father Cowley said. A certain gombeen man of our acquaintance.
 11524	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11525	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—With a broken back, is it? Mr Dedalus asked.
 11526	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11527	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The same, Simon, Father Cowley answered. Reuben of that ilk. I’m just
 11528	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twaiting for Ben Dollard. He’s going to say a word to long John to get
 11529	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim to take those two men off. All I want is a little time.
 11530	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11531	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe looked with vague hope up and down the quay, a big apple bulging in
 11532	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this neck.
 11533	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11534	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I know, Mr Dedalus said, nodding. Poor old bockedy Ben! He’s always
 11535	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoing a good turn for someone. Hold hard!
 11536	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11537	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe put on his glasses and gazed towards the metal bridge an instant.
 11538	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11539	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—There he is, by God, he said, arse and pockets.
 11540	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11541	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBen Dollard’s loose blue cutaway and square hat above large slops
 11542	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcrossed the quay in full gait from the metal bridge. He came towards
 11543	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem at an amble, scratching actively behind his coattails.
 11544	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11545	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAs he came near Mr Dedalus greeted:
 11546	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11547	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Hold that fellow with the bad trousers.
 11548	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11549	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Hold him now, Ben Dollard said.
 11550	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11551	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Dedalus eyed with cold wandering scorn various points of Ben
 11552	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDollard’s figure. Then, turning to Father Cowley with a nod, he muttered
 11553	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsneeringly:
 11554	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11555	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That’s a pretty garment, isn’t it, for a summer’s day?
 11556	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11557	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Why, God eternally curse your soul, Ben Dollard growled furiously, I
 11558	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthrew out more clothes in my time than you ever saw.
 11559	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11560	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe stood beside them beaming, on them first and on his roomy clothes
 11561	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom points of which Mr Dedalus flicked fluff, saying:
 11562	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11563	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—They were made for a man in his health, Ben, anyhow.
 11564	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11565	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Bad luck to the jewman that made them, Ben Dollard said. Thanks be to
 11566	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGod he’s not paid yet.
 11567	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11568	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And how is that basso profondo, Benjamin? Father Cowley asked.
 11569	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11570	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCashel Boyle O’Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell, murmuring,
 11571	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tglassyeyed, strode past the Kildare street club.
 11572	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11573	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBen Dollard frowned and, making suddenly a chanter’s mouth, gave forth a
 11574	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeep note.
 11575	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11576	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Aw! he said.
 11577	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11578	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That’s the style, Mr Dedalus said, nodding to its drone.
 11579	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11580	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What about that? Ben Dollard said. Not too dusty? What?
 11581	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11582	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe turned to both.
 11583	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11584	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That’ll do, Father Cowley said, nodding also.
 11585	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11586	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe reverend Hugh C. Love walked from the old chapterhouse of saint
 11587	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMary’s abbey past James and Charles Kennedy’s, rectifiers, attended by
 11588	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGeraldines tall and personable, towards the Tholsel beyond the ford of
 11589	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thurdles.
 11590	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11591	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBen Dollard with a heavy list towards the shopfronts led them forward,
 11592	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this joyful fingers in the air.
 11593	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11594	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Come along with me to the subsheriff’s office, he said. I want to
 11595	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshow you the new beauty Rock has for a bailiff. He’s a cross between
 11596	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLobengula and Lynchehaun. He’s well worth seeing, mind you. Come along.
 11597	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI saw John Henry Menton casually in the Bodega just now and it will
 11598	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcost me a fall if I don’t... Wait awhile... We’re on the right lay, Bob,
 11599	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbelieve you me.
 11600	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11601	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—For a few days tell him, Father Cowley said anxiously.
 11602	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11603	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBen Dollard halted and stared, his loud orifice open, a dangling button
 11604	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof his coat wagging brightbacked from its thread as he wiped away the
 11605	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theavy shraums that clogged his eyes to hear aright.
 11606	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11607	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What few days? he boomed. Hasn’t your landlord distrained for rent?
 11608	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11609	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He has, Father Cowley said.
 11610	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11611	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Then our friend’s writ is not worth the paper it’s printed on, Ben
 11612	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDollard said. The landlord has the prior claim. I gave him all the
 11613	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tparticulars. 29 Windsor avenue. Love is the name?
 11614	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11615	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That’s right, Father Cowley said. The reverend Mr Love. He’s a minister
 11616	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the country somewhere. But are you sure of that?
 11617	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11618	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You can tell Barabbas from me, Ben Dollard said, that he can put that
 11619	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twrit where Jacko put the nuts.
 11620	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11621	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe led Father Cowley boldly forward, linked to his bulk.
 11622	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11623	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Filberts I believe they were, Mr Dedalus said, as he dropped his
 11624	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tglasses on his coatfront, following them.
 11625	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11626	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The youngster will be all right, Martin Cunningham said, as they passed
 11627	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tout of the Castleyard gate.
 11628	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11629	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe policeman touched his forehead.
 11630	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11631	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—God bless you, Martin Cunningham said, cheerily.
 11632	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11633	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe signed to the waiting jarvey who chucked at the reins and set on
 11634	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttowards Lord Edward street.
 11635	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11636	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBronze by gold, Miss Kennedy’s head by Miss Douce’s head, appeared above
 11637	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe crossblind of the Ormond hotel.
 11638	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11639	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, Martin Cunningham said, fingering his beard. I wrote to Father
 11640	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tConmee and laid the whole case before him.
 11641	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11642	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You could try our friend, Mr Power suggested backward.
 11643	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11644	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Boyd? Martin Cunningham said shortly. Touch me not.
 11645	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11646	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJohn Wyse Nolan, lagging behind, reading the list, came after them
 11647	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquickly down Cork hill.
 11648	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11649	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOn the steps of the City hall Councillor Nannetti, descending, hailed
 11650	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAlderman Cowley and Councillor Abraham Lyon ascending.
 11651	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11652	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe castle car wheeled empty into upper Exchange street.
 11653	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11654	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Look here, Martin, John Wyse Nolan said, overtaking them at the Mail
 11655	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toffice. I see Bloom put his name down for five shillings.
 11656	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11657	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Quite right, Martin Cunningham said, taking the list. And put down the
 11658	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfive shillings too.
 11659	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11660	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Without a second word either, Mr Power said.
 11661	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11662	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Strange but true, Martin Cunningham added.
 11663	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11664	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJohn Wyse Nolan opened wide eyes.
 11665	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11666	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’ll say there is much kindness in the jew, he quoted, elegantly.
 11667	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11668	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey went down Parliament street.
 11669	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11670	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—There’s Jimmy Henry, Mr Power said, just heading for Kavanagh’s.
 11671	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11672	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Righto, Martin Cunningham said. Here goes.
 11673	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11674	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOutside la Maison Claire Blazes Boylan waylaid Jack Mooney’s
 11675	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrother-in-law, humpy, tight, making for the liberties.
 11676	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11677	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJohn Wyse Nolan fell back with Mr Power, while Martin Cunningham took
 11678	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe elbow of a dapper little man in a shower of hail suit, who walked
 11679	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tuncertainly, with hasty steps past Micky Anderson’s watches.
 11680	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11681	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The assistant town clerk’s corns are giving him some trouble, John Wyse
 11682	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNolan told Mr Power.
 11683	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11684	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey followed round the corner towards James Kavanagh’s winerooms. The
 11685	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tempty castle car fronted them at rest in Essex gate. Martin Cunningham,
 11686	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspeaking always, showed often the list at which Jimmy Henry did not
 11687	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tglance.
 11688	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11689	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And long John Fanning is here too, John Wyse Nolan said, as large as
 11690	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlife.
 11691	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11692	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe tall form of long John Fanning filled the doorway where he stood.
 11693	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11694	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Good day, Mr Subsheriff, Martin Cunningham said, as all halted and
 11695	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgreeted.
 11696	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11697	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLong John Fanning made no way for them. He removed his large Henry Clay
 11698	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdecisively and his large fierce eyes scowled intelligently over all
 11699	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir faces.
 11700	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11701	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Are the conscript fathers pursuing their peaceful deliberations? he
 11702	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaid with rich acrid utterance to the assistant town clerk.
 11703	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11704	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHell open to christians they were having, Jimmy Henry said pettishly,
 11705	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabout their damned Irish language. Where was the marshal, he wanted
 11706	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto know, to keep order in the council chamber. And old Barlow the
 11707	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmacebearer laid up with asthma, no mace on the table, nothing in order,
 11708	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tno quorum even, and Hutchinson, the lord mayor, in Llandudno and little
 11709	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLorcan Sherlock doing locum tenens for him. Damned Irish language,
 11710	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlanguage of our forefathers.
 11711	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11712	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLong John Fanning blew a plume of smoke from his lips.
 11713	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11714	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMartin Cunningham spoke by turns, twirling the peak of his beard, to the
 11715	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tassistant town clerk and the subsheriff, while John Wyse Nolan held his
 11716	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpeace.
 11717	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11718	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What Dignam was that? long John Fanning asked.
 11719	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11720	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJimmy Henry made a grimace and lifted his left foot.
 11721	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11722	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, my corns! he said plaintively. Come upstairs for goodness’ sake till
 11723	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI sit down somewhere. Uff! Ooo! Mind!
 11724	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11725	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTestily he made room for himself beside long John Fanning’s flank and
 11726	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpassed in and up the stairs.
 11727	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11728	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Come on up, Martin Cunningham said to the subsheriff. I don’t think you
 11729	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknew him or perhaps you did, though.
 11730	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11731	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWith John Wyse Nolan Mr Power followed them in.
 11732	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11733	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Decent little soul he was, Mr Power said to the stalwart back of long
 11734	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJohn Fanning ascending towards long John Fanning in the mirror.
 11735	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11736	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Rather lowsized. Dignam of Menton’s office that was, Martin Cunningham
 11737	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaid.
 11738	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11739	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLong John Fanning could not remember him.
 11740	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11741	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tClatter of horsehoofs sounded from the air.
 11742	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11743	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What’s that? Martin Cunningham said.
 11744	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11745	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAll turned where they stood. John Wyse Nolan came down again. From the
 11746	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcool shadow of the doorway he saw the horses pass Parliament street,
 11747	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tharness and glossy pasterns in sunlight shimmering. Gaily they went past
 11748	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbefore his cool unfriendly eyes, not quickly. In saddles of the leaders,
 11749	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tleaping leaders, rode outriders.
 11750	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11751	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What was it? Martin Cunningham asked, as they went on up the staircase.
 11752	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11753	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The lord lieutenantgeneral and general governor of Ireland, John Wyse
 11754	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNolan answered from the stairfoot.
 11755	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11756	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAs they trod across the thick carpet Buck Mulligan whispered behind his
 11757	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPanama to Haines:
 11758	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11759	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Parnell’s brother. There in the corner.
 11760	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11761	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey chose a small table near the window, opposite a longfaced man whose
 11762	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeard and gaze hung intently down on a chessboard.
 11763	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11764	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Is that he? Haines asked, twisting round in his seat.
 11765	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11766	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, Mulligan said. That’s John Howard, his brother, our city marshal.
 11767	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11768	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJohn Howard Parnell translated a white bishop quietly and his grey claw
 11769	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twent up again to his forehead whereat it rested. An instant after, under
 11770	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tits screen, his eyes looked quickly, ghostbright, at his foe and fell
 11771	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tonce more upon a working corner.
 11772	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11773	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’ll take a mélange, Haines said to the waitress.
 11774	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11775	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Two mélanges, Buck Mulligan said. And bring us some scones and butter
 11776	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand some cakes as well.
 11777	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11778	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhen she had gone he said, laughing:
 11779	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11780	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—We call it D.B.C. because they have damn bad cakes. O, but you missed
 11781	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDedalus on Hamlet.
 11782	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11783	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHaines opened his newbought book.
 11784	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11785	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’m sorry, he said. Shakespeare is the happy huntingground of all minds
 11786	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat have lost their balance.
 11787	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11788	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe onelegged sailor growled at the area of 14 Nelson street:
 11789	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11790	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—England expects...
 11791	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11792	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan’s primrose waistcoat shook gaily to his laughter.
 11793	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11794	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You should see him, he said, when his body loses its balance. Wandering
 11795	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tÆngus I call him.
 11796	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11797	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I am sure he has an idée fixe, Haines said, pinching his chin
 11798	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthoughtfully with thumb and forefinger. Now I am speculating what it
 11799	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twould be likely to be. Such persons always have.
 11800	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11801	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan bent across the table gravely.
 11802	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11803	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—They drove his wits astray, he said, by visions of hell. He will never
 11804	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcapture the Attic note. The note of Swinburne, of all poets, the white
 11805	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeath and the ruddy birth. That is his tragedy. He can never be a poet.
 11806	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe joy of creation...
 11807	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11808	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Eternal punishment, Haines said, nodding curtly. I see. I tackled him
 11809	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthis morning on belief. There was something on his mind, I saw.
 11810	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIt’s rather interesting because professor Pokorny of Vienna makes an
 11811	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinteresting point out of that.
 11812	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11813	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan’s watchful eyes saw the waitress come. He helped her to
 11814	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunload her tray.
 11815	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11816	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He can find no trace of hell in ancient Irish myth, Haines said, amid
 11817	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe cheerful cups. The moral idea seems lacking, the sense of destiny,
 11818	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof retribution. Rather strange he should have just that fixed idea. Does
 11819	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the write anything for your movement?
 11820	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11821	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe sank two lumps of sugar deftly longwise through the whipped cream.
 11822	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuck Mulligan slit a steaming scone in two and plastered butter over its
 11823	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsmoking pith. He bit off a soft piece hungrily.
 11824	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11825	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ten years, he said, chewing and laughing. He is going to write
 11826	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsomething in ten years.
 11827	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11828	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Seems a long way off, Haines said, thoughtfully lifting his spoon.
 11829	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStill, I shouldn’t wonder if he did after all.
 11830	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11831	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe tasted a spoonful from the creamy cone of his cup.
 11832	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11833	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—This is real Irish cream I take it, he said with forbearance. I don’t
 11834	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twant to be imposed on.
 11835	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11836	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tElijah, skiff, light crumpled throwaway, sailed eastward by flanks of
 11837	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tships and trawlers, amid an archipelago of corks, beyond new Wapping
 11838	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstreet past Benson’s ferry, and by the threemasted schooner Rosevean
 11839	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom Bridgwater with bricks.
 11840	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11841	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAlmidano Artifoni walked past Holles street, past Sewell’s yard.
 11842	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBehind him Cashel Boyle O’Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell, with
 11843	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstickumbrelladustcoat dangling, shunned the lamp before Mr Law Smith’s
 11844	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thouse and, crossing, walked along Merrion square. Distantly behind him a
 11845	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblind stripling tapped his way by the wall of College park.
 11846	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11847	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCashel Boyle O’Connor Fitzmaurice Tisdall Farrell walked as far as
 11848	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Lewis Werner’s cheerful windows, then turned and strode back along
 11849	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMerrion square, his stickumbrelladustcoat dangling.
 11850	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11851	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAt the corner of Wilde’s house he halted, frowned at Elijah’s name
 11852	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tannounced on the Metropolitan hall, frowned at the distant pleasance of
 11853	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tduke’s lawn. His eyeglass flashed frowning in the sun. With ratsteeth
 11854	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbared he muttered:
 11855	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11856	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Coactus volui.
 11857	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11858	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe strode on for Clare street, grinding his fierce word.
 11859	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11860	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAs he strode past Mr Bloom’s dental windows the sway of his dustcoat
 11861	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrushed rudely from its angle a slender tapping cane and swept onwards,
 11862	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thaving buffeted a thewless body. The blind stripling turned his sickly
 11863	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tface after the striding form.
 11864	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11865	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—God’s curse on you, he said sourly, whoever you are! You’re blinder nor
 11866	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI am, you bitch’s bastard!
 11867	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11868	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOpposite Ruggy O’Donohoe’s Master Patrick Aloysius Dignam, pawing the
 11869	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpound and a half of Mangan’s, late Fehrenbach’s, porksteaks he had been
 11870	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsent for, went along warm Wicklow street dawdling. It was too blooming
 11871	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdull sitting in the parlour with Mrs Stoer and Mrs Quigley and Mrs
 11872	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMacDowell and the blind down and they all at their sniffles and sipping
 11873	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsups of the superior tawny sherry uncle Barney brought from Tunney’s.
 11874	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd they eating crumbs of the cottage fruitcake, jawing the whole
 11875	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblooming time and sighing.
 11876	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11877	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAfter Wicklow lane the window of Madame Doyle, courtdress milliner,
 11878	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstopped him. He stood looking in at the two puckers stripped to their
 11879	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpelts and putting up their props. From the sidemirrors two mourning
 11880	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMasters Dignam gaped silently. Myler Keogh, Dublin’s pet lamb, will
 11881	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmeet sergeantmajor Bennett, the Portobello bruiser, for a purse of fifty
 11882	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsovereigns. Gob, that’d be a good pucking match to see. Myler Keogh,
 11883	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat’s the chap sparring out to him with the green sash. Two bar
 11884	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tentrance, soldiers half price. I could easy do a bunk on ma. Master
 11885	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDignam on his left turned as he turned. That’s me in mourning. When
 11886	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis it? May the twentysecond. Sure, the blooming thing is all over. He
 11887	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tturned to the right and on his right Master Dignam turned, his cap awry,
 11888	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this collar sticking up. Buttoning it down, his chin lifted, he saw the
 11889	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\timage of Marie Kendall, charming soubrette, beside the two puckers. One
 11890	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof them mots that do be in the packets of fags Stoer smokes that his old
 11891	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfellow welted hell out of him for one time he found out.
 11892	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11893	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMaster Dignam got his collar down and dawdled on. The best pucker going
 11894	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor strength was Fitzsimons. One puck in the wind from that fellow would
 11895	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknock you into the middle of next week, man. But the best pucker for
 11896	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tscience was Jem Corbet before Fitzsimons knocked the stuffings out of
 11897	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim, dodging and all.
 11898	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11899	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn Grafton street Master Dignam saw a red flower in a toff’s mouth and
 11900	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta swell pair of kicks on him and he listening to what the drunk was
 11901	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttelling him and grinning all the time.
 11902	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11903	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNo Sandymount tram.
 11904	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11905	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMaster Dignam walked along Nassau street, shifted the porksteaks to
 11906	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this other hand. His collar sprang up again and he tugged it down. The
 11907	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblooming stud was too small for the buttonhole of the shirt, blooming
 11908	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tend to it. He met schoolboys with satchels. I’m not going tomorrow
 11909	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teither, stay away till Monday. He met other schoolboys. Do they notice
 11910	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI’m in mourning? Uncle Barney said he’d get it into the paper tonight.
 11911	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThen they’ll all see it in the paper and read my name printed and pa’s
 11912	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tname.
 11913	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11914	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis face got all grey instead of being red like it was and there was a
 11915	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfly walking over it up to his eye. The scrunch that was when they
 11916	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twere screwing the screws into the coffin: and the bumps when they were
 11917	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbringing it downstairs.
 11918	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11919	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPa was inside it and ma crying in the parlour and uncle Barney telling
 11920	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe men how to get it round the bend. A big coffin it was, and high and
 11921	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theavylooking. How was that? The last night pa was boosed he was standing
 11922	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton the landing there bawling out for his boots to go out to Tunney’s for
 11923	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto boose more and he looked butty and short in his shirt. Never see him
 11924	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tagain. Death, that is. Pa is dead. My father is dead. He told me to be
 11925	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta good son to ma. I couldn’t hear the other things he said but I saw
 11926	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this tongue and his teeth trying to say it better. Poor pa. That was
 11927	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Dignam, my father. I hope he’s in purgatory now because he went to
 11928	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconfession to Father Conroy on Saturday night.
 11929	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11930	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWilliam Humble, earl of Dudley, and lady Dudley, accompanied by
 11931	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlieutenantcolonel Heseltine, drove out after luncheon from the viceregal
 11932	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlodge. In the following carriage were the honourable Mrs Paget, Miss de
 11933	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCourcy and the honourable Gerald Ward A.D.C. in attendance.
 11934	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 11935	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe cavalcade passed out by the lower gate of Phoenix park saluted by
 11936	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tobsequious policemen and proceeded past Kingsbridge along the northern
 11937	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquays. The viceroy was most cordially greeted on his way through the
 11938	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmetropolis. At Bloody bridge Mr Thomas Kernan beyond the river greeted
 11939	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim vainly from afar. Between Queen’s and Whitworth bridges lord
 11940	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDudley’s viceregal carriages passed and were unsaluted by Mr Dudley
 11941	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhite, B. L., M. A., who stood on Arran quay outside Mrs M. E. White’s,
 11942	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe pawnbroker’s, at the corner of Arran street west stroking his nose
 11943	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith his forefinger, undecided whether he should arrive at Phibsborough
 11944	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmore quickly by a triple change of tram or by hailing a car or on foot
 11945	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthrough Smithfield, Constitution hill and Broadstone terminus. In the
 11946	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tporch of Four Courts Richie Goulding with the costbag of Goulding,
 11947	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCollis and Ward saw him with surprise. Past Richmond bridge at the
 11948	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoorstep of the office of Reuben J Dodd, solicitor, agent for the
 11949	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPatriotic Insurance Company, an elderly female about to enter changed
 11950	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther plan and retracing her steps by King’s windows smiled credulously
 11951	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton the representative of His Majesty. From its sluice in Wood quay wall
 11952	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunder Tom Devan’s office Poddle river hung out in fealty a tongue of
 11953	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tliquid sewage. Above the crossblind of the Ormond hotel, gold by bronze,
 11954	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMiss Kennedy’s head by Miss Douce’s head watched and admired. On Ormond
 11955	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquay Mr Simon Dedalus, steering his way from the greenhouse for the
 11956	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsubsheriff’s office, stood still in midstreet and brought his hat low.
 11957	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis Excellency graciously returned Mr Dedalus’ greeting. From Cahill’s
 11958	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcorner the reverend Hugh C. Love, M.A., made obeisance unperceived,
 11959	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmindful of lords deputies whose hands benignant had held of yore rich
 11960	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tadvowsons. On Grattan bridge Lenehan and M’Coy, taking leave of each
 11961	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tother, watched the carriages go by. Passing by Roger Greene’s office and
 11962	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDollard’s big red printinghouse Gerty MacDowell, carrying the Catesby’s
 11963	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcork lino letters for her father who was laid up, knew by the style
 11964	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit was the lord and lady lieutenant but she couldn’t see what Her
 11965	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tExcellency had on because the tram and Spring’s big yellow furniture van
 11966	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thad to stop in front of her on account of its being the lord lieutenant.
 11967	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBeyond Lundy Foot’s from the shaded door of Kavanagh’s winerooms
 11968	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJohn Wyse Nolan smiled with unseen coldness towards the lord
 11969	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlieutenantgeneral and general governor of Ireland. The Right Honourable
 11970	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWilliam Humble, earl of Dudley, G. C. V. O., passed Micky Anderson’s all
 11971	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttimes ticking watches and Henry and James’s wax smartsuited freshcheeked
 11972	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmodels, the gentleman Henry, dernier cri James. Over against Dame gate
 11973	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTom Rochford and Nosey Flynn watched the approach of the cavalcade. Tom
 11974	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRochford, seeing the eyes of lady Dudley fixed on him, took his thumbs
 11975	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquickly out of the pockets of his claret waistcoat and doffed his cap
 11976	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto her. A charming soubrette, great Marie Kendall, with dauby cheeks and
 11977	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlifted skirt smiled daubily from her poster upon William Humble, earl
 11978	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof Dudley, and upon lieutenantcolonel H. G. Heseltine, and also upon
 11979	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe honourable Gerald Ward A. D. C. From the window of the D. B. C. Buck
 11980	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMulligan gaily, and Haines gravely, gazed down on the viceregal equipage
 11981	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tover the shoulders of eager guests, whose mass of forms darkened the
 11982	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchessboard whereon John Howard Parnell looked intently. In Fownes’s
 11983	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstreet Dilly Dedalus, straining her sight upward from Chardenal’s first
 11984	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFrench primer, saw sunshades spanned and wheelspokes spinning in the
 11985	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tglare. John Henry Menton, filling the doorway of Commercial Buildings,
 11986	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstared from winebig oyster eyes, holding a fat gold hunter watch not
 11987	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlooked at in his fat left hand not feeling it. Where the foreleg of King
 11988	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBilly’s horse pawed the air Mrs Breen plucked her hastening husband
 11989	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tback from under the hoofs of the outriders. She shouted in his ear the
 11990	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttidings. Understanding, he shifted his tomes to his left breast
 11991	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand saluted the second carriage. The honourable Gerald Ward A.D.C.,
 11992	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tagreeably surprised, made haste to reply. At Ponsonby’s corner a jaded
 11993	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhite flagon H. halted and four tallhatted white flagons halted behind
 11994	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim, E.L.Y.‘S, while outriders pranced past and carriages. Opposite
 11995	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPigott’s music warerooms Mr Denis J Maginni, professor of dancing &c,
 11996	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgaily apparelled, gravely walked, outpassed by a viceroy and unobserved.
 11997	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBy the provost’s wall came jauntily Blazes Boylan, stepping in tan shoes
 11998	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand socks with skyblue clocks to the refrain of My girl’s a Yorkshire
 11999	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgirl.

 12001	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBlazes Boylan presented to the leaders’ skyblue frontlets and high
 12002	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taction a skyblue tie, a widebrimmed straw hat at a rakish angle and a
 12003	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsuit of indigo serge. His hands in his jacket pockets forgot to salute
 12004	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbut he offered to the three ladies the bold admiration of his eyes and
 12005	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe red flower between his lips. As they drove along Nassau street His
 12006	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tExcellency drew the attention of his bowing consort to the programme of
 12007	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmusic which was being discoursed in College park. Unseen brazen highland
 12008	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tladdies blared and drumthumped after the cortège:

 12026	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPatrick Aloysius Dignam, waiting, saw salutes being given to the gent
 12027	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith the topper and raised also his new black cap with fingers greased
 12028	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby porksteak paper. His collar too sprang up. The viceroy, on his way to
 12029	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinaugurate the Mirus bazaar in aid of funds for Mercer’s hospital,

 12031	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstripling opposite Broadbent’s. In Lower Mount street a pedestrian in a
 12032	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrown macintosh, eating dry bread, passed swiftly and unscathed across
 12033	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe viceroy’s path. At the Royal Canal bridge, from his hoarding,
 12034	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Eugene Stratton, his blub lips agrin, bade all comers welcome to
 12035	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPembroke township. At Haddington road corner two sanded women halted
 12036	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthemselves, an umbrella and a bag in which eleven cockles rolled to view
 12037	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith wonder the lord mayor and lady mayoress without his golden chain.

 12042	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprince consort, in 1849 and the salute of Almidano Artifoni’s sturdy
 12043	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttrousers swallowed by a closing door.

 12144	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBronzelydia by Minagold.

 12150	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPray for him! Pray, good people!

 12176	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBronze by gold, miss Douce’s head by miss Kennedy’s head, over the
 12177	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcrossblind of the Ormond bar heard the viceregal hoofs go by, ringing
 12178	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsteel.
 12179	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12180	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Is that her? asked miss Kennedy.
 12181	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12182	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMiss Douce said yes, sitting with his ex, pearl grey and eau de Nil.
 12183	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12184	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Exquisite contrast, miss Kennedy said.
 12185	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12186	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhen all agog miss Douce said eagerly:
 12187	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12188	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Look at the fellow in the tall silk.
 12189	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12190	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who? Where? gold asked more eagerly.
 12191	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12192	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—In the second carriage, miss Douce’s wet lips said, laughing in the
 12193	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsun.
 12194	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12195	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe’s looking. Mind till I see.
 12196	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12197	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe darted, bronze, to the backmost corner, flattening her face against

 12201	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 12203	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12204	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe laughed:
 12205	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12206	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O wept! Aren’t men frightful idiots?
 12207	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12208	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWith sadness.
 12209	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12210	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMiss Kennedy sauntered sadly from bright light, twining a loose hair
 12211	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbehind an ear. Sauntering sadly, gold no more, she twisted twined a

 12213	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12214	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—It’s them has the fine times, sadly then she said.
 12215	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12216	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA man.
 12217	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12218	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBloowho went by by Moulang’s pipes bearing in his breast the sweets
 12219	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof sin, by Wine’s antiques, in memory bearing sweet sinful words, by
 12220	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCarroll’s dusky battered plate, for Raoul.

 12222	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe boots to them, them in the bar, them barmaids came. For them

 12224	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 12226	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12227	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMiss Kennedy with manners transposed the teatray down to an upturned
 12228	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlithia crate, safe from eyes, low.
 12229	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12230	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What is it? loud boots unmannerly asked.
 12231	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 12233	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12234	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Your beau, is it?
 12235	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12236	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA haughty bronze replied:

 12239	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\timpertinent insolence.

 12249	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twring his ear for him a yard long.
 12250	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12251	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLadylike in exquisite contrast.
 12252	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 12257	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twaiting for their teas to draw. They pawed their blouses, both of black
 12258	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsatin, two and nine a yard, waiting for their teas to draw, and two and
 12259	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseven.
 12260	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 12283	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12284	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMiss Kennedy, pouring now a fulldrawn tea, grimaced and prayed:

 12308	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 12321	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 12324	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBloowhose dark eye read Aaron Figatner’s name. Why do I always think

 12327	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunder, come to me. God they believe she is: or goddess. Those today. I

 12329	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe might be Mulligan. All comely virgins. That brings those rakes of
 12330	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfellows in: her white.

 12376	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoors as I. Religion pays. Must see him for that par. Eat first. I want.

 12429	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbe a great tonic in the air down there. But a long threatening comes at
 12430	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlast, they say. Yes. Yes.

 12434	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12435	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNone nought said nothing. Yes.
 12436	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12437	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGaily miss Douce polished a tumbler, trilling:
 12438	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12439	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, Idolores, queen of the eastern seas!
 12440	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12441	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Was Mr Lidwell in today?

 12443	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn came Lenehan. Round him peered Lenehan. Mr Bloom reached Essex
 12444	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbridge. Yes, Mr Bloom crossed bridge of Yessex. To Martha I must write.
 12445	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuy paper. Daly’s. Girl there civil. Bloom. Old Bloom. Blue bloom is on
 12446	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe rye.
 12447	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 12450	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLenehan came forward.

 12459	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgaze upon a page:
 12460	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 12486	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12487	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Greetings from the famous son of a famous father.
 12488	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12489	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who may he be? Mr Dedalus asked.
 12490	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12491	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLenehan opened most genial arms. Who?
 12492	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12493	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who may he be? he asked. Can you ask? Stephen, the youthful bard.
 12494	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12495	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDry.
 12496	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12497	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Dedalus, famous father, laid by his dry filled pipe.
 12498	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12499	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I see, he said. I didn’t recognise him for the moment. I hear he is
 12500	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tkeeping very select company. Have you seen him lately?
 12501	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12502	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe had.
 12503	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12504	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I quaffed the nectarbowl with him this very day, said Lenehan. In
 12505	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMooney’s en ville and in Mooney’s sur mer. He had received the rhino for
 12506	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe labour of his muse.
 12507	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12508	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe smiled at bronze’s teabathed lips, at listening lips and eyes:
 12509	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12510	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The élite of Erin hung upon his lips. The ponderous pundit, Hugh
 12511	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMacHugh, Dublin’s most brilliant scribe and editor and that minstrel boy
 12512	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the wild wet west who is known by the euphonious appellation of the
 12513	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tO’Madden Burke.
 12514	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12515	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAfter an interval Mr Dedalus raised his grog and
 12516	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12517	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That must have been highly diverting, said he. I see.
 12518	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12519	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe see. He drank. With faraway mourning mountain eye. Set down his
 12520	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tglass.
 12521	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12522	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe looked towards the saloon door.
 12523	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12524	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I see you have moved the piano.
 12525	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12526	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The tuner was in today, miss Douce replied, tuning it for the smoking
 12527	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconcert and I never heard such an exquisite player.
 12528	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12529	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Is that a fact?
 12530	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12531	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Didn’t he, miss Kennedy? The real classical, you know. And blind too,
 12532	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoor fellow. Not twenty I’m sure he was.
 12533	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12534	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Is that a fact? Mr Dedalus said.
 12535	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12536	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe drank and strayed away.
 12537	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12538	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—So sad to look at his face, miss Douce condoled.
 12539	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12540	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGod’s curse on bitch’s bastard.
 12541	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12542	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTink to her pity cried a diner’s bell. To the door of the bar and
 12543	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdiningroom came bald Pat, came bothered Pat, came Pat, waiter of Ormond.
 12544	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLager for diner. Lager without alacrity she served.
 12545	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12546	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWith patience Lenehan waited for Boylan with impatience, for
 12547	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjinglejaunty blazes boy.
 12548	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12549	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tUpholding the lid he (who?) gazed in the coffin (coffin?) at the oblique
 12550	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttriple (piano!) wires. He pressed (the same who pressed indulgently her
 12551	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thand), soft pedalling, a triple of keys to see the thicknesses of felt
 12552	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tadvancing, to hear the muffled hammerfall in action.
 12553	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12554	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTwo sheets cream vellum paper one reserve two envelopes when I was in
 12555	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWisdom Hely’s wise Bloom in Daly’s Henry Flower bought. Are you not
 12556	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thappy in your home? Flower to console me and a pin cuts lo. Means
 12557	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsomething, language of flow. Was it a daisy? Innocence that is.
 12558	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRespectable girl meet after mass. Thanks awfully muchly. Wise Bloom eyed
 12559	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton the door a poster, a swaying mermaid smoking mid nice waves. Smoke
 12560	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmermaids, coolest whiff of all. Hair streaming: lovelorn. For some man.
 12561	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFor Raoul. He eyed and saw afar on Essex bridge a gay hat riding on a
 12562	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjaunting car. It is. Again. Third time. Coincidence.
 12563	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12564	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJingling on supple rubbers it jaunted from the bridge to Ormond quay.
 12565	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFollow. Risk it. Go quick. At four. Near now. Out.
 12566	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12567	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Twopence, sir, the shopgirl dared to say.
 12568	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12569	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Aha... I was forgetting... Excuse...
 12570	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12571	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And four.
 12572	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12573	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAt four she. Winsomely she on Bloohimwhom smiled. Bloo smi qui go.
 12574	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTernoon. Think you’re the only pebble on the beach? Does that to all.
 12575	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12576	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFor men.
 12577	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12578	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn drowsy silence gold bent on her page.
 12579	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12580	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFrom the saloon a call came, long in dying. That was a tuningfork the
 12581	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttuner had that he forgot that he now struck. A call again. That he now
 12582	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoised that it now throbbed. You hear? It throbbed, pure, purer, softly
 12583	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand softlier, its buzzing prongs. Longer in dying call.
 12584	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12585	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPat paid for diner’s popcorked bottle: and over tumbler, tray and
 12586	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpopcorked bottle ere he went he whispered, bald and bothered, with miss
 12587	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDouce.
 12588	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12589	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The bright stars fade...
 12590	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12591	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA voiceless song sang from within, singing:
 12592	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12593	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—... the morn is breaking.
 12594	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12595	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA duodene of birdnotes chirruped bright treble answer under sensitive
 12596	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thands. Brightly the keys, all twinkling, linked, all harpsichording,
 12597	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcalled to a voice to sing the strain of dewy morn, of youth, of love’s
 12598	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tleavetaking, life’s, love’s morn.
 12599	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12600	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The dewdrops pearl...
 12601	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12602	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLenehan’s lips over the counter lisped a low whistle of decoy.
 12603	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12604	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—But look this way, he said, rose of Castile.
 12605	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12606	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJingle jaunted by the curb and stopped.
 12607	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12608	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe rose and closed her reading, rose of Castile: fretted, forlorn,
 12609	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdreamily rose.
 12610	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12611	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Did she fall or was she pushed? he asked her.
 12612	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12613	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe answered, slighting:
 12614	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12615	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ask no questions and you’ll hear no lies.
 12616	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12617	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLike lady, ladylike.
 12618	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12619	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBlazes Boylan’s smart tan shoes creaked on the barfloor where he strode.
 12620	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYes, gold from anear by bronze from afar. Lenehan heard and knew and
 12621	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thailed him:
 12622	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12623	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—See the conquering hero comes.
 12624	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12625	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBetween the car and window, warily walking, went Bloom, unconquered
 12626	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thero. See me he might. The seat he sat on: warm. Black wary hecat walked
 12627	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttowards Richie Goulding’s legal bag, lifted aloft, saluting.
 12628	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12629	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And I from thee...
 12630	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12631	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I heard you were round, said Blazes Boylan.
 12632	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12633	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe touched to fair miss Kennedy a rim of his slanted straw. She smiled
 12634	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton him. But sister bronze outsmiled her, preening for him her richer
 12635	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thair, a bosom and a rose.
 12636	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12637	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSmart Boylan bespoke potions.
 12638	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12639	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What’s your cry? Glass of bitter? Glass of bitter, please, and a
 12640	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsloegin for me. Wire in yet?
 12641	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12642	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNot yet. At four she. Who said four?
 12643	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12644	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCowley’s red lugs and bulging apple in the door of the sheriff’s office.
 12645	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12646	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAvoid. Goulding a chance. What is he doing in the Ormond? Car waiting.
 12647	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWait.
 12648	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12649	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHello. Where off to? Something to eat? I too was just. In here. What,
 12650	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOrmond? Best value in Dublin. Is that so? Diningroom. Sit tight there.
 12651	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSee, not be seen. I think I’ll join you. Come on. Richie led on. Bloom
 12652	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfollowed bag. Dinner fit for a prince.
 12653	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12654	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMiss Douce reached high to take a flagon, stretching her satin arm, her
 12655	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbust, that all but burst, so high.
 12656	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12657	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O! O! jerked Lenehan, gasping at each stretch. O!
 12658	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12659	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBut easily she seized her prey and led it low in triumph.
 12660	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12661	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Why don’t you grow? asked Blazes Boylan.
 12662	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12663	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShebronze, dealing from her oblique jar thick syrupy liquor for his
 12664	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlips, looked as it flowed (flower in his coat: who gave him?), and
 12665	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsyrupped with her voice:
 12666	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12667	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Fine goods in small parcels.
 12668	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 12670	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12671	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Here’s fortune, Blazes said.
 12672	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 12674	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 12679	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Sceptre will win in a canter, he said.

 12682	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknow. Fancy of a friend of mine.
 12683	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12684	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLenehan still drank and grinned at his tilted ale and at miss Douce’s
 12685	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlips that all but hummed, not shut, the oceansong her lips had trilled.
 12686	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIdolores. The eastern seas.
 12687	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12688	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tClock whirred. Miss Kennedy passed their way (flower, wonder who gave),
 12689	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbearing away teatray. Clock clacked.
 12690	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12691	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMiss Douce took Boylan’s coin, struck boldly the cashregister. It
 12692	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tclanged. Clock clacked. Fair one of Egypt teased and sorted in the till
 12693	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand hummed and handed coins in change. Look to the west. A clack. For
 12694	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tme.
 12695	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12696	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What time is that? asked Blazes Boylan. Four?

 12705	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe bag of Goulding, Collis, Ward led Bloom by ryebloom flowered tables.
 12706	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAimless he chose with agitated aim, bald Pat attending, a table near
 12707	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe door. Be near. At four. Has he forgotten? Perhaps a trick. Not come:
 12708	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhet appetite. I couldn’t do. Wait, wait. Pat, waiter, waited.
 12709	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12710	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSparkling bronze azure eyed Blazure’s skyblue bow and eyes.

 12712	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Go on, pressed Lenehan. There’s no-one. He never heard.

 12714	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—... to Flora’s lips did hie.
 12715	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12716	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHigh, a high note pealed in the treble clear.

 12724	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12725	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I could not leave thee...
 12726	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12727	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Afterwits, miss Douce promised coyly.
 12728	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12729	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—No, now, urged Lenehan. Sonnez la cloche! O do! There’s no-one.
 12730	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12731	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe looked. Quick. Miss Kenn out of earshot. Sudden bent. Two kindling
 12732	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfaces watched her bend.
 12733	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12734	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tQuavering the chords strayed from the air, found it again, lost chord,
 12735	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand lost and found it, faltering.
 12736	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 12740	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem still, bending, suspending, with wilful eyes.

 12742	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Sonnez!

 12745	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsmackwarm against her smackable a woman’s warmhosed thigh.
 12746	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12747	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—La cloche! cried gleeful Lenehan. Trained by owner. No sawdust there.
 12748	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12749	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe smilesmirked supercilious (wept! aren’t men?), but, lightward
 12750	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgliding, mild she smiled on Boylan.
 12751	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12752	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You’re the essence of vulgarity, she in gliding said.
 12753	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12754	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBoylan, eyed, eyed. Tossed to fat lips his chalice, drank off his

 12756	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teyes went after, after her gliding head as it went down the bar by
 12757	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmirrors, gilded arch for ginger ale, hock and claret glasses shimmering,
 12758	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta spiky shell, where it concerted, mirrored, bronze with sunnier bronze.
 12759	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12760	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYes, bronze from anearby.
 12761	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 12763	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 12765	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 12767	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12768	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Wait a shake, begged Lenehan, drinking quickly. I wanted to tell you.
 12769	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTom Rochford...
 12770	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12771	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Come on to blazes, said Blazes Boylan, going.
 12772	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12773	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLenehan gulped to go.
 12774	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12775	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Got the horn or what? he said. Wait. I’m coming.
 12776	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12777	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe followed the hasty creaking shoes but stood by nimbly by the
 12778	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthreshold, saluting forms, a bulky with a slender.
 12779	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12780	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—How do you do, Mr Dollard?
 12781	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12782	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Eh? How do? How do? Ben Dollard’s vague bass answered, turning an
 12783	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinstant from Father Cowley’s woe. He won’t give you any trouble, Bob.
 12784	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAlf Bergan will speak to the long fellow. We’ll put a barleystraw in
 12785	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat Judas Iscariot’s ear this time.
 12786	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12787	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSighing Mr Dedalus came through the saloon, a finger soothing an eyelid.
 12788	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12789	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Hoho, we will, Ben Dollard yodled jollily. Come on, Simon. Give us a
 12790	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tditty. We heard the piano.
 12791	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12792	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBald Pat, bothered waiter, waited for drink orders. Power for Richie.
 12793	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd Bloom? Let me see. Not make him walk twice. His corns. Four now. How
 12794	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twarm this black is. Course nerves a bit. Refracts (is it?) heat. Let me
 12795	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsee. Cider. Yes, bottle of cider.
 12796	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12797	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What’s that? Mr Dedalus said. I was only vamping, man.
 12798	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12799	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Come on, come on, Ben Dollard called. Begone dull care. Come, Bob.
 12800	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12801	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe ambled Dollard, bulky slops, before them (hold that fellow with the:
 12802	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thold him now) into the saloon. He plumped him Dollard on the stool. His
 12803	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgouty paws plumped chords. Plumped, stopped abrupt.
 12804	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12805	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBald Pat in the doorway met tealess gold returning. Bothered, he wanted
 12806	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPower and cider. Bronze by the window, watched, bronze from afar.
 12807	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12808	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJingle a tinkle jaunted.
 12809	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 12810	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBloom heard a jing, a little sound. He’s off. Light sob of breath Bloom
 12811	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsighed on the silent bluehued flowers. Jingling. He’s gone. Jingle.
 12812	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHear.

 13343	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplus six is seven. Do anything you like with figures juggling. Always

 13406	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjingled. By Dlugacz’ porkshop bright tubes of Agendath trotted a
 13407	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgallantbuttocked mare.

 13410	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 13411	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, Mr Bloom said. Town traveller. Nothing doing, I expect.

 13434	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tToo poetical that about the sad. Music did that. Music hath charms.
 13435	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShakespeare said. Quotations every day in the year. To be or not to be.
 13436	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWisdom while you wait.

 13442	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEnough. Barney Kiernan’s I promised to meet them. Dislike that job.

 13478	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfaintly that that they heard, each for herself alone, then each for
 13479	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tother, hearing the plash of waves, loudly, a silent roar.
 13480	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 13481	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBronze by a weary gold, anear, afar, they listened.
 13482	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 13483	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHer ear too is a shell, the peeping lobe there. Been to the seaside.
 13484	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLovely seaside girls. Skin tanned raw. Should have put on coldcream
 13485	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfirst make it brown. Buttered toast. O and that lotion mustn’t forget.
 13486	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFever near her mouth. Your head it simply. Hair braided over: shell with
 13487	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseaweed. Why do they hide their ears with seaweed hair? And Turks the
 13488	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmouth, why? Her eyes over the sheet. Yashmak. Find the way in. A cave.

 13688	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBlank face. Virgin should say: or fingered only. Write something on it:
 13689	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpage. If not what becomes of them? Decline, despair. Keeps them young.
 13690	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEven admire themselves. See. Play on her. Lip blow. Body of white woman,
 13691	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta flute alive. Blow gentle. Loud. Three holes, all women. Goddess I
 13692	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdidn’t see. They want it. Not too much polite. That’s why he gets them.
 13693	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGold in your pocket, brass in your face. Say something. Make her hear.
 13694	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWith look to look. Songs without words. Molly, that hurdygurdy boy.
 13695	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe knew he meant the monkey was sick. Or because so like the Spanish.
 13696	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tUnderstand animals too that way. Solomon did. Gift of nature.

 13703	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbastard. A good thought, boy, to come. One hour’s your time to live,
 13704	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyour last.

 13710	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPurefoy. Hope she’s over. Because their wombs.

 13712	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA liquid of womb of woman eyeball gazed under a fence of lashes, calmly,
 13713	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thearing. See real beauty of the eye when she not speaks. On yonder
 13714	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\triver. At each slow satiny heaving bosom’s wave (her heaving embon) red
 13715	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trose rose slowly sank red rose. Heartbeats: her breath: breath that is
