 13994	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI was just passing the time of day with old Troy of the D. M. P. at the
 13995	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcorner of Arbour hill there and be damned but a bloody sweep came along
 13996	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand he near drove his gear into my eye. I turned around to let him have
 13997	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe weight of my tongue when who should I see dodging along Stony Batter
 13998	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tonly Joe Hynes.
 13999	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14000	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Lo, Joe, says I. How are you blowing? Did you see that bloody
 14001	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchimneysweep near shove my eye out with his brush?
 14002	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14003	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Soot’s luck, says Joe. Who’s the old ballocks you were talking to?
 14004	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14005	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Old Troy, says I, was in the force. I’m on two minds not to give that
 14006	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfellow in charge for obstructing the thoroughfare with his brooms and
 14007	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tladders.
 14008	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14009	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What are you doing round those parts? says Joe.
 14010	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14011	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Devil a much, says I. There’s a bloody big foxy thief beyond by the
 14012	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgarrison church at the corner of Chicken lane—old Troy was just giving
 14013	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tme a wrinkle about him—lifted any God’s quantity of tea and sugar to
 14014	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpay three bob a week said he had a farm in the county Down off a
 14015	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thop-of-my-thumb by the name of Moses Herzog over there near Heytesbury
 14016	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstreet.
 14017	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14018	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Circumcised? says Joe.
 14019	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14020	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ay, says I. A bit off the top. An old plumber named Geraghty. I’m
 14021	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thanging on to his taw now for the past fortnight and I can’t get a penny
 14022	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tout of him.
 14023	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14024	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That the lay you’re on now? says Joe.
 14025	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14026	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ay, says I. How are the mighty fallen! Collector of bad and doubtful
 14027	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdebts. But that’s the most notorious bloody robber you’d meet in a day’s
 14028	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twalk and the face on him all pockmarks would hold a shower of rain.
 14029	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTell him, says he, I dare him, says he, and I doubledare him to send
 14030	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou round here again or if he does, says he, I’ll have him summonsed up
 14031	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbefore the court, so I will, for trading without a licence. And he after
 14032	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstuffing himself till he’s fit to burst. Jesus, I had to laugh at the
 14033	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlittle jewy getting his shirt out. He drink me my teas. He eat me my
 14034	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsugars. Because he no pay me my moneys?
 14035	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14036	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFor nonperishable goods bought of Moses Herzog, of 13 Saint Kevin’s
 14037	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tparade in the city of Dublin, Wood quay ward, merchant, hereinafter
 14038	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcalled the vendor, and sold and delivered to Michael E. Geraghty,
 14039	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tesquire, of 29 Arbour hill in the city of Dublin, Arran quay ward,
 14040	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgentleman, hereinafter called the purchaser, videlicet, five pounds
 14041	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tavoirdupois of first choice tea at three shillings and no pence per
 14042	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpound avoirdupois and three stone avoirdupois of sugar, crushed crystal,
 14043	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat threepence per pound avoirdupois, the said purchaser debtor to the
 14044	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaid vendor of one pound five shillings and sixpence sterling for value
 14045	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treceived which amount shall be paid by said purchaser to said vendor in
 14046	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tweekly instalments every seven calendar days of three shillings and no
 14047	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpence sterling: and the said nonperishable goods shall not be pawned or
 14048	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpledged or sold or otherwise alienated by the said purchaser but shall
 14049	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbe and remain and be held to be the sole and exclusive property of the
 14050	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaid vendor to be disposed of at his good will and pleasure until the
 14051	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaid amount shall have been duly paid by the said purchaser to the said
 14052	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvendor in the manner herein set forth as this day hereby agreed between
 14053	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe said vendor, his heirs, successors, trustees and assigns of the one
 14054	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpart and the said purchaser, his heirs, successors, trustees and assigns
 14055	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the other part.
 14056	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14057	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Are you a strict t.t.? says Joe.
 14058	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14059	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Not taking anything between drinks, says I.
 14060	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14061	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What about paying our respects to our friend? says Joe.
 14062	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14063	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who? says I. Sure, he’s out in John of God’s off his head, poor man.
 14064	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14065	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Drinking his own stuff? says Joe.
 14066	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14067	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ay, says I. Whisky and water on the brain.
 14068	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14069	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Come around to Barney Kiernan’s, says Joe. I want to see the citizen.
 14070	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14071	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Barney mavourneen’s be it, says I. Anything strange or wonderful, Joe?
 14072	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14073	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Not a word, says Joe. I was up at that meeting in the City Arms.
 14074	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14075	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—-What was that, Joe? says I.
 14076	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14077	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Cattle traders, says Joe, about the foot and mouth disease. I want to
 14078	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgive the citizen the hard word about it.
 14079	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14080	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo we went around by the Linenhall barracks and the back of the
 14081	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcourthouse talking of one thing or another. Decent fellow Joe when he
 14082	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thas it but sure like that he never has it. Jesus, I couldn’t get over
 14083	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat bloody foxy Geraghty, the daylight robber. For trading without a
 14084	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlicence, says he.
 14085	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14086	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn Inisfail the fair there lies a land, the land of holy Michan. There
 14087	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trises a watchtower beheld of men afar. There sleep the mighty dead as in
 14088	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlife they slept, warriors and princes of high renown. A pleasant land
 14089	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit is in sooth of murmuring waters, fishful streams where sport the
 14090	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgurnard, the plaice, the roach, the halibut, the gibbed haddock, the
 14091	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgrilse, the dab, the brill, the flounder, the pollock, the mixed coarse
 14092	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfish generally and other denizens of the aqueous kingdom too numerous to
 14093	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbe enumerated. In the mild breezes of the west and of the east the lofty
 14094	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttrees wave in different directions their firstclass foliage, the wafty
 14095	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsycamore, the Lebanonian cedar, the exalted planetree, the eugenic
 14096	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teucalyptus and other ornaments of the arboreal world with which
 14097	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat region is thoroughly well supplied. Lovely maidens sit in close
 14098	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tproximity to the roots of the lovely trees singing the most lovely songs
 14099	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhile they play with all kinds of lovely objects as for example golden
 14100	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tingots, silvery fishes, crans of herrings, drafts of eels, codlings,
 14101	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcreels of fingerlings, purple seagems and playful insects. And heroes
 14102	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvoyage from afar to woo them, from Eblana to Slievemargy, the peerless
 14103	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprinces of unfettered Munster and of Connacht the just and of smooth
 14104	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsleek Leinster and of Cruachan’s land and of Armagh the splendid and of
 14105	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe noble district of Boyle, princes, the sons of kings.
 14106	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14107	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd there rises a shining palace whose crystal glittering roof is seen
 14108	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby mariners who traverse the extensive sea in barks built expressly for
 14109	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat purpose, and thither come all herds and fatlings and firstfruits
 14110	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof that land for O’Connell Fitzsimon takes toll of them, a chieftain
 14111	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdescended from chieftains. Thither the extremely large wains bring
 14112	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfoison of the fields, flaskets of cauliflowers, floats of spinach,
 14113	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpineapple chunks, Rangoon beans, strikes of tomatoes, drums of figs,
 14114	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrills of Swedes, spherical potatoes and tallies of iridescent kale,
 14115	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYork and Savoy, and trays of onions, pearls of the earth, and punnets of
 14116	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmushrooms and custard marrows and fat vetches and bere and rape and red
 14117	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgreen yellow brown russet sweet big bitter ripe pomellated apples and
 14118	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchips of strawberries and sieves of gooseberries, pulpy and pelurious,
 14119	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand strawberries fit for princes and raspberries from their canes.
 14120	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14121	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI dare him, says he, and I doubledare him. Come out here, Geraghty, you
 14122	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnotorious bloody hill and dale robber!
 14123	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14124	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd by that way wend the herds innumerable of bellwethers and flushed
 14125	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tewes and shearling rams and lambs and stubble geese and medium steers
 14126	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand roaring mares and polled calves and longwools and storesheep and
 14127	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCuffe’s prime springers and culls and sowpigs and baconhogs and the
 14128	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvarious different varieties of highly distinguished swine and Angus
 14129	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theifers and polly bulllocks of immaculate pedigree together with prime
 14130	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpremiated milchcows and beeves: and there is ever heard a trampling,
 14131	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcackling, roaring, lowing, bleating, bellowing, rumbling, grunting,
 14132	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchamping, chewing, of sheep and pigs and heavyhooved kine from
 14133	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpasturelands of Lusk and Rush and Carrickmines and from the streamy
 14134	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvales of Thomond, from the M’Gillicuddy’s reeks the inaccessible and
 14135	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlordly Shannon the unfathomable, and from the gentle declivities of the
 14136	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplace of the race of Kiar, their udders distended with superabundance of
 14137	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmilk and butts of butter and rennets of cheese and farmer’s firkins and
 14138	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttargets of lamb and crannocks of corn and oblong eggs in great hundreds,
 14139	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvarious in size, the agate with this dun.
 14140	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14141	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo we turned into Barney Kiernan’s and there, sure enough, was the
 14142	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcitizen up in the corner having a great confab with himself and that
 14143	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbloody mangy mongrel, Garryowen, and he waiting for what the sky would
 14144	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrop in the way of drink.
 14145	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14146	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—There he is, says I, in his gloryhole, with his cruiskeen lawn and his
 14147	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tload of papers, working for the cause.
 14148	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14149	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe bloody mongrel let a grouse out of him would give you the creeps. Be
 14150	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta corporal work of mercy if someone would take the life of that bloody
 14151	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdog. I’m told for a fact he ate a good part of the breeches off a
 14152	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconstabulary man in Santry that came round one time with a blue paper
 14153	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabout a licence.
 14154	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14155	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Stand and deliver, says he.
 14156	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14157	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That’s all right, citizen, says Joe. Friends here.
 14158	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14159	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Pass, friends, says he.
 14160	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14161	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThen he rubs his hand in his eye and says he:
 14162	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14163	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What’s your opinion of the times?
 14164	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14165	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDoing the rapparee and Rory of the hill. But, begob, Joe was equal to
 14166	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe occasion.
 14167	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14168	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I think the markets are on a rise, says he, sliding his hand down his
 14169	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfork.
 14170	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14171	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo begob the citizen claps his paw on his knee and he says:
 14172	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14173	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Foreign wars is the cause of it.
 14174	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14175	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd says Joe, sticking his thumb in his pocket:
 14176	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14177	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—It’s the Russians wish to tyrannise.
 14178	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14179	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Arrah, give over your bloody codding, Joe, says I. I’ve a thirst on me
 14180	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI wouldn’t sell for half a crown.
 14181	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14182	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Give it a name, citizen, says Joe.
 14183	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14184	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Wine of the country, says he.
 14185	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14186	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What’s yours? says Joe.
 14187	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14188	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ditto MacAnaspey, says I.
 14189	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14190	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Three pints, Terry, says Joe. And how’s the old heart, citizen? says
 14191	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the.
 14192	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14193	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Never better, a chara, says he. What Garry? Are we going to win? Eh?
 14194	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14195	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd with that he took the bloody old towser by the scruff of the neck
 14196	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand, by Jesus, he near throttled him.
 14197	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14198	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe figure seated on a large boulder at the foot of a round tower was
 14199	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat of a broadshouldered deepchested stronglimbed frankeyed redhaired
 14200	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfreelyfreckled shaggybearded widemouthed largenosed longheaded
 14201	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeepvoiced barekneed brawnyhanded hairylegged ruddyfaced sinewyarmed
 14202	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thero. From shoulder to shoulder he measured several ells and his
 14203	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trocklike mountainous knees were covered, as was likewise the rest of his
 14204	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbody wherever visible, with a strong growth of tawny prickly hair in
 14205	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thue and toughness similar to the mountain gorse (Ulex Europeus).
 14206	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe widewinged nostrils, from which bristles of the same tawny hue
 14207	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprojected, were of such capaciousness that within their cavernous
 14208	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tobscurity the fieldlark might easily have lodged her nest. The eyes
 14209	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin which a tear and a smile strove ever for the mastery were of the
 14210	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdimensions of a goodsized cauliflower. A powerful current of warm breath
 14211	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tissued at regular intervals from the profound cavity of his mouth
 14212	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhile in rhythmic resonance the loud strong hale reverberations of his
 14213	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tformidable heart thundered rumblingly causing the ground, the summit of
 14214	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe lofty tower and the still loftier walls of the cave to vibrate and
 14215	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttremble.
 14216	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14217	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe wore a long unsleeved garment of recently flayed oxhide reaching
 14218	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto the knees in a loose kilt and this was bound about his middle by
 14219	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta girdle of plaited straw and rushes. Beneath this he wore trews of
 14220	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeerskin, roughly stitched with gut. His nether extremities were encased
 14221	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin high Balbriggan buskins dyed in lichen purple, the feet being shod
 14222	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith brogues of salted cowhide laced with the windpipe of the same
 14223	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeast. From his girdle hung a row of seastones which jangled at every
 14224	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmovement of his portentous frame and on these were graven with rude
 14225	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyet striking art the tribal images of many Irish heroes and heroines of
 14226	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tantiquity, Cuchulin, Conn of hundred battles, Niall of nine hostages,
 14227	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBrian of Kincora, the ardri Malachi, Art MacMurragh, Shane O’Neill,
 14228	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather John Murphy, Owen Roe, Patrick Sarsfield, Red Hugh O’Donnell,
 14229	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRed Jim MacDermott, Soggarth Eoghan O’Growney, Michael Dwyer, Francy
 14230	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHiggins, Henry Joy M’Cracken, Goliath, Horace Wheatley, Thomas Conneff,
 14231	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPeg Woffington, the Village Blacksmith, Captain Moonlight, Captain
 14232	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBoycott, Dante Alighieri, Christopher Columbus, S. Fursa, S. Brendan,
 14233	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMarshal MacMahon, Charlemagne, Theobald Wolfe Tone, the Mother of the
 14234	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMaccabees, the Last of the Mohicans, the Rose of Castile, the Man for
 14235	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGalway, The Man that Broke the Bank at Monte Carlo, The Man in the Gap,
 14236	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe Woman Who Didn’t, Benjamin Franklin, Napoleon Bonaparte, John L.
 14237	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSullivan, Cleopatra, Savourneen Deelish, Julius Caesar, Paracelsus, sir
 14238	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThomas Lipton, William Tell, Michelangelo Hayes, Muhammad, the Bride of
 14239	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLammermoor, Peter the Hermit, Peter the Packer, Dark Rosaleen, Patrick
 14240	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tW. Shakespeare, Brian Confucius, Murtagh Gutenberg, Patricio Velasquez,
 14241	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCaptain Nemo, Tristan and Isolde, the first Prince of Wales, Thomas
 14242	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCook and Son, the Bold Soldier Boy, Arrah na Pogue, Dick Turpin, Ludwig
 14243	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBeethoven, the Colleen Bawn, Waddler Healy, Angus the Culdee, Dolly
 14244	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMount, Sidney Parade, Ben Howth, Valentine Greatrakes, Adam and Eve,
 14245	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tArthur Wellesley, Boss Croker, Herodotus, Jack the Giantkiller, Gautama
 14246	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBuddha, Lady Godiva, The Lily of Killarney, Balor of the Evil Eye,
 14247	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe Queen of Sheba, Acky Nagle, Joe Nagle, Alessandro Volta, Jeremiah
 14248	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tO’Donovan Rossa, Don Philip O’Sullivan Beare. A couched spear of
 14249	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tacuminated granite rested by him while at his feet reposed a savage
 14250	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanimal of the canine tribe whose stertorous gasps announced that he was
 14251	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsunk in uneasy slumber, a supposition confirmed by hoarse growls and
 14252	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspasmodic movements which his master repressed from time to time
 14253	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby tranquilising blows of a mighty cudgel rudely fashioned out of
 14254	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpaleolithic stone.
 14255	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14256	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo anyhow Terry brought the three pints Joe was standing and begob the
 14257	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsight nearly left my eyes when I saw him land out a quid. O, as true as
 14258	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI’m telling you. A goodlooking sovereign.
 14259	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14260	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And there’s more where that came from, says he.
 14261	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14262	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Were you robbing the poorbox, Joe? says I.
 14263	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14264	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Sweat of my brow, says Joe. ‘Twas the prudent member gave me the
 14265	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twheeze.
 14266	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14267	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I saw him before I met you, says I, sloping around by Pill lane and
 14268	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGreek street with his cod’s eye counting up all the guts of the fish.
 14269	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14270	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWho comes through Michan’s land, bedight in sable armour? O’Bloom,
 14271	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe son of Rory: it is he. Impervious to fear is Rory’s son: he of the
 14272	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprudent soul.
 14273	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14274	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—For the old woman of Prince’s street, says the citizen, the subsidised
 14275	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\torgan. The pledgebound party on the floor of the house. And look at this
 14276	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblasted rag, says he. Look at this, says he. The Irish Independent, if
 14277	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou please, founded by Parnell to be the workingman’s friend. Listen to
 14278	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe births and deaths in the Irish all for Ireland Independent, and I’ll
 14279	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthank you and the marriages.
 14280	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14281	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd he starts reading them out:
 14282	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14283	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Gordon, Barnfield crescent, Exeter; Redmayne of Iffley, Saint Anne’s on
 14284	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSea: the wife of William T Redmayne of a son. How’s that, eh? Wright and
 14285	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFlint, Vincent and Gillett to Rotha Marion daughter of Rosa and the
 14286	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlate George Alfred Gillett, 179 Clapham road, Stockwell, Playwood and
 14287	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRidsdale at Saint Jude’s, Kensington by the very reverend Dr Forrest,
 14288	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdean of Worcester. Eh? Deaths. Bristow, at Whitehall lane, London: Carr,
 14289	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStoke Newington, of gastritis and heart disease: Cockburn, at the Moat
 14290	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thouse, Chepstow...
 14291	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14292	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I know that fellow, says Joe, from bitter experience.
 14293	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14294	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Cockburn. Dimsey, wife of David Dimsey, late of the admiralty: Miller,
 14295	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTottenham, aged eightyfive: Welsh, June 12, at 35 Canning street,
 14296	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLiverpool, Isabella Helen. How’s that for a national press, eh, my brown
 14297	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tson! How’s that for Martin Murphy, the Bantry jobber?
 14298	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14299	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ah, well, says Joe, handing round the boose. Thanks be to God they had
 14300	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe start of us. Drink that, citizen.
 14301	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14302	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I will, says he, honourable person.
 14303	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14304	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Health, Joe, says I. And all down the form.
 14305	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14306	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAh! Ow! Don’t be talking! I was blue mouldy for the want of that pint.
 14307	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDeclare to God I could hear it hit the pit of my stomach with a click.
 14308	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14309	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd lo, as they quaffed their cup of joy, a godlike messenger came
 14310	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tswiftly in, radiant as the eye of heaven, a comely youth and behind him
 14311	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthere passed an elder of noble gait and countenance, bearing the sacred
 14312	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tscrolls of law and with him his lady wife a dame of peerless lineage,
 14313	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfairest of her race.
 14314	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14315	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLittle Alf Bergan popped in round the door and hid behind Barney’s
 14316	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsnug, squeezed up with the laughing. And who was sitting up there in
 14317	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe corner that I hadn’t seen snoring drunk blind to the world only Bob
 14318	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDoran. I didn’t know what was up and Alf kept making signs out of the
 14319	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoor. And begob what was it only that bloody old pantaloon Denis Breen
 14320	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin his bathslippers with two bloody big books tucked under his oxter and
 14321	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe wife hotfoot after him, unfortunate wretched woman, trotting like a
 14322	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoodle. I thought Alf would split.
 14323	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14324	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Look at him, says he. Breen. He’s traipsing all round Dublin with a
 14325	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpostcard someone sent him with U.P.: up on it to take a li...
 14326	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14327	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd he doubled up.
 14328	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14329	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Take a what? says I.
 14330	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14331	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Libel action, says he, for ten thousand pounds.
 14332	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14333	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O hell! says I.
 14334	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14335	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe bloody mongrel began to growl that’d put the fear of God in you
 14336	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseeing something was up but the citizen gave him a kick in the ribs.
 14337	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14338	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Bi i dho husht, says he.
 14339	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14340	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who? says Joe.
 14341	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14342	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Breen, says Alf. He was in John Henry Menton’s and then he went round
 14343	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto Collis and Ward’s and then Tom Rochford met him and sent him round to
 14344	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe subsheriff’s for a lark. O God, I’ve a pain laughing. U. p: up. The
 14345	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlong fellow gave him an eye as good as a process and now the bloody old
 14346	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlunatic is gone round to Green street to look for a G man.
 14347	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14348	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—When is long John going to hang that fellow in Mountjoy? says Joe.
 14349	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14350	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Bergan, says Bob Doran, waking up. Is that Alf Bergan?
 14351	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14352	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, says Alf. Hanging? Wait till I show you. Here, Terry, give us a
 14353	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpony. That bloody old fool! Ten thousand pounds. You should have seen
 14354	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlong John’s eye. U.P....
 14355	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14356	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd he started laughing.
 14357	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14358	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who are you laughing at? says Bob Doran. Is that Bergan?
 14359	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14360	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Hurry up, Terry boy, says Alf.
 14361	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14362	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTerence O’Ryan heard him and straightway brought him a crystal cup
 14363	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfull of the foamy ebon ale which the noble twin brothers Bungiveagh and
 14364	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBungardilaun brew ever in their divine alevats, cunning as the sons of
 14365	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeathless Leda. For they garner the succulent berries of the hop and
 14366	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmass and sift and bruise and brew them and they mix therewith sour
 14367	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjuices and bring the must to the sacred fire and cease not night or day
 14368	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom their toil, those cunning brothers, lords of the vat.
 14369	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14370	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThen did you, chivalrous Terence, hand forth, as to the manner born,
 14371	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat nectarous beverage and you offered the crystal cup to him that
 14372	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthirsted, the soul of chivalry, in beauty akin to the immortals.
 14373	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14374	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBut he, the young chief of the O’Bergan’s, could ill brook to be outdone
 14375	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin generous deeds but gave therefor with gracious gesture a testoon of
 14376	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcostliest bronze. Thereon embossed in excellent smithwork was seen
 14377	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe image of a queen of regal port, scion of the house of Brunswick,
 14378	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tVictoria her name, Her Most Excellent Majesty, by grace of God of the
 14379	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tUnited Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland and of the British dominions
 14380	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeyond the sea, queen, defender of the faith, Empress of India, even
 14381	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshe, who bore rule, a victress over many peoples, the wellbeloved, for
 14382	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey knew and loved her from the rising of the sun to the going down
 14383	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthereof, the pale, the dark, the ruddy and the ethiop.
 14384	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14385	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What’s that bloody freemason doing, says the citizen, prowling up and
 14386	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdown outside?
 14387	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14388	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What’s that? says Joe.
 14389	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14390	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Here you are, says Alf, chucking out the rhino. Talking about hanging,
 14391	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI’ll show you something you never saw. Hangmen’s letters. Look at here.
 14392	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14393	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo he took a bundle of wisps of letters and envelopes out of his pocket.
 14394	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 14396	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14397	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Honest injun, says Alf. Read them.
 14398	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 14400	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14401	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who are you laughing at? says Bob Doran.
 14402	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14403	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo I saw there was going to be a bit of a dust Bob’s a queer chap when
 14404	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe porter’s up in him so says I just to make talk:
 14405	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14406	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—How’s Willy Murray those times, Alf?
 14407	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14408	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I don’t know, says Alf I saw him just now in Capel street with Paddy
 14409	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDignam. Only I was running after that...
 14410	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14411	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You what? says Joe, throwing down the letters. With who?
 14412	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 14414	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14415	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Is it Paddy? says Joe.

 14422	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 14424	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14425	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Sure I’m after seeing him not five minutes ago, says Alf, as plain as a
 14426	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpikestaff.
 14427	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 14429	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 14431	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 14433	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith him, the two of them there near whatdoyoucallhim’s... What? Dignam
 14434	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdead?
 14435	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 14439	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14440	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Maybe so, says Joe. They took the liberty of burying him this morning
 14441	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanyhow.
 14442	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14443	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Paddy? says Alf.
 14444	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14445	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ay, says Joe. He paid the debt of nature, God be merciful to him.
 14446	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14447	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Good Christ! says Alf.
 14448	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14449	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBegob he was what you might call flabbergasted.
 14450	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14451	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn the darkness spirit hands were felt to flutter and when prayer by
 14452	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttantras had been directed to the proper quarter a faint but increasing
 14453	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tluminosity of ruby light became gradually visible, the apparition of
 14454	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe etheric double being particularly lifelike owing to the discharge
 14455	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof jivic rays from the crown of the head and face. Communication was
 14456	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teffected through the pituitary body and also by means of the orangefiery
 14457	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand scarlet rays emanating from the sacral region and solar plexus.
 14458	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tQuestioned by his earthname as to his whereabouts in the heavenworld he
 14459	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstated that he was now on the path of pralaya or return but was still
 14460	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsubmitted to trial at the hands of certain bloodthirsty entities on the
 14461	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlower astral levels. In reply to a question as to his first sensations
 14462	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the great divide beyond he stated that previously he had seen as in a
 14463	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tglass darkly but that those who had passed over had summit possibilities
 14464	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof atmic development opened up to them. Interrogated as to whether life
 14465	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthere resembled our experience in the flesh he stated that he had heard
 14466	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom more favoured beings now in the spirit that their abodes were
 14467	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tequipped with every modern home comfort such as talafana, alavatar,
 14468	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thatakalda, wataklasat and that the highest adepts were steeped in
 14469	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twaves of volupcy of the very purest nature. Having requested a quart of
 14470	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbuttermilk this was brought and evidently afforded relief. Asked if he
 14471	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thad any message for the living he exhorted all who were still at the
 14472	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twrong side of Maya to acknowledge the true path for it was reported
 14473	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin devanic circles that Mars and Jupiter were out for mischief on the
 14474	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teastern angle where the ram has power. It was then queried whether there
 14475	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twere any special desires on the part of the defunct and the reply was:
 14476	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWe greet you, friends of earth, who are still in the body. Mind C. K.
 14477	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoesn’t pile it on. It was ascertained that the reference was to Mr
 14478	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCornelius Kelleher, manager of Messrs H. J. O’Neill’s popular
 14479	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfuneral establishment, a personal friend of the defunct, who had been
 14480	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tresponsible for the carrying out of the interment arrangements. Before
 14481	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeparting he requested that it should be told to his dear son Patsy that
 14482	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe other boot which he had been looking for was at present under the
 14483	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcommode in the return room and that the pair should be sent to Cullen’s
 14484	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto be soled only as the heels were still good. He stated that this had
 14485	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgreatly perturbed his peace of mind in the other region and earnestly
 14486	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trequested that his desire should be made known.
 14487	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14488	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAssurances were given that the matter would be attended to and it was
 14489	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tintimated that this had given satisfaction.
 14490	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14491	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe is gone from mortal haunts: O’Dignam, sun of our morning. Fleet was
 14492	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this foot on the bracken: Patrick of the beamy brow. Wail, Banba, with
 14493	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyour wind: and wail, O ocean, with your whirlwind.
 14494	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14495	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—There he is again, says the citizen, staring out.
 14496	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14497	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who? says I.
 14498	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14499	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Bloom, says he. He’s on point duty up and down there for the last ten
 14500	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tminutes.
 14501	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14502	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd, begob, I saw his physog do a peep in and then slidder off again.
 14503	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14504	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLittle Alf was knocked bawways. Faith, he was.
 14505	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14506	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Good Christ! says he. I could have sworn it was him.
 14507	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14508	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd says Bob Doran, with the hat on the back of his poll, lowest
 14509	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblackguard in Dublin when he’s under the influence:
 14510	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14511	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who said Christ is good?
 14512	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14513	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I beg your parsnips, says Alf.
 14514	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14515	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Is that a good Christ, says Bob Doran, to take away poor little Willy
 14516	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDignam?
 14517	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14518	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ah, well, says Alf, trying to pass it off. He’s over all his troubles.
 14519	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14520	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBut Bob Doran shouts out of him.
 14521	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14522	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He’s a bloody ruffian, I say, to take away poor little Willy Dignam.
 14523	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14524	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTerry came down and tipped him the wink to keep quiet, that they didn’t
 14525	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twant that kind of talk in a respectable licensed premises. And Bob Doran
 14526	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstarts doing the weeps about Paddy Dignam, true as you’re there.
 14527	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14528	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The finest man, says he, snivelling, the finest purest character.
 14529	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14530	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe tear is bloody near your eye. Talking through his bloody hat. Fitter
 14531	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor him go home to the little sleepwalking bitch he married, Mooney, the
 14532	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbumbailiff’s daughter, mother kept a kip in Hardwicke street, that
 14533	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tused to be stravaging about the landings Bantam Lyons told me that was
 14534	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstopping there at two in the morning without a stitch on her, exposing
 14535	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther person, open to all comers, fair field and no favour.
 14536	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14537	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The noblest, the truest, says he. And he’s gone, poor little Willy,
 14538	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoor little Paddy Dignam.
 14539	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14540	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd mournful and with a heavy heart he bewept the extinction of that
 14541	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeam of heaven.
 14542	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14543	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOld Garryowen started growling again at Bloom that was skeezing round
 14544	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe door.
 14545	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14546	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Come in, come on, he won’t eat you, says the citizen.
 14547	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14548	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo Bloom slopes in with his cod’s eye on the dog and he asks Terry was
 14549	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMartin Cunningham there.
 14550	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14551	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, Christ M’Keown, says Joe, reading one of the letters. Listen to
 14552	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthis, will you?
 14553	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14554	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd he starts reading out one.
 14555	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14556	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      7 Hunter Street,
 14557	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      Liverpool.
 14558	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      To the High Sheriff of Dublin,
 14559	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      Dublin.
 14560	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14561	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHonoured sir i beg to offer my services in the abovementioned painful
 14562	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcase i hanged Joe Gann in Bootle jail on the 12 of Febuary 1900 and i
 14563	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thanged...
 14564	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14565	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Show us, Joe, says I.
 14566	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
