 14568	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPentonville prison and i was assistant when...
 14569	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14570	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Jesus, says I.
 14571	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14572	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—... Billington executed the awful murderer Toad Smith...
 14573	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14574	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe citizen made a grab at the letter.
 14575	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14576	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Hold hard, says Joe, i have a special nack of putting the noose once in
 14577	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the can’t get out hoping to be favoured i remain, honoured sir, my terms
 14578	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis five ginnees.
 14579	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14580	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      H. Rumbold,
 14581	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      Master Barber.
 14582	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14583	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And a barbarous bloody barbarian he is too, says the citizen.
 14584	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14585	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And the dirty scrawl of the wretch, says Joe. Here, says he, take them
 14586	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto hell out of my sight, Alf. Hello, Bloom, says he, what will you have?
 14587	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14588	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo they started arguing about the point, Bloom saying he wouldn’t and he
 14589	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcouldn’t and excuse him no offence and all to that and then he said well
 14590	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the’d just take a cigar. Gob, he’s a prudent member and no mistake.
 14591	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14592	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Give us one of your prime stinkers, Terry, says Joe.
 14593	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14594	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd Alf was telling us there was one chap sent in a mourning card with a
 14595	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblack border round it.
 14596	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14597	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—They’re all barbers, says he, from the black country that would hang
 14598	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir own fathers for five quid down and travelling expenses.
 14599	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14600	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd he was telling us there’s two fellows waiting below to pull his
 14601	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theels down when he gets the drop and choke him properly and then they
 14602	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchop up the rope after and sell the bits for a few bob a skull.
 14603	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14604	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn the dark land they bide, the vengeful knights of the razor. Their
 14605	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeadly coil they grasp: yea, and therein they lead to Erebus whatsoever
 14606	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twight hath done a deed of blood for I will on nowise suffer it even so
 14607	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaith the Lord.
 14608	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14609	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo they started talking about capital punishment and of course Bloom
 14610	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcomes out with the why and the wherefore and all the codology of the
 14611	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbusiness and the old dog smelling him all the time I’m told those jewies
 14612	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoes have a sort of a queer odour coming off them for dogs about I don’t
 14613	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknow what all deterrent effect and so forth and so on.
 14614	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14615	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—There’s one thing it hasn’t a deterrent effect on, says Alf.
 14616	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14617	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What’s that? says Joe.
 14618	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14619	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The poor bugger’s tool that’s being hanged, says Alf.
 14620	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14621	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That so? says Joe.
 14622	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14623	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—God’s truth, says Alf. I heard that from the head warder that was in
 14624	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKilmainham when they hanged Joe Brady, the invincible. He told me when
 14625	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey cut him down after the drop it was standing up in their faces like
 14626	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta poker.
 14627	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14628	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ruling passion strong in death, says Joe, as someone said.
 14629	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14630	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That can be explained by science, says Bloom. It’s only a natural
 14631	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tphenomenon, don’t you see, because on account of the...
 14632	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14633	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd then he starts with his jawbreakers about phenomenon and science and
 14634	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthis phenomenon and the other phenomenon.
 14635	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14636	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe distinguished scientist Herr Professor Luitpold Blumenduft tendered
 14637	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmedical evidence to the effect that the instantaneous fracture of the
 14638	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcervical vertebrae and consequent scission of the spinal cord would,
 14639	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taccording to the best approved tradition of medical science, be
 14640	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcalculated to inevitably produce in the human subject a violent
 14641	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tganglionic stimulus of the nerve centres of the genital apparatus,
 14642	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthereby causing the elastic pores of the corpora cavernosa to rapidly
 14643	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdilate in such a way as to instantaneously facilitate the flow of blood
 14644	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto that part of the human anatomy known as the penis or male organ
 14645	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tresulting in the phenomenon which has been denominated by the faculty a
 14646	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmorbid upwards and outwards philoprogenitive erection in articulo mortis
 14647	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tper diminutionem capitis.
 14648	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14649	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo of course the citizen was only waiting for the wink of the word and
 14650	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the starts gassing out of him about the invincibles and the old guard and
 14651	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe men of sixtyseven and who fears to speak of ninetyeight and Joe with
 14652	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim about all the fellows that were hanged, drawn and transported for
 14653	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe cause by drumhead courtmartial and a new Ireland and new this, that
 14654	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand the other. Talking about new Ireland he ought to go and get a new
 14655	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdog so he ought. Mangy ravenous brute sniffing and sneezing all round
 14656	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe place and scratching his scabs. And round he goes to Bob Doran that
 14657	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas standing Alf a half one sucking up for what he could get. So of
 14658	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcourse Bob Doran starts doing the bloody fool with him:
 14659	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14660	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Give us the paw! Give the paw, doggy! Good old doggy! Give the paw
 14661	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\there! Give us the paw!
 14662	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14663	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tArrah, bloody end to the paw he’d paw and Alf trying to keep him from
 14664	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttumbling off the bloody stool atop of the bloody old dog and he talking
 14665	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall kinds of drivel about training by kindness and thoroughbred dog and
 14666	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tintelligent dog: give you the bloody pip. Then he starts scraping a few
 14667	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbits of old biscuit out of the bottom of a Jacobs’ tin he told Terry to
 14668	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbring. Gob, he golloped it down like old boots and his tongue hanging
 14669	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tout of him a yard long for more. Near ate the tin and all, hungry bloody
 14670	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmongrel.
 14671	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14672	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd the citizen and Bloom having an argument about the point, the
 14673	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrothers Sheares and Wolfe Tone beyond on Arbour Hill and Robert Emmet
 14674	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand die for your country, the Tommy Moore touch about Sara Curran and
 14675	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshe’s far from the land. And Bloom, of course, with his knockmedown
 14676	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcigar putting on swank with his lardy face. Phenomenon! The fat heap he
 14677	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmarried is a nice old phenomenon with a back on her like a ballalley.
 14678	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTime they were stopping up in the City Arms pisser Burke told me there
 14679	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas an old one there with a cracked loodheramaun of a nephew and Bloom
 14680	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttrying to get the soft side of her doing the mollycoddle playing bézique
 14681	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto come in for a bit of the wampum in her will and not eating meat of a
 14682	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFriday because the old one was always thumping her craw and taking the
 14683	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlout out for a walk. And one time he led him the rounds of Dublin and,
 14684	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby the holy farmer, he never cried crack till he brought him home as
 14685	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrunk as a boiled owl and he said he did it to teach him the evils of
 14686	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\talcohol and by herrings, if the three women didn’t near roast him, it’s
 14687	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta queer story, the old one, Bloom’s wife and Mrs O’Dowd that kept the
 14688	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thotel. Jesus, I had to laugh at pisser Burke taking them off chewing the
 14689	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfat. And Bloom with his but don’t you see? and but on the other hand.
 14690	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd sure, more be token, the lout I’m told was in Power’s after, the
 14691	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblender’s, round in Cope street going home footless in a cab five times
 14692	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the week after drinking his way through all the samples in the bloody
 14693	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\testablishment. Phenomenon!
 14694	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14695	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The memory of the dead, says the citizen taking up his pintglass and
 14696	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tglaring at Bloom.
 14697	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14698	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ay, ay, says Joe.
 14699	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14700	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You don’t grasp my point, says Bloom. What I mean is...
 14701	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14702	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Sinn Fein! says the citizen. Sinn Fein amhain! The friends we love are
 14703	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby our side and the foes we hate before us.
 14704	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14705	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe last farewell was affecting in the extreme. From the belfries far
 14706	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand near the funereal deathbell tolled unceasingly while all around the
 14707	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgloomy precincts rolled the ominous warning of a hundred muffled drums
 14708	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpunctuated by the hollow booming of pieces of ordnance. The deafening
 14709	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tclaps of thunder and the dazzling flashes of lightning which lit up
 14710	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe ghastly scene testified that the artillery of heaven had lent its
 14711	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsupernatural pomp to the already gruesome spectacle. A torrential rain
 14712	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoured down from the floodgates of the angry heavens upon the
 14713	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbared heads of the assembled multitude which numbered at the
 14714	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlowest computation five hundred thousand persons. A posse of Dublin
 14715	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMetropolitan police superintended by the Chief Commissioner in person
 14716	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmaintained order in the vast throng for whom the York street brass and
 14717	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treed band whiled away the intervening time by admirably rendering on
 14718	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir blackdraped instruments the matchless melody endeared to us from
 14719	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe cradle by Speranza’s plaintive muse. Special quick excursion trains
 14720	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand upholstered charabancs had been provided for the comfort of our
 14721	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcountry cousins of whom there were large contingents. Considerable
 14722	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tamusement was caused by the favourite Dublin streetsingers L-n-h-n and
 14723	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tM-ll-g-n who sang The Night before Larry was stretched in their usual
 14724	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmirth-provoking fashion. Our two inimitable drolls did a roaring trade
 14725	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith their broadsheets among lovers of the comedy element and nobody
 14726	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twho has a corner in his heart for real Irish fun without vulgarity
 14727	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twill grudge them their hardearned pennies. The children of the Male and
 14728	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFemale Foundling Hospital who thronged the windows overlooking the scene
 14729	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twere delighted with this unexpected addition to the day’s entertainment
 14730	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand a word of praise is due to the Little Sisters of the Poor for their
 14731	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\texcellent idea of affording the poor fatherless and motherless children
 14732	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta genuinely instructive treat. The viceregal houseparty which included
 14733	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmany wellknown ladies was chaperoned by Their Excellencies to the most
 14734	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfavourable positions on the grandstand while the picturesque foreign
 14735	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdelegation known as the Friends of the Emerald Isle was accommodated
 14736	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton a tribune directly opposite. The delegation, present in full force,
 14737	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconsisted of Commendatore Bacibaci Beninobenone (the semiparalysed doyen
 14738	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the party who had to be assisted to his seat by the aid of a
 14739	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpowerful steam crane), Monsieur Pierrepaul Petitépatant, the Grandjoker
 14740	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tVladinmire Pokethankertscheff, the Archjoker Leopold Rudolph von
 14741	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSchwanzenbad-Hodenthaler, Countess Marha Virága Kisászony Putrápesthi,
 14742	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHiram Y. Bomboost, Count Athanatos Karamelopulos, Ali Baba Backsheesh
 14743	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRahat Lokum Effendi, Señor Hidalgo Caballero Don Pecadillo y Palabras
 14744	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ty Paternoster de la Malora de la Malaria, Hokopoko Harakiri, Hi Hung
 14745	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tChang, Olaf Kobberkeddelsen, Mynheer Trik van Trumps, Pan Poleaxe
 14746	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPaddyrisky, Goosepond Prhklstr Kratchinabritchisitch, Borus
 14747	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHupinkoff, Herr Hurhausdirektorpresident Hans Chuechli-Steuerli,
 14748	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNationalgymnasiummuseumsanatoriumandsuspensoriumsordinaryprivatdocentgeneralhistoryspecialprofessordoctor
 14749	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKriegfried Ueberallgemein. All the delegates without exception expressed
 14750	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthemselves in the strongest possible heterogeneous terms concerning
 14751	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe nameless barbarity which they had been called upon to witness. An
 14752	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanimated altercation (in which all took part) ensued among the F. O.
 14753	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tT. E. I. as to whether the eighth or the ninth of March was the correct
 14754	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdate of the birth of Ireland’s patron saint. In the course of the
 14755	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\targument cannonballs, scimitars, boomerangs, blunderbusses, stinkpots,
 14756	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmeatchoppers, umbrellas, catapults, knuckledusters, sandbags, lumps
 14757	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof pig iron were resorted to and blows were freely exchanged. The
 14758	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbaby policeman, Constable MacFadden, summoned by special courier from
 14759	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBooterstown, quickly restored order and with lightning promptitude
 14760	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tproposed the seventeenth of the month as a solution equally honourable
 14761	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor both contending parties. The readywitted ninefooter’s suggestion at
 14762	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tonce appealed to all and was unanimously accepted. Constable MacFadden
 14763	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas heartily congratulated by all the F. O. T. E. I., several of
 14764	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhom were bleeding profusely. Commendatore Beninobenone having been
 14765	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\textricated from underneath the presidential armchair, it was explained
 14766	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby his legal adviser Avvocato Pagamimi that the various articles
 14767	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsecreted in his thirtytwo pockets had been abstracted by him during the
 14768	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taffray from the pockets of his junior colleagues in the hope of bringing
 14769	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem to their senses. The objects (which included several hundred
 14770	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tladies’ and gentlemen’s gold and silver watches) were promptly restored
 14771	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto their rightful owners and general harmony reigned supreme.
 14772	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14773	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tQuietly, unassumingly Rumbold stepped on to the scaffold in faultless
 14774	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmorning dress and wearing his favourite flower, the Gladiolus Cruentus.
 14775	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe announced his presence by that gentle Rumboldian cough which so many
 14776	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thave tried (unsuccessfully) to imitate—short, painstaking yet withal so
 14777	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcharacteristic of the man. The arrival of the worldrenowned headsman was
 14778	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgreeted by a roar of acclamation from the huge concourse, the viceregal
 14779	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tladies waving their handkerchiefs in their excitement while the even
 14780	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmore excitable foreign delegates cheered vociferously in a medley of
 14781	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcries, hoch, banzai, eljen, zivio, chinchin, polla kronia, hiphip, vive,
 14782	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAllah, amid which the ringing evviva of the delegate of the land of song
 14783	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(a high double F recalling those piercingly lovely notes with which
 14784	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe eunuch Catalani beglamoured our greatgreatgrandmothers) was easily
 14785	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdistinguishable. It was exactly seventeen o’clock. The signal for prayer
 14786	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas then promptly given by megaphone and in an instant all heads were
 14787	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbared, the commendatore’s patriarchal sombrero, which has been in the
 14788	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpossession of his family since the revolution of Rienzi, being removed
 14789	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby his medical adviser in attendance, Dr Pippi. The learned prelate who
 14790	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tadministered the last comforts of holy religion to the hero martyr when
 14791	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabout to pay the death penalty knelt in a most christian spirit in a
 14792	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpool of rainwater, his cassock above his hoary head, and offered up to
 14793	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe throne of grace fervent prayers of supplication. Hand by the block
 14794	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstood the grim figure of the executioner, his visage being concealed in
 14795	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta tengallon pot with two circular perforated apertures through which his
 14796	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teyes glowered furiously. As he awaited the fatal signal he tested the
 14797	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tedge of his horrible weapon by honing it upon his brawny forearm or
 14798	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdecapitated in rapid succession a flock of sheep which had been provided
 14799	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby the admirers of his fell but necessary office. On a handsome mahogany
 14800	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttable near him were neatly arranged the quartering knife, the various
 14801	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfinely tempered disembowelling appliances (specially supplied by the
 14802	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tworldfamous firm of cutlers, Messrs John Round and Sons, Sheffield),
 14803	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta terra cotta saucepan for the reception of the duodenum, colon,
 14804	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblind intestine and appendix etc when successfully extracted and two
 14805	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcommodious milkjugs destined to receive the most precious blood of the
 14806	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmost precious victim. The housesteward of the amalgamated cats’ and
 14807	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdogs’ home was in attendance to convey these vessels when replenished
 14808	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto that beneficent institution. Quite an excellent repast consisting of
 14809	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trashers and eggs, fried steak and onions, done to a nicety, delicious
 14810	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thot breakfast rolls and invigorating tea had been considerately provided
 14811	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby the authorities for the consumption of the central figure of the
 14812	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttragedy who was in capital spirits when prepared for death and evinced
 14813	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe keenest interest in the proceedings from beginning to end but he,
 14814	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith an abnegation rare in these our times, rose nobly to the occasion
 14815	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand expressed the dying wish (immediately acceded to) that the meal
 14816	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshould be divided in aliquot parts among the members of the sick and
 14817	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tindigent roomkeepers’ association as a token of his regard and esteem.
 14818	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe nec and non plus ultra of emotion were reached when the blushing
 14819	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbride elect burst her way through the serried ranks of the bystanders
 14820	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand flung herself upon the muscular bosom of him who was about to be
 14821	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlaunched into eternity for her sake. The hero folded her willowy form in
 14822	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta loving embrace murmuring fondly Sheila, my own. Encouraged by this use
 14823	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof her christian name she kissed passionately all the various suitable
 14824	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tareas of his person which the decencies of prison garb permitted her
 14825	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tardour to reach. She swore to him as they mingled the salt streams of
 14826	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir tears that she would ever cherish his memory, that she would never
 14827	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tforget her hero boy who went to his death with a song on his lips as if
 14828	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the were but going to a hurling match in Clonturk park. She brought back
 14829	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto his recollection the happy days of blissful childhood together on the
 14830	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbanks of Anna Liffey when they had indulged in the innocent pastimes
 14831	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the young and, oblivious of the dreadful present, they both laughed
 14832	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theartily, all the spectators, including the venerable pastor, joining in
 14833	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe general merriment. That monster audience simply rocked with delight.
 14834	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBut anon they were overcome with grief and clasped their hands for the
 14835	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlast time. A fresh torrent of tears burst from their lachrymal ducts
 14836	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand the vast concourse of people, touched to the inmost core, broke
 14837	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinto heartrending sobs, not the least affected being the aged prebendary
 14838	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thimself. Big strong men, officers of the peace and genial giants of the
 14839	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\troyal Irish constabulary, were making frank use of their handkerchiefs
 14840	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand it is safe to say that there was not a dry eye in that record
 14841	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tassemblage. A most romantic incident occurred when a handsome young
 14842	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOxford graduate, noted for his chivalry towards the fair sex, stepped
 14843	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tforward and, presenting his visiting card, bankbook and genealogical
 14844	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttree, solicited the hand of the hapless young lady, requesting her to
 14845	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tname the day, and was accepted on the spot. Every lady in the audience
 14846	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas presented with a tasteful souvenir of the occasion in the shape of
 14847	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta skull and crossbones brooch, a timely and generous act which evoked
 14848	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta fresh outburst of emotion: and when the gallant young Oxonian (the
 14849	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbearer, by the way, of one of the most timehonoured names in Albion’s
 14850	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thistory) placed on the finger of his blushing fiancée an expensive
 14851	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tengagement ring with emeralds set in the form of a fourleaved shamrock
 14852	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe excitement knew no bounds. Nay, even the stern provostmarshal,
 14853	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlieutenantcolonel Tomkin-Maxwell ffrenchmullan Tomlinson, who presided
 14854	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton the sad occasion, he who had blown a considerable number of sepoys
 14855	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom the cannonmouth without flinching, could not now restrain his
 14856	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnatural emotion. With his mailed gauntlet he brushed away a furtive tear
 14857	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand was overheard, by those privileged burghers who happened to be in
 14858	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this immediate entourage, to murmur to himself in a faltering undertone:
 14859	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14860	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—God blimey if she aint a clinker, that there bleeding tart. Blimey it
 14861	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmakes me kind of bleeding cry, straight, it does, when I sees her cause
 14862	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI thinks of my old mashtub what’s waiting for me down Limehouse way.
 14863	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14864	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo then the citizen begins talking about the Irish language and the
 14865	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcorporation meeting and all to that and the shoneens that can’t speak
 14866	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir own language and Joe chipping in because he stuck someone for a
 14867	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquid and Bloom putting in his old goo with his twopenny stump that
 14868	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the cadged off of Joe and talking about the Gaelic league and the
 14869	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tantitreating league and drink, the curse of Ireland. Antitreating is
 14870	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabout the size of it. Gob, he’d let you pour all manner of drink down
 14871	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this throat till the Lord would call him before you’d ever see the froth
 14872	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof his pint. And one night I went in with a fellow into one of their
 14873	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmusical evenings, song and dance about she could get up on a truss of
 14874	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thay she could my Maureen Lay and there was a fellow with a Ballyhooly
 14875	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblue ribbon badge spiffing out of him in Irish and a lot of colleen
 14876	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbawns going about with temperance beverages and selling medals
 14877	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand oranges and lemonade and a few old dry buns, gob, flahoolagh
 14878	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tentertainment, don’t be talking. Ireland sober is Ireland free. And
 14879	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthen an old fellow starts blowing into his bagpipes and all the gougers
 14880	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshuffling their feet to the tune the old cow died of. And one or two
 14881	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsky pilots having an eye around that there was no goings on with the
 14882	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfemales, hitting below the belt.
 14883	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14884	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo howandever, as I was saying, the old dog seeing the tin was empty
 14885	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstarts mousing around by Joe and me. I’d train him by kindness, so I
 14886	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twould, if he was my dog. Give him a rousing fine kick now and again
 14887	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhere it wouldn’t blind him.
 14888	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14889	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Afraid he’ll bite you? says the citizen, jeering.
 14890	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14891	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—No, says I. But he might take my leg for a lamppost.
 14892	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14893	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo he calls the old dog over.
 14894	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14895	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What’s on you, Garry? says he.
 14896	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14897	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThen he starts hauling and mauling and talking to him in Irish and the
 14898	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\told towser growling, letting on to answer, like a duet in the opera.
 14899	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSuch growling you never heard as they let off between them. Someone that
 14900	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thas nothing better to do ought to write a letter pro bono publico to the
 14901	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpapers about the muzzling order for a dog the like of that. Growling
 14902	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand grousing and his eye all bloodshot from the drouth is in it and the
 14903	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thydrophobia dropping out of his jaws.
 14904	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14905	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAll those who are interested in the spread of human culture among the
 14906	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlower animals (and their name is legion) should make a point of not
 14907	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmissing the really marvellous exhibition of cynanthropy given by the
 14908	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfamous old Irish red setter wolfdog formerly known by the sobriquet of
 14909	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGarryowen and recently rechristened by his large circle of friends and
 14910	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tacquaintances Owen Garry. The exhibition, which is the result of years
 14911	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof training by kindness and a carefully thoughtout dietary system,
 14912	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcomprises, among other achievements, the recitation of verse. Our
 14913	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgreatest living phonetic expert (wild horses shall not drag it from us!)
 14914	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thas left no stone unturned in his efforts to delucidate and compare the
 14915	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tverse recited and has found it bears a striking resemblance (the italics
 14916	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tare ours) to the ranns of ancient Celtic bards. We are not speaking so
 14917	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmuch of those delightful lovesongs with which the writer who conceals
 14918	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this identity under the graceful pseudonym of the Little Sweet Branch has
 14919	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfamiliarised the bookloving world but rather (as a contributor D. O.
 14920	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tC. points out in an interesting communication published by an evening
 14921	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcontemporary) of the harsher and more personal note which is found in
 14922	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe satirical effusions of the famous Raftery and of Donal MacConsidine
 14923	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto say nothing of a more modern lyrist at present very much in the
 14924	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpublic eye. We subjoin a specimen which has been rendered into English
 14925	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby an eminent scholar whose name for the moment we are not at liberty
 14926	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto disclose though we believe that our readers will find the topical
 14927	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tallusion rather more than an indication. The metrical system of
 14928	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe canine original, which recalls the intricate alliterative and
 14929	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tisosyllabic rules of the Welsh englyn, is infinitely more complicated
 14930	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbut we believe our readers will agree that the spirit has been well
 14931	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcaught. Perhaps it should be added that the effect is greatly increased
 14932	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tif Owen’s verse be spoken somewhat slowly and indistinctly in a tone
 14933	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsuggestive of suppressed rancour.
 14934	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14935	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     The curse of my curses
 14936	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Seven days every day
 14937	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     And seven dry Thursdays
 14938	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     On you, Barney Kiernan,
 14939	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Has no sup of water
 14940	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     To cool my courage,
 14941	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     And my guts red roaring
 14942	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     After Lowry’s lights.
 14943	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14944	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo he told Terry to bring some water for the dog and, gob, you could
 14945	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thear him lapping it up a mile off. And Joe asked him would he have
 14946	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanother.
 14947	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14948	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I will, says he, a chara, to show there’s no ill feeling.
 14949	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14950	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGob, he’s not as green as he’s cabbagelooking. Arsing around from one
 14951	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpub to another, leaving it to your own honour, with old Giltrap’s dog
 14952	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand getting fed up by the ratepayers and corporators. Entertainment for
 14953	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tman and beast. And says Joe:
 14954	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14955	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Could you make a hole in another pint?
 14956	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14957	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Could a swim duck? says I.
 14958	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14959	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Same again, Terry, says Joe. Are you sure you won’t have anything in
 14960	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe way of liquid refreshment? says he.
 14961	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14962	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Thank you, no, says Bloom. As a matter of fact I just wanted to meet
 14963	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMartin Cunningham, don’t you see, about this insurance of poor Dignam’s.
 14964	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMartin asked me to go to the house. You see, he, Dignam, I mean, didn’t
 14965	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tserve any notice of the assignment on the company at the time and
 14966	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnominally under the act the mortgagee can’t recover on the policy.
 14967	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14968	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Holy Wars, says Joe, laughing, that’s a good one if old Shylock is
 14969	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlanded. So the wife comes out top dog, what?
 14970	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14971	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, that’s a point, says Bloom, for the wife’s admirers.
 14972	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14973	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Whose admirers? says Joe.
 14974	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14975	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The wife’s advisers, I mean, says Bloom.
 14976	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14977	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThen he starts all confused mucking it up about mortgagor under the act
 14978	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlike the lord chancellor giving it out on the bench and for the benefit
 14979	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the wife and that a trust is created but on the other hand that
 14980	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDignam owed Bridgeman the money and if now the wife or the widow
 14981	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcontested the mortgagee’s right till he near had the head of me addled
 14982	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith his mortgagor under the act. He was bloody safe he wasn’t run in
 14983	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thimself under the act that time as a rogue and vagabond only he had a
 14984	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfriend in court. Selling bazaar tickets or what do you call it royal
 14985	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHungarian privileged lottery. True as you’re there. O, commend me to an
 14986	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tisraelite! Royal and privileged Hungarian robbery.
 14987	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14988	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo Bob Doran comes lurching around asking Bloom to tell Mrs Dignam he
 14989	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas sorry for her trouble and he was very sorry about the funeral and
 14990	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto tell her that he said and everyone who knew him said that there was
 14991	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnever a truer, a finer than poor little Willy that’s dead to tell her.
 14992	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tChoking with bloody foolery. And shaking Bloom’s hand doing the tragic
 14993	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto tell her that. Shake hands, brother. You’re a rogue and I’m another.
 14994	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 14995	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Let me, said he, so far presume upon our acquaintance which, however
 14996	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tslight it may appear if judged by the standard of mere time, is founded,
 14997	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tas I hope and believe, on a sentiment of mutual esteem as to request of
 14998	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou this favour. But, should I have overstepped the limits of reserve
 14999	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlet the sincerity of my feelings be the excuse for my boldness.
 15000	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15001	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—No, rejoined the other, I appreciate to the full the motives which
 15002	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tactuate your conduct and I shall discharge the office you entrust to
 15003	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tme consoled by the reflection that, though the errand be one of sorrow,
 15004	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthis proof of your confidence sweetens in some measure the bitterness of
 15005	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe cup.
 15006	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15007	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Then suffer me to take your hand, said he. The goodness of your heart,
 15008	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI feel sure, will dictate to you better than my inadequate words
 15009	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe expressions which are most suitable to convey an emotion whose
 15010	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoignancy, were I to give vent to my feelings, would deprive me even of
 15011	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspeech.
 15012	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15013	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd off with him and out trying to walk straight. Boosed at five
 15014	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\to’clock. Night he was near being lagged only Paddy Leonard knew the
 15015	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbobby, 14A. Blind to the world up in a shebeen in Bride street after
 15016	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tclosing time, fornicating with two shawls and a bully on guard, drinking
 15017	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tporter out of teacups. And calling himself a Frenchy for the shawls,
 15018	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJoseph Manuo, and talking against the Catholic religion, and he serving
 15019	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmass in Adam and Eve’s when he was young with his eyes shut, who wrote
 15020	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe new testament, and the old testament, and hugging and smugging. And
 15021	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe two shawls killed with the laughing, picking his pockets, the bloody
 15022	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfool and he spilling the porter all over the bed and the two shawls
 15023	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tscreeching laughing at one another. How is your testament? Have you got
 15024	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tan old testament? Only Paddy was passing there, I tell you what. Then
 15025	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsee him of a Sunday with his little concubine of a wife, and she wagging
 15026	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther tail up the aisle of the chapel with her patent boots on her, no
 15027	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tless, and her violets, nice as pie, doing the little lady. Jack Mooney’s
 15028	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsister. And the old prostitute of a mother procuring rooms to street
 15029	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcouples. Gob, Jack made him toe the line. Told him if he didn’t patch up
 15030	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe pot, Jesus, he’d kick the shite out of him.
 15031	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15032	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo Terry brought the three pints.
 15033	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15034	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Here, says Joe, doing the honours. Here, citizen.
 15035	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15036	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Slan leat, says he.
 15037	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 15039	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15040	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGob, he had his mouth half way down the tumbler already. Want a small
 15041	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfortune to keep him in drinks.
 15042	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15043	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who is the long fellow running for the mayoralty, Alf? says Joe.

 15048	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 15051	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I thought so, says Joe. I saw him up at that meeting now with William
 15052	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tField, M. P., the cattle traders.

 15054	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Hairy Iopas, says the citizen, that exploded volcano, the darling of
 15055	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall countries and the idol of his own.
 15056	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15057	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo Joe starts telling the citizen about the foot and mouth disease
 15058	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand the cattle traders and taking action in the matter and the citizen
 15059	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsending them all to the rightabout and Bloom coming out with his
 15060	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsheepdip for the scab and a hoose drench for coughing calves and the
 15061	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tguaranteed remedy for timber tongue. Because he was up one time in a
 15062	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknacker’s yard. Walking about with his book and pencil here’s my head
 15063	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand my heels are coming till Joe Cuffe gave him the order of the boot
 15064	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor giving lip to a grazier. Mister Knowall. Teach your grandmother how
 15065	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto milk ducks. Pisser Burke was telling me in the hotel the wife used
 15066	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto be in rivers of tears some times with Mrs O’Dowd crying her eyes out
 15067	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith her eight inches of fat all over her. Couldn’t loosen her farting
 15068	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstrings but old cod’s eye was waltzing around her showing her how to do
 15069	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit. What’s your programme today? Ay. Humane methods. Because the poor
 15070	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanimals suffer and experts say and the best known remedy that doesn’t
 15071	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcause pain to the animal and on the sore spot administer gently. Gob,
 15072	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the’d have a soft hand under a hen.
 15073	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15074	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGa Ga Gara. Klook Klook Klook. Black Liz is our hen. She lays eggs for
 15075	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tus. When she lays her egg she is so glad. Gara. Klook Klook Klook. Then
 15076	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcomes good uncle Leo. He puts his hand under black Liz and takes her
 15077	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfresh egg. Ga ga ga ga Gara. Klook Klook Klook.
 15078	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15079	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Anyhow, says Joe, Field and Nannetti are going over tonight to London
 15080	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto ask about it on the floor of the house of commons.

 15083	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tas it happens.
 15084	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 15088	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tField is going. I couldn’t phone. No. You’re sure?
 15089	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15090	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Nannan’s going too, says Joe. The league told him to ask a question
 15091	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttomorrow about the commissioner of police forbidding Irish games in the
 15092	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpark. What do you think of that, citizen? The Sluagh na h-Eireann.
 15093	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15094	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Cowe Conacre (Multifarnham. Nat.): Arising out of the question of
 15095	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmy honourable friend, the member for Shillelagh, may I ask the right
 15096	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thonourable gentleman whether the government has issued orders that these
 15097	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanimals shall be slaughtered though no medical evidence is forthcoming
 15098	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tas to their pathological condition?
 15099	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15100	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Allfours (Tamoshant. Con.): Honourable members are already in
 15101	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpossession of the evidence produced before a committee of the whole
 15102	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thouse. I feel I cannot usefully add anything to that. The answer to the
 15103	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thonourable member’s question is in the affirmative.
 15104	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15105	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Orelli O’Reilly (Montenotte. Nat.): Have similar orders been issued
 15106	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor the slaughter of human animals who dare to play Irish games in the
 15107	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPhoenix park?
 15108	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15109	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Allfours: The answer is in the negative.
 15110	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 15112	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMitchelstown telegram inspired the policy of gentlemen on the Treasury
 15113	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbench? (O! O!)
 15114	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15115	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Allfours: I must have notice of that question.
 15116	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15117	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Staylewit (Buncombe. Ind.): Don’t hesitate to shoot.
 15118	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15119	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(Ironical opposition cheers.)
 15120	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 15122	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15123	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(The house rises. Cheers.)
 15124	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15125	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—There’s the man, says Joe, that made the Gaelic sports revival. There
 15126	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the is sitting there. The man that got away James Stephens. The champion
 15127	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof all Ireland at putting the sixteen pound shot. What was your best
 15128	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthrow, citizen?
 15129	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15130	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Na bacleis, says the citizen, letting on to be modest. There was a time
 15131	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI was as good as the next fellow anyhow.
 15132	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15133	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Put it there, citizen, says Joe. You were and a bloody sight better.
 15134	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15135	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Is that really a fact? says Alf.
 15136	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15137	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, says Bloom. That’s well known. Did you not know that?
 15138	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15139	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo off they started about Irish sports and shoneen games the like of
 15140	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlawn tennis and about hurley and putting the stone and racy of the soil
 15141	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand building up a nation once again and all to that. And of course Bloom
 15142	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thad to have his say too about if a fellow had a rower’s heart violent
 15143	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\texercise was bad. I declare to my antimacassar if you took up a straw
 15144	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom the bloody floor and if you said to Bloom: Look at, Bloom. Do you
 15145	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsee that straw? That’s a straw. Declare to my aunt he’d talk about it
 15146	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor an hour so he would and talk steady.
 15147	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15148	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA most interesting discussion took place in the ancient hall of Brian
 15149	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tO’Ciarnain’s in Sraid na Bretaine Bheag, under the auspices of Sluagh na
 15150	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\th-Eireann, on the revival of ancient Gaelic sports and the importance of
 15151	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tphysical culture, as understood in ancient Greece and ancient Rome
 15152	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand ancient Ireland, for the development of the race. The venerable
 15153	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpresident of the noble order was in the chair and the attendance was
 15154	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof large dimensions. After an instructive discourse by the chairman,
 15155	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta magnificent oration eloquently and forcibly expressed, a most
 15156	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinteresting and instructive discussion of the usual high standard of
 15157	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\texcellence ensued as to the desirability of the revivability of the
 15158	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tancient games and sports of our ancient Panceltic forefathers. The
 15159	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twellknown and highly respected worker in the cause of our old tongue, Mr
 15160	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJoseph M’Carthy Hynes, made an eloquent appeal for the resuscitation of
 15161	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe ancient Gaelic sports and pastimes, practised morning and evening
 15162	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby Finn MacCool, as calculated to revive the best traditions of manly
 15163	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstrength and prowess handed down to us from ancient ages. L. Bloom, who
 15164	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmet with a mixed reception of applause and hisses, having espoused the
 15165	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnegative the vocalist chairman brought the discussion to a close, in
 15166	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tresponse to repeated requests and hearty plaudits from all parts of
 15167	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta bumper house, by a remarkably noteworthy rendering of the immortal
 15168	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThomas Osborne Davis’ evergreen verses (happily too familiar to need
 15169	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trecalling here) A nation once again in the execution of which the
 15170	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tveteran patriot champion may be said without fear of contradiction
 15171	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto have fairly excelled himself. The Irish Caruso-Garibaldi was in
 15172	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsuperlative form and his stentorian notes were heard to the greatest
 15173	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tadvantage in the timehonoured anthem sung as only our citizen can sing
 15174	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit. His superb highclass vocalism, which by its superquality greatly
 15175	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tenhanced his already international reputation, was vociferously
 15176	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tapplauded by the large audience among which were to be noticed many
 15177	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprominent members of the clergy as well as representatives of the press
 15178	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand the bar and the other learned professions. The proceedings then
 15179	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tterminated.
 15180	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15181	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAmongst the clergy present were the very rev. William Delany, S. J., L.
 15182	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tL. D.; the rt rev. Gerald Molloy, D. D.; the rev. P. J. Kavanagh, C. S.
 15183	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSp.; the rev. T. Waters, C. C.; the rev. John M. Ivers, P. P.; the rev.
 15184	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tP. J. Cleary, O. S. F.; the rev. L. J. Hickey, O. P.; the very rev. Fr.
 15185	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNicholas, O. S. F. C.; the very rev. B. Gorman, O. D. C.; the rev. T.
 15186	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMaher, S. J.; the very rev. James Murphy, S. J.; the rev. John Lavery,
 15187	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tV. F.; the very rev. William Doherty, D. D.; the rev. Peter Fagan, O.
 15188	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tM.; the rev. T. Brangan, O. S. A.; the rev. J. Flavin, C. C.; the
 15189	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trev. M. A. Hackett, C. C.; the rev. W. Hurley, C. C.; the rt rev. Mgr
 15190	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tM’Manus, V. G.; the rev. B. R. Slattery, O. M. I.; the very rev. M.
 15191	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tD. Scally, P. P.; the rev. F. T. Purcell, O. P.; the very rev. Timothy
 15192	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcanon Gorman, P. P.; the rev. J. Flanagan, C. C. The laity included P.
 15193	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFay, T. Quirke, etc., etc.
 15194	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15195	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Talking about violent exercise, says Alf, were you at that
 15196	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKeogh-Bennett match?
 15197	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15198	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—No, says Joe.
 15199	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15200	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I heard So and So made a cool hundred quid over it, says Alf.
 15201	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15202	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who? Blazes? says Joe.
 15203	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15204	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd says Bloom:
 15205	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15206	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What I meant about tennis, for example, is the agility and training the
 15207	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teye.
 15208	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15209	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ay, Blazes, says Alf. He let out that Myler was on the beer to run up
 15210	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe odds and he swatting all the time.
 15211	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15212	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—We know him, says the citizen. The traitor’s son. We know what put
 15213	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEnglish gold in his pocket.
 15214	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15215	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—True for you, says Joe.
 15216	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15217	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd Bloom cuts in again about lawn tennis and the circulation of the
 15218	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblood, asking Alf:
 15219	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15220	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Now, don’t you think, Bergan?
 15221	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15222	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Myler dusted the floor with him, says Alf. Heenan and Sayers was only
 15223	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta bloody fool to it. Handed him the father and mother of a beating. See
 15224	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe little kipper not up to his navel and the big fellow swiping. God,
 15225	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the gave him one last puck in the wind, Queensberry rules and all, made
 15226	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim puke what he never ate.
 15227	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15228	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIt was a historic and a hefty battle when Myler and Percy were scheduled
 15229	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto don the gloves for the purse of fifty sovereigns. Handicapped as he
 15230	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas by lack of poundage, Dublin’s pet lamb made up for it by superlative
 15231	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tskill in ringcraft. The final bout of fireworks was a gruelling for both
 15232	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchampions. The welterweight sergeantmajor had tapped some lively claret
 15233	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the previous mixup during which Keogh had been receivergeneral of
 15234	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trights and lefts, the artilleryman putting in some neat work on the
 15235	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpet’s nose, and Myler came on looking groggy. The soldier got to
 15236	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbusiness, leading off with a powerful left jab to which the Irish
 15237	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgladiator retaliated by shooting out a stiff one flush to the point of
 15238	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBennett’s jaw. The redcoat ducked but the Dubliner lifted him with a
 15239	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tleft hook, the body punch being a fine one. The men came to handigrips.
 15240	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMyler quickly became busy and got his man under, the bout ending with
 15241	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe bulkier man on the ropes, Myler punishing him. The Englishman, whose
 15242	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tright eye was nearly closed, took his corner where he was liberally
 15243	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrenched with water and when the bell went came on gamey and brimful of
 15244	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpluck, confident of knocking out the fistic Eblanite in jigtime. It was
 15245	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta fight to a finish and the best man for it. The two fought like tigers
 15246	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand excitement ran fever high. The referee twice cautioned Pucking Percy
 15247	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor holding but the pet was tricky and his footwork a treat to watch.
 15248	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAfter a brisk exchange of courtesies during which a smart upper cut of
 15249	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe military man brought blood freely from his opponent’s mouth the
 15250	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlamb suddenly waded in all over his man and landed a terrific left to
 15251	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBattling Bennett’s stomach, flooring him flat. It was a knockout clean
 15252	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand clever. Amid tense expectation the Portobello bruiser was being
 15253	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcounted out when Bennett’s second Ole Pfotts Wettstein threw in the
 15254	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttowel and the Santry boy was declared victor to the frenzied cheers of
 15255	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe public who broke through the ringropes and fairly mobbed him with
 15256	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdelight.
 15257	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15258	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He knows which side his bread is buttered, says Alf. I hear he’s
 15259	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trunning a concert tour now up in the north.
 15260	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15261	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He is, says Joe. Isn’t he?
 15262	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15263	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who? says Bloom. Ah, yes. That’s quite true. Yes, a kind of summer
 15264	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttour, you see. Just a holiday.
 15265	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15266	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Mrs B. is the bright particular star, isn’t she? says Joe.
 15267	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15268	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—My wife? says Bloom. She’s singing, yes. I think it will be a success
 15269	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoo.
 15270	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15271	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe’s an excellent man to organise. Excellent.
 15272	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15273	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHoho begob says I to myself says I. That explains the milk in the
 15274	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcocoanut and absence of hair on the animal’s chest. Blazes doing the
 15275	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttootle on the flute. Concert tour. Dirty Dan the dodger’s son off Island
 15276	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbridge that sold the same horses twice over to the government to fight
 15277	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe Boers. Old Whatwhat. I called about the poor and water rate, Mr
 15278	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBoylan. You what? The water rate, Mr Boylan. You whatwhat? That’s the
 15279	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbucko that’ll organise her, take my tip. ‘Twixt me and you Caddareesh.
 15280	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15281	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPride of Calpe’s rocky mount, the ravenhaired daughter of Tweedy. There
 15282	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgrew she to peerless beauty where loquat and almond scent the air. The
 15283	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgardens of Alameda knew her step: the garths of olives knew and bowed.
 15284	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe chaste spouse of Leopold is she: Marion of the bountiful bosoms.
 15285	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15286	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd lo, there entered one of the clan of the O’Molloy’s, a comely hero
 15287	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof white face yet withal somewhat ruddy, his majesty’s counsel learned
 15288	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the law, and with him the prince and heir of the noble line of
 15289	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLambert.
