 15310	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15311	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Hope so, says Ned.
 15312	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15313	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNow what were those two at? J. J. getting him off the grand jury list
 15314	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand the other give him a leg over the stile. With his name in Stubbs’s.
 15315	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPlaying cards, hobnobbing with flash toffs with a swank glass in their
 15316	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teye, adrinking fizz and he half smothered in writs and garnishee orders.
 15317	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPawning his gold watch in Cummins of Francis street where no-one would
 15318	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknow him in the private office when I was there with Pisser releasing
 15319	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this boots out of the pop. What’s your name, sir? Dunne, says he. Ay, and
 15320	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdone says I. Gob, he’ll come home by weeping cross one of those days,
 15321	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI’m thinking.
 15322	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15323	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Did you see that bloody lunatic Breen round there? says Alf. U.P.: up.
 15324	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15325	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, says J. J. Looking for a private detective.
 15326	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15327	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ay, says Ned. And he wanted right go wrong to address the court only
 15328	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCorny Kelleher got round him telling him to get the handwriting examined
 15329	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfirst.
 15330	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15331	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ten thousand pounds, says Alf, laughing. God, I’d give anything to hear
 15332	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim before a judge and jury.
 15333	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15334	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Was it you did it, Alf? says Joe. The truth, the whole truth and
 15335	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnothing but the truth, so help you Jimmy Johnson.
 15336	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15337	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Me? says Alf. Don’t cast your nasturtiums on my character.
 15338	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15339	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Whatever statement you make, says Joe, will be taken down in evidence
 15340	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tagainst you.
 15341	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15342	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Of course an action would lie, says J. J. It implies that he is not
 15343	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcompos mentis. U.P.: up.
 15344	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15345	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Compos your eye! says Alf, laughing. Do you know that he’s balmy? Look
 15346	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat his head. Do you know that some mornings he has to get his hat on
 15347	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith a shoehorn.
 15348	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15349	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, says J. J., but the truth of a libel is no defence to an
 15350	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tindictment for publishing it in the eyes of the law.
 15351	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15352	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ha ha, Alf, says Joe.
 15353	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15354	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Still, says Bloom, on account of the poor woman, I mean his wife.
 15355	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15356	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Pity about her, says the citizen. Or any other woman marries a half and
 15357	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thalf.
 15358	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15359	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—How half and half? says Bloom. Do you mean he...
 15360	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15361	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Half and half I mean, says the citizen. A fellow that’s neither fish
 15362	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnor flesh.
 15363	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15364	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Nor good red herring, says Joe.
 15365	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15366	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That what’s I mean, says the citizen. A pishogue, if you know what that
 15367	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis.
 15368	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15369	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBegob I saw there was trouble coming. And Bloom explaining he meant on
 15370	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taccount of it being cruel for the wife having to go round after the
 15371	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\told stuttering fool. Cruelty to animals so it is to let that bloody
 15372	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpovertystricken Breen out on grass with his beard out tripping him,
 15373	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbringing down the rain. And she with her nose cockahoop after she
 15374	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmarried him because a cousin of his old fellow’s was pewopener to the
 15375	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpope. Picture of him on the wall with his Smashall Sweeney’s moustaches,
 15376	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe signior Brini from Summerhill, the eyetallyano, papal Zouave to the
 15377	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHoly Father, has left the quay and gone to Moss street. And who was
 15378	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the, tell us? A nobody, two pair back and passages, at seven shillings a
 15379	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tweek, and he covered with all kinds of breastplates bidding defiance to
 15380	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe world.
 15381	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15382	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And moreover, says J. J., a postcard is publication. It was held to be
 15383	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsufficient evidence of malice in the testcase Sadgrove v. Hole. In my
 15384	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\topinion an action might lie.
 15385	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15386	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSix and eightpence, please. Who wants your opinion? Let us drink our
 15387	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpints in peace. Gob, we won’t be let even do that much itself.
 15388	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15389	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, good health, Jack, says Ned.
 15390	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15391	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Good health, Ned, says J. J.
 15392	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15393	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—-There he is again, says Joe.
 15394	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15395	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Where? says Alf.
 15396	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15397	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd begob there he was passing the door with his books under his oxter
 15398	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand the wife beside him and Corny Kelleher with his wall eye looking in
 15399	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tas they went past, talking to him like a father, trying to sell him a
 15400	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsecondhand coffin.
 15401	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15402	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—How did that Canada swindle case go off? says Joe.
 15403	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15404	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Remanded, says J. J.
 15405	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15406	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOne of the bottlenosed fraternity it was went by the name of James
 15407	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWought alias Saphiro alias Spark and Spiro, put an ad in the papers
 15408	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaying he’d give a passage to Canada for twenty bob. What? Do you see
 15409	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tany green in the white of my eye? Course it was a bloody barney. What?
 15410	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSwindled them all, skivvies and badhachs from the county Meath, ay, and
 15411	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this own kidney too. J. J. was telling us there was an ancient Hebrew
 15412	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tZaretsky or something weeping in the witnessbox with his hat on him,
 15413	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tswearing by the holy Moses he was stuck for two quid.
 15414	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15415	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who tried the case? says Joe.
 15416	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15417	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Recorder, says Ned.
 15418	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15419	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Poor old sir Frederick, says Alf, you can cod him up to the two eyes.
 15420	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15421	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Heart as big as a lion, says Ned. Tell him a tale of woe about arrears
 15422	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof rent and a sick wife and a squad of kids and, faith, he’ll dissolve
 15423	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin tears on the bench.
 15424	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15425	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ay, says Alf. Reuben J was bloody lucky he didn’t clap him in the dock
 15426	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe other day for suing poor little Gumley that’s minding stones, for
 15427	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe corporation there near Butt bridge.
 15428	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15429	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd he starts taking off the old recorder letting on to cry:
 15430	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15431	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A most scandalous thing! This poor hardworking man! How many children?
 15432	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTen, did you say?
 15433	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15434	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, your worship. And my wife has the typhoid.
 15435	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15436	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And the wife with typhoid fever! Scandalous! Leave the court
 15437	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\timmediately, sir. No, sir, I’ll make no order for payment. How dare you,
 15438	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsir, come up before me and ask me to make an order! A poor hardworking
 15439	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tindustrious man! I dismiss the case.
 15440	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15441	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd whereas on the sixteenth day of the month of the oxeyed goddess and
 15442	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the third week after the feastday of the Holy and Undivided Trinity,
 15443	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe daughter of the skies, the virgin moon being then in her first
 15444	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquarter, it came to pass that those learned judges repaired them to the
 15445	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thalls of law. There master Courtenay, sitting in his own chamber, gave
 15446	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this rede and master Justice Andrews, sitting without a jury in the
 15447	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprobate court, weighed well and pondered the claim of the first
 15448	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchargeant upon the property in the matter of the will propounded and
 15449	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfinal testamentary disposition in re the real and personal estate of the
 15450	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlate lamented Jacob Halliday, vintner, deceased, versus Livingstone, an
 15451	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinfant, of unsound mind, and another. And to the solemn court of Green
 15452	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstreet there came sir Frederick the Falconer. And he sat him there about
 15453	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe hour of five o’clock to administer the law of the brehons at the
 15454	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcommission for all that and those parts to be holden in and for the
 15455	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcounty of the city of Dublin. And there sat with him the high sinhedrim
 15456	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the twelve tribes of Iar, for every tribe one man, of the tribe of
 15457	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPatrick and of the tribe of Hugh and of the tribe of Owen and of the
 15458	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttribe of Conn and of the tribe of Oscar and of the tribe of Fergus and
 15459	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the tribe of Finn and of the tribe of Dermot and of the tribe of
 15460	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCormac and of the tribe of Kevin and of the tribe of Caolte and of the
 15461	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttribe of Ossian, there being in all twelve good men and true. And he
 15462	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconjured them by Him who died on rood that they should well and
 15463	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttruly try and true deliverance make in the issue joined between their
 15464	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsovereign lord the king and the prisoner at the bar and true verdict
 15465	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgive according to the evidence so help them God and kiss the book. And
 15466	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey rose in their seats, those twelve of Iar, and they swore by
 15467	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe name of Him Who is from everlasting that they would do His
 15468	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trightwiseness. And straightway the minions of the law led forth from
 15469	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir donjon keep one whom the sleuthhounds of justice had apprehended
 15470	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin consequence of information received. And they shackled him hand and
 15471	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfoot and would take of him ne bail ne mainprise but preferred a charge
 15472	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tagainst him for he was a malefactor.
 15473	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15474	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Those are nice things, says the citizen, coming over here to Ireland
 15475	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfilling the country with bugs.
 15476	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15477	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo Bloom lets on he heard nothing and he starts talking with Joe,
 15478	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttelling him he needn’t trouble about that little matter till the first
 15479	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbut if he would just say a word to Mr Crawford. And so Joe swore high
 15480	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand holy by this and by that he’d do the devil and all.
 15481	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15482	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Because, you see, says Bloom, for an advertisement you must have
 15483	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trepetition. That’s the whole secret.
 15484	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15485	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Rely on me, says Joe.
 15486	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15487	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Swindling the peasants, says the citizen, and the poor of Ireland. We
 15488	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twant no more strangers in our house.
 15489	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15490	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, I’m sure that will be all right, Hynes, says Bloom. It’s just that
 15491	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKeyes, you see.
 15492	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15493	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Consider that done, says Joe.
 15494	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15495	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Very kind of you, says Bloom.
 15496	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15497	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The strangers, says the citizen. Our own fault. We let them come in.
 15498	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWe brought them in. The adulteress and her paramour brought the Saxon
 15499	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trobbers here.
 15500	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15501	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Decree nisi, says J. J.
 15502	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15503	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd Bloom letting on to be awfully deeply interested in nothing, a
 15504	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspider’s web in the corner behind the barrel, and the citizen scowling
 15505	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tafter him and the old dog at his feet looking up to know who to bite and
 15506	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhen.
 15507	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15508	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A dishonoured wife, says the citizen, that’s what’s the cause of all
 15509	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tour misfortunes.
 15510	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15511	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And here she is, says Alf, that was giggling over the Police Gazette
 15512	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith Terry on the counter, in all her warpaint.
 15513	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15514	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Give us a squint at her, says I.
 15515	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15516	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd what was it only one of the smutty yankee pictures Terry borrows off
 15517	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof Corny Kelleher. Secrets for enlarging your private parts. Misconduct
 15518	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof society belle. Norman W. Tupper, wealthy Chicago contractor, finds
 15519	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpretty but faithless wife in lap of officer Taylor. Belle in her
 15520	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbloomers misconducting herself, and her fancyman feeling for her tickles
 15521	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand Norman W. Tupper bouncing in with his peashooter just in time to be
 15522	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlate after she doing the trick of the loop with officer Taylor.
 15523	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15524	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O jakers, Jenny, says Joe, how short your shirt is!
 15525	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15526	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—There’s hair, Joe, says I. Get a queer old tailend of corned beef off
 15527	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof that one, what?
 15528	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15529	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo anyhow in came John Wyse Nolan and Lenehan with him with a face on
 15530	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim as long as a late breakfast.
 15531	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15532	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, says the citizen, what’s the latest from the scene of action?
 15533	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat did those tinkers in the city hall at their caucus meeting decide
 15534	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabout the Irish language?
 15535	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15536	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tO’Nolan, clad in shining armour, low bending made obeisance to the
 15537	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpuissant and high and mighty chief of all Erin and did him to wit of
 15538	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat which had befallen, how that the grave elders of the most obedient
 15539	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcity, second of the realm, had met them in the tholsel, and there, after
 15540	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdue prayers to the gods who dwell in ether supernal, had taken solemn
 15541	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcounsel whereby they might, if so be it might be, bring once more into
 15542	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thonour among mortal men the winged speech of the seadivided Gael.
 15543	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15544	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—It’s on the march, says the citizen. To hell with the bloody brutal
 15545	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSassenachs and their patois.
 15546	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15547	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo J. J. puts in a word, doing the toff about one story was good till
 15548	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou heard another and blinking facts and the Nelson policy, putting your
 15549	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblind eye to the telescope and drawing up a bill of attainder to impeach
 15550	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta nation, and Bloom trying to back him up moderation and botheration and
 15551	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir colonies and their civilisation.
 15552	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15553	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Their syphilisation, you mean, says the citizen. To hell with them! The
 15554	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcurse of a goodfornothing God light sideways on the bloody thicklugged
 15555	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsons of whores’ gets! No music and no art and no literature worthy of
 15556	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe name. Any civilisation they have they stole from us. Tonguetied sons
 15557	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof bastards’ ghosts.
 15558	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15559	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The European family, says J. J....
 15560	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15561	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—They’re not European, says the citizen. I was in Europe with Kevin Egan
 15562	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof Paris. You wouldn’t see a trace of them or their language anywhere in
 15563	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEurope except in a cabinet d’aisance.
 15564	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15565	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd says John Wyse:
 15566	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15567	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Full many a flower is born to blush unseen.
 15568	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15569	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd says Lenehan that knows a bit of the lingo:
 15570	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15571	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Conspuez les Anglais! Perfide Albion!
 15572	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15573	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe said and then lifted he in his rude great brawny strengthy hands the
 15574	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmedher of dark strong foamy ale and, uttering his tribal slogan Lamh
 15575	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDearg Abu, he drank to the undoing of his foes, a race of mighty
 15576	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvalorous heroes, rulers of the waves, who sit on thrones of alabaster
 15577	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsilent as the deathless gods.
 15578	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15579	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What’s up with you, says I to Lenehan. You look like a fellow that had
 15580	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlost a bob and found a tanner.
 15581	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15582	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Gold cup, says he.
 15583	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15584	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who won, Mr Lenehan? says Terry.
 15585	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15586	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Throwaway, says he, at twenty to one. A rank outsider. And the rest
 15587	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnowhere.
 15588	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15589	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And Bass’s mare? says Terry.
 15590	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15591	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Still running, says he. We’re all in a cart. Boylan plunged two quid on
 15592	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmy tip Sceptre for himself and a lady friend.
 15593	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15594	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I had half a crown myself, says Terry, on Zinfandel that Mr Flynn gave
 15595	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tme. Lord Howard de Walden’s.
 15596	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15597	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Twenty to one, says Lenehan. Such is life in an outhouse. Throwaway,
 15598	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsays he. Takes the biscuit, and talking about bunions. Frailty, thy name
 15599	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis Sceptre.
 15600	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15601	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo he went over to the biscuit tin Bob Doran left to see if there was
 15602	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanything he could lift on the nod, the old cur after him backing his
 15603	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tluck with his mangy snout up. Old Mother Hubbard went to the cupboard.
 15604	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15605	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Not there, my child, says he.
 15606	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15607	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Keep your pecker up, says Joe. She’d have won the money only for the
 15608	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tother dog.
 15609	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15610	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd J. J. and the citizen arguing about law and history with Bloom
 15611	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsticking in an odd word.
 15612	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15613	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Some people, says Bloom, can see the mote in others’ eyes but they
 15614	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcan’t see the beam in their own.
 15615	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15616	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Raimeis, says the citizen. There’s no-one as blind as the fellow that
 15617	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twon’t see, if you know what that means. Where are our missing twenty
 15618	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmillions of Irish should be here today instead of four, our lost tribes?
 15619	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd our potteries and textiles, the finest in the whole world! And our
 15620	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twool that was sold in Rome in the time of Juvenal and our flax and our
 15621	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdamask from the looms of Antrim and our Limerick lace, our tanneries and
 15622	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tour white flint glass down there by Ballybough and our Huguenot poplin
 15623	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat we have since Jacquard de Lyon and our woven silk and our Foxford
 15624	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttweeds and ivory raised point from the Carmelite convent in New Ross,
 15625	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnothing like it in the whole wide world. Where are the Greek merchants
 15626	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat came through the pillars of Hercules, the Gibraltar now grabbed by
 15627	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe foe of mankind, with gold and Tyrian purple to sell in Wexford at
 15628	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe fair of Carmen? Read Tacitus and Ptolemy, even Giraldus Cambrensis.
 15629	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWine, peltries, Connemara marble, silver from Tipperary, second to none,
 15630	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tour farfamed horses even today, the Irish hobbies, with king Philip
 15631	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof Spain offering to pay customs duties for the right to fish in our
 15632	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twaters. What do the yellowjohns of Anglia owe us for our ruined trade
 15633	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand our ruined hearths? And the beds of the Barrow and Shannon they
 15634	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twon’t deepen with millions of acres of marsh and bog to make us all die
 15635	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof consumption?
 15636	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15637	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—As treeless as Portugal we’ll be soon, says John Wyse, or Heligoland
 15638	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith its one tree if something is not done to reafforest the land.
 15639	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLarches, firs, all the trees of the conifer family are going fast. I was
 15640	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treading a report of lord Castletown’s...
 15641	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15642	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Save them, says the citizen, the giant ash of Galway and the chieftain
 15643	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\telm of Kildare with a fortyfoot bole and an acre of foliage. Save the
 15644	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttrees of Ireland for the future men of Ireland on the fair hills of
 15645	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEire, O.
 15646	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15647	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Europe has its eyes on you, says Lenehan.
 15648	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15649	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe fashionable international world attended en masse this afternoon
 15650	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat the wedding of the chevalier Jean Wyse de Neaulan, grand high chief
 15651	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tranger of the Irish National Foresters, with Miss Fir Conifer of Pine
 15652	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tValley. Lady Sylvester Elmshade, Mrs Barbara Lovebirch, Mrs Poll Ash,
 15653	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMrs Holly Hazeleyes, Miss Daphne Bays, Miss Dorothy Canebrake, Mrs Clyde
 15654	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTwelvetrees, Mrs Rowan Greene, Mrs Helen Vinegadding, Miss Virginia
 15655	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCreeper, Miss Gladys Beech, Miss Olive Garth, Miss Blanche Maple, Mrs
 15656	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMaud Mahogany, Miss Myra Myrtle, Miss Priscilla Elderflower, Miss
 15657	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBee Honeysuckle, Miss Grace Poplar, Miss O Mimosa San, Miss Rachel
 15658	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCedarfrond, the Misses Lilian and Viola Lilac, Miss Timidity Aspenall,
 15659	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMrs Kitty Dewey-Mosse, Miss May Hawthorne, Mrs Gloriana Palme, Mrs Liana
 15660	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tForrest, Mrs Arabella Blackwood and Mrs Norma Holyoake of Oakholme Regis
 15661	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgraced the ceremony by their presence. The bride who was given away by
 15662	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther father, the M’Conifer of the Glands, looked exquisitely charming in
 15663	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta creation carried out in green mercerised silk, moulded on an underslip
 15664	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof gloaming grey, sashed with a yoke of broad emerald and finished with
 15665	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta triple flounce of darkerhued fringe, the scheme being relieved by
 15666	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbretelles and hip insertions of acorn bronze. The maids of honour, Miss
 15667	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLarch Conifer and Miss Spruce Conifer, sisters of the bride, wore very
 15668	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbecoming costumes in the same tone, a dainty motif of plume rose being
 15669	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tworked into the pleats in a pinstripe and repeated capriciously in the
 15670	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjadegreen toques in the form of heron feathers of paletinted coral.
 15671	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSenhor Enrique Flor presided at the organ with his wellknown ability
 15672	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand, in addition to the prescribed numbers of the nuptial mass, played
 15673	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta new and striking arrangement of Woodman, spare that tree at the
 15674	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconclusion of the service. On leaving the church of Saint Fiacre in
 15675	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHorto after the papal blessing the happy pair were subjected to a
 15676	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplayful crossfire of hazelnuts, beechmast, bayleaves, catkins of willow,
 15677	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tivytod, hollyberries, mistletoe sprigs and quicken shoots. Mr and Mrs
 15678	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWyse Conifer Neaulan will spend a quiet honeymoon in the Black Forest.
 15679	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15680	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And our eyes are on Europe, says the citizen. We had our trade with
 15681	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSpain and the French and with the Flemings before those mongrels were
 15682	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpupped, Spanish ale in Galway, the winebark on the winedark waterway.
 15683	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15684	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And will again, says Joe.
 15685	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15686	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And with the help of the holy mother of God we will again, says the
 15687	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcitizen, clapping his thigh. Our harbours that are empty will be full
 15688	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tagain, Queenstown, Kinsale, Galway, Blacksod Bay, Ventry in the kingdom
 15689	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof Kerry, Killybegs, the third largest harbour in the wide world with
 15690	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta fleet of masts of the Galway Lynches and the Cavan O’Reillys and the
 15691	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tO’Kennedys of Dublin when the earl of Desmond could make a treaty with
 15692	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe emperor Charles the Fifth himself. And will again, says he, when the
 15693	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfirst Irish battleship is seen breasting the waves with our own flag to
 15694	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe fore, none of your Henry Tudor’s harps, no, the oldest flag afloat,
 15695	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe flag of the province of Desmond and Thomond, three crowns on a blue
 15696	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfield, the three sons of Milesius.
 15697	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15698	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd he took the last swig out of the pint. Moya. All wind and piss like
 15699	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta tanyard cat. Cows in Connacht have long horns. As much as his bloody
 15700	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlife is worth to go down and address his tall talk to the assembled
 15701	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmultitude in Shanagolden where he daren’t show his nose with the Molly
 15702	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMaguires looking for him to let daylight through him for grabbing the
 15703	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tholding of an evicted tenant.
 15704	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15705	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Hear, hear to that, says John Wyse. What will you have?
 15706	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15707	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—An imperial yeomanry, says Lenehan, to celebrate the occasion.
 15708	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15709	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Half one, Terry, says John Wyse, and a hands up. Terry! Are you asleep?
 15710	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15711	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, sir, says Terry. Small whisky and bottle of Allsop. Right, sir.
 15712	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15713	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHanging over the bloody paper with Alf looking for spicy bits instead of
 15714	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tattending to the general public. Picture of a butting match, trying to
 15715	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcrack their bloody skulls, one chap going for the other with his head
 15716	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdown like a bull at a gate. And another one: Black Beast Burned in
 15717	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOmaha, Ga. A lot of Deadwood Dicks in slouch hats and they firing at a
 15718	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSambo strung up in a tree with his tongue out and a bonfire under
 15719	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim. Gob, they ought to drown him in the sea after and electrocute and
 15720	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcrucify him to make sure of their job.
 15721	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15722	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—But what about the fighting navy, says Ned, that keeps our foes at bay?
 15723	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15724	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’ll tell you what about it, says the citizen. Hell upon earth it is.
 15725	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRead the revelations that’s going on in the papers about flogging on
 15726	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe training ships at Portsmouth. A fellow writes that calls himself
 15727	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDisgusted One.
 15728	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15729	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo he starts telling us about corporal punishment and about the crew
 15730	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof tars and officers and rearadmirals drawn up in cocked hats and the
 15731	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tparson with his protestant bible to witness punishment and a young lad
 15732	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrought out, howling for his ma, and they tie him down on the buttend of
 15733	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta gun.
 15734	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15735	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A rump and dozen, says the citizen, was what that old ruffian sir John
 15736	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBeresford called it but the modern God’s Englishman calls it caning on
 15737	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe breech.
 15738	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15739	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd says John Wyse:
 15740	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15741	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—‘Tis a custom more honoured in the breach than in the observance.
 15742	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15743	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThen he was telling us the master at arms comes along with a long cane
 15744	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand he draws out and he flogs the bloody backside off of the poor lad
 15745	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttill he yells meila murder.
 15746	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15747	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That’s your glorious British navy, says the citizen, that bosses the
 15748	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tearth. The fellows that never will be slaves, with the only hereditary
 15749	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchamber on the face of God’s earth and their land in the hands of a
 15750	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdozen gamehogs and cottonball barons. That’s the great empire they boast
 15751	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabout of drudges and whipped serfs.
 15752	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15753	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—On which the sun never rises, says Joe.
 15754	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15755	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And the tragedy of it is, says the citizen, they believe it. The
 15756	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunfortunate yahoos believe it.
 15757	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15758	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey believe in rod, the scourger almighty, creator of hell upon earth,
 15759	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand in Jacky Tar, the son of a gun, who was conceived of unholy boast,
 15760	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tborn of the fighting navy, suffered under rump and dozen, was scarified,
 15761	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tflayed and curried, yelled like bloody hell, the third day he arose
 15762	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tagain from the bed, steered into haven, sitteth on his beamend till
 15763	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfurther orders whence he shall come to drudge for a living and be paid.
 15764	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15765	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—But, says Bloom, isn’t discipline the same everywhere. I mean wouldn’t
 15766	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit be the same here if you put force against force?
 15767	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15768	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDidn’t I tell you? As true as I’m drinking this porter if he was at his
 15769	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlast gasp he’d try to downface you that dying was living.
 15770	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15771	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—We’ll put force against force, says the citizen. We have our greater
 15772	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIreland beyond the sea. They were driven out of house and home in the
 15773	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblack 47. Their mudcabins and their shielings by the roadside were laid
 15774	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlow by the batteringram and the Times rubbed its hands and told the
 15775	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhitelivered Saxons there would soon be as few Irish in Ireland as
 15776	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tredskins in America. Even the Grand Turk sent us his piastres. But the
 15777	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSassenach tried to starve the nation at home while the land was full
 15778	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof crops that the British hyenas bought and sold in Rio de Janeiro. Ay,
 15779	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey drove out the peasants in hordes. Twenty thousand of them died in
 15780	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe coffinships. But those that came to the land of the free remember
 15781	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe land of bondage. And they will come again and with a vengeance, no
 15782	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcravens, the sons of Granuaile, the champions of Kathleen ni Houlihan.
 15783	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15784	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Perfectly true, says Bloom. But my point was...
 15785	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15786	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—We are a long time waiting for that day, citizen, says Ned. Since the
 15787	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoor old woman told us that the French were on the sea and landed at
 15788	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKillala.
 15789	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15790	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ay, says John Wyse. We fought for the royal Stuarts that reneged us
 15791	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tagainst the Williamites and they betrayed us. Remember Limerick and the
 15792	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbroken treatystone. We gave our best blood to France and Spain, the
 15793	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twild geese. Fontenoy, eh? And Sarsfield and O’Donnell, duke of Tetuan
 15794	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin Spain, and Ulysses Browne of Camus that was fieldmarshal to Maria
 15795	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTeresa. But what did we ever get for it?
 15796	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15797	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The French! says the citizen. Set of dancing masters! Do you know what
 15798	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit is? They were never worth a roasted fart to Ireland. Aren’t they
 15799	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttrying to make an Entente cordiale now at Tay Pay’s dinnerparty with
 15800	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tperfidious Albion? Firebrands of Europe and they always were.
 15801	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15802	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Conspuez les Français, says Lenehan, nobbling his beer.
 15803	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15804	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And as for the Prooshians and the Hanoverians, says Joe, haven’t we
 15805	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thad enough of those sausageeating bastards on the throne from George the
 15806	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\telector down to the German lad and the flatulent old bitch that’s dead?
 15807	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15808	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJesus, I had to laugh at the way he came out with that about the old one
 15809	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith the winkers on her, blind drunk in her royal palace every night of
 15810	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGod, old Vic, with her jorum of mountain dew and her coachman carting
 15811	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther up body and bones to roll into bed and she pulling him by the
 15812	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhiskers and singing him old bits of songs about Ehren on the Rhine and
 15813	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcome where the boose is cheaper.
 15814	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15815	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, says J. J. We have Edward the peacemaker now.
 15816	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15817	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Tell that to a fool, says the citizen. There’s a bloody sight more pox
 15818	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthan pax about that boyo. Edward Guelph-Wettin!
 15819	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15820	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And what do you think, says Joe, of the holy boys, the priests
 15821	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand bishops of Ireland doing up his room in Maynooth in His Satanic
 15822	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMajesty’s racing colours and sticking up pictures of all the horses his
 15823	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjockeys rode. The earl of Dublin, no less.
 15824	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15825	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—They ought to have stuck up all the women he rode himself, says little
 15826	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAlf.
 15827	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15828	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd says J. J.:
 15829	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15830	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Considerations of space influenced their lordships’ decision.
 15831	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15832	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Will you try another, citizen? says Joe.
 15833	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15834	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, sir, says he. I will.
 15835	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15836	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You? says Joe.
 15837	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15838	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Beholden to you, Joe, says I. May your shadow never grow less.
 15839	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15840	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Repeat that dose, says Joe.
 15841	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15842	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBloom was talking and talking with John Wyse and he quite excited with
 15843	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this dunducketymudcoloured mug on him and his old plumeyes rolling about.
 15844	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15845	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Persecution, says he, all the history of the world is full of it.
 15846	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPerpetuating national hatred among nations.
 15847	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15848	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—But do you know what a nation means? says John Wyse.
 15849	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15850	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, says Bloom.
 15851	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15852	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What is it? says John Wyse.
 15853	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15854	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A nation? says Bloom. A nation is the same people living in the same
 15855	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplace.
 15856	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15857	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—By God, then, says Ned, laughing, if that’s so I’m a nation for I’m
 15858	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tliving in the same place for the past five years.
 15859	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15860	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo of course everyone had the laugh at Bloom and says he, trying to muck
 15861	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tout of it:
 15862	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15863	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Or also living in different places.
 15864	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15865	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That covers my case, says Joe.
 15866	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15867	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What is your nation if I may ask? says the citizen.
 15868	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15869	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ireland, says Bloom. I was born here. Ireland.
 15870	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15871	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe citizen said nothing only cleared the spit out of his gullet and,
 15872	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgob, he spat a Red bank oyster out of him right in the corner.
 15873	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15874	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—After you with the push, Joe, says he, taking out his handkerchief to
 15875	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tswab himself dry.
 15876	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15877	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Here you are, citizen, says Joe. Take that in your right hand and
 15878	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trepeat after me the following words.
 15879	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15880	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe muchtreasured and intricately embroidered ancient Irish facecloth
 15881	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tattributed to Solomon of Droma and Manus Tomaltach og MacDonogh, authors
 15882	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the Book of Ballymote, was then carefully produced and called forth
 15883	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprolonged admiration. No need to dwell on the legendary beauty of the
 15884	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcornerpieces, the acme of art, wherein one can distinctly discern each
 15885	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the four evangelists in turn presenting to each of the four masters
 15886	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this evangelical symbol, a bogoak sceptre, a North American puma (a far
 15887	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnobler king of beasts than the British article, be it said in passing),
 15888	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta Kerry calf and a golden eagle from Carrantuohill. The scenes depicted
 15889	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton the emunctory field, showing our ancient duns and raths and cromlechs
 15890	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand grianauns and seats of learning and maledictive stones, are as
 15891	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twonderfully beautiful and the pigments as delicate as when the Sligo
 15892	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tilluminators gave free rein to their artistic fantasy long long ago in
 15893	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe time of the Barmecides. Glendalough, the lovely lakes of Killarney,
 15894	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe ruins of Clonmacnois, Cong Abbey, Glen Inagh and the Twelve Pins,
 15895	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIreland’s Eye, the Green Hills of Tallaght, Croagh Patrick, the brewery
 15896	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof Messrs Arthur Guinness, Son and Company (Limited), Lough Neagh’s
 15897	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbanks, the vale of Ovoca, Isolde’s tower, the Mapas obelisk, Sir Patrick
 15898	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDun’s hospital, Cape Clear, the glen of Aherlow, Lynch’s castle, the
 15899	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tScotch house, Rathdown Union Workhouse at Loughlinstown, Tullamore jail,
 15900	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCastleconnel rapids, Kilballymacshonakill, the cross at Monasterboice,
 15901	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJury’s Hotel, S. Patrick’s Purgatory, the Salmon Leap, Maynooth college
 15902	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trefectory, Curley’s hole, the three birthplaces of the first duke of
 15903	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWellington, the rock of Cashel, the bog of Allen, the Henry Street
 15904	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWarehouse, Fingal’s Cave—all these moving scenes are still there for us
 15905	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoday rendered more beautiful still by the waters of sorrow which have
 15906	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpassed over them and by the rich incrustations of time.
 15907	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15908	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Show us over the drink, says I. Which is which?
 15909	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15910	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That’s mine, says Joe, as the devil said to the dead policeman.
 15911	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15912	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And I belong to a race too, says Bloom, that is hated and persecuted.
 15913	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAlso now. This very moment. This very instant.
 15914	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15915	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGob, he near burnt his fingers with the butt of his old cigar.
 15916	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15917	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Robbed, says he. Plundered. Insulted. Persecuted. Taking what belongs
 15918	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto us by right. At this very moment, says he, putting up his fist, sold
 15919	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby auction in Morocco like slaves or cattle.
 15920	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15921	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Are you talking about the new Jerusalem? says the citizen.
 15922	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15923	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’m talking about injustice, says Bloom.
 15924	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15925	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Right, says John Wyse. Stand up to it then with force like men.
 15926	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15927	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThat’s an almanac picture for you. Mark for a softnosed bullet. Old
 15928	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlardyface standing up to the business end of a gun. Gob, he’d adorn a
 15929	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsweepingbrush, so he would, if he only had a nurse’s apron on him. And
 15930	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthen he collapses all of a sudden, twisting around all the opposite, as
 15931	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlimp as a wet rag.
 15932	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15933	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—But it’s no use, says he. Force, hatred, history, all that. That’s not
 15934	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlife for men and women, insult and hatred. And everybody knows that it’s
 15935	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe very opposite of that that is really life.
 15936	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15937	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What? says Alf.
 15938	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15939	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Love, says Bloom. I mean the opposite of hatred. I must go now, says
 15940	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the to John Wyse. Just round to the court a moment to see if Martin is
 15941	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthere. If he comes just say I’ll be back in a second. Just a moment.
 15942	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15943	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWho’s hindering you? And off he pops like greased lightning.
 15944	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15945	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A new apostle to the gentiles, says the citizen. Universal love.
 15946	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15947	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, says John Wyse. Isn’t that what we’re told. Love your neighbour.
 15948	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15949	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That chap? says the citizen. Beggar my neighbour is his motto. Love,
 15950	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmoya! He’s a nice pattern of a Romeo and Juliet.
 15951	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15952	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLove loves to love love. Nurse loves the new chemist. Constable 14A
 15953	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tloves Mary Kelly. Gerty MacDowell loves the boy that has the bicycle. M.
 15954	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tB. loves a fair gentleman. Li Chi Han lovey up kissy Cha Pu Chow. Jumbo,
 15955	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe elephant, loves Alice, the elephant. Old Mr Verschoyle with the ear
 15956	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttrumpet loves old Mrs Verschoyle with the turnedin eye. The man in the
 15957	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrown macintosh loves a lady who is dead. His Majesty the King loves Her
 15958	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMajesty the Queen. Mrs Norman W. Tupper loves officer Taylor. You love
 15959	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta certain person. And this person loves that other person because
 15960	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teverybody loves somebody but God loves everybody.
 15961	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15962	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, Joe, says I, your very good health and song. More power, citizen.
 15963	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15964	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Hurrah, there, says Joe.
 15965	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15966	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—The blessing of God and Mary and Patrick on you, says the citizen.
 15967	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15968	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd he ups with his pint to wet his whistle.
 15969	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15970	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—We know those canters, says he, preaching and picking your pocket. What
 15971	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabout sanctimonious Cromwell and his ironsides that put the women and
 15972	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchildren of Drogheda to the sword with the bible text God is love pasted
 15973	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tround the mouth of his cannon? The bible! Did you read that skit in the
 15974	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tUnited Irishman today about that Zulu chief that’s visiting England?
 15975	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15976	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What’s that? says Joe.
 15977	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15978	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo the citizen takes up one of his paraphernalia papers and he starts
 15979	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treading out:
 15980	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 15981	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A delegation of the chief cotton magnates of Manchester was presented
 15982	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyesterday to His Majesty the Alaki of Abeakuta by Gold Stick in Waiting,
 15983	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLord Walkup of Walkup on Eggs, to tender to His Majesty the heartfelt
 15984	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthanks of British traders for the facilities afforded them in his
 15985	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdominions. The delegation partook of luncheon at the conclusion of which
 15986	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe dusky potentate, in the course of a happy speech, freely translated
 15987	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby the British chaplain, the reverend Ananias Praisegod Barebones,
 15988	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttendered his best thanks to Massa Walkup and emphasised the cordial
 15989	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trelations existing between Abeakuta and the British empire, stating that
 15990	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the treasured as one of his dearest possessions an illuminated bible,
 15991	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe volume of the word of God and the secret of England’s greatness,
 15992	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgraciously presented to him by the white chief woman, the great squaw
 15993	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tVictoria, with a personal dedication from the august hand of the Royal
 15994	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDonor. The Alaki then drank a lovingcup of firstshot usquebaugh to the
 15995	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoast Black and White from the skull of his immediate predecessor in the
 15996	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdynasty Kakachakachak, surnamed Forty Warts, after which he visited the
 15997	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchief factory of Cottonopolis and signed his mark in the visitors’ book,
 15998	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsubsequently executing a charming old Abeakutic wardance, in the course
 15999	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof which he swallowed several knives and forks, amid hilarious applause
 16000	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom the girl hands.
 16001	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16002	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Widow woman, says Ned. I wouldn’t doubt her. Wonder did he put that
 16003	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbible to the same use as I would.
 16004	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16005	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Same only more so, says Lenehan. And thereafter in that fruitful land
 16006	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe broadleaved mango flourished exceedingly.
 16007	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16008	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Is that by Griffith? says John Wyse.
 16009	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16010	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—No, says the citizen. It’s not signed Shanganagh. It’s only initialled:
 16011	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tP.
 16012	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16013	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And a very good initial too, says Joe.
 16014	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16015	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That’s how it’s worked, says the citizen. Trade follows the flag.
 16016	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16017	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, says J. J., if they’re any worse than those Belgians in the Congo
 16018	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFree State they must be bad. Did you read that report by a man what’s
 16019	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthis his name is?
 16020	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16021	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Casement, says the citizen. He’s an Irishman.
 16022	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16023	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, that’s the man, says J. J. Raping the women and girls and flogging
 16024	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe natives on the belly to squeeze all the red rubber they can out of
 16025	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem.
 16026	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16027	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I know where he’s gone, says Lenehan, cracking his fingers.
 16028	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16029	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who? says I.
 16030	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16031	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Bloom, says he. The courthouse is a blind. He had a few bob on
 16032	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThrowaway and he’s gone to gather in the shekels.
 16033	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16034	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Is it that whiteeyed kaffir? says the citizen, that never backed a
 16035	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thorse in anger in his life?
 16036	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16037	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That’s where he’s gone, says Lenehan. I met Bantam Lyons going to back
 16038	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat horse only I put him off it and he told me Bloom gave him the tip.
 16039	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBet you what you like he has a hundred shillings to five on. He’s the
 16040	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tonly man in Dublin has it. A dark horse.
 16041	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16042	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He’s a bloody dark horse himself, says Joe.
 16043	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16044	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Mind, Joe, says I. Show us the entrance out.
 16045	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16046	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—There you are, says Terry.
 16047	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16048	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGoodbye Ireland I’m going to Gort. So I just went round the back of
 16049	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe yard to pumpship and begob (hundred shillings to five) while I was
 16050	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tletting off my (Throwaway twenty to) letting off my load gob says I
 16051	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto myself I knew he was uneasy in his (two pints off of Joe and one in
 16052	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSlattery’s off) in his mind to get off the mark to (hundred shillings
 16053	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis five quid) and when they were in the (dark horse) pisser Burke was
 16054	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttelling me card party and letting on the child was sick (gob, must have
 16055	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdone about a gallon) flabbyarse of a wife speaking down the tube she’s
 16056	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbetter or she’s (ow!) all a plan so he could vamoose with the pool if he
 16057	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twon or (Jesus, full up I was) trading without a licence (ow!) Ireland my
 16058	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnation says he (hoik! phthook!) never be up to those bloody (there’s the
 16059	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlast of it) Jerusalem (ah!) cuckoos.
 16060	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16061	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo anyhow when I got back they were at it dingdong, John Wyse saying it
 16062	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas Bloom gave the ideas for Sinn Fein to Griffith to put in his paper
 16063	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall kinds of jerrymandering, packed juries and swindling the taxes off
 16064	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the government and appointing consuls all over the world to walk
 16065	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabout selling Irish industries. Robbing Peter to pay Paul. Gob, that
 16066	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tputs the bloody kybosh on it if old sloppy eyes is mucking up the show.
 16067	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGive us a bloody chance. God save Ireland from the likes of that bloody
 16068	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmouseabout. Mr Bloom with his argol bargol. And his old fellow before
 16069	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim perpetrating frauds, old Methusalem Bloom, the robbing bagman, that
 16070	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoisoned himself with the prussic acid after he swamping the country
 16071	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith his baubles and his penny diamonds. Loans by post on easy terms.
 16072	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAny amount of money advanced on note of hand. Distance no object. No
 16073	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsecurity. Gob, he’s like Lanty MacHale’s goat that’d go a piece of the
 16074	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\troad with every one.
 16075	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16076	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, it’s a fact, says John Wyse. And there’s the man now that’ll tell
 16077	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou all about it, Martin Cunningham.
 16078	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16079	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSure enough the castle car drove up with Martin on it and Jack Power
 16080	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith him and a fellow named Crofter or Crofton, pensioner out of
 16081	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe collector general’s, an orangeman Blackburn does have on the
 16082	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tregistration and he drawing his pay or Crawford gallivanting around the
 16083	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcountry at the king’s expense.
 16084	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16085	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOur travellers reached the rustic hostelry and alighted from their
 16086	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpalfreys.
 16087	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16088	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Ho, varlet! cried he, who by his mien seemed the leader of the party.
 16089	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSaucy knave! To us!
 16090	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16091	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo saying he knocked loudly with his swordhilt upon the open lattice.
 16092	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16093	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMine host came forth at the summons, girding him with his tabard.
 16094	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16095	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Give you good den, my masters, said he with an obsequious bow.
 16096	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16097	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Bestir thyself, sirrah! cried he who had knocked. Look to our steeds.
 16098	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd for ourselves give us of your best for ifaith we need it.
 16099	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16100	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Lackaday, good masters, said the host, my poor house has but a bare
 16101	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlarder. I know not what to offer your lordships.
 16102	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16103	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—How now, fellow? cried the second of the party, a man of pleasant
 16104	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcountenance, So servest thou the king’s messengers, master Taptun?
 16105	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16106	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAn instantaneous change overspread the landlord’s visage.
 16107	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16108	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Cry you mercy, gentlemen, he said humbly. An you be the king’s
 16109	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmessengers (God shield His Majesty!) you shall not want for aught. The
 16110	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tking’s friends (God bless His Majesty!) shall not go afasting in my
 16111	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thouse I warrant me.
 16112	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16113	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Then about! cried the traveller who had not spoken, a lusty trencherman
 16114	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby his aspect. Hast aught to give us?
 16115	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16116	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMine host bowed again as he made answer:
 16117	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16118	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What say you, good masters, to a squab pigeon pasty, some collops of
 16119	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvenison, a saddle of veal, widgeon with crisp hog’s bacon, a boar’s head
 16120	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith pistachios, a bason of jolly custard, a medlar tansy and a flagon
 16121	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof old Rhenish?
 16122	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16123	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Gadzooks! cried the last speaker. That likes me well. Pistachios!
 16124	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16125	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Aha! cried he of the pleasant countenance. A poor house and a bare
 16126	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlarder, quotha! ‘Tis a merry rogue.
 16127	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16128	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo in comes Martin asking where was Bloom.
 16129	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16130	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Where is he? says Lenehan. Defrauding widows and orphans.
 16131	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16132	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Isn’t that a fact, says John Wyse, what I was telling the citizen about
 16133	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBloom and the Sinn Fein?
 16134	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16135	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That’s so, says Martin. Or so they allege.
 16136	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16137	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who made those allegations? says Alf.
 16138	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16139	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I, says Joe. I’m the alligator.
 16140	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16141	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And after all, says John Wyse, why can’t a jew love his country like
 16142	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe next fellow?
 16143	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16144	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Why not? says J. J., when he’s quite sure which country it is.
 16145	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16146	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Is he a jew or a gentile or a holy Roman or a swaddler or what the hell
 16147	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis he? says Ned. Or who is he? No offence, Crofton.
 16148	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16149	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Who is Junius? says J. J.
 16150	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16151	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—We don’t want him, says Crofter the Orangeman or presbyterian.
 16152	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16153	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He’s a perverted jew, says Martin, from a place in Hungary and it was
 16154	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the drew up all the plans according to the Hungarian system. We know that
 16155	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the castle.
 16156	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16157	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Isn’t he a cousin of Bloom the dentist? says Jack Power.
 16158	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16159	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Not at all, says Martin. Only namesakes. His name was Virag, the
 16160	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfather’s name that poisoned himself. He changed it by deedpoll, the
 16161	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfather did.
 16162	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16163	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—That’s the new Messiah for Ireland! says the citizen. Island of saints
 16164	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand sages!
 16165	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16166	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, they’re still waiting for their redeemer, says Martin. For that
 16167	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmatter so are we.
 16168	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16169	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Yes, says J. J., and every male that’s born they think it may be their
 16170	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMessiah. And every jew is in a tall state of excitement, I believe, till
 16171	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the knows if he’s a father or a mother.
 16172	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16173	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Expecting every moment will be his next, says Lenehan.
 16174	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16175	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, by God, says Ned, you should have seen Bloom before that son of his
 16176	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat died was born. I met him one day in the south city markets buying a
 16177	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttin of Neave’s food six weeks before the wife was delivered.
 16178	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16179	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—En ventre sa mère, says J. J.
 16180	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16181	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Do you call that a man? says the citizen.
 16182	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16183	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I wonder did he ever put it out of sight, says Joe.
 16184	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16185	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, there were two children born anyhow, says Jack Power.
 16186	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16187	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And who does he suspect? says the citizen.
 16188	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16189	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGob, there’s many a true word spoken in jest. One of those mixed
 16190	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmiddlings he is. Lying up in the hotel Pisser was telling me once a
 16191	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmonth with headache like a totty with her courses. Do you know what I’m
 16192	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttelling you? It’d be an act of God to take a hold of a fellow the like
 16193	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof that and throw him in the bloody sea. Justifiable homicide, so it
 16194	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twould. Then sloping off with his five quid without putting up a pint of
 16195	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstuff like a man. Give us your blessing. Not as much as would blind your
 16196	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teye.
 16197	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16198	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Charity to the neighbour, says Martin. But where is he? We can’t wait.
 16199	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16200	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A wolf in sheep’s clothing, says the citizen. That’s what he is. Virag
 16201	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom Hungary! Ahasuerus I call him. Cursed by God.
 16202	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16203	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Have you time for a brief libation, Martin? says Ned.
 16204	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16205	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Only one, says Martin. We must be quick. J. J. and S.
 16206	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16207	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You, Jack? Crofton? Three half ones, Terry.
 16208	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16209	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Saint Patrick would want to land again at Ballykinlar and convert us,
 16210	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsays the citizen, after allowing things like that to contaminate our
 16211	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshores.
 16212	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16213	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, says Martin, rapping for his glass. God bless all here is my
 16214	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprayer.
 16215	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16216	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Amen, says the citizen.
 16217	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16218	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And I’m sure He will, says Joe.
 16219	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16220	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd at the sound of the sacring bell, headed by a crucifer with
 16221	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tacolytes, thurifers, boatbearers, readers, ostiarii, deacons and
 16222	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsubdeacons, the blessed company drew nigh of mitred abbots and priors
 16223	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand guardians and monks and friars: the monks of Benedict of Spoleto,
 16224	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCarthusians and Camaldolesi, Cistercians and Olivetans, Oratorians
 16225	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand Vallombrosans, and the friars of Augustine, Brigittines,
 16226	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPremonstratensians, Servi, Trinitarians, and the children of Peter
 16227	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNolasco: and therewith from Carmel mount the children of Elijah prophet
 16228	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tled by Albert bishop and by Teresa of Avila, calced and other: and
 16229	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfriars, brown and grey, sons of poor Francis, capuchins, cordeliers,
 16230	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tminimes and observants and the daughters of Clara: and the sons of
 16231	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDominic, the friars preachers, and the sons of Vincent: and the monks
 16232	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof S. Wolstan: and Ignatius his children: and the confraternity of the
 16233	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchristian brothers led by the reverend brother Edmund Ignatius Rice. And

 16248	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand S. Michan and S. Herman-Joseph and the three patrons of holy youth
