 16250	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand the saints Gervasius, Servasius and Bonifacius and S. Bride and S.
 16251	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKieran and S. Canice of Kilkenny and S. Jarlath of Tuam and S. Finbarr
 16252	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand S. Pappin of Ballymun and Brother Aloysius Pacificus and Brother
 16253	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLouis Bellicosus and the saints Rose of Lima and of Viterbo and S.
 16254	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMartha of Bethany and S. Mary of Egypt and S. Lucy and S. Brigid and
 16255	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tS. Attracta and S. Dympna and S. Ita and S. Marion Calpensis and
 16256	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe Blessed Sister Teresa of the Child Jesus and S. Barbara and S.
 16257	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tScholastica and S. Ursula with eleven thousand virgins. And all came
 16258	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith nimbi and aureoles and gloriae, bearing palms and harps and swords
 16259	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand olive crowns, in robes whereon were woven the blessed symbols of
 16260	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir efficacies, inkhorns, arrows, loaves, cruses, fetters, axes,
 16261	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttrees, bridges, babes in a bathtub, shells, wallets, shears, keys,
 16262	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdragons, lilies, buckshot, beards, hogs, lamps, bellows, beehives,
 16263	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsoupladles, stars, snakes, anvils, boxes of vaseline, bells, crutches,
 16264	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tforceps, stags’ horns, watertight boots, hawks, millstones, eyes on a
 16265	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdish, wax candles, aspergills, unicorns. And as they wended their way by
 16266	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNelson’s Pillar, Henry street, Mary street, Capel street, Little Britain
 16267	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstreet chanting the introit in Epiphania Domini which beginneth Surge,
 16268	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tilluminare and thereafter most sweetly the gradual Omnes which saith de
 16269	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSaba venient they did divers wonders such as casting out devils, raising
 16270	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe dead to life, multiplying fishes, healing the halt and the blind,
 16271	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdiscovering various articles which had been mislaid, interpreting and
 16272	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfulfilling the scriptures, blessing and prophesying. And last, beneath
 16273	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta canopy of cloth of gold came the reverend Father O’Flynn attended by
 16274	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMalachi and Patrick. And when the good fathers had reached the appointed
 16275	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplace, the house of Bernard Kiernan and Co, limited, 8, 9 and 10 little
 16276	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBritain street, wholesale grocers, wine and brandy shippers, licensed fo
 16277	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe sale of beer, wine and spirits for consumption on the premises, the
 16278	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcelebrant blessed the house and censed the mullioned windows and
 16279	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe groynes and the vaults and the arrises and the capitals and the
 16280	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpediments and the cornices and the engrailed arches and the spires and
 16281	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe cupolas and sprinkled the lintels thereof with blessed water and
 16282	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprayed that God might bless that house as he had blessed the house of
 16283	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAbraham and Isaac and Jacob and make the angels of His light to inhabit
 16284	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttherein. And entering he blessed the viands and the beverages and the
 16285	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcompany of all the blessed answered his prayers.
 16286	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16287	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Adiutorium nostrum in nomine Domini.
 16288	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16289	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Qui fecit cœlum et terram.
 16290	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16291	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Dominus vobiscum.
 16292	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16293	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Et cum spiritu tuo.
 16294	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16295	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd he laid his hands upon that he blessed and gave thanks and he prayed
 16296	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand they all with him prayed:
 16297	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16298	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Deus, cuius verbo sanctificantur omnia, benedictionem tuam effunde
 16299	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsuper creaturas istas: et praesta ut quisquis eis secundum legem et
 16300	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvoluntatem Tuam cum gratiarum actione usus fuerit per invocationem
 16301	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsanctissimi nominis Tui corporis sanitatem et animæ tutelam Te auctore
 16302	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpercipiat per Christum Dominum nostrum.
 16303	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16304	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—And so say all of us, says Jack.
 16305	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16306	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Thousand a year, Lambert, says Crofton or Crawford.
 16307	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16308	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Right, says Ned, taking up his John Jameson. And butter for fish.
 16309	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16310	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI was just looking around to see who the happy thought would strike when
 16311	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbe damned but in he comes again letting on to be in a hell of a hurry.
 16312	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16313	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I was just round at the courthouse, says he, looking for you. I hope
 16314	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI’m not...
 16315	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16316	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—No, says Martin, we’re ready.
 16317	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16318	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCourthouse my eye and your pockets hanging down with gold and silver.
 16319	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMean bloody scut. Stand us a drink itself. Devil a sweet fear! There’s
 16320	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta jew for you! All for number one. Cute as a shithouse rat. Hundred to
 16321	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfive.
 16322	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16323	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Don’t tell anyone, says the citizen,
 16324	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16325	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Beg your pardon, says he.
 16326	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16327	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Come on boys, says Martin, seeing it was looking blue. Come along now.
 16328	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16329	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Don’t tell anyone, says the citizen, letting a bawl out of him. It’s a
 16330	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsecret.
 16331	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16332	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd the bloody dog woke up and let a growl.
 16333	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16334	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Bye bye all, says Martin.
 16335	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16336	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd he got them out as quick as he could, Jack Power and Crofton or
 16337	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhatever you call him and him in the middle of them letting on to be all
 16338	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat sea and up with them on the bloody jaunting car.
 16339	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16340	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Off with you, says Martin to the jarvey.
 16341	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16342	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe milkwhite dolphin tossed his mane and, rising in the golden poop the
 16343	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thelmsman spread the bellying sail upon the wind and stood off forward
 16344	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith all sail set, the spinnaker to larboard. A many comely nymphs drew
 16345	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnigh to starboard and to larboard and, clinging to the sides of
 16346	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe noble bark, they linked their shining forms as doth the cunning
 16347	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twheelwright when he fashions about the heart of his wheel the
 16348	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tequidistant rays whereof each one is sister to another and he binds them
 16349	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall with an outer ring and giveth speed to the feet of men whenas they
 16350	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tride to a hosting or contend for the smile of ladies fair. Even so did
 16351	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey come and set them, those willing nymphs, the undying sisters. And
 16352	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey laughed, sporting in a circle of their foam: and the bark clave the
 16353	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twaves.
 16354	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16355	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBut begob I was just lowering the heel of the pint when I saw the
 16356	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcitizen getting up to waddle to the door, puffing and blowing with the
 16357	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdropsy, and he cursing the curse of Cromwell on him, bell, book and
 16358	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcandle in Irish, spitting and spatting out of him and Joe and little Alf
 16359	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tround him like a leprechaun trying to peacify him.
 16360	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16361	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Let me alone, says he.
 16362	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16363	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd begob he got as far as the door and they holding him and he bawls
 16364	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tout of him:
 16365	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16366	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Three cheers for Israel!
 16367	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16368	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tArrah, sit down on the parliamentary side of your arse for Christ’ sake
 16369	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand don’t be making a public exhibition of yourself. Jesus, there’s
 16370	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\talways some bloody clown or other kicking up a bloody murder about
 16371	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbloody nothing. Gob, it’d turn the porter sour in your guts, so it
 16372	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twould.
 16373	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16374	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd all the ragamuffins and sluts of the nation round the door and
 16375	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMartin telling the jarvey to drive ahead and the citizen bawling and Alf
 16376	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand Joe at him to whisht and he on his high horse about the jews and
 16377	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe loafers calling for a speech and Jack Power trying to get him to sit
 16378	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdown on the car and hold his bloody jaw and a loafer with a patch over
 16379	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this eye starts singing If the man in the moon was a jew, jew, jew and a
 16380	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tslut shouts out of her:
 16381	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16382	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Eh, mister! Your fly is open, mister!
 16383	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16384	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd says he:
 16385	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16386	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Mendelssohn was a jew and Karl Marx and Mercadante and Spinoza. And the
 16387	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSaviour was a jew and his father was a jew. Your God.
 16388	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16389	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—He had no father, says Martin. That’ll do now. Drive ahead.
 16390	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16391	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Whose God? says the citizen.
 16392	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16393	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Well, his uncle was a jew, says he. Your God was a jew. Christ was a
 16394	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjew like me.
 16395	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16396	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGob, the citizen made a plunge back into the shop.
 16397	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16398	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—By Jesus, says he, I’ll brain that bloody jewman for using the holy
 16399	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tname.
 16400	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16401	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBy Jesus, I’ll crucify him so I will. Give us that biscuitbox here.
 16402	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16403	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Stop! Stop! says Joe.
 16404	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16405	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA large and appreciative gathering of friends and acquaintances from
 16406	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe metropolis and greater Dublin assembled in their thousands to bid
 16407	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfarewell to Nagyaságos uram Lipóti Virag, late of Messrs Alexander
 16408	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThom’s, printers to His Majesty, on the occasion of his departure
 16409	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor the distant clime of Százharminczbrojúgulyás-Dugulás (Meadow of
 16410	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMurmuring Waters). The ceremony which went off with great éclat was
 16411	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcharacterised by the most affecting cordiality. An illuminated scroll
 16412	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof ancient Irish vellum, the work of Irish artists, was presented to
 16413	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe distinguished phenomenologist on behalf of a large section of the
 16414	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcommunity and was accompanied by the gift of a silver casket, tastefully
 16415	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\texecuted in the style of ancient Celtic ornament, a work which reflects
 16416	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tevery credit on the makers, Messrs Jacob agus Jacob. The departing guest
 16417	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas the recipient of a hearty ovation, many of those who were present
 16418	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeing visibly moved when the select orchestra of Irish pipes struck
 16419	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tup the wellknown strains of Come Back to Erin, followed immediately
 16420	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby Rakóczsy’s March. Tarbarrels and bonfires were lighted along the
 16421	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcoastline of the four seas on the summits of the Hill of Howth, Three
 16422	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRock Mountain, Sugarloaf, Bray Head, the mountains of Mourne, the
 16423	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGaltees, the Ox and Donegal and Sperrin peaks, the Nagles and the
 16424	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBograghs, the Connemara hills, the reeks of M’Gillicuddy, Slieve Aughty,
 16425	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSlieve Bernagh and Slieve Bloom. Amid cheers that rent the welkin,
 16426	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tresponded to by answering cheers from a big muster of henchmen on the
 16427	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdistant Cambrian and Caledonian hills, the mastodontic pleasureship
 16428	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tslowly moved away saluted by a final floral tribute from the
 16429	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trepresentatives of the fair sex who were present in large numbers while,
 16430	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tas it proceeded down the river, escorted by a flotilla of barges, the
 16431	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tflags of the Ballast office and Custom House were dipped in salute as
 16432	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twere also those of the electrical power station at the Pigeonhouse and
 16433	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe Poolbeg Light. Visszontlátásra, kedvés barátom! Visszontlátásra!
 16434	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGone but not forgotten.
 16435	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16436	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGob, the devil wouldn’t stop him till he got hold of the bloody tin
 16437	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanyhow and out with him and little Alf hanging on to his elbow and he
 16438	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshouting like a stuck pig, as good as any bloody play in the Queen’s
 16439	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\troyal theatre:
 16440	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16441	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Where is he till I murder him?
 16442	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16443	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd Ned and J. J. paralysed with the laughing.
 16444	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16445	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Bloody wars, says I, I’ll be in for the last gospel.
 16446	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16447	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBut as luck would have it the jarvey got the nag’s head round the other
 16448	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tway and off with him.
 16449	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16450	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Hold on, citizen, says Joe. Stop!
 16451	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16452	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBegob he drew his hand and made a swipe and let fly. Mercy of God the
 16453	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsun was in his eyes or he’d have left him for dead. Gob, he near sent it
 16454	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinto the county Longford. The bloody nag took fright and the old
 16455	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmongrel after the car like bloody hell and all the populace shouting and
 16456	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlaughing and the old tinbox clattering along the street.
 16457	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16458	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe catastrophe was terrific and instantaneous in its effect. The
 16459	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tobservatory of Dunsink registered in all eleven shocks, all of the fifth
 16460	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgrade of Mercalli’s scale, and there is no record extant of a similar
 16461	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseismic disturbance in our island since the earthquake of 1534, the year
 16462	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the rebellion of Silken Thomas. The epicentre appears to have been
 16463	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat part of the metropolis which constitutes the Inn’s Quay ward and
 16464	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tparish of Saint Michan covering a surface of fortyone acres, two roods
 16465	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand one square pole or perch. All the lordly residences in the vicinity
 16466	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the palace of justice were demolished and that noble edifice itself,
 16467	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin which at the time of the catastrophe important legal debates were in
 16468	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprogress, is literally a mass of ruins beneath which it is to be
 16469	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfeared all the occupants have been buried alive. From the reports of
 16470	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teyewitnesses it transpires that the seismic waves were accompanied by
 16471	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta violent atmospheric perturbation of cyclonic character. An article of
 16472	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theadgear since ascertained to belong to the much respected clerk of the
 16473	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcrown and peace Mr George Fottrell and a silk umbrella with gold handle
 16474	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith the engraved initials, crest, coat of arms and house number of
 16475	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe erudite and worshipful chairman of quarter sessions sir Frederick
 16476	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFalkiner, recorder of Dublin, have been discovered by search parties
 16477	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin remote parts of the island respectively, the former on the third
 16478	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbasaltic ridge of the giant’s causeway, the latter embedded to the
 16479	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\textent of one foot three inches in the sandy beach of Holeopen bay near
 16480	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe old head of Kinsale. Other eyewitnesses depose that they observed
 16481	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tan incandescent object of enormous proportions hurtling through the
 16482	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tatmosphere at a terrifying velocity in a trajectory directed southwest
 16483	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby west. Messages of condolence and sympathy are being hourly received
 16484	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom all parts of the different continents and the sovereign pontiff
 16485	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thas been graciously pleased to decree that a special missa pro defunctis
 16486	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshall be celebrated simultaneously by the ordinaries of each and every
 16487	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcathedral church of all the episcopal dioceses subject to the spiritual
 16488	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tauthority of the Holy See in suffrage of the souls of those faithful
 16489	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeparted who have been so unexpectedly called away from our midst. The
 16490	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twork of salvage, removal of débris, human remains etc has been entrusted
 16491	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto Messrs Michael Meade and Son, 159 Great Brunswick street, and Messrs
 16492	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tT. and C. Martin, 77, 78, 79 and 80 North Wall, assisted by the men
 16493	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand officers of the Duke of Cornwall’s light infantry under the general
 16494	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsupervision of H. R. H., rear admiral, the right honourable sir Hercules
 16495	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHannibal Habeas Corpus Anderson, K. G., K. P., K. T., P. C., K. C. B.,
 16496	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tM. P., J. P., M. B., D. S. O., S. O. D., M. F. H., M. R. I. A., B. L.,
 16497	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMus. Doc., P. L. G., F. T. C. D., F. R. U. I., F. R. C. P. I. and F. R.
 16498	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tC. S. I.
 16499	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16500	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYou never saw the like of it in all your born puff. Gob, if he got that
 16501	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlottery ticket on the side of his poll he’d remember the gold cup, he
 16502	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twould so, but begob the citizen would have been lagged for assault and
 16503	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbattery and Joe for aiding and abetting. The jarvey saved his life by
 16504	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfurious driving as sure as God made Moses. What? O, Jesus, he did. And
 16505	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the let a volley of oaths after him.
 16506	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16507	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Did I kill him, says he, or what?
 16508	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16509	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd he shouting to the bloody dog:
 16510	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16511	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—After him, Garry! After him, boy!
 16512	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16513	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd the last we saw was the bloody car rounding the corner and old
 16514	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsheepsface on it gesticulating and the bloody mongrel after it with his
 16515	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlugs back for all he was bloody well worth to tear him limb from limb.
 16516	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHundred to five! Jesus, he took the value of it out of him, I promise
 16517	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou.
 16518	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16519	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhen, lo, there came about them all a great brightness and they beheld
 16520	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe chariot wherein He stood ascend to heaven. And they beheld Him in
 16521	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe chariot, clothed upon in the glory of the brightness, having raiment
 16522	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tas of the sun, fair as the moon and terrible that for awe they durst not
 16523	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlook upon Him. And there came a voice out of heaven, calling: Elijah!
 16524	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tElijah! And He answered with a main cry: Abba! Adonai! And they beheld
 16525	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHim even Him, ben Bloom Elijah, amid clouds of angels ascend to the
 16526	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tglory of the brightness at an angle of fortyfive degrees over Donohoe’s
 16527	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin Little Green street like a shot off a shovel.
 16528	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 16533	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t[ 13 ]
 16534	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16535	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe summer evening had begun to fold the world in its mysterious
 16536	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tembrace. Far away in the west the sun was setting and the last glow of
 16537	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall too fleeting day lingered lovingly on sea and strand, on the proud
 16538	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpromontory of dear old Howth guarding as ever the waters of the bay, on
 16539	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe weedgrown rocks along Sandymount shore and, last but not least, on
 16540	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe quiet church whence there streamed forth at times upon the stillness
 16541	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe voice of prayer to her who is in her pure radiance a beacon ever to
 16542	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe stormtossed heart of man, Mary, star of the sea.
 16543	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16544	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe three girl friends were seated on the rocks, enjoying the evening
 16545	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tscene and the air which was fresh but not too chilly. Many a time and
 16546	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toft were they wont to come there to that favourite nook to have a cosy
 16547	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchat beside the sparkling waves and discuss matters feminine, Cissy
 16548	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCaffrey and Edy Boardman with the baby in the pushcar and Tommy and
 16549	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJacky Caffrey, two little curlyheaded boys, dressed in sailor suits with
 16550	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcaps to match and the name H. M. S. Belleisle printed on both. For Tommy
 16551	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand Jacky Caffrey were twins, scarce four years old and very noisy and
 16552	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspoiled twins sometimes but for all that darling little fellows with
 16553	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbright merry faces and endearing ways about them. They were dabbling in
 16554	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe sand with their spades and buckets, building castles as children do,
 16555	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tor playing with their big coloured ball, happy as the day was long. And
 16556	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEdy Boardman was rocking the chubby baby to and fro in the pushcar while
 16557	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat young gentleman fairly chuckled with delight. He was but eleven
 16558	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmonths and nine days old and, though still a tiny toddler, was just
 16559	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeginning to lisp his first babyish words. Cissy Caffrey bent over to
 16560	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim to tease his fat little plucks and the dainty dimple in his chin.
 16561	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16562	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Now, baby, Cissy Caffrey said. Say out big, big. I want a drink of
 16563	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twater.
 16564	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16565	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd baby prattled after her:
 16566	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16567	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A jink a jink a jawbo.
 16568	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16569	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCissy Caffrey cuddled the wee chap for she was awfully fond of children,
 16570	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tso patient with little sufferers and Tommy Caffrey could never be got to
 16571	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttake his castor oil unless it was Cissy Caffrey that held his nose and
 16572	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpromised him the scatty heel of the loaf or brown bread with golden
 16573	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsyrup on. What a persuasive power that girl had! But to be sure baby
 16574	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBoardman was as good as gold, a perfect little dote in his new fancy
 16575	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbib. None of your spoilt beauties, Flora MacFlimsy sort, was Cissy
 16576	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCaffrey. A truerhearted lass never drew the breath of life, always with
 16577	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta laugh in her gipsylike eyes and a frolicsome word on her cherryripe
 16578	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tred lips, a girl lovable in the extreme. And Edy Boardman laughed too at
 16579	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe quaint language of little brother.
 16580	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16581	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBut just then there was a slight altercation between Master Tommy and
 16582	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMaster Jacky. Boys will be boys and our two twins were no exception
 16583	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto this golden rule. The apple of discord was a certain castle of sand
 16584	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhich Master Jacky had built and Master Tommy would have it right go
 16585	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twrong that it was to be architecturally improved by a frontdoor like the
 16586	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMartello tower had. But if Master Tommy was headstrong Master Jacky was
 16587	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tselfwilled too and, true to the maxim that every little Irishman’s house
 16588	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis his castle, he fell upon his hated rival and to such purpose that the
 16589	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twouldbe assailant came to grief and (alas to relate!) the coveted castle
 16590	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoo. Needless to say the cries of discomfited Master Tommy drew the
 16591	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tattention of the girl friends.
 16592	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16593	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Come here, Tommy, his sister called imperatively. At once! And you,
 16594	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJacky, for shame to throw poor Tommy in the dirty sand. Wait till I
 16595	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcatch you for that.
 16596	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16597	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis eyes misty with unshed tears Master Tommy came at her call for their
 16598	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbig sister’s word was law with the twins. And in a sad plight he was
 16599	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoo after his misadventure. His little man-o’-war top and unmentionables
 16600	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twere full of sand but Cissy was a past mistress in the art of smoothing
 16601	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tover life’s tiny troubles and very quickly not one speck of sand was to
 16602	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbe seen on his smart little suit. Still the blue eyes were glistening
 16603	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith hot tears that would well up so she kissed away the hurtness and
 16604	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshook her hand at Master Jacky the culprit and said if she was near him
 16605	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshe wouldn’t be far from him, her eyes dancing in admonition.
 16606	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16607	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Nasty bold Jacky! she cried.
 16608	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16609	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe put an arm round the little mariner and coaxed winningly:
 16610	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16611	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What’s your name? Butter and cream?
 16612	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16613	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Tell us who is your sweetheart, spoke Edy Boardman. Is Cissy your
 16614	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsweetheart?
 16615	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16616	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Nao, tearful Tommy said.
 16617	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16618	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Is Edy Boardman your sweetheart? Cissy queried.
 16619	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16620	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Nao, Tommy said.
 16621	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16622	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I know, Edy Boardman said none too amiably with an arch glance from her
 16623	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshortsighted eyes. I know who is Tommy’s sweetheart. Gerty is Tommy’s
 16624	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsweetheart.
 16625	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16626	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Nao, Tommy said on the verge of tears.
 16627	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16628	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCissy’s quick motherwit guessed what was amiss and she whispered to
 16629	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEdy Boardman to take him there behind the pushcar where the gentleman
 16630	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcouldn’t see and to mind he didn’t wet his new tan shoes.
 16631	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16632	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBut who was Gerty?
 16633	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16634	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGerty MacDowell who was seated near her companions, lost in thought,
 16635	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgazing far away into the distance was, in very truth, as fair a specimen
 16636	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof winsome Irish girlhood as one could wish to see. She was pronounced
 16637	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeautiful by all who knew her though, as folks often said, she was
 16638	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmore a Giltrap than a MacDowell. Her figure was slight and graceful,
 16639	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinclining even to fragility but those iron jelloids she had been taking
 16640	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof late had done her a world of good much better than the Widow Welch’s
 16641	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfemale pills and she was much better of those discharges she used to
 16642	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tget and that tired feeling. The waxen pallor of her face was almost
 16643	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspiritual in its ivorylike purity though her rosebud mouth was a genuine
 16644	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCupid’s bow, Greekly perfect. Her hands were of finely veined alabaster
 16645	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith tapering fingers and as white as lemonjuice and queen of ointments
 16646	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcould make them though it was not true that she used to wear kid gloves
 16647	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin bed or take a milk footbath either. Bertha Supple told that once to
 16648	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEdy Boardman, a deliberate lie, when she was black out at daggers drawn
 16649	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith Gerty (the girl chums had of course their little tiffs from time to
 16650	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttime like the rest of mortals) and she told her not to let on whatever
 16651	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshe did that it was her that told her or she’d never speak to her
 16652	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tagain. No. Honour where honour is due. There was an innate refinement, a
 16653	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlanguid queenly hauteur about Gerty which was unmistakably evidenced in
 16654	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther delicate hands and higharched instep. Had kind fate but willed her
 16655	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto be born a gentlewoman of high degree in her own right and had she
 16656	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tonly received the benefit of a good education Gerty MacDowell might
 16657	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teasily have held her own beside any lady in the land and have seen
 16658	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\therself exquisitely gowned with jewels on her brow and patrician suitors
 16659	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat her feet vying with one another to pay their devoirs to her.
 16660	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMayhap it was this, the love that might have been, that lent to her
 16661	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsoftlyfeatured face at whiles a look, tense with suppressed meaning,
 16662	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat imparted a strange yearning tendency to the beautiful eyes, a charm
 16663	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfew could resist. Why have women such eyes of witchery? Gerty’s were of
 16664	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe bluest Irish blue, set off by lustrous lashes and dark expressive
 16665	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrows. Time was when those brows were not so silkily seductive. It
 16666	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas Madame Vera Verity, directress of the Woman Beautiful page of the
 16667	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPrincess Novelette, who had first advised her to try eyebrowleine which
 16668	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgave that haunting expression to the eyes, so becoming in leaders
 16669	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof fashion, and she had never regretted it. Then there was blushing
 16670	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tscientifically cured and how to be tall increase your height and you
 16671	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thave a beautiful face but your nose? That would suit Mrs Dignam because
 16672	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshe had a button one. But Gerty’s crowning glory was her wealth of
 16673	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twonderful hair. It was dark brown with a natural wave in it. She had cut
 16674	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit that very morning on account of the new moon and it nestled about
 16675	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther pretty head in a profusion of luxuriant clusters and pared her nails
 16676	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoo, Thursday for wealth. And just now at Edy’s words as a telltale
 16677	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tflush, delicate as the faintest rosebloom, crept into her cheeks she
 16678	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlooked so lovely in her sweet girlish shyness that of a surety God’s
 16679	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfair land of Ireland did not hold her equal.
 16680	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16681	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFor an instant she was silent with rather sad downcast eyes. She
 16682	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas about to retort but something checked the words on her tongue.
 16683	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tInclination prompted her to speak out: dignity told her to be silent.
 16684	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe pretty lips pouted awhile but then she glanced up and broke out into
 16685	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta joyous little laugh which had in it all the freshness of a young May
 16686	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmorning. She knew right well, no-one better, what made squinty Edy
 16687	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsay that because of him cooling in his attentions when it was simply a
 16688	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlovers’ quarrel. As per usual somebody’s nose was out of joint about the
 16689	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tboy that had the bicycle off the London bridge road always riding up
 16690	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand down in front of her window. Only now his father kept him in in the
 16691	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tevenings studying hard to get an exhibition in the intermediate that was
 16692	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton and he was going to go to Trinity college to study for a doctor when
 16693	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the left the high school like his brother W. E. Wylie who was racing
 16694	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the bicycle races in Trinity college university. Little recked he
 16695	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tperhaps for what she felt, that dull aching void in her heart sometimes,
 16696	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpiercing to the core. Yet he was young and perchance he might learn
 16697	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto love her in time. They were protestants in his family and of course
 16698	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGerty knew Who came first and after Him the Blessed Virgin and then
 16699	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSaint Joseph. But he was undeniably handsome with an exquisite nose and
 16700	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the was what he looked, every inch a gentleman, the shape of his head too
 16701	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat the back without his cap on that she would know anywhere something
 16702	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toff the common and the way he turned the bicycle at the lamp with his
 16703	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thands off the bars and also the nice perfume of those good cigarettes
 16704	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand besides they were both of a size too he and she and that was why Edy
 16705	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBoardman thought she was so frightfully clever because he didn’t go and
 16706	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tride up and down in front of her bit of a garden.
 16707	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16708	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGerty was dressed simply but with the instinctive taste of a votary of
 16709	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDame Fashion for she felt that there was just a might that he might be
 16710	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tout. A neat blouse of electric blue selftinted by dolly dyes (because it
 16711	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas expected in the Lady’s Pictorial that electric blue would be worn)
 16712	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith a smart vee opening down to the division and kerchief pocket (in
 16713	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhich she always kept a piece of cottonwool scented with her
 16714	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfavourite perfume because the handkerchief spoiled the sit) and a navy
 16715	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthreequarter skirt cut to the stride showed off her slim graceful figure
 16716	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto perfection. She wore a coquettish little love of a hat of wideleaved
 16717	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnigger straw contrast trimmed with an underbrim of eggblue chenille and
 16718	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat the side a butterfly bow of silk to tone. All Tuesday week afternoon
 16719	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshe was hunting to match that chenille but at last she found what she
 16720	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twanted at Clery’s summer sales, the very it, slightly shopsoiled but you
 16721	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twould never notice, seven fingers two and a penny. She did it up all by
 16722	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\therself and what joy was hers when she tried it on then, smiling at the
 16723	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlovely reflection which the mirror gave back to her! And when she put
 16724	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit on the waterjug to keep the shape she knew that that would take the
 16725	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshine out of some people she knew. Her shoes were the newest thing in
 16726	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfootwear (Edy Boardman prided herself that she was very petite but she
 16727	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnever had a foot like Gerty MacDowell, a five, and never would ash,
 16728	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toak or elm) with patent toecaps and just one smart buckle over
 16729	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther higharched instep. Her wellturned ankle displayed its perfect
 16730	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tproportions beneath her skirt and just the proper amount and no more of
 16731	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther shapely limbs encased in finespun hose with highspliced heels and
 16732	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twide garter tops. As for undies they were Gerty’s chief care and who
 16733	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat knows the fluttering hopes and fears of sweet seventeen (though
 16734	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGerty would never see seventeen again) can find it in his heart to
 16735	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblame her? She had four dinky sets with awfully pretty stitchery,
 16736	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthree garments and nighties extra, and each set slotted with different
 16737	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcoloured ribbons, rosepink, pale blue, mauve and peagreen, and she aired
 16738	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem herself and blued them when they came home from the wash and ironed
 16739	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem and she had a brickbat to keep the iron on because she wouldn’t
 16740	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttrust those washerwomen as far as she’d see them scorching the things.
 16741	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe was wearing the blue for luck, hoping against hope, her own colour
 16742	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand lucky too for a bride to have a bit of blue somewhere on her because
 16743	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe green she wore that day week brought grief because his father
 16744	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrought him in to study for the intermediate exhibition and because
 16745	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshe thought perhaps he might be out because when she was dressing that
 16746	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmorning she nearly slipped up the old pair on her inside out and that
 16747	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas for luck and lovers’ meeting if you put those things on inside
 16748	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tout or if they got untied that he was thinking about you so long as it
 16749	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twasn’t of a Friday.
 16750	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16751	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd yet and yet! That strained look on her face! A gnawing sorrow is
 16752	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthere all the time. Her very soul is in her eyes and she would give
 16753	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tworlds to be in the privacy of her own familiar chamber where, giving
 16754	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tway to tears, she could have a good cry and relieve her pentup feelings
 16755	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthough not too much because she knew how to cry nicely before the
 16756	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmirror. You are lovely, Gerty, it said. The paly light of evening falls
 16757	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tupon a face infinitely sad and wistful. Gerty MacDowell yearns in vain.
 16758	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYes, she had known from the very first that her daydream of a marriage
 16759	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thas been arranged and the weddingbells ringing for Mrs Reggy Wylie T.
 16760	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tC. D. (because the one who married the elder brother would be Mrs Wylie)
 16761	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand in the fashionable intelligence Mrs Gertrude Wylie was wearing a
 16762	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsumptuous confection of grey trimmed with expensive blue fox was not
 16763	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto be. He was too young to understand. He would not believe in love, a
 16764	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twoman’s birthright. The night of the party long ago in Stoer’s (he was
 16765	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstill in short trousers) when they were alone and he stole an arm round
 16766	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther waist she went white to the very lips. He called her little one in
 16767	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta strangely husky voice and snatched a half kiss (the first!) but it
 16768	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas only the end of her nose and then he hastened from the room with a
 16769	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tremark about refreshments. Impetuous fellow! Strength of character had
 16770	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnever been Reggy Wylie’s strong point and he who would woo and win Gerty
 16771	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMacDowell must be a man among men. But waiting, always waiting to
 16772	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbe asked and it was leap year too and would soon be over. No prince
 16773	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcharming is her beau ideal to lay a rare and wondrous love at her feet
 16774	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbut rather a manly man with a strong quiet face who had not found
 16775	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this ideal, perhaps his hair slightly flecked with grey, and who would
 16776	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunderstand, take her in his sheltering arms, strain her to him in all
 16777	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe strength of his deep passionate nature and comfort her with a long
 16778	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlong kiss. It would be like heaven. For such a one she yearns this balmy
 16779	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsummer eve. With all the heart of her she longs to be his only, his
 16780	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taffianced bride for riches for poor, in sickness in health, till death
 16781	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tus two part, from this to this day forward.
 16782	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16783	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd while Edy Boardman was with little Tommy behind the pushcar she was
 16784	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjust thinking would the day ever come when she could call herself his
 16785	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlittle wife to be. Then they could talk about her till they went blue in
 16786	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe face, Bertha Supple too, and Edy, little spitfire, because she would
 16787	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbe twentytwo in November. She would care for him with creature comforts
 16788	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoo for Gerty was womanly wise and knew that a mere man liked that
 16789	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfeeling of hominess. Her griddlecakes done to a goldenbrown hue and
 16790	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tqueen Ann’s pudding of delightful creaminess had won golden opinions
 16791	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom all because she had a lucky hand also for lighting a fire, dredge
 16792	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the fine selfraising flour and always stir in the same direction,
 16793	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthen cream the milk and sugar and whisk well the white of eggs though
 16794	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshe didn’t like the eating part when there were any people that made her
 16795	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshy and often she wondered why you couldn’t eat something poetical like
 16796	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tviolets or roses and they would have a beautifully appointed drawingroom
 16797	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith pictures and engravings and the photograph of grandpapa Giltrap’s
 16798	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlovely dog Garryowen that almost talked it was so human and chintz
 16799	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcovers for the chairs and that silver toastrack in Clery’s summer
 16800	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjumble sales like they have in rich houses. He would be tall with
 16801	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbroad shoulders (she had always admired tall men for a husband) with
 16802	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tglistening white teeth under his carefully trimmed sweeping moustache
 16803	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand they would go on the continent for their honeymoon (three wonderful
 16804	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tweeks!) and then, when they settled down in a nice snug and cosy little
 16805	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thomely house, every morning they would both have brekky, simple but
 16806	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tperfectly served, for their own two selves and before he went out to
 16807	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbusiness he would give his dear little wifey a good hearty hug and gaze
 16808	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor a moment deep down into her eyes.
 16809	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16810	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEdy Boardman asked Tommy Caffrey was he done and he said yes so then she
 16811	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbuttoned up his little knickerbockers for him and told him to run off
 16812	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand play with Jacky and to be good now and not to fight. But Tommy said
 16813	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the wanted the ball and Edy told him no that baby was playing with the
 16814	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tball and if he took it there’d be wigs on the green but Tommy said it
 16815	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas his ball and he wanted his ball and he pranced on the ground, if
 16816	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou please. The temper of him! O, he was a man already was little Tommy
 16817	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCaffrey since he was out of pinnies. Edy told him no, no and to be off
 16818	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnow with him and she told Cissy Caffrey not to give in to him.
 16819	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16820	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—You’re not my sister, naughty Tommy said. It’s my ball.
 16821	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16822	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBut Cissy Caffrey told baby Boardman to look up, look up high at her
 16823	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfinger and she snatched the ball quickly and threw it along the sand and
 16824	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTommy after it in full career, having won the day.
 16825	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16826	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Anything for a quiet life, laughed Ciss.
 16827	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16828	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd she tickled tiny tot’s two cheeks to make him forget and played
 16829	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\there’s the lord mayor, here’s his two horses, here’s his gingerbread
 16830	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcarriage and here he walks in, chinchopper, chinchopper, chinchopper
 16831	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchin. But Edy got as cross as two sticks about him getting his own way
 16832	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlike that from everyone always petting him.
 16833	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16834	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—I’d like to give him something, she said, so I would, where I won’t
 16835	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsay.
 16836	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16837	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—On the beeoteetom, laughed Cissy merrily.
 16838	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16839	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGerty MacDowell bent down her head and crimsoned at the idea of Cissy
 16840	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaying an unladylike thing like that out loud she’d be ashamed of her
 16841	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlife to say, flushing a deep rosy red, and Edy Boardman said she was
 16842	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsure the gentleman opposite heard what she said. But not a pin cared
 16843	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCiss.
 16844	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16845	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Let him! she said with a pert toss of her head and a piquant tilt of
 16846	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther nose. Give it to him too on the same place as quick as I’d look at
 16847	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim.
 16848	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16849	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMadcap Ciss with her golliwog curls. You had to laugh at her sometimes.
 16850	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFor instance when she asked you would you have some more Chinese tea and
 16851	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjaspberry ram and when she drew the jugs too and the men’s faces on her
 16852	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnails with red ink make you split your sides or when she wanted to go
 16853	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhere you know she said she wanted to run and pay a visit to the Miss
 16854	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhite. That was just like Cissycums. O, and will you ever forget her the
 16855	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tevening she dressed up in her father’s suit and hat and the burned cork
 16856	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmoustache and walked down Tritonville road, smoking a cigarette. There
 16857	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas none to come up to her for fun. But she was sincerity itself, one of
 16858	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe bravest and truest hearts heaven ever made, not one of your twofaced
 16859	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthings, too sweet to be wholesome.
 16860	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16861	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd then there came out upon the air the sound of voices and the pealing
 16862	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanthem of the organ. It was the men’s temperance retreat conducted
 16863	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby the missioner, the reverend John Hughes S. J., rosary, sermon and
 16864	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbenediction of the Most Blessed Sacrament. They were there gathered
 16865	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttogether without distinction of social class (and a most edifying
 16866	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspectacle it was to see) in that simple fane beside the waves, after the
 16867	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstorms of this weary world, kneeling before the feet of the immaculate,
 16868	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treciting the litany of Our Lady of Loreto, beseeching her to intercede
 16869	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor them, the old familiar words, holy Mary, holy virgin of virgins. How
 16870	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsad to poor Gerty’s ears! Had her father only avoided the clutches of
 16871	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe demon drink, by taking the pledge or those powders the drink habit
 16872	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcured in Pearson’s Weekly, she might now be rolling in her carriage,
 16873	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsecond to none. Over and over had she told herself that as she mused by
 16874	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe dying embers in a brown study without the lamp because she hated two
 16875	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlights or oftentimes gazing out of the window dreamily by the hour at
 16876	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe rain falling on the rusty bucket, thinking. But that vile decoction
 16877	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhich has ruined so many hearths and homes had cast its shadow over her
 16878	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchildhood days. Nay, she had even witnessed in the home circle deeds of
 16879	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tviolence caused by intemperance and had seen her own father, a prey to
 16880	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe fumes of intoxication, forget himself completely for if there was
 16881	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tone thing of all things that Gerty knew it was that the man who lifts
 16882	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this hand to a woman save in the way of kindness, deserves to be branded
 16883	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tas the lowest of the low.
 16884	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16885	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd still the voices sang in supplication to the Virgin most powerful,
 16886	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tVirgin most merciful. And Gerty, rapt in thought, scarce saw or heard
 16887	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther companions or the twins at their boyish gambols or the gentleman
 16888	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toff Sandymount green that Cissy Caffrey called the man that was so like
 16889	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thimself passing along the strand taking a short walk. You never saw him
 16890	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tany way screwed but still and for all that she would not like him for a
 16891	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfather because he was too old or something or on account of his face
 16892	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(it was a palpable case of Doctor Fell) or his carbuncly nose with the
 16893	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpimples on it and his sandy moustache a bit white under his nose. Poor
 16894	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfather! With all his faults she loved him still when he sang Tell me,
 16895	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMary, how to woo thee or My love and cottage near Rochelle and they had
 16896	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstewed cockles and lettuce with Lazenby’s salad dressing for supper and
 16897	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhen he sang The moon hath raised with Mr Dignam that died suddenly and
 16898	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas buried, God have mercy on him, from a stroke. Her mother’s birthday
 16899	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat was and Charley was home on his holidays and Tom and Mr Dignam and
 16900	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMrs and Patsy and Freddy Dignam and they were to have had a group taken.
 16901	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNo-one would have thought the end was so near. Now he was laid to rest.
 16902	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd her mother said to him to let that be a warning to him for the rest
 16903	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof his days and he couldn’t even go to the funeral on account of the
 16904	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgout and she had to go into town to bring him the letters and samples
 16905	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom his office about Catesby’s cork lino, artistic, standard designs,
 16906	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfit for a palace, gives tiptop wear and always bright and cheery in the
 16907	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thome.
 16908	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16909	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA sterling good daughter was Gerty just like a second mother in the
 16910	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thouse, a ministering angel too with a little heart worth its weight in
 16911	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgold. And when her mother had those raging splitting headaches who was
 16912	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit rubbed the menthol cone on her forehead but Gerty though she didn’t
 16913	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlike her mother’s taking pinches of snuff and that was the only single
 16914	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthing they ever had words about, taking snuff. Everyone thought the
 16915	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tworld of her for her gentle ways. It was Gerty who turned off the gas at
 16916	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe main every night and it was Gerty who tacked up on the wall of that
 16917	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplace where she never forgot every fortnight the chlorate of lime Mr
 16918	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTunney the grocer’s christmas almanac, the picture of halcyon days
 16919	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhere a young gentleman in the costume they used to wear then with a
 16920	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthreecornered hat was offering a bunch of flowers to his ladylove with
 16921	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toldtime chivalry through her lattice window. You could see there was a
 16922	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstory behind it. The colours were done something lovely. She was in
 16923	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta soft clinging white in a studied attitude and the gentleman was in
 16924	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchocolate and he looked a thorough aristocrat. She often looked at them
 16925	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdreamily when she went there for a certain purpose and felt her own
 16926	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tarms that were white and soft just like hers with the sleeves back
 16927	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand thought about those times because she had found out in Walker’s
 16928	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpronouncing dictionary that belonged to grandpapa Giltrap about the
 16929	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thalcyon days what they meant.
 16930	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16931	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe twins were now playing in the most approved brotherly fashion
 16932	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttill at last Master Jacky who was really as bold as brass there was
 16933	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tno getting behind that deliberately kicked the ball as hard as ever he
 16934	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcould down towards the seaweedy rocks. Needless to say poor Tommy was
 16935	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnot slow to voice his dismay but luckily the gentleman in black who was

 16937	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe ball. Our two champions claimed their plaything with lusty cries and

 16941	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstopped right under Gerty’s skirt near the little pool by the rock. The

 16944	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstupid ball hadn’t come rolling down to her and she gave a kick but she
 16945	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmissed and Edy and Cissy laughed.
 16946	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 16949	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGerty smiled assent and bit her lip. A delicate pink crept into her

 16960	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 16961	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThrough the open window of the church the fragrant incense was wafted

 16963	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toriginal sin, spiritual vessel, pray for us, honourable vessel, pray

 16972	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 17003	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGerty wished to goodness they would take their squalling baby home out
 17004	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof that and not get on her nerves, no hour to be out, and the little
 17005	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrats of twins. She gazed out towards the distant sea. It was like the
 17006	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpaintings that man used to do on the pavement with all the coloured

 17011	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpitapat. Yes, it was her he was looking at, and there was meaning in his

 17013	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand through, read her very soul. Wonderful eyes they were, superbly

 17021	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas in deep mourning, she could see that, and the story of a haunting

 17023	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit was. He was looking up so intently, so still, and he saw her kick the

 17025	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshe swung them like that thoughtfully with the toes down. She was glad

 17027	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tReggy Wylie might be out but that was far away. Here was that of which
 17028	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshe had so often dreamed. It was he who mattered and there was joy on
 17029	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther face because she wanted him because she felt instinctively that he

 17031	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther dreamhusband, because she knew on the instant it was him. If he had
 17032	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsuffered, more sinned against than sinning, or even, even, if he had

 17035	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther. There were wounds that wanted healing with heartbalm. She was a

 17037	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthose cyclists showing off what they hadn’t got and she just yearned to

 17039	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmake him forget the memory of the past. Then mayhap he would embrace her
 17040	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgently, like a real man, crushing her soft body to him, and love her,

 17042	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 17043	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRefuge of sinners. Comfortress of the afflicted. Ora pro nobis. Well has
 17044	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit been said that whosoever prays to her with faith and constancy can
 17045	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnever be lost or cast away: and fitly is she too a haven of refuge for
 17046	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe afflicted because of the seven dolours which transpierced her own
 17047	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theart. Gerty could picture the whole scene in the church, the stained

 17056	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thair for fear he could see, not to be troubled because that was only the

 17069	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe exasperating little brats of twins began to quarrel again and Jacky

 17095	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tQueen of angels, queen of patriarchs, queen of prophets, of all saints,

 17106	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgosa cramen tum. Three and eleven she paid for those stockings in

 17113	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCissy came up along the strand with the two twins and their ball with

 17120	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\talmost maddening in its sweetness. You would have to travel many a long

 17129	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 17130	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEdy Boardman was noticing it too because she was squinting at Gerty,
 17131	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thalf smiling, with her specs like an old maid, pretending to nurse the
 17132	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbaby. Irritable little gnat she was and always would be and that was why
 17133	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tno-one could get on with her poking her nose into what was no concern of
 17134	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thers. And she said to Gerty:
 17135	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 17136	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—A penny for your thoughts.
 17137	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 17138	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—What? replied Gerty with a smile reinforced by the whitest of teeth. I
 17139	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas only wondering was it late.
 17140	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 17141	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBecause she wished to goodness they’d take the snottynosed twins and
 17142	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir babby home to the mischief out of that so that was why she just
 17143	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgave a gentle hint about its being late. And when Cissy came up Edy
 17144	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tasked her the time and Miss Cissy, as glib as you like, said it was half
 17145	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpast kissing time, time to kiss again. But Edy wanted to know because
 17146	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey were told to be in early.
 17147	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 17148	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—Wait, said Cissy, I’ll run ask my uncle Peter over there what’s the
 17149	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttime by his conundrum.
 17150	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 17151	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo over she went and when he saw her coming she could see him take his
 17152	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thand out of his pocket, getting nervous, and beginning to play with his
 17153	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twatchchain, looking up at the church. Passionate nature though he was
 17154	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGerty could see that he had enormous control over himself. One moment he
 17155	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thad been there, fascinated by a loveliness that made him gaze, and the
 17156	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnext moment it was the quiet gravefaced gentleman, selfcontrol expressed
 17157	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin every line of his distinguishedlooking figure.
 17158	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 17159	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCissy said to excuse her would he mind please telling her what was the
 17160	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tright time and Gerty could see him taking out his watch, listening to it
 17161	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand looking up and clearing his throat and he said he was very sorry his
 17162	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twatch was stopped but he thought it must be after eight because the
 17163	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsun was set. His voice had a cultured ring in it and though he spoke in
 17164	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmeasured accents there was a suspicion of a quiver in the mellow tones.
 17165	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCissy said thanks and came back with her tongue out and said uncle said
 17166	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this waterworks were out of order.
 17167	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 17169	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgot up again and censed the Blessed Sacrament and knelt down and he told
 17170	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFather Conroy that one of the candles was just going to set fire to the

 17174	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcould see and he was looking all the time that he was winding the watch

 17176	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tback into his pockets. She felt a kind of a sensation rushing all over
 17177	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther and she knew by the feel of her scalp and that irritation against
 17178	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther stays that that thing must be coming on because the last time too
 17179	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas when she clipped her hair on account of the moon. His dark eyes
 17180	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfixed themselves on her again drinking in her every contour, literally
 17181	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tworshipping at her shrine. If ever there was undisguised admiration in a
 17182	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tman’s passionate gaze it was there plain to be seen on that man’s face.
 17183	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIt is for you, Gertrude MacDowell, and you know it.
 17184	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 17185	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEdy began to get ready to go and it was high time for her and Gerty
 17186	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnoticed that that little hint she gave had had the desired effect
 17187	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbecause it was a long way along the strand to where there was the place

 17189	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir hair to make herself attractive of course and Canon O’Hanlon stood

 17194	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tscathing politeness when Edy asked her was she heartbroken about her
 17195	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbest boy throwing her over. Gerty winced sharply. A brief cold blaze
 17196	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshone from her eyes that spoke volumes of scorn immeasurable. It hurt—O
 17197	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyes, it cut deep because Edy had her own quiet way of saying things
 17198	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlike that she knew would wound like the confounded little cat she was.

 17203	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the would never understand what he had meant to her and for an instant
 17204	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthere was in the blue eyes a quick stinging of tears. Their eyes were
 17205	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprobing her mercilessly but with a brave effort she sparkled back in
 17206	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsympathy as she glanced at her new conquest for them to see.
 17207	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 17208	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t—O, responded Gerty, quick as lightning, laughing, and the proud head
 17209	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tflashed up. I can throw my cap at who I like because it’s leap year.
 17210	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 17211	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHer words rang out crystalclear, more musical than the cooing of the
 17212	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tringdove, but they cut the silence icily. There was that in her young

 17214	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor Mr Reggy with his swank and his bit of money she could just chuck

 17216	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmuch as a second thought on him and tear his silly postcard into a dozen
 17217	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpieces. And if ever after he dared to presume she could give him one
 17218	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlook of measured scorn that would make him shrivel up on the spot. Miss
 17219	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpuny little Edy’s countenance fell to no slight extent and Gerty could

 17222	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstruck home for her petty jealousy and they both knew that she was
 17223	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsomething aloof, apart, in another sphere, that she was not of them and
 17224	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnever would be and there was somebody else too that knew it and saw it
 17225	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tso they could put that in their pipe and smoke it.

 17238	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe slight contretemps claimed her attention but in two twos she set

 17249	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 17254	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe lighthouses so picturesque she would have loved to do with a box of

 17260	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tVaughan and other tales. For Gerty had her dreams that no-one knew of.
 17261	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tShe loved to read poetry and when she got a keepsake from Bertha Supple
 17262	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof that lovely confession album with the coralpink cover to write her
 17263	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthoughts in she laid it in the drawer of her toilettable which, though
 17264	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit did not err on the side of luxury, was scrupulously neat and clean.
 17265	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIt was there she kept her girlish treasure trove, the tortoiseshell
 17266	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcombs, her child of Mary badge, the whiterose scent, the eyebrowleine,
 17267	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther alabaster pouncetbox and the ribbons to change when her things came
 17268	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thome from the wash and there were some beautiful thoughts written in it
 17269	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin violet ink that she bought in Hely’s of Dame Street for she felt that
 17270	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshe too could write poetry if she could only express herself like that
 17271	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoem that appealed to her so deeply that she had copied out of the
 17272	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnewspaper she found one evening round the potherbs. Art thou real, my
 17273	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tideal? it was called by Louis J Walsh, Magherafelt, and after there was
 17274	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsomething about twilight, wilt thou ever? and ofttimes the beauty of
 17275	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoetry, so sad in its transient loveliness, had misted her eyes with
 17276	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsilent tears for she felt that the years were slipping by for her,
 17277	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tone by one, and but for that one shortcoming she knew she need fear no
 17278	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcompetition and that was an accident coming down Dalkey hill and she
 17279	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\talways tried to conceal it. But it must end, she felt. If she saw that
 17280	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmagic lure in his eyes there would be no holding back for her. Love
 17281	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlaughs at locksmiths. She would make the great sacrifice. Her every
 17282	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teffort would be to share his thoughts. Dearer than the whole world
 17283	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twould she be to him and gild his days with happiness. There was the
 17284	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tallimportant question and she was dying to know was he a married man or
 17285	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta widower who had lost his wife or some tragedy like the nobleman
 17286	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith the foreign name from the land of song had to have her put into a
 17287	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmadhouse, cruel only to be kind. But even if—what then? Would it make
 17288	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta very great difference? From everything in the least indelicate her
 17289	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfinebred nature instinctively recoiled. She loathed that sort of person,
 17290	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe fallen women off the accommodation walk beside the Dodder that went
 17291	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith the soldiers and coarse men with no respect for a girl’s honour,
 17292	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdegrading the sex and being taken up to the police station. No, no:
 17293	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnot that. They would be just good friends like a big brother and sister
 17294	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twithout all that other in spite of the conventions of Society with a big
 17295	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tess. Perhaps it was an old flame he was in mourning for from the days
 17296	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeyond recall. She thought she understood. She would try to understand
 17297	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim because men were so different. The old love was waiting, waiting
 17298	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith little white hands stretched out, with blue appealing eyes. Heart
 17299	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof mine! She would follow, her dream of love, the dictates of her heart
 17300	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat told her he was her all in all, the only man in all the world for
 17301	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther for love was the master guide. Nothing else mattered. Come what
 17302	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmight she would be wild, untrammelled, free.

 17312	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd they all looked was it sheet lightning but Tommy saw it too over the

 17316	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 17317	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd they all ran down the strand to see over the houses and the church,

 17324	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcall. If they could run like rossies she could sit so she said she could
 17325	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsee from where she was. The eyes that were fastened upon her set her
 17326	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpulses tingling. She looked at him a moment, meeting his glance, and
 17327	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta light broke in upon her. Whitehot passion was in that face, passion
 17328	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsilent as the grave, and it had made her his. At last they were left
 17329	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\talone without the others to pry and pass remarks and she knew he could
 17330	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbe trusted to the death, steadfast, a sterling man, a man of inflexible
 17331	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thonour to his fingertips. His hands and face were working and a tremour
 17332	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twent over her. She leaned back far to look up where the fireworks were
 17333	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand she caught her knee in her hands so as not to fall back looking up
 17334	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand there was no-one to see only him and her when she revealed all her
 17335	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgraceful beautifully shaped legs like that, supply soft and delicately
 17336	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trounded, and she seemed to hear the panting of his heart, his hoarse

 17338	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thotblooded, because Bertha Supple told her once in dead secret and made
 17339	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther swear she’d never about the gentleman lodger that was staying with
 17340	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem out of the Congested Districts Board that had pictures cut out of
 17341	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpapers of those skirtdancers and highkickers and she said he used to do
 17342	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsomething not very nice that you could imagine sometimes in the bed. But
 17343	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthis was altogether different from a thing like that because there was
 17344	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall the difference because she could almost feel him draw her face to
 17345	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this and the first quick hot touch of his handsome lips. Besides there
 17346	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas absolution so long as you didn’t do the other thing before being
 17347	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmarried and there ought to be women priests that would understand
 17348	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twithout your telling out and Cissy Caffrey too sometimes had that dreamy
 17349	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tkind of dreamy look in her eyes so that she too, my dear, and Winny
 17350	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRippingham so mad about actors’ photographs and besides it was on

 17353	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd Jacky Caffrey shouted to look, there was another and she leaned back

 17358	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlong Roman candle going up over the trees, up, up, and, in the tense

 17364	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthose other pettiwidth, the green, four and eleven, on account of being
