 18325	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taccounted him of real parts) so grieved he also in no less measure
 18326	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor young Stephen for that he lived riotously with those wastrels and
 18327	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmurdered his goods with whores.
 18328	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18329	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAbout that present time young Stephen filled all cups that stood empty
 18330	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tso as there remained but little mo if the prudenter had not shadowed
 18331	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir approach from him that still plied it very busily who, praying for
 18332	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe intentions of the sovereign pontiff, he gave them for a pledge the
 18333	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvicar of Christ which also as he said is vicar of Bray. Now drink we,
 18334	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquod he, of this mazer and quaff ye this mead which is not indeed parcel
 18335	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof my body but my soul’s bodiment. Leave ye fraction of bread to them
 18336	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat live by bread alone. Be not afeard neither for any want for this
 18337	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twill comfort more than the other will dismay. See ye here. And he showed
 18338	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem glistering coins of the tribute and goldsmith notes the worth of
 18339	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttwo pound nineteen shilling that he had, he said, for a song which he
 18340	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twrit. They all admired to see the foresaid riches in such dearth of
 18341	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmoney as was herebefore. His words were then these as followeth: Know
 18342	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall men, he said, time’s ruins build eternity’s mansions. What means
 18343	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthis? Desire’s wind blasts the thorntree but after it becomes from a
 18344	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbramblebush to be a rose upon the rood of time. Mark me now. In woman’s
 18345	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twomb word is made flesh but in the spirit of the maker all flesh
 18346	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat passes becomes the word that shall not pass away. This is the
 18347	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpostcreation. Omnis caro ad te veniet. No question but her name is
 18348	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpuissant who aventried the dear corse of our Agenbuyer, Healer and Herd,
 18349	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tour mighty mother and mother most venerable and Bernardus saith aptly
 18350	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat She hath an omnipotentiam deiparae supplicem, that is to wit, an
 18351	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\talmightiness of petition because she is the second Eve and she won
 18352	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tus, saith Augustine too, whereas that other, our grandam, which we are
 18353	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlinked up with by successive anastomosis of navelcords sold us all,
 18354	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseed, breed and generation, for a penny pippin. But here is the matter
 18355	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnow. Or she knew him, that second I say, and was but creature of her
 18356	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcreature, vergine madre, figlia di tuo figlio, or she knew him not and
 18357	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthen stands she in the one denial or ignorancy with Peter Piscator who
 18358	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlives in the house that Jack built and with Joseph the joiner patron of
 18359	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe happy demise of all unhappy marriages, parceque M. Léo Taxil nous
 18360	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta dit que qui l’avait mise dans cette fichue position c’était le
 18361	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsacré pigeon, ventre de Dieu! Entweder transubstantiality oder
 18362	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconsubstantiality but in no case subsubstantiality. And all cried out
 18363	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tupon it for a very scurvy word. A pregnancy without joy, he said, a
 18364	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbirth without pangs, a body without blemish, a belly without bigness.
 18365	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLet the lewd with faith and fervour worship. With will will we
 18366	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twithstand, withsay.
 18367	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18368	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHereupon Punch Costello dinged with his fist upon the board and would
 18369	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsing a bawdy catch Staboo Stabella about a wench that was put in pod of
 18370	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta jolly swashbuckler in Almany which he did straightways now attack:
 18371	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe first three months she was not well, Staboo, when here nurse Quigley
 18372	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom the door angerly bid them hist ye should shame you nor was it
 18373	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnot meet as she remembered them being her mind was to have all orderly
 18374	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tagainst lord Andrew came for because she was jealous that no gasteful
 18375	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tturmoil might shorten the honour of her guard. It was an ancient and
 18376	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta sad matron of a sedate look and christian walking, in habit dun
 18377	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeseeming her megrims and wrinkled visage, nor did her hortative want of
 18378	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit effect for incontinently Punch Costello was of them all embraided and
 18379	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey reclaimed the churl with civil rudeness some and shaked him with
 18380	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmenace of blandishments others whiles they all chode with him, a murrain
 18381	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseize the dolt, what a devil he would be at, thou chuff, thou puny, thou
 18382	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgot in peasestraw, thou losel, thou chitterling, thou spawn of a rebel,
 18383	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthou dykedropt, thou abortion thou, to shut up his drunken drool out
 18384	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof that like a curse of God ape, the good sir Leopold that had for his
 18385	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcognisance the flower of quiet, margerain gentle, advising also the
 18386	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttime’s occasion as most sacred and most worthy to be most sacred. In
 18387	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHorne’s house rest should reign.
 18388	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18389	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTo be short this passage was scarce by when Master Dixon of Mary in
 18390	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEccles, goodly grinning, asked young Stephen what was the reason why he
 18391	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thad not cided to take friar’s vows and he answered him obedience in the
 18392	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twomb, chastity in the tomb but involuntary poverty all his days. Master
 18393	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLenehan at this made return that he had heard of those nefarious deeds
 18394	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand how, as he heard hereof counted, he had besmirched the lily virtue
 18395	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof a confiding female which was corruption of minors and they all
 18396	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tintershowed it too, waxing merry and toasting to his fathership. But he
 18397	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaid very entirely it was clean contrary to their suppose for he was
 18398	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe eternal son and ever virgin. Thereat mirth grew in them the more and
 18399	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey rehearsed to him his curious rite of wedlock for the disrobing and
 18400	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeflowering of spouses, as the priests use in Madagascar island, she
 18401	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto be in guise of white and saffron, her groom in white and grain, with
 18402	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tburning of nard and tapers, on a bridebed while clerks sung kyries and
 18403	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe anthem Ut novetur sexus omnis corporis mysterium till she was
 18404	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthere unmaided. He gave them then a much admirable hymen minim by those
 18405	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdelicate poets Master John Fletcher and Master Francis Beaumont that is
 18406	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin their Maid’s Tragedy that was writ for a like twining of lovers: To
 18407	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbed, to bed was the burden of it to be played with accompanable concent
 18408	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tupon the virginals. An exquisite dulcet epithalame of most mollificative
 18409	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsuadency for juveniles amatory whom the odoriferous flambeaus of the
 18410	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tparanymphs have escorted to the quadrupedal proscenium of connubial
 18411	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcommunion. Well met they were, said Master Dixon, joyed, but, harkee,
 18412	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyoung sir, better were they named Beau Mount and Lecher for, by my
 18413	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttroth, of such a mingling much might come. Young Stephen said indeed to
 18414	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this best remembrance they had but the one doxy between them and she of
 18415	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe stews to make shift with in delights amorous for life ran very high
 18416	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin those days and the custom of the country approved with it. Greater
 18417	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlove than this, he said, no man hath that a man lay down his wife for
 18418	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this friend. Go thou and do likewise. Thus, or words to that effect,
 18419	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaith Zarathustra, sometime regius professor of French letters to the
 18420	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tuniversity of Oxtail nor breathed there ever that man to whom mankind
 18421	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas more beholden. Bring a stranger within thy tower it will go hard but
 18422	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthou wilt have the secondbest bed. Orate, fratres, pro memetipso. And
 18423	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall the people shall say, Amen. Remember, Erin, thy generations and
 18424	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthy days of old, how thou settedst little by me and by my word and
 18425	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbroughtedst in a stranger to my gates to commit fornication in my
 18426	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsight and to wax fat and kick like Jeshurum. Therefore hast thou
 18427	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsinned against my light and hast made me, thy lord, to be the slave of
 18428	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tservants. Return, return, Clan Milly: forget me not, O Milesian. Why
 18429	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thast thou done this abomination before me that thou didst spurn me for
 18430	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta merchant of jalaps and didst deny me to the Roman and to the Indian of
 18431	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdark speech with whom thy daughters did lie luxuriously? Look forth now,
 18432	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmy people, upon the land of behest, even from Horeb and from Nebo and
 18433	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom Pisgah and from the Horns of Hatten unto a land flowing with milk
 18434	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand money. But thou hast suckled me with a bitter milk: my moon and my
 18435	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsun thou hast quenched for ever. And thou hast left me alone for ever
 18436	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the dark ways of my bitterness: and with a kiss of ashes hast thou
 18437	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tkissed my mouth. This tenebrosity of the interior, he proceeded to say,
 18438	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thath not been illumined by the wit of the septuagint nor so much as
 18439	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmentioned for the Orient from on high Which brake hell’s gates visited a
 18440	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdarkness that was foraneous. Assuefaction minorates atrocities (as Tully
 18441	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaith of his darling Stoics) and Hamlet his father showeth the prince no
 18442	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblister of combustion. The adiaphane in the noon of life is an Egypt’s
 18443	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplague which in the nights of prenativity and postmortemity is their
 18444	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmost proper ubi and quomodo. And as the ends and ultimates of all things
 18445	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taccord in some mean and measure with their inceptions and originals,
 18446	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat same multiplicit concordance which leads forth growth from birth
 18447	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taccomplishing by a retrogressive metamorphosis that minishing and
 18448	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tablation towards the final which is agreeable unto nature so is it with
 18449	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tour subsolar being. The aged sisters draw us into life: we wail, batten,
 18450	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsport, clip, clasp, sunder, dwindle, die: over us dead they bend. First,
 18451	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaved from waters of old Nile, among bulrushes, a bed of fasciated
 18452	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twattles: at last the cavity of a mountain, an occulted sepulchre amid
 18453	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe conclamation of the hillcat and the ossifrage. And as no man knows
 18454	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe ubicity of his tumulus nor to what processes we shall thereby be
 18455	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tushered nor whether to Tophet or to Edenville in the like way is all
 18456	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thidden when we would backward see from what region of remoteness the
 18457	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhatness of our whoness hath fetched his whenceness.
 18458	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18459	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThereto Punch Costello roared out mainly Etienne chanson but he loudly
 18460	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbid them, lo, wisdom hath built herself a house, this vast majestic
 18461	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlongstablished vault, the crystal palace of the Creator, all in applepie
 18462	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\torder, a penny for him who finds the pea.
 18463	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18464	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Behold the mansion reared by dedal Jack
 18465	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     See the malt stored in many a refluent sack,
 18466	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     In the proud cirque of Jackjohn’s bivouac.
 18467	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18468	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA black crack of noise in the street here, alack, bawled back. Loud on
 18469	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tleft Thor thundered: in anger awful the hammerhurler. Came now the storm
 18470	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat hist his heart. And Master Lynch bade him have a care to flout and
 18471	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twitwanton as the god self was angered for his hellprate and paganry. And
 18472	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the that had erst challenged to be so doughty waxed wan as they might all
 18473	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmark and shrank together and his pitch that was before so haught uplift
 18474	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas now of a sudden quite plucked down and his heart shook within the
 18475	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcage of his breast as he tasted the rumour of that storm. Then did some
 18476	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmock and some jeer and Punch Costello fell hard again to his yale which
 18477	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMaster Lenehan vowed he would do after and he was indeed but a word and
 18478	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta blow on any the least colour. But the braggart boaster cried that an
 18479	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\told Nobodaddy was in his cups it was muchwhat indifferent and he would
 18480	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnot lag behind his lead. But this was only to dye his desperation as
 18481	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcowed he crouched in Horne’s hall. He drank indeed at one draught to
 18482	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpluck up a heart of any grace for it thundered long rumblingly over all
 18483	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe heavens so that Master Madden, being godly certain whiles, knocked
 18484	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim on his ribs upon that crack of doom and Master Bloom, at the
 18485	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbraggart’s side, spoke to him calming words to slumber his great fear,
 18486	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tadvertising how it was no other thing but a hubbub noise that he heard,
 18487	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe discharge of fluid from the thunderhead, look you, having taken
 18488	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplace, and all of the order of a natural phenomenon.
 18489	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18490	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBut was young Boasthard’s fear vanquished by Calmer’s words? No, for he
 18491	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thad in his bosom a spike named Bitterness which could not by words be
 18492	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdone away. And was he then neither calm like the one nor godly like the
 18493	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tother? He was neither as much as he would have liked to be either. But
 18494	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcould he not have endeavoured to have found again as in his youth the
 18495	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbottle Holiness that then he lived withal? Indeed no for Grace was not
 18496	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthere to find that bottle. Heard he then in that clap the voice of the
 18497	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgod Bringforth or, what Calmer said, a hubbub of Phenomenon? Heard?
 18498	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhy, he could not but hear unless he had plugged him up the tube
 18499	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tUnderstanding (which he had not done). For through that tube he saw that
 18500	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the was in the land of Phenomenon where he must for a certain one day die
 18501	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tas he was like the rest too a passing show. And would he not accept to
 18502	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdie like the rest and pass away? By no means would he though he must nor
 18503	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twould he make more shows according as men do with wives which Phenomenon
 18504	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thas commanded them to do by the book Law. Then wotted he nought of that
 18505	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tother land which is called Believe-on-Me, that is the land of promise
 18506	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhich behoves to the king Delightful and shall be for ever where there
 18507	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis no death and no birth neither wiving nor mothering at which all shall
 18508	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcome as many as believe on it? Yes, Pious had told him of that land and
 18509	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tChaste had pointed him to the way but the reason was that in the way he
 18510	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfell in with a certain whore of an eyepleasing exterior whose name, she
 18511	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaid, is Bird-in-the-Hand and she beguiled him wrongways from the true
 18512	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpath by her flatteries that she said to him as, Ho, you pretty man, turn
 18513	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taside hither and I will show you a brave place, and she lay at him so
 18514	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tflatteringly that she had him in her grot which is named Two-in-the-Bush
 18515	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tor, by some learned, Carnal Concupiscence.
 18516	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18517	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThis was it what all that company that sat there at commons in Manse
 18518	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof Mothers the most lusted after and if they met with this whore
 18519	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBird-in-the-Hand (which was within all foul plagues, monsters and a
 18520	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twicked devil) they would strain the last but they would make at her and
 18521	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknow her. For regarding Believe-on-Me they said it was nought else
 18522	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbut notion and they could conceive no thought of it for, first,
 18523	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTwo-in-the-Bush whither she ticed them was the very goodliest grot and
 18524	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin it were four pillows on which were four tickets with these words
 18525	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprinted on them, Pickaback and Topsyturvy and Shameface and Cheek by
 18526	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJowl and, second, for that foul plague Allpox and the monsters they
 18527	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcared not for them for Preservative had given them a stout shield of
 18528	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toxengut and, third, that they might take no hurt neither from Offspring
 18529	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat was that wicked devil by virtue of this same shield which was
 18530	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnamed Killchild. So were they all in their blind fancy, Mr Cavil and Mr
 18531	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSometimes Godly, Mr Ape Swillale, Mr False Franklin, Mr Dainty Dixon,
 18532	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYoung Boasthard and Mr Cautious Calmer. Wherein, O wretched company,
 18533	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twere ye all deceived for that was the voice of the god that was in a
 18534	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvery grievous rage that he would presently lift his arm up and
 18535	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspill their souls for their abuses and their spillings done by them
 18536	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcontrariwise to his word which forth to bring brenningly biddeth.
 18537	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18538	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSo Thursday sixteenth June Patk. Dignam laid in clay of an apoplexy and
 18539	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tafter hard drought, please God, rained, a bargeman coming in by water a
 18540	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfifty mile or thereabout with turf saying the seed won’t sprout, fields
 18541	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tathirst, very sadcoloured and stunk mightily, the quags and tofts too.
 18542	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHard to breathe and all the young quicks clean consumed without sprinkle
 18543	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthis long while back as no man remembered to be without. The rosy buds
 18544	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall gone brown and spread out blobs and on the hills nought but dry flag
 18545	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand faggots that would catch at first fire. All the world saying, for
 18546	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taught they knew, the big wind of last February a year that did havoc the
 18547	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tland so pitifully a small thing beside this barrenness. But by and
 18548	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby, as said, this evening after sundown, the wind sitting in the
 18549	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twest, biggish swollen clouds to be seen as the night increased and the
 18550	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tweatherwise poring up at them and some sheet lightnings at first and
 18551	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tafter, past ten of the clock, one great stroke with a long thunder and
 18552	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin a brace of shakes all scamper pellmell within door for the smoking
 18553	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshower, the men making shelter for their straws with a clout or
 18554	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tkerchief, womenfolk skipping off with kirtles catched up soon as the
 18555	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpour came. In Ely place, Baggot street, Duke’s lawn, thence through
 18556	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMerrion green up to Holles street a swash of water flowing that was
 18557	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbefore bonedry and not one chair or coach or fiacre seen about but
 18558	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tno more crack after that first. Over against the Rt. Hon. Mr Justice
 18559	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFitzgibbon’s door (that is to sit with Mr Healy the lawyer upon the
 18560	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcollege lands) Mal. Mulligan a gentleman’s gentleman that had but come
 18561	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom Mr Moore’s the writer’s (that was a papish but is now, folk say,
 18562	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta good Williamite) chanced against Alec. Bannon in a cut bob (which are
 18563	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnow in with dance cloaks of Kendal green) that was new got to town from
 18564	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMullingar with the stage where his coz and Mal M’s brother will stay a
 18565	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmonth yet till Saint Swithin and asks what in the earth he does there,
 18566	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the bound home and he to Andrew Horne’s being stayed for to crush a cup
 18567	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof wine, so he said, but would tell him of a skittish heifer, big of
 18568	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther age and beef to the heel, and all this while poured with rain and
 18569	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tso both together on to Horne’s. There Leop. Bloom of Crawford’s journal
 18570	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsitting snug with a covey of wags, likely brangling fellows, Dixon jun.,
 18571	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tscholar of my lady of Mercy’s, Vin. Lynch, a Scots fellow, Will. Madden,
 18572	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tT. Lenehan, very sad about a racer he fancied and Stephen D. Leop. Bloom
 18573	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthere for a languor he had but was now better, he having dreamed tonight
 18574	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta strange fancy of his dame Mrs Moll with red slippers on in a pair of
 18575	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTurkey trunks which is thought by those in ken to be for a change and
 18576	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMistress Purefoy there, that got in through pleading her belly, and now
 18577	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton the stools, poor body, two days past her term, the midwives sore put
 18578	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto it and can’t deliver, she queasy for a bowl of riceslop that is a
 18579	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshrewd drier up of the insides and her breath very heavy more than good
 18580	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand should be a bullyboy from the knocks, they say, but God give her
 18581	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsoon issue. ‘Tis her ninth chick to live, I hear, and Lady day bit off
 18582	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther last chick’s nails that was then a twelvemonth and with other three
 18583	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall breastfed that died written out in a fair hand in the king’s bible.
 18584	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHer hub fifty odd and a methodist but takes the sacrament and is to
 18585	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbe seen any fair sabbath with a pair of his boys off Bullock harbour
 18586	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdapping on the sound with a heavybraked reel or in a punt he has
 18587	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttrailing for flounder and pollock and catches a fine bag, I hear. In sum
 18588	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tan infinite great fall of rain and all refreshed and will much increase
 18589	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe harvest yet those in ken say after wind and water fire shall come
 18590	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor a prognostication of Malachi’s almanac (and I hear that Mr Russell
 18591	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thas done a prophetical charm of the same gist out of the Hindustanish
 18592	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor his farmer’s gazette) to have three things in all but this a mere
 18593	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfetch without bottom of reason for old crones and bairns yet sometimes
 18594	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey are found in the right guess with their queerities no telling how.
 18595	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18596	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWith this came up Lenehan to the feet of the table to say how the letter
 18597	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas in that night’s gazette and he made a show to find it about him
 18598	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(for he swore with an oath that he had been at pains about it) but on
 18599	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen’s persuasion he gave over the search and was bidden to sit near
 18600	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby which he did mighty brisk. He was a kind of sport gentleman that
 18601	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twent for a merryandrew or honest pickle and what belonged of women,
 18602	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thorseflesh or hot scandal he had it pat. To tell the truth he was mean
 18603	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin fortunes and for the most part hankered about the coffeehouses
 18604	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand low taverns with crimps, ostlers, bookies, Paul’s men, runners,
 18605	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tflatcaps, waistcoateers, ladies of the bagnio and other rogues of the
 18606	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgame or with a chanceable catchpole or a tipstaff often at nights
 18607	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttill broad day of whom he picked up between his sackpossets much loose
 18608	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgossip. He took his ordinary at a boilingcook’s and if he had but gotten
 18609	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinto him a mess of broken victuals or a platter of tripes with a bare
 18610	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttester in his purse he could always bring himself off with his tongue,
 18611	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsome randy quip he had from a punk or whatnot that every mother’s son of
 18612	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthem would burst their sides. The other, Costello that is, hearing this
 18613	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttalk asked was it poetry or a tale. Faith, no, he says, Frank (that was
 18614	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this name), ‘tis all about Kerry cows that are to be butchered along of
 18615	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe plague. But they can go hang, says he with a wink, for me with their
 18616	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbully beef, a pox on it. There’s as good fish in this tin as ever came
 18617	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tout of it and very friendly he offered to take of some salty sprats that
 18618	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstood by which he had eyed wishly in the meantime and found the place
 18619	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhich was indeed the chief design of his embassy as he was sharpset.
 18620	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMort aux vaches, says Frank then in the French language that had been
 18621	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tindentured to a brandyshipper that has a winelodge in Bordeaux and he
 18622	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspoke French like a gentleman too. From a child this Frank had been
 18623	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta donought that his father, a headborough, who could ill keep him to
 18624	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tschool to learn his letters and the use of the globes, matriculated at
 18625	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe university to study the mechanics but he took the bit between his
 18626	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tteeth like a raw colt and was more familiar with the justiciary and the
 18627	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tparish beadle than with his volumes. One time he would be a playactor,
 18628	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthen a sutler or a welsher, then nought would keep him from the bearpit
 18629	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand the cocking main, then he was for the ocean sea or to hoof it on
 18630	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe roads with the romany folk, kidnapping a squire’s heir by favour of
 18631	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmoonlight or fecking maids’ linen or choking chicken behind a hedge. He
 18632	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thad been off as many times as a cat has lives and back again with naked
 18633	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpockets as many more to his father the headborough who shed a pint
 18634	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof tears as often as he saw him. What, says Mr Leopold with his hands
 18635	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tacross, that was earnest to know the drift of it, will they slaughter
 18636	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall? I protest I saw them but this day morning going to the Liverpool
 18637	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tboats, says he. I can scarce believe ‘tis so bad, says he. And he had
 18638	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\texperience of the like brood beasts and of springers, greasy hoggets and
 18639	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twether wool, having been some years before actuary for Mr Joseph Cuffe,
 18640	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta worthy salesmaster that drove his trade for live stock and meadow
 18641	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tauctions hard by Mr Gavin Low’s yard in Prussia street. I question with
 18642	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou there, says he. More like ‘tis the hoose or the timber tongue. Mr
 18643	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen, a little moved but very handsomely told him no such matter and
 18644	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat he had dispatches from the emperor’s chief tailtickler thanking
 18645	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim for the hospitality, that was sending over Doctor Rinderpest, the
 18646	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbestquoted cowcatcher in all Muscovy, with a bolus or two of physic to
 18647	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttake the bull by the horns. Come, come, says Mr Vincent, plain dealing.
 18648	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe’ll find himself on the horns of a dilemma if he meddles with a
 18649	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbull that’s Irish, says he. Irish by name and irish by nature, says Mr
 18650	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen, and he sent the ale purling about, an Irish bull in an English
 18651	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchinashop. I conceive you, says Mr Dixon. It is that same bull that was
 18652	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsent to our island by farmer Nicholas, the bravest cattlebreeder of them
 18653	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall, with an emerald ring in his nose. True for you, says Mr Vincent
 18654	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcross the table, and a bullseye into the bargain, says he, and a plumper
 18655	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand a portlier bull, says he, never shit on shamrock. He had horns
 18656	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgalore, a coat of cloth of gold and a sweet smoky breath coming out of
 18657	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this nostrils so that the women of our island, leaving doughballs and
 18658	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trollingpins, followed after him hanging his bulliness in daisychains.
 18659	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat for that, says Mr Dixon, but before he came over farmer Nicholas
 18660	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat was a eunuch had him properly gelded by a college of doctors who
 18661	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twere no better off than himself. So be off now, says he, and do all my
 18662	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcousin german the lord Harry tells you and take a farmer’s blessing, and
 18663	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith that he slapped his posteriors very soundly. But the slap and the
 18664	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblessing stood him friend, says Mr Vincent, for to make up he taught him
 18665	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta trick worth two of the other so that maid, wife, abbess and widow to
 18666	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthis day affirm that they would rather any time of the month whisper
 18667	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin his ear in the dark of a cowhouse or get a lick on the nape from his
 18668	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlong holy tongue than lie with the finest strapping young ravisher in
 18669	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe four fields of all Ireland. Another then put in his word: And they
 18670	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdressed him, says he, in a point shift and petticoat with a tippet and
 18671	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgirdle and ruffles on his wrists and clipped his forelock and rubbed him
 18672	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall over with spermacetic oil and built stables for him at every turn of
 18673	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe road with a gold manger in each full of the best hay in the market
 18674	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tso that he could doss and dung to his heart’s content. By this time the
 18675	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfather of the faithful (for so they called him) was grown so heavy that
 18676	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the could scarce walk to pasture. To remedy which our cozening dames and
 18677	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdamsels brought him his fodder in their apronlaps and as soon as his
 18678	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbelly was full he would rear up on his hind quarters to show their
 18679	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tladyships a mystery and roar and bellow out of him in bulls’ language
 18680	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand they all after him. Ay, says another, and so pampered was he that he
 18681	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twould suffer nought to grow in all the land but green grass for himself
 18682	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(for that was the only colour to his mind) and there was a board put up
 18683	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton a hillock in the middle of the island with a printed notice, saying:
 18684	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBy the Lord Harry, Green is the grass that grows on the ground. And,
 18685	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsays Mr Dixon, if ever he got scent of a cattleraider in Roscommon or
 18686	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe wilds of Connemara or a husbandman in Sligo that was sowing as much
 18687	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tas a handful of mustard or a bag of rapeseed out he’d run amok over half
 18688	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe countryside rooting up with his horns whatever was planted and all
 18689	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby lord Harry’s orders. There was bad blood between them at first, says
 18690	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Vincent, and the lord Harry called farmer Nicholas all the old Nicks
 18691	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the world and an old whoremaster that kept seven trulls in his house
 18692	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand I’ll meddle in his matters, says he. I’ll make that animal smell
 18693	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thell, says he, with the help of that good pizzle my father left me. But
 18694	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tone evening, says Mr Dixon, when the lord Harry was cleaning his royal
 18695	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpelt to go to dinner after winning a boatrace (he had spade oars for
 18696	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thimself but the first rule of the course was that the others were to row
 18697	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith pitchforks) he discovered in himself a wonderful likeness to a bull
 18698	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand on picking up a blackthumbed chapbook that he kept in the pantry
 18699	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the found sure enough that he was a lefthanded descendant of the famous
 18700	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchampion bull of the Romans, Bos Bovum, which is good bog Latin for boss
 18701	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the show. After that, says Mr Vincent, the lord Harry put his head
 18702	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinto a cow’s drinkingtrough in the presence of all his courtiers and
 18703	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpulling it out again told them all his new name. Then, with the water
 18704	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trunning off him, he got into an old smock and skirt that had belonged to
 18705	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this grandmother and bought a grammar of the bulls’ language to study
 18706	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbut he could never learn a word of it except the first personal pronoun
 18707	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhich he copied out big and got off by heart and if ever he went out for
 18708	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta walk he filled his pockets with chalk to write it upon what took his
 18709	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfancy, the side of a rock or a teahouse table or a bale of cotton or
 18710	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta corkfloat. In short, he and the bull of Ireland were soon as fast
 18711	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfriends as an arse and a shirt. They were, says Mr Stephen, and the end
 18712	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas that the men of the island seeing no help was toward, as the ungrate
 18713	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twomen were all of one mind, made a wherry raft, loaded themselves and
 18714	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir bundles of chattels on shipboard, set all masts erect, manned the
 18715	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyards, sprang their luff, heaved to, spread three sheets in the wind,
 18716	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tput her head between wind and water, weighed anchor, ported her helm,
 18717	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tran up the jolly Roger, gave three times three, let the bullgine run,
 18718	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpushed off in their bumboat and put to sea to recover the main of
 18719	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAmerica. Which was the occasion, says Mr Vincent, of the composing by a
 18720	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tboatswain of that rollicking chanty:
 18721	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18722	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     —Pope Peter’s but a pissabed.
 18723	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     A man’s a man for a’ that.
 18724	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18725	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOur worthy acquaintance Mr Malachi Mulligan now appeared in the doorway
 18726	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tas the students were finishing their apologue accompanied with a friend
 18727	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhom he had just rencountered, a young gentleman, his name Alec Bannon,
 18728	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twho had late come to town, it being his intention to buy a colour or a
 18729	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcornetcy in the fencibles and list for the wars. Mr Mulligan was civil
 18730	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tenough to express some relish of it all the more as it jumped with a
 18731	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tproject of his own for the cure of the very evil that had been touched
 18732	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton. Whereat he handed round to the company a set of pasteboard cards
 18733	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhich he had had printed that day at Mr Quinnell’s bearing a legend
 18734	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprinted in fair italics: Mr Malachi Mulligan. Fertiliser and Incubator.
 18735	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLambay Island. His project, as he went on to expound, was to withdraw
 18736	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom the round of idle pleasures such as form the chief business of sir
 18737	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFopling Popinjay and sir Milksop Quidnunc in town and to devote himself
 18738	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto the noblest task for which our bodily organism has been framed. Well,
 18739	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlet us hear of it, good my friend, said Mr Dixon. I make no doubt it
 18740	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsmacks of wenching. Come, be seated, both. ‘Tis as cheap sitting as
 18741	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstanding. Mr Mulligan accepted of the invitation and, expatiating upon
 18742	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this design, told his hearers that he had been led into this thought by
 18743	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta consideration of the causes of sterility, both the inhibitory and the
 18744	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprohibitory, whether the inhibition in its turn were due to conjugal
 18745	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvexations or to a parsimony of the balance as well as whether the
 18746	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprohibition proceeded from defects congenital or from proclivities
 18747	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tacquired. It grieved him plaguily, he said, to see the nuptial couch
 18748	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdefrauded of its dearest pledges: and to reflect upon so many agreeable
 18749	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfemales with rich jointures, a prey to the vilest bonzes, who hide their
 18750	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tflambeau under a bushel in an uncongenial cloister or lose their womanly
 18751	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbloom in the embraces of some unaccountable muskin when they might
 18752	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmultiply the inlets of happiness, sacrificing the inestimable jewel of
 18753	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir sex when a hundred pretty fellows were at hand to caress, this, he
 18754	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tassured them, made his heart weep. To curb this inconvenient (which
 18755	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the concluded due to a suppression of latent heat), having advised with
 18756	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcertain counsellors of worth and inspected into this matter, he had
 18757	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tresolved to purchase in fee simple for ever the freehold of Lambay
 18758	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tisland from its holder, lord Talbot de Malahide, a Tory gentleman of
 18759	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnote much in favour with our ascendancy party. He proposed to set up
 18760	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthere a national fertilising farm to be named Omphalos with an obelisk
 18761	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thewn and erected after the fashion of Egypt and to offer his dutiful
 18762	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyeoman services for the fecundation of any female of what grade of life
 18763	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsoever who should there direct to him with the desire of fulfilling the
 18764	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfunctions of her natural. Money was no object, he said, nor would he
 18765	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttake a penny for his pains. The poorest kitchenwench no less than the
 18766	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\topulent lady of fashion, if so be their constructions and their tempers
 18767	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twere warm persuaders for their petitions, would find in him their man.
 18768	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFor his nutriment he shewed how he would feed himself exclusively upon a
 18769	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdiet of savoury tubercles and fish and coneys there, the flesh of these
 18770	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlatter prolific rodents being highly recommended for his purpose, both
 18771	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbroiled and stewed with a blade of mace and a pod or two of capsicum
 18772	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchillies. After this homily which he delivered with much warmth of
 18773	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tasseveration Mr Mulligan in a trice put off from his hat a kerchief with
 18774	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhich he had shielded it. They both, it seems, had been overtaken by the
 18775	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\train and for all their mending their pace had taken water, as might be
 18776	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tobserved by Mr Mulligan’s smallclothes of a hodden grey which was now
 18777	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsomewhat piebald. His project meanwhile was very favourably entertained
 18778	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby his auditors and won hearty eulogies from all though Mr Dixon of
 18779	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMary’s excepted to it, asking with a finicking air did he purpose also
 18780	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto carry coals to Newcastle. Mr Mulligan however made court to the
 18781	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tscholarly by an apt quotation from the classics which, as it dwelt
 18782	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tupon his memory, seemed to him a sound and tasteful support of his
 18783	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcontention: Talis ac tanta depravatio hujus seculi, O quirites,
 18784	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tut matresfamiliarum nostrae lascivas cujuslibet semiviri libici
 18785	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttitillationes testibus ponderosis atque excelsis erectionibus
 18786	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcenturionum Romanorum magnopere anteponunt, while for those of ruder wit
 18787	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the drove home his point by analogies of the animal kingdom more suitable
 18788	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto their stomach, the buck and doe of the forest glade, the farmyard
 18789	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrake and duck.
 18790	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18791	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tValuing himself not a little upon his elegance, being indeed a proper
 18792	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tman of person, this talkative now applied himself to his dress with
 18793	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanimadversions of some heat upon the sudden whimsy of the atmospherics
 18794	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhile the company lavished their encomiums upon the project he had
 18795	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tadvanced. The young gentleman, his friend, overjoyed as he was at a
 18796	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpassage that had late befallen him, could not forbear to tell it his
 18797	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnearest neighbour. Mr Mulligan, now perceiving the table, asked for whom
 18798	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twere those loaves and fishes and, seeing the stranger, he made him
 18799	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta civil bow and said, Pray, sir, was you in need of any professional
 18800	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tassistance we could give? Who, upon his offer, thanked him very
 18801	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\theartily, though preserving his proper distance, and replied that he was
 18802	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcome there about a lady, now an inmate of Horne’s house, that was in an
 18803	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinteresting condition, poor body, from woman’s woe (and here he fetched
 18804	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta deep sigh) to know if her happiness had yet taken place. Mr Dixon,
 18805	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto turn the table, took on to ask of Mr Mulligan himself whether
 18806	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this incipient ventripotence, upon which he rallied him, betokened an
 18807	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tovoblastic gestation in the prostatic utricle or male womb or was due,
 18808	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tas with the noted physician, Mr Austin Meldon, to a wolf in the stomach.
 18809	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFor answer Mr Mulligan, in a gale of laughter at his smalls, smote
 18810	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thimself bravely below the diaphragm, exclaiming with an admirable droll
 18811	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmimic of Mother Grogan (the most excellent creature of her sex though
 18812	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t‘tis pity she’s a trollop): There’s a belly that never bore a bastard.
 18813	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThis was so happy a conceit that it renewed the storm of mirth and threw
 18814	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe whole room into the most violent agitations of delight. The spry
 18815	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trattle had run on in the same vein of mimicry but for some larum in the
 18816	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tantechamber.
 18817	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18818	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHere the listener who was none other than the Scotch student, a little
 18819	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfume of a fellow, blond as tow, congratulated in the liveliest fashion
 18820	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith the young gentleman and, interrupting the narrative at a salient
 18821	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoint, having desired his visavis with a polite beck to have the
 18822	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tobligingness to pass him a flagon of cordial waters at the same time by
 18823	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta questioning poise of the head (a whole century of polite breeding had
 18824	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnot achieved so nice a gesture) to which was united an equivalent but
 18825	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcontrary balance of the bottle asked the narrator as plainly as was ever
 18826	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdone in words if he might treat him with a cup of it. Mais bien sûr,
 18827	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnoble stranger, said he cheerily, et mille compliments. That you may
 18828	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand very opportunely. There wanted nothing but this cup to crown my
 18829	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfelicity. But, gracious heaven, was I left with but a crust in my wallet
 18830	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand a cupful of water from the well, my God, I would accept of them and
 18831	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfind it in my heart to kneel down upon the ground and give thanks to
 18832	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe powers above for the happiness vouchsafed me by the Giver of good
 18833	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthings. With these words he approached the goblet to his lips, took a
 18834	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcomplacent draught of the cordial, slicked his hair and, opening his
 18835	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbosom, out popped a locket that hung from a silk riband, that very
 18836	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpicture which he had cherished ever since her hand had wrote therein.
 18837	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGazing upon those features with a world of tenderness, Ah, Monsieur, he
 18838	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaid, had you but beheld her as I did with these eyes at that affecting
 18839	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinstant with her dainty tucker and her new coquette cap (a gift for her
 18840	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfeastday as she told me prettily) in such an artless disorder, of so
 18841	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmelting a tenderness, ‘pon my conscience, even you, Monsieur, had been
 18842	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\timpelled by generous nature to deliver yourself wholly into the hands of
 18843	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsuch an enemy or to quit the field for ever. I declare, I was never so
 18844	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttouched in all my life. God, I thank thee, as the Author of my days!
 18845	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThrice happy will he be whom so amiable a creature will bless with her
 18846	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfavours. A sigh of affection gave eloquence to these words and, having
 18847	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treplaced the locket in his bosom, he wiped his eye and sighed again.
 18848	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBeneficent Disseminator of blessings to all Thy creatures, how great
 18849	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand universal must be that sweetest of Thy tyrannies which can hold in
 18850	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthrall the free and the bond, the simple swain and the polished coxcomb,
 18851	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe lover in the heyday of reckless passion and the husband of maturer
 18852	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyears. But indeed, sir, I wander from the point. How mingled and
 18853	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\timperfect are all our sublunary joys. Maledicity! he exclaimed in
 18854	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanguish. Would to God that foresight had but remembered me to take my
 18855	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcloak along! I could weep to think of it. Then, though it had poured
 18856	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseven showers, we were neither of us a penny the worse. But beshrew me,
 18857	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the cried, clapping hand to his forehead, tomorrow will be a new day and,
 18858	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthousand thunders, I know of a marchand de capotes, Monsieur Poyntz,
 18859	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom whom I can have for a livre as snug a cloak of the French fashion
 18860	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tas ever kept a lady from wetting. Tut, tut! cries Le Fécondateur,
 18861	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttripping in, my friend Monsieur Moore, that most accomplished traveller
 18862	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(I have just cracked a half bottle avec lui in a circle of the best wits
 18863	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the town), is my authority that in Cape Horn, ventre biche, they have
 18864	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta rain that will wet through any, even the stoutest cloak. A drenching
 18865	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof that violence, he tells me, sans blague, has sent more than one
 18866	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tluckless fellow in good earnest posthaste to another world. Pooh! A
 18867	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlivre! cries Monsieur Lynch. The clumsy things are dear at a sou. One
 18868	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tumbrella, were it no bigger than a fairy mushroom, is worth ten such
 18869	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstopgaps. No woman of any wit would wear one. My dear Kitty told me
 18870	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoday that she would dance in a deluge before ever she would starve in
 18871	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsuch an ark of salvation for, as she reminded me (blushing piquantly and
 18872	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhispering in my ear though there was none to snap her words but giddy
 18873	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbutterflies), dame Nature, by the divine blessing, has implanted it in
 18874	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tour hearts and it has become a household word that il y a deux choses
 18875	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor which the innocence of our original garb, in other circumstances a
 18876	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbreach of the proprieties, is the fittest, nay, the only garment. The
 18877	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfirst, said she (and here my pretty philosopher, as I handed her to her
 18878	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttilbury, to fix my attention, gently tipped with her tongue the outer
 18879	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchamber of my ear), the first is a bath... But at this point a bell
 18880	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttinkling in the hall cut short a discourse which promised so bravely for
 18881	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe enrichment of our store of knowledge.
 18882	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18883	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAmid the general vacant hilarity of the assembly a bell rang and, while
 18884	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall were conjecturing what might be the cause, Miss Callan entered and,
 18885	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thaving spoken a few words in a low tone to young Mr Dixon, retired with
 18886	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta profound bow to the company. The presence even for a moment among a
 18887	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tparty of debauchees of a woman endued with every quality of modesty and
 18888	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnot less severe than beautiful refrained the humourous sallies even of
 18889	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe most licentious but her departure was the signal for an outbreak of
 18890	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tribaldry. Strike me silly, said Costello, a low fellow who was fuddled.
 18891	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA monstrous fine bit of cowflesh! I’ll be sworn she has rendezvoused
 18892	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou. What, you dog? Have you a way with them? Gad’s bud, immensely
 18893	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tso, said Mr Lynch. The bedside manner it is that they use in the Mater
 18894	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thospice. Demme, does not Doctor O’Gargle chuck the nuns there under the
 18895	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchin. As I look to be saved I had it from my Kitty who has been wardmaid
 18896	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthere any time these seven months. Lawksamercy, doctor, cried the young
 18897	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblood in the primrose vest, feigning a womanish simper and with immodest
 18898	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsquirmings of his body, how you do tease a body! Drat the man! Bless
 18899	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tme, I’m all of a wibbly wobbly. Why, you’re as bad as dear little Father
 18900	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCantekissem, that you are! May this pot of four half choke me, cried
 18901	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCostello, if she aint in the family way. I knows a lady what’s got a
 18902	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhite swelling quick as I claps eyes on her. The young surgeon, however,
 18903	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trose and begged the company to excuse his retreat as the nurse had just
 18904	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthen informed him that he was needed in the ward. Merciful providence
 18905	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thad been pleased to put a period to the sufferings of the lady who was
 18906	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tenceinte which she had borne with a laudable fortitude and she had
 18907	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgiven birth to a bouncing boy. I want patience, said he, with those
 18908	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twho, without wit to enliven or learning to instruct, revile an ennobling
 18909	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprofession which, saving the reverence due to the Deity, is the greatest
 18910	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpower for happiness upon the earth. I am positive when I say that if
 18911	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tneed were I could produce a cloud of witnesses to the excellence of
 18912	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther noble exercitations which, so far from being a byword, should be a
 18913	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tglorious incentive in the human breast. I cannot away with them. What?
 18914	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMalign such an one, the amiable Miss Callan, who is the lustre of
 18915	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther own sex and the astonishment of ours? And at an instant the most
 18916	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmomentous that can befall a puny child of clay? Perish the thought! I
 18917	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshudder to think of the future of a race where the seeds of such malice
 18918	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thave been sown and where no right reverence is rendered to mother and
 18919	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmaid in house of Horne. Having delivered himself of this rebuke he
 18920	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsaluted those present on the by and repaired to the door. A murmur
 18921	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof approval arose from all and some were for ejecting the low soaker
 18922	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twithout more ado, a design which would have been effected nor would
 18923	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the have received more than his bare deserts had he not abridged his
 18924	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttransgression by affirming with a horrid imprecation (for he swore a
 18925	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tround hand) that he was as good a son of the true fold as ever drew
 18926	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbreath. Stap my vitals, said he, them was always the sentiments of
 18927	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thonest Frank Costello which I was bred up most particular to honour thy
 18928	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfather and thy mother that had the best hand to a rolypoly or a hasty
 18929	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpudding as you ever see what I always looks back on with a loving heart.
 18930	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18931	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTo revert to Mr Bloom who, after his first entry, had been conscious of
 18932	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsome impudent mocks which he however had borne with as being the fruits
 18933	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof that age upon which it is commonly charged that it knows not
 18934	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpity. The young sparks, it is true, were as full of extravagancies
 18935	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tas overgrown children: the words of their tumultuary discussions
 18936	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twere difficultly understood and not often nice: their testiness and
 18937	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toutrageous mots were such that his intellects resiled from: nor were
 18938	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey scrupulously sensible of the proprieties though their fund of
 18939	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstrong animal spirits spoke in their behalf. But the word of Mr Costello
 18940	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twas an unwelcome language for him for he nauseated the wretch that
 18941	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseemed to him a cropeared creature of a misshapen gibbosity, born out
 18942	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof wedlock and thrust like a crookback toothed and feet first into the
 18943	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tworld, which the dint of the surgeon’s pliers in his skull lent indeed
 18944	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta colour to, so as to put him in thought of that missing link of
 18945	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcreation’s chain desiderated by the late ingenious Mr Darwin. It was now
 18946	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor more than the middle span of our allotted years that he had passed
 18947	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthrough the thousand vicissitudes of existence and, being of a wary
 18948	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tascendancy and self a man of rare forecast, he had enjoined his heart
 18949	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto repress all motions of a rising choler and, by intercepting them
 18950	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith the readiest precaution, foster within his breast that plenitude
 18951	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof sufferance which base minds jeer at, rash judgers scorn and all find
 18952	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttolerable and but tolerable. To those who create themselves wits at the
 18953	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcost of feminine delicacy (a habit of mind which he never did hold
 18954	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith) to them he would concede neither to bear the name nor to herit
 18955	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe tradition of a proper breeding: while for such that, having lost
 18956	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall forbearance, can lose no more, there remained the sharp antidote of
 18957	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\texperience to cause their insolency to beat a precipitate and inglorious
 18958	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tretreat. Not but what he could feel with mettlesome youth which, caring
 18959	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnought for the mows of dotards or the gruntlings of the severe, is ever
 18960	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(as the chaste fancy of the Holy Writer expresses it) for eating of the
 18961	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttree forbid it yet not so far forth as to pretermit humanity upon any
 18962	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcondition soever towards a gentlewoman when she was about her lawful
 18963	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toccasions. To conclude, while from the sister’s words he had reckoned
 18964	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tupon a speedy delivery he was, however, it must be owned, not a little
 18965	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\talleviated by the intelligence that the issue so auspicated after an
 18966	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tordeal of such duress now testified once more to the mercy as well as to
 18967	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe bounty of the Supreme Being.
 18968	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18969	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAccordingly he broke his mind to his neighbour, saying that, to express
 18970	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this notion of the thing, his opinion (who ought not perchance to express
 18971	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tone) was that one must have a cold constitution and a frigid genius not
 18972	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto be rejoiced by this freshest news of the fruition of her confinement
 18973	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsince she had been in such pain through no fault of hers. The dressy
 18974	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyoung blade said it was her husband’s that put her in that expectation
 18975	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tor at least it ought to be unless she were another Ephesian matron. I
 18976	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmust acquaint you, said Mr Crotthers, clapping on the table so as to
 18977	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tevoke a resonant comment of emphasis, old Glory Allelujurum was round
 18978	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tagain today, an elderly man with dundrearies, preferring through his
 18979	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnose a request to have word of Wilhelmina, my life, as he calls her. I
 18980	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbade him hold himself in readiness for that the event would burst anon.
 18981	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t‘Slife, I’ll be round with you. I cannot but extol the virile potency of
 18982	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe old bucko that could still knock another child out of her. All fell
 18983	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto praising of it, each after his own fashion, though the same young
 18984	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblade held with his former view that another than her conjugial had
 18985	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeen the man in the gap, a clerk in orders, a linkboy (virtuous) or
 18986	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tan itinerant vendor of articles needed in every household. Singular,
 18987	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcommuned the guest with himself, the wonderfully unequal faculty of
 18988	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmetempsychosis possessed by them, that the puerperal dormitory and the
 18989	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdissecting theatre should be the seminaries of such frivolity, that the
 18990	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmere acquisition of academic titles should suffice to transform in a
 18991	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpinch of time these votaries of levity into exemplary practitioners of
 18992	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tan art which most men anywise eminent have esteemed the noblest. But,
 18993	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the further added, it is mayhap to relieve the pentup feelings that in
 18994	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcommon oppress them for I have more than once observed that birds of a
 18995	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfeather laugh together.
 18996	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 18997	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBut with what fitness, let it be asked of the noble lord, his patron,
 18998	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thas this alien, whom the concession of a gracious prince has admitted
 18999	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto civic rights, constituted himself the lord paramount of our
 19000	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinternal polity? Where is now that gratitude which loyalty should have
 19001	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcounselled? During the recent war whenever the enemy had a temporary
 19002	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tadvantage with his granados did this traitor to his kind not seize that
 19003	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmoment to discharge his piece against the empire of which he is a tenant
 19004	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat will while he trembled for the security of his four per cents? Has he
 19005	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tforgotten this as he forgets all benefits received? Or is it that from
 19006	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeing a deluder of others he has become at last his own dupe as he is,
 19007	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tif report belie him not, his own and his only enjoyer? Far be it from
 19008	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcandour to violate the bedchamber of a respectable lady, the daughter of
 19009	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta gallant major, or to cast the most distant reflections upon her
 19010	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvirtue but if he challenges attention there (as it was indeed highly his
 19011	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinterest not to have done) then be it so. Unhappy woman, she has been
 19012	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoo long and too persistently denied her legitimate prerogative to
 19013	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlisten to his objurgations with any other feeling than the derision of
 19014	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe desperate. He says this, a censor of morals, a very pelican in his
 19015	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpiety, who did not scruple, oblivious of the ties of nature, to attempt
 19016	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tillicit intercourse with a female domestic drawn from the lowest strata
 19017	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof society! Nay, had the hussy’s scouringbrush not been her tutelary
 19018	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tangel, it had gone with her as hard as with Hagar, the Egyptian! In the
 19019	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquestion of the grazing lands his peevish asperity is notorious and in
 19020	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMr Cuffe’s hearing brought upon him from an indignant rancher a scathing
 19021	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tretort couched in terms as straightforward as they were bucolic. It ill
 19022	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbecomes him to preach that gospel. Has he not nearer home a seedfield
 19023	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat lies fallow for the want of the ploughshare? A habit reprehensible
 19024	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat puberty is second nature and an opprobrium in middle life. If he must
 19025	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdispense his balm of Gilead in nostrums and apothegms of dubious taste
 19026	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto restore to health a generation of unfledged profligates let his
 19027	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpractice consist better with the doctrines that now engross him. His
 19028	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmarital breast is the repository of secrets which decorum is reluctant
 19029	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto adduce. The lewd suggestions of some faded beauty may console him for
 19030	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta consort neglected and debauched but this new exponent of morals and
 19031	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thealer of ills is at his best an exotic tree which, when rooted in
 19032	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tits native orient, throve and flourished and was abundant in balm
 19033	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbut, transplanted to a clime more temperate, its roots have lost their
 19034	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquondam vigour while the stuff that comes away from it is stagnant, acid
 19035	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand inoperative.
 19036	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 19037	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe news was imparted with a circumspection recalling the ceremonial
 19038	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tusage of the Sublime Porte by the second female infirmarian to the
 19039	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjunior medical officer in residence, who in his turn announced to the
 19040	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdelegation that an heir had been born. When he had betaken himself
 19041	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto the women’s apartment to assist at the prescribed ceremony of the
 19042	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tafterbirth in the presence of the secretary of state for domestic
 19043	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taffairs and the members of the privy council, silent in unanimous
 19044	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\texhaustion and approbation the delegates, chafing under the length and
 19045	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsolemnity of their vigil and hoping that the joyful occurrence would
 19046	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpalliate a licence which the simultaneous absence of abigail and
 19047	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tobstetrician rendered the easier, broke out at once into a strife of
 19048	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttongues. In vain the voice of Mr Canvasser Bloom was heard endeavouring
 19049	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto urge, to mollify, to refrain. The moment was too propitious for the
 19050	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdisplay of that discursiveness which seemed the only bond of union among
 19051	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttempers so divergent. Every phase of the situation was successively
 19052	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teviscerated: the prenatal repugnance of uterine brothers, the Caesarean
 19053	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsection, posthumity with respect to the father and, that rarer form,
 19054	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith respect to the mother, the fratricidal case known as the Childs
 19055	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMurder and rendered memorable by the impassioned plea of Mr Advocate
 19056	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBushe which secured the acquittal of the wrongfully accused, the
 19057	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trights of primogeniture and king’s bounty touching twins and triplets,
 19058	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmiscarriages and infanticides, simulated or dissimulated, the acardiac
 19059	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfoetus in foetu and aprosopia due to a congestion, the agnathia
 19060	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof certain chinless Chinamen (cited by Mr Candidate Mulligan) in
 19061	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconsequence of defective reunion of the maxillary knobs along the medial
 19062	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tline so that (as he said) one ear could hear what the other spoke, the
 19063	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbenefits of anesthesia or twilight sleep, the prolongation of labour
 19064	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpains in advanced gravidancy by reason of pressure on the vein, the
 19065	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpremature relentment of the amniotic fluid (as exemplified in the
 19066	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tactual case) with consequent peril of sepsis to the matrix, artificial
 19067	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinsemination by means of syringes, involution of the womb consequent
 19068	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tupon the menopause, the problem of the perpetration of the species in
 19069	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe case of females impregnated by delinquent rape, that distressing
 19070	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmanner of delivery called by the Brandenburghers Sturzgeburt, the
 19071	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trecorded instances of multiseminal, twikindled and monstrous births
 19072	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconceived during the catamenic period or of consanguineous parents—in a
 19073	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tword all the cases of human nativity which Aristotle has classified
 19074	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin his masterpiece with chromolithographic illustrations. The gravest
 19075	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tproblems of obstetrics and forensic medicine were examined with as much
 19076	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanimation as the most popular beliefs on the state of pregnancy such as
 19077	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe forbidding to a gravid woman to step over a countrystile lest,
 19078	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby her movement, the navelcord should strangle her creature and
 19079	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe injunction upon her in the event of a yearning, ardently and
 19080	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tineffectually entertained, to place her hand against that part of her
 19081	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tperson which long usage has consecrated as the seat of castigation.
 19082	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe abnormalities of harelip, breastmole, supernumerary digits, negro’s
 19083	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinkle, strawberry mark and portwine stain were alleged by one as a prima
 19084	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfacie and natural hypothetical explanation of those swineheaded (the
 19085	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcase of Madame Grissel Steevens was not forgotten) or doghaired infants
 19086	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toccasionally born. The hypothesis of a plasmic memory, advanced by the
 19087	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCaledonian envoy and worthy of the metaphysical traditions of the land
 19088	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the stood for, envisaged in such cases an arrest of embryonic development
 19089	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat some stage antecedent to the human. An outlandish delegate sustained
 19090	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tagainst both these views, with such heat as almost carried conviction,
 19091	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe theory of copulation between women and the males of brutes, his
 19092	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tauthority being his own avouchment in support of fables such as that of
 19093	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe Minotaur which the genius of the elegant Latin poet has handed down
 19094	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto us in the pages of his Metamorphoses. The impression made by his
 19095	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twords was immediate but shortlived. It was effaced as easily as it had
 19096	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeen evoked by an allocution from Mr Candidate Mulligan in that vein of
 19097	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpleasantry which none better than he knew how to affect, postulating as
 19098	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe supremest object of desire a nice clean old man. Contemporaneously,
 19099	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta heated argument having arisen between Mr Delegate Madden and Mr
 19100	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCandidate Lynch regarding the juridical and theological dilemma created
 19101	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the event of one Siamese twin predeceasing the other, the difficulty
 19102	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby mutual consent was referred to Mr Canvasser Bloom for instant
 19103	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsubmittal to Mr Coadjutor Deacon Dedalus. Hitherto silent, whether the
 19104	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbetter to show by preternatural gravity that curious dignity of the
 19105	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgarb with which he was invested or in obedience to an inward voice, he
 19106	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdelivered briefly and, as some thought, perfunctorily the ecclesiastical
 19107	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tordinance forbidding man to put asunder what God has joined.
 19108	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 19109	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBut Malachias’ tale began to freeze them with horror. He conjured up the
 19110	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tscene before them. The secret panel beside the chimney slid back and in
 19111	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe recess appeared... Haines! Which of us did not feel his flesh creep!
 19112	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe had a portfolio full of Celtic literature in one hand, in the other
 19113	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta phial marked Poison. Surprise, horror, loathing were depicted on all
 19114	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfaces while he eyed them with a ghostly grin. I anticipated some such
 19115	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treception, he began with an eldritch laugh, for which, it seems, history
 19116	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis to blame. Yes, it is true. I am the murderer of Samuel Childs.
 19117	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd how I am punished! The inferno has no terrors for me. This is the
 19118	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tappearance is on me. Tare and ages, what way would I be resting at all,
 19119	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the muttered thickly, and I tramping Dublin this while back with my share
