 24056	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Card of the races. Racing card!
 24057	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Ten to one the field!
 24058	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Tommy on the clay here! Tommy on the clay!
 24059	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Ten to one bar one! Ten to one bar one!
 24060	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Try your luck on Spinning Jenny!
 24061	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Ten to one bar one!
 24062	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Sell the monkey, boys! Sell the monkey!
 24063	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     I’ll give ten to one!
 24064	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Ten to one bar one!
 24065	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24066	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(A dark horse, riderless, bolts like a phantom past the winningpost,
 24067	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this mane moonfoaming, his eyeballs stars. The field follows, a bunch of
 24068	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbucking mounts. Skeleton horses, Sceptre, Maximum the Second, Zinfandel,
 24069	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe Duke of Westminster’s Shotover, Repulse, the Duke of Beaufort’s
 24070	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCeylon, prix de Paris. Dwarfs ride them, rustyarmoured, leaping, leaping

 24072	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tisabelle nag, Cock of the North, the favourite, honey cap, green jacket,

 24309	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdogsbody killed her bitchbody. She kicked the bucket. (Tears of molten
 24310	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbutter fall from his eyes on to the scone.) Our great sweet mother! Epi
 24311	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toinopa ponton.
 24312	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24313	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTHE MOTHER: (Comes nearer, breathing upon him softly her breath of
 24314	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twetted ashes.) All must go through it, Stephen. More women than men in
 24315	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe world. You too. Time will come.

 24318	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou, mother. He offended your memory. Cancer did it, not I. Destiny.
 24319	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24320	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTHE MOTHER: (A green rill of bile trickling from a side of her mouth.)
 24321	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tYou sang that song to me. Love’s bitter mystery.
 24322	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24323	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSTEPHEN: (Eagerly.) Tell me the word, mother, if you know now. The word
 24324	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknown to all men.
 24325	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24326	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTHE MOTHER: Who saved you the night you jumped into the train at
 24327	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDalkey with Paddy Lee? Who had pity for you when you were sad among the
 24328	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstrangers? Prayer is allpowerful. Prayer for the suffering souls in the
 24329	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tUrsuline manual and forty days’ indulgence. Repent, Stephen.
 24330	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24331	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSTEPHEN: The ghoul! Hyena!
 24332	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24333	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTHE MOTHER: I pray for you in my other world. Get Dilly to make you that
 24334	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tboiled rice every night after your brainwork. Years and years I loved
 24335	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou, O, my son, my firstborn, when you lay in my womb.
 24336	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24337	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tZOE: (Fanning herself with the grate fan.) I’m melting!
 24338	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24339	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFLORRY: (Points to Stephen.) Look! He’s white.
 24340	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 24342	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24343	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTHE MOTHER: (With smouldering eyes.) Repent! O, the fire of hell!

 24346	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thead and bloody bones.
 24347	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24348	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTHE MOTHER: (Her face drawing near and nearer, sending out an ashen
 24349	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbreath.) Beware! (She raises her blackened withered right arm slowly
 24350	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttowards Stephen’s breast with outstretched finger.) Beware God’s hand!
 24351	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(A green crab with malignant red eyes sticks deep its grinning claws in
 24352	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen’s heart.)
 24353	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24354	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSTEPHEN: (Strangled with rage.) Shite! (His features grow drawn grey and
 24355	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\told.)
 24356	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24357	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBLOOM: (At the window.) What?
 24358	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24359	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSTEPHEN: Ah non, par exemple! The intellectual imagination! With me all
 24360	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tor not at all. Non serviam!
 24361	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24362	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFLORRY: Give him some cold water. Wait. (She rushes out.)

 24370	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24371	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTHE MOTHER: (In the agony of her deathrattle.) Have mercy on Stephen,
 24372	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLord, for my sake! Inexpressible was my anguish when expiring with love,
 24373	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgrief and agony on Mount Calvary.

 24401	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 24404	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 24406	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 24410	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat? Ten shillings. You’re a witness.

 24413	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlifted enough off him? Didn’t he...?

 24425	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnot sixpenceworth of damage done. Ten shillings!
 24426	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24427	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFLORRY: (With a glass of water, enters.) Where is he?
 24428	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 24430	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24431	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBLOOM: O, I know. Bulldog on the premises. But he’s a Trinity student.
 24432	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPatrons of your establishment. Gentlemen that pay the rent. (He makes a
 24433	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmasonic sign.) Know what I mean? Nephew of the vicechancellor. You don’t

 24592	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(Edward the Seventh appears in an archway. He wears a white jersey on
 24593	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhich an image of the Sacred Heart is stitched with the insignia of

 24598	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmade in Germany. In his left hand he holds a plasterer’s bucket on which
 24599	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis printed Défense d’uriner. A roar of welcome greets him.)
 24600	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24601	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEDWARD THE SEVENTH: (Slowly, solemnly but indistinctly.) Peace, perfect
 24602	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpeace. For identification, bucket in my hand. Cheerio, boys. (He turns
 24603	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto his subjects.) We have come here to witness a clean straight fight
 24604	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand we heartily wish both men the best of good luck. Mahak makar a bak.

 24609	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24610	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPRIVATE CARR: (To Stephen.) Say it again.

 24612	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSTEPHEN: (Nervous, friendly, pulls himself up.) I understand your point
 24613	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof view though I have no king myself for the moment. This is the age of
 24614	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpatent medicines. A discussion is difficult down here. But this is the
 24615	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoint. You die for your country. Suppose. (He places his arm on Private
 24616	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCarr’s sleeve.) Not that I wish it for you. But I say: Let my country
 24617	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdie for me. Up to the present it has done so. I didn’t want it to die.
 24618	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDamn death. Long live life!
 24619	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24620	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEDWARD THE SEVENTH: (Levitates over heaps of slain, in the garb and with

 24622	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24623	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      My methods are new and are causing surprise.
 24624	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      To make the blind see I throw dust in their eyes.

 24631	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24632	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBLOOM: (To the privates, softly.) He doesn’t know what he’s saying.

 24634	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tknow him. He’s a gentleman, a poet. It’s all right.

 24637	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjudge of impostors.
 24638	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24639	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPRIVATE CARR: I don’t give a bugger who he is.
 24640	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24641	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPRIVATE COMPTON: We don’t give a bugger who he is.
 24642	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24643	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSTEPHEN: I seem to annoy them. Green rag to a bull.
 24644	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24645	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(Kevin Egan of Paris in black Spanish tasselled shirt and peep-o’-day
 24646	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tboy’s hat signs to Stephen.)
 24647	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24648	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKEVIN EGAN: H’lo! Bonjour! The vieille ogresse with the dents jaunes.
 24649	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24650	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(Patrice Egan peeps from behind, his rabbitface nibbling a quince leaf.)
 24651	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24652	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPATRICE: Socialiste!
 24653	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24654	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDON EMILE PATRIZIO FRANZ RUPERT POPE HENNESSY: (In medieval hauberk, two
 24655	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twild geese volant on his helm, with noble indignation points a mailed
 24656	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thand against the privates.) Werf those eykes to footboden, big grand
 24657	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tporcos of johnyellows todos covered of gravy!
 24658	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24659	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBLOOM: (To Stephen.) Come home. You’ll get into trouble.
 24660	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24661	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSTEPHEN: (Swaying.) I don’t avoid it. He provokes my intelligence.
 24662	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24663	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBIDDY THE CLAP: One immediately observes that he is of patrician
 24664	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlineage.
 24665	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24666	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTHE VIRAGO: Green above the red, says he. Wolfe Tone.
 24667	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24668	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTHE BAWD: The red’s as good as the green. And better. Up the soldiers!
 24669	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tUp King Edward!
 24670	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24671	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA ROUGH: (Laughs.) Ay! Hands up to De Wet.
 24672	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24673	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTHE CITIZEN: (With a huge emerald muffler and shillelagh, calls.)
 24674	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24675	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     May the God above
 24676	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Send down a dove
 24677	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     With teeth as sharp as razors
 24678	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     To slit the throats
 24679	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Of the English dogs
 24680	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     That hanged our Irish leaders.
 24681	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24682	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTHE CROPPY BOY: (The ropenoose round his neck, gripes in his issuing
 24683	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbowels with both hands.)
 24684	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24685	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      I bear no hate to a living thing,
 24686	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      But I love my country beyond the king.
 24687	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24688	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRUMBOLD, DEMON BARBER: (Accompanied by two blackmasked assistants,
 24689	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tadvances with gladstone bag which he opens.) Ladies and gents,
 24690	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcleaver purchased by Mrs Pearcy to slay Mogg. Knife with which Voisin
 24691	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdismembered the wife of a compatriot and hid remains in a sheet in the
 24692	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcellar, the unfortunate female’s throat being cut from ear to ear. Phial
 24693	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcontaining arsenic retrieved from body of Miss Barron which sent Seddon
 24694	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto the gallows.
 24695	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24696	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(He jerks the rope. The assistants leap at the victim’s legs and drag
 24697	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim downward, grunting: the croppy boy’s tongue protrudes violently.)
 24698	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24699	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTHE CROPPY BOY:
 24700	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24701	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      Horhot ho hray hor hother’s hest.
 24702	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24703	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(He gives up the ghost. A violent erection of the hanged sends gouts
 24704	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof sperm spouting through his deathclothes on to the cobblestones. Mrs
 24705	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBellingham, Mrs Yelverton Barry and the Honourable Mrs Mervyn Talboys
 24706	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trush forward with their handkerchiefs to sop it up.)
 24707	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24708	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRUMBOLD: I’m near it myself. (He undoes the noose.) Rope which hanged
 24709	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe awful rebel. Ten shillings a time. As applied to Her Royal Highness.
 24710	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(He plunges his head into the gaping belly of the hanged and draws out
 24711	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this head again clotted with coiled and smoking entrails.) My painful
 24712	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tduty has now been done. God save the king!
 24713	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24714	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEDWARD THE SEVENTH: (Dances slowly, solemnly, rattling his bucket, and
 24715	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsings with soft contentment.)
 24716	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24717	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      On coronation day, on coronation day,
 24718	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      O, won’t we have a merry time,
 24719	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      Drinking whisky, beer and wine!
 24720	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24721	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPRIVATE CARR: Here. What are you saying about my king?
 24722	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24723	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSTEPHEN: (Throws up his hands.) O, this is too monotonous! Nothing. He
 24724	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twants my money and my life, though want must be his master, for some
 24725	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbrutish empire of his. Money I haven’t. (He searches his pockets
 24726	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvaguely.) Gave it to someone.
 24727	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24728	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPRIVATE CARR: Who wants your bleeding money?
 24729	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24730	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSTEPHEN: (Tries to move off.) Will someone tell me where I am least
 24731	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlikely to meet these necessary evils? Ça se voit aussi à Paris. Not that
 24732	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI... But, by Saint Patrick...!
 24733	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24734	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(The women’s heads coalesce. Old Gummy Granny in sugarloaf hat appears

 24738	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSTEPHEN: Aha! I know you, gammer! Hamlet, revenge! The old sow that eats
 24739	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther farrow!
 24740	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 24742	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof Spain’s daughter, alanna. Strangers in my house, bad manners to them!
 24743	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(She keens with banshee woe.) Ochone! Ochone! Silk of the kine! (She
 24744	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twails.) You met with poor old Ireland and how does she stand?

 24746	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSTEPHEN: How do I stand you? The hat trick! Where’s the third person of
 24747	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe Blessed Trinity? Soggarth Aroon? The reverend Carrion Crow.
 24748	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 24750	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 24757	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmisunderstanding.

 24763	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24764	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPRIVATE COMPTON: Go it, Harry. Do him one in the eye. He’s a proboer.

 24770	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tour monarch.

 24775	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(Casqued halberdiers in armour thrust forward a pentice of gutted
 24776	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspearpoints. Major Tweedy, moustached like Turko the terrible, in
 24777	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbearskin cap with hackleplume and accoutrements, with epaulettes, gilt

 24795	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBIDDY THE CLAP: Methinks yon sable knight will joust it with the best.

 24802	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      The harlot’s cry from street to street
 24803	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      Shall weave Old Ireland’s windingsheet.

 24809	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdumb? You are the link between nations and generations. Speak, woman,
 24810	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsacred lifegiver!
 24811	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 24813	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyou? Amn’t I your girl? Cissy’s your girl. (She cries.) Police!
 24814	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24815	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSTEPHEN: (Ecstatically, to Cissy Caffrey.)
 24816	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24817	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     White thy fambles, red thy gan
 24818	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     And thy quarrons dainty is.
 24819	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24820	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tVOICES: Police!
 24821	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24822	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDISTANT VOICES: Dublin’s burning! Dublin’s burning! On fire, on fire!
 24823	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24824	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(Brimstone fires spring up. Dense clouds roll past. Heavy Gatling guns
 24825	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tboom. Pandemonium. Troops deploy. Gallop of hoofs. Artillery. Hoarse
 24826	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcommands. Bells clang. Backers shout. Drunkards bawl. Whores screech.
 24827	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFoghorns hoot. Cries of valour. Shrieks of dying. Pikes clash on
 24828	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcuirasses. Thieves rob the slain. Birds of prey, winging from the sea,
 24829	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trising from marshlands, swooping from eyries, hover screaming, gannets,
 24830	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcormorants, vultures, goshawks, climbing woodcocks, peregrines, merlins,
 24831	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblackgrouse, sea eagles, gulls, albatrosses, barnacle geese. The
 24832	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmidnight sun is darkened. The earth trembles. The dead of Dublin
 24833	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom Prospect and Mount Jerome in white sheepskin overcoats and black
 24834	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgoatfell cloaks arise and appear to many. A chasm opens with a noiseless
 24835	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyawn. Tom Rochford, winner, in athlete’s singlet and breeches, arrives
 24836	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat the head of the national hurdle handicap and leaps into the void.
 24837	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe is followed by a race of runners and leapers. In wild attitudes they
 24838	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tspring from the brink. Their bodies plunge. Factory lasses with fancy
 24839	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tclothes toss redhot Yorkshire baraabombs. Society ladies lift their
 24840	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tskirts above their heads to protect themselves. Laughing witches in red
 24841	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcutty sarks ride through the air on broomsticks. Quakerlyster plasters
 24842	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblisters. It rains dragons’ teeth. Armed heroes spring up from furrows.
 24843	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThey exchange in amity the pass of knights of the red cross and fight
 24844	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tduels with cavalry sabres: Wolfe Tone against Henry Grattan, Smith
 24845	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tO’Brien against Daniel O’Connell, Michael Davitt against Isaac Butt,
 24846	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJustin M’Carthy against Parnell, Arthur Griffith against John Redmond,
 24847	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJohn O’Leary against Lear O’Johnny, Lord Edward Fitzgerald against Lord
 24848	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGerald Fitzedward, The O’Donoghue of the Glens against The Glens of
 24849	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe O’Donoghue. On an eminence, the centre of the earth, rises the
 24850	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfieldaltar of Saint Barbara. Black candles rise from its gospel and
 24851	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tepistle horns. From the high barbacans of the tower two shafts of light
 24852	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfall on the smokepalled altarstone. On the altarstone Mrs Mina Purefoy,
 24853	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgoddess of unreason, lies, naked, fettered, a chalice resting on her
 24854	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tswollen belly. Father Malachi O’Flynn in a lace petticoat and reversed
 24855	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchasuble, his two left feet back to the front, celebrates camp mass. The
 24856	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tReverend Mr Hugh C Haines Love M. A. in a plain cassock and mortarboard,
 24857	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this head and collar back to the front, holds over the celebrant’s head
 24858	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tan open umbrella.)
 24859	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24860	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFATHER MALACHI O’FLYNN: Introibo ad altare diaboli.

 24862	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTHE REVEREND MR HAINES LOVE: To the devil which hath made glad my young
 24863	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdays.

 24899	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBLOOM: (Runs to Lynch.) Can’t you get him away?

 24901	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tLYNCH: He likes dialectic, the universal language. Kitty! (To Bloom.)

 24904	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(He drags Kitty away.)

 24910	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24911	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSTEPHEN: Stick, no. Reason. This feast of pure reason.
 24912	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24913	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCISSY CAFFREY: (Pulling Private Carr.) Come on, you’re boosed. He
 24914	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinsulted me but I forgive him. (Shouting in his ear.) I forgive him for
 24915	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinsulting me.
 24916	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24917	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBLOOM: (Over Stephen’s shoulder.) Yes, go. You see he’s incapable.
 24918	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24919	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPRIVATE CARR: (Breaks loose.) I’ll insult him.
 24920	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24921	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(He rushes towards Stephen, fist outstretched, and strikes him in the
 24922	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tface. Stephen totters, collapses, falls, stunned. He lies prone, his
 24923	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tface to the sky, his hat rolling to the wall. Bloom follows and picks it
 24924	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tup.)
 24925	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24926	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMAJOR TWEEDY: (Loudly.) Carbine in bucket! Cease fire! Salute!
 24927	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24928	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTHE RETRIEVER: (Barking furiously.) Ute ute ute ute ute ute ute ute.
 24929	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24930	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTHE CROWD: Let him up! Don’t strike him when he’s down! Air! Who? The
 24931	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsoldier hit him. He’s a professor. Is he hurted? Don’t manhandle him!
 24932	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe’s fainted!
 24933	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24934	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA HAG: What call had the redcoat to strike the gentleman and he under
 24935	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe influence. Let them go and fight the Boers!
 24936	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24937	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTHE BAWD: Listen to who’s talking! Hasn’t the soldier a right to go with
 24938	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this girl? He gave him the coward’s blow.
 24939	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24940	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(They grab at each other’s hair, claw at each other and spit.)
 24941	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24942	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTHE RETRIEVER: (Barking.) Wow wow wow.
 24943	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24944	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBLOOM: (Shoves them back, loudly.) Get back, stand back!
 24945	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24946	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPRIVATE COMPTON: (Tugging his comrade.) Here. Bugger off, Harry. Here’s
 24947	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe cops! (Two raincaped watch, tall, stand in the group.)
 24948	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24949	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFIRST WATCH: What’s wrong here?
 24950	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24951	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPRIVATE COMPTON: We were with this lady. And he insulted us. And
 24952	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tassaulted my chum. (The retriever barks.) Who owns the bleeding tyke?
 24953	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24954	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCISSY CAFFREY: (With expectation.) Is he bleeding!
 24955	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24956	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA MAN: (Rising from his knees.) No. Gone off. He’ll come to all right.
 24957	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24958	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBLOOM: (Glances sharply at the man.) Leave him to me. I can easily...
 24959	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24960	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSECOND WATCH: Who are you? Do you know him?
 24961	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24962	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPRIVATE CARR: (Lurches towards the watch.) He insulted my lady friend.
 24963	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24964	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBLOOM: (Angrily.) You hit him without provocation. I’m a witness.
 24965	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tConstable, take his regimental number.
 24966	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24967	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSECOND WATCH: I don’t want your instructions in the discharge of my
 24968	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tduty.
 24969	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24970	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPRIVATE COMPTON: (Pulling his comrade.) Here, bugger off Harry. Or
 24971	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBennett’ll shove you in the lockup.
 24972	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24973	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPRIVATE CARR: (Staggering as he is pulled away.) God fuck old Bennett.
 24974	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe’s a whitearsed bugger. I don’t give a shit for him.
 24975	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24976	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFIRST WATCH: (Takes out his notebook.) What’s his name?
 24977	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24978	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBLOOM: (Peering over the crowd.) I just see a car there. If you give me
 24979	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta hand a second, sergeant...
 24980	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24981	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFIRST WATCH: Name and address.
 24982	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24983	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(Corny Kelleher, weepers round his hat, a death wreath in his hand,
 24984	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tappears among the bystanders.)
 24985	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 24987	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbit sprung. Get those policemen to move those loafers back.
 24988	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24989	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSECOND WATCH: Night, Mr Kelleher.
 24990	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24991	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCORNY KELLEHER: (To the watch, with drawling eye.) That’s all right.
 24992	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI know him. Won a bit on the races. Gold cup. Throwaway. (He laughs.)
 24993	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTwenty to one. Do you follow me?
 24994	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 24995	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFIRST WATCH: (Turns to the crowd.) Here, what are you all gaping at?
 24996	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMove on out of that.
 24997	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 24999	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 25000	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCORNY KELLEHER: Leave it to me, sergeant. That’ll be all right. (He
 25001	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlaughs, shaking his head.) We were often as bad ourselves, ay or worse.
 25002	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat? Eh, what?
 25003	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 25004	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFIRST WATCH: (Laughs.) I suppose so.

 25007	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe slate. (He lilts, wagging his head.) With my tooraloom tooraloom
 25008	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttooraloom tooraloom. What, eh, do you follow me?

 25015	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 25020	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tany scandal, you understand. Father is a wellknown highly respected

 25039	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBLOOM: (Blows.) Providential you came on the scene. You have a car?...

 25042	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe car brought up against the scaffolding.) Two commercials that were
 25043	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstanding fizz in Jammet’s. Like princes, faith. One of them lost two
 25044	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tquid on the race. Drowning his grief. And were on for a go with the
 25045	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjolly girls. So I landed them up on Behan’s car and down to nighttown.

 25048	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 25049	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCORNY KELLEHER: (Laughs.) Sure they wanted me to join in with the mots.
 25050	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNo, by God, says I. Not for old stagers like myself and yourself. (He
 25051	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlaughs again and leers with lacklustre eye.) Thanks be to God we have it
 25052	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the house, what, eh, do you follow me? Hah, hah, hah!

 25056	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfellow, he’s laid up for the past week) and we had a liquor together and

 25094	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(The jarvey chucks the reins and raises his whip encouragingly. The
 25095	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcar and horse back slowly, awkwardly, and turn. Corny Kelleher on the
 25096	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsideseat sways his head to and fro in sign of mirth at Bloom’s plight.
 25097	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe jarvey joins in the mute pantomimic merriment nodding from the
 25098	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfarther seat. Bloom shakes his head in mute mirthful reply. With thumb
 25099	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand palm Corny Kelleher reassures that the two bobbies will allow the
 25100	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsleep to continue for what else is to be done. With a slow nod Bloom
 25101	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconveys his gratitude as that is exactly what Stephen needs. The car
 25102	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjingles tooraloom round the corner of the tooraloom lane. Corny Kelleher
 25103	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tagain reassuralooms with his hand. Bloom with his hand assuralooms Corny
 25104	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKelleher that he is reassuraloomtay. The tinkling hoofs and jingling
 25105	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tharness grow fainter with their tooralooloo looloo lay. Bloom, holding
 25106	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin his hand Stephen’s hat, festooned with shavings, and ashplant, stands
 25107	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tirresolute. Then he bends to him and shakes him by the shoulder.)
 25108	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 25109	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBLOOM: Eh! Ho! (There is no answer; he bends again.) Mr Dedalus! (There
 25110	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tis no answer.) The name if you call. Somnambulist. (He bends again
 25111	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand, hesitating, brings his mouth near the face of the prostrate form.)
 25112	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen! (There is no answer. He calls again.) Stephen!
 25113	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 25114	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSTEPHEN: (Groans.) Who? Black panther. Vampire. (He sighs and stretches
 25115	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thimself, then murmurs thickly with prolonged vowels.)
 25116	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 25117	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Who... drive... Fergus now
 25118	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     And pierce... wood’s woven shade?...
 25119	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 25121	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 25123	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe buttons of Stephen’s waistcoat.) To breathe. (He brushes the
 25124	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twoodshavings from Stephen’s clothes with light hand and fingers.) One
 25125	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpound seven. Not hurt anyhow. (He listens.) What?
 25126	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 25127	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSTEPHEN: (Murmurs.)
 25128	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 25129	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t    ... shadows... the woods
 25130	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t    ... white breast... dim sea.
 25131	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 25132	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(He stretches out his arms, sighs again and curls his body. Bloom,
 25133	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tholding the hat and ashplant, stands erect. A dog barks in the distance.
 25134	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBloom tightens and loosens his grip on the ashplant. He looks down on
 25135	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen’s face and form.)
 25136	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 25137	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBLOOM: (Communes with the night.) Face reminds me of his poor mother.
 25138	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn the shady wood. The deep white breast. Ferguson, I think I caught.
 25139	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA girl. Some girl. Best thing could happen him. (He murmurs.)... swear
 25140	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat I will always hail, ever conceal, never reveal, any part or parts,
 25141	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tart or arts... (He murmurs.)... in the rough sands of the sea... a
 25142	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcabletow’s length from the shore... where the tide ebbs... and flows ...
 25143	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 25144	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(Silent, thoughtful, alert he stands on guard, his fingers at his lips
 25145	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the attitude of secret master. Against the dark wall a figure appears
 25146	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tslowly, a fairy boy of eleven, a changeling, kidnapped, dressed in an
 25147	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEton suit with glass shoes and a little bronze helmet, holding a book
 25148	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin his hand. He reads from right to left inaudibly, smiling, kissing the
 25149	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpage.)
 25150	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 25151	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBLOOM: (Wonderstruck, calls inaudibly.) Rudy!
 25152	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 25153	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRUDY: (Gazes, unseeing, into Bloom’s eyes and goes on reading, kissing,
 25154	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsmiling. He has a delicate mauve face. On his suit he has diamond and
 25155	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\truby buttons. In his free left hand he holds a slim ivory cane with a
 25156	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tviolet bowknot. A white lambkin peeps out of his waistcoat pocket.)
 25157	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
