 28831	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tguest, emerged silently, doubly dark, from obscurity by a passage from
 28832	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe rere of the house into the penumbra of the garden?
 28833	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28834	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe heaventree of stars hung with humid nightblue fruit.
 28835	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28836	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWith what meditations did Bloom accompany his demonstration to his
 28837	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcompanion of various constellations?
 28838	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28839	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMeditations of evolution increasingly vaster: of the moon invisible in
 28840	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tincipient lunation, approaching perigee: of the infinite lattiginous
 28841	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tscintillating uncondensed milky way, discernible by daylight by an
 28842	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tobserver placed at the lower end of a cylindrical vertical shaft 5000
 28843	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tft deep sunk from the surface towards the centre of the earth: of Sirius
 28844	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(alpha in Canis Maior) 10 lightyears (57,000,000,000,000 miles) distant
 28845	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand in volume 900 times the dimension of our planet: of Arcturus: of the
 28846	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprecession of equinoxes: of Orion with belt and sextuple sun theta and
 28847	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnebula in which 100 of our solar systems could be contained: of moribund
 28848	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand of nascent new stars such as Nova in 1901: of our system plunging
 28849	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttowards the constellation of Hercules: of the parallax or parallactic
 28850	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrift of socalled fixed stars, in reality evermoving wanderers from
 28851	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\timmeasurably remote eons to infinitely remote futures in comparison with
 28852	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhich the years, threescore and ten, of allotted human life formed a
 28853	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tparenthesis of infinitesimal brevity.
 28854	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28855	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWere there obverse meditations of involution increasingly less vast?
 28856	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28857	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOf the eons of geological periods recorded in the stratifications of the
 28858	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tearth: of the myriad minute entomological organic existences concealed
 28859	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin cavities of the earth, beneath removable stones, in hives and mounds,
 28860	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof microbes, germs, bacteria, bacilli, spermatozoa: of the incalculable
 28861	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttrillions of billions of millions of imperceptible molecules contained
 28862	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby cohesion of molecular affinity in a single pinhead: of the universe
 28863	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof human serum constellated with red and white bodies, themselves
 28864	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tuniverses of void space constellated with other bodies, each, in
 28865	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcontinuity, its universe of divisible component bodies of which each was
 28866	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tagain divisible in divisions of redivisible component bodies, dividends
 28867	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand divisors ever diminishing without actual division till, if the
 28868	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprogress were carried far enough, nought nowhere was never reached.
 28869	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28870	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhy did he not elaborate these calculations to a more precise result?
 28871	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28872	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBecause some years previously in 1886 when occupied with the problem of
 28873	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe quadrature of the circle he had learned of the existence of a number
 28874	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcomputed to a relative degree of accuracy to be of such magnitude and
 28875	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof so many places, e.g., the 9th power of the 9th power of 9, that, the
 28876	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tresult having been obtained, 33 closely printed volumes of 1000 pages
 28877	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\teach of innumerable quires and reams of India paper would have to be
 28878	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trequisitioned in order to contain the complete tale of its printed
 28879	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tintegers of units, tens, hundreds, thousands, tens of thousands,
 28880	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thundreds of thousands, millions, tens of millions, hundreds of millions,
 28881	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbillions, the nucleus of the nebula of every digit of every series
 28882	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcontaining succinctly the potentiality of being raised to the utmost
 28883	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tkinetic elaboration of any power of any of its powers.
 28884	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28885	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDid he find the problems of the inhabitability of the planets and their
 28886	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsatellites by a race, given in species, and of the possible social and
 28887	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmoral redemption of said race by a redeemer, easier of solution?
 28888	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28889	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOf a different order of difficulty. Conscious that the human organism,
 28890	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnormally capable of sustaining an atmospheric pressure of 19 tons,
 28891	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhen elevated to a considerable altitude in the terrestrial atmosphere
 28892	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsuffered with arithmetical progression of intensity, according as
 28893	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe line of demarcation between troposphere and stratosphere was
 28894	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tapproximated from nasal hemorrhage, impeded respiration and vertigo,
 28895	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhen proposing this problem for solution, he had conjectured as a
 28896	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tworking hypothesis which could not be proved impossible that a more
 28897	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tadaptable and differently anatomically constructed race of beings might
 28898	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsubsist otherwise under Martian, Mercurial, Veneral, Jovian, Saturnian,
 28899	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNeptunian or Uranian sufficient and equivalent conditions, though
 28900	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tan apogean humanity of beings created in varying forms with finite
 28901	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdifferences resulting similar to the whole and to one another would
 28902	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprobably there as here remain inalterably and inalienably attached to
 28903	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvanities, to vanities of vanities and to all that is vanity.
 28904	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28905	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAnd the problem of possible redemption? The minor was proved by the
 28906	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmajor.
 28907	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28908	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhich various features of the constellations were in turn considered?
 28909	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28910	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe various colours significant of various degrees of vitality (white,
 28911	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyellow, crimson, vermilion, cinnabar): their degrees of brilliancy:
 28912	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir magnitudes revealed up to and including the 7th: their positions:
 28913	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe waggoner’s star: Walsingham way: the chariot of David: the annular
 28914	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcinctures of Saturn: the condensation of spiral nebulae into suns: the
 28915	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinterdependent gyrations of double suns: the independent synchronous
 28916	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdiscoveries of Galileo, Simon Marius, Piazzi, Le Verrier, Herschel,
 28917	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tGalle: the systematisations attempted by Bode and Kepler of cubes
 28918	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof distances and squares of times of revolution: the almost infinite
 28919	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcompressibility of hirsute comets and their vast elliptical egressive
 28920	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand reentrant orbits from perihelion to aphelion: the sidereal origin of
 28921	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmeteoric stones: the Libyan floods on Mars about the period of the birth
 28922	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the younger astroscopist: the annual recurrence of meteoric showers
 28923	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabout the period of the feast of S. Lawrence (martyr, 10 August): the
 28924	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmonthly recurrence known as the new moon with the old moon in her arms:
 28925	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe posited influence of celestial on human bodies: the appearance of a
 28926	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstar (1st magnitude) of exceeding brilliancy dominating by night and
 28927	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tday (a new luminous sun generated by the collision and amalgamation in
 28928	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tincandescence of two nonluminous exsuns) about the period of the
 28929	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbirth of William Shakespeare over delta in the recumbent neversetting
 28930	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconstellation of Cassiopeia and of a star (2nd magnitude) of similar
 28931	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\torigin but of lesser brilliancy which had appeared in and disappeared
 28932	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom the constellation of the Corona Septentrionalis about the period
 28933	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the birth of Leopold Bloom and of other stars of (presumably) similar
 28934	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\torigin which had (effectively or presumably) appeared in and disappeared
 28935	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom the constellation of Andromeda about the period of the birth of
 28936	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStephen Dedalus, and in and from the constellation of Auriga some years
 28937	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tafter the birth and death of Rudolph Bloom, junior, and in and from
 28938	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tother constellations some years before or after the birth or death of
 28939	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tother persons: the attendant phenomena of eclipses, solar and lunar,
 28940	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom immersion to emersion, abatement of wind, transit of shadow,
 28941	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttaciturnity of winged creatures, emergence of nocturnal or crepuscular
 28942	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanimals, persistence of infernal light, obscurity of terrestrial waters,
 28943	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpallor of human beings.
 28944	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28945	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis (Bloom’s) logical conclusion, having weighed the matter and allowing
 28946	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor possible error?
 28947	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28948	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThat it was not a heaventree, not a heavengrot, not a heavenbeast, not
 28949	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta heavenman. That it was a Utopia, there being no known method from
 28950	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe known to the unknown: an infinity renderable equally finite by the
 28951	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsuppositious apposition of one or more bodies equally of the same and of
 28952	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdifferent magnitudes: a mobility of illusory forms immobilised in space,
 28953	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tremobilised in air: a past which possibly had ceased to exist as a
 28954	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpresent before its probable spectators had entered actual present
 28955	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\texistence.
 28956	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28957	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWas he more convinced of the esthetic value of the spectacle?
 28958	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28959	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIndubitably in consequence of the reiterated examples of poets in the
 28960	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdelirium of the frenzy of attachment or in the abasement of rejection
 28961	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinvoking ardent sympathetic constellations or the frigidity of the
 28962	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsatellite of their planet.
 28963	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28964	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDid he then accept as an article of belief the theory of astrological
 28965	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinfluences upon sublunary disasters?
 28966	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28967	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIt seemed to him as possible of proof as of confutation and the
 28968	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnomenclature employed in its selenographical charts as attributable to
 28969	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tverifiable intuition as to fallacious analogy: the lake of dreams, the
 28970	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsea of rains, the gulf of dews, the ocean of fecundity.
 28971	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28972	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat special affinities appeared to him to exist between the moon and
 28973	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twoman?
 28974	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28975	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHer antiquity in preceding and surviving successive tellurian
 28976	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgenerations: her nocturnal predominance: her satellitic dependence:
 28977	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther luminary reflection: her constancy under all her phases, rising
 28978	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand setting by her appointed times, waxing and waning: the forced
 28979	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinvariability of her aspect: her indeterminate response to inaffirmative
 28980	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinterrogation: her potency over effluent and refluent waters: her power
 28981	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto enamour, to mortify, to invest with beauty, to render insane, to
 28982	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tincite to and aid delinquency: the tranquil inscrutability of her
 28983	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvisage: the terribility of her isolated dominant implacable resplendent
 28984	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpropinquity: her omens of tempest and of calm: the stimulation of her
 28985	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlight, her motion and her presence: the admonition of her craters, her
 28986	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tarid seas, her silence: her splendour, when visible: her attraction,
 28987	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhen invisible.
 28988	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28989	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat visible luminous sign attracted Bloom’s, who attracted Stephen’s,
 28990	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgaze?
 28991	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28992	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn the second storey (rere) of his (Bloom’s) house the light of a
 28993	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tparaffin oil lamp with oblique shade projected on a screen of roller
 28994	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblind supplied by Frank O’Hara, window blind, curtain pole and revolving
 28995	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshutter manufacturer, 16 Aungier street.
 28996	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 28997	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHow did he elucidate the mystery of an invisible attractive person, his
 28998	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twife Marion (Molly) Bloom, denoted by a visible splendid sign, a lamp?
 28999	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29000	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWith indirect and direct verbal allusions or affirmations: with subdued
 29001	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taffection and admiration: with description: with impediment: with
 29002	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsuggestion.
 29003	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29004	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBoth then were silent?
 29005	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29006	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSilent, each contemplating the other in both mirrors of the reciprocal
 29007	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tflesh of theirhisnothis fellowfaces.
 29008	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29009	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWere they indefinitely inactive?
 29010	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29011	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAt Stephen’s suggestion, at Bloom’s instigation both, first Stephen,
 29012	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthen Bloom, in penumbra urinated, their sides contiguous, their organs
 29013	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof micturition reciprocally rendered invisible by manual circumposition,
 29014	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir gazes, first Bloom’s, then Stephen’s, elevated to the projected
 29015	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tluminous and semiluminous shadow.
 29016	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29017	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSimilarly?
 29018	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29019	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe trajectories of their, first sequent, then simultaneous, urinations
 29020	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twere dissimilar: Bloom’s longer, less irruent, in the incomplete form of
 29021	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe bifurcated penultimate alphabetical letter, who in his ultimate
 29022	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tyear at High School (1880) had been capable of attaining the point
 29023	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof greatest altitude against the whole concurrent strength of the
 29024	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinstitution, 210 scholars: Stephen’s higher, more sibilant, who in the
 29025	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tultimate hours of the previous day had augmented by diuretic consumption
 29026	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tan insistent vesical pressure.
 29027	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29028	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat different problems presented themselves to each concerning the
 29029	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinvisible audible collateral organ of the other?
 29030	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29031	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTo Bloom: the problems of irritability, tumescence, rigidity,
 29032	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treactivity, dimension, sanitariness, pilosity.
 29033	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29034	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTo Stephen: the problem of the sacerdotal integrity of Jesus circumcised
 29035	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(1 January, holiday of obligation to hear mass and abstain from
 29036	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunnecessary servile work) and the problem as to whether the divine
 29037	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprepuce, the carnal bridal ring of the holy Roman catholic apostolic
 29038	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchurch, conserved in Calcata, were deserving of simple hyperduly or of
 29039	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe fourth degree of latria accorded to the abscission of such divine
 29040	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\texcrescences as hair and toenails.
 29041	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29042	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat celestial sign was by both simultaneously observed?
 29043	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29044	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA star precipitated with great apparent velocity across the firmament
 29045	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom Vega in the Lyre above the zenith beyond the stargroup of the Tress
 29046	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof Berenice towards the zodiacal sign of Leo.
 29047	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29048	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHow did the centripetal remainer afford egress to the centrifugal
 29049	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdeparter?
 29050	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29051	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBy inserting the barrel of an arruginated male key in the hole of an
 29052	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunstable female lock, obtaining a purchase on the bow of the key and
 29053	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tturning its wards from right to left, withdrawing a bolt from its
 29054	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstaple, pulling inward spasmodically an obsolescent unhinged door and
 29055	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trevealing an aperture for free egress and free ingress.
 29056	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29057	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHow did they take leave, one of the other, in separation?
 29058	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29059	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tStanding perpendicular at the same door and on different sides of its
 29060	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbase, the lines of their valedictory arms, meeting at any point and
 29061	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tforming any angle less than the sum of two right angles.
 29062	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29063	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat sound accompanied the union of their tangent, the disunion of their
 29064	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(respectively) centrifugal and centripetal hands?
 29065	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29066	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe sound of the peal of the hour of the night by the chime of the bells
 29067	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin the church of Saint George.
 29068	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29069	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat echoes of that sound were by both and each heard?
 29070	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29071	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBy Stephen:
 29072	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29073	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      Liliata rutilantium. Turma circumdet.
 29074	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t      Iubilantium te virginum. Chorus excipiat.
 29075	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 29077	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29078	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Heigho, heigho,
 29079	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t     Heigho, heigho.
 29080	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29081	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhere were the several members of the company which with Bloom that day
 29082	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat the bidding of that peal had travelled from Sandymount in the south
 29083	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto Glasnevin in the north?

 29085	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMartin Cunningham (in bed), Jack Power (in bed), Simon Dedalus (in bed),
 29086	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNed Lambert (in bed), Tom Kernan (in bed), Joe Hynes (in bed), John
 29087	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHenry Menton (in bed), Bernard Corrigan (in bed), Patsy Dignam (in bed),
 29088	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tPaddy Dignam (in the grave).

 29090	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAlone, what did Bloom hear?

 29092	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe double reverberation of retreating feet on the heavenborn earth, the
 29093	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdouble vibration of a jew’s harp in the resonant lane.
 29094	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29095	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAlone, what did Bloom feel?
 29096	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29097	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe cold of interstellar space, thousands of degrees below freezing
 29098	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoint or the absolute zero of Fahrenheit, Centigrade or Réaumur: the
 29099	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tincipient intimations of proximate dawn.
 29100	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29101	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOf what did bellchime and handtouch and footstep and lonechill remind
 29102	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim?
 29103	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29104	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOf companions now in various manners in different places defunct: Percy
 29105	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tApjohn (killed in action, Modder River), Philip Gilligan (phthisis,
 29106	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJervis Street hospital), Matthew F. Kane (accidental drowning, Dublin
 29107	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBay), Philip Moisel (pyemia, Heytesbury street), Michael Hart (phthisis,
 29108	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMater Misericordiae hospital), Patrick Dignam (apoplexy, Sandymount).
 29109	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29110	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat prospect of what phenomena inclined him to remain?
 29111	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29112	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe disparition of three final stars, the diffusion of daybreak, the
 29113	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tapparition of a new solar disk.
 29114	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29115	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHad he ever been a spectator of those phenomena?
 29116	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29117	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOnce, in 1887, after a protracted performance of charades in the house
 29118	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof Luke Doyle, Kimmage, he had awaited with patience the apparition
 29119	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the diurnal phenomenon, seated on a wall, his gaze turned in the
 29120	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdirection of Mizrach, the east.
 29121	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29122	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe remembered the initial paraphenomena?
 29123	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29124	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMore active air, a matutinal distant cock, ecclesiastical clocks at
 29125	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvarious points, avine music, the isolated tread of an early wayfarer,
 29126	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe visible diffusion of the light of an invisible luminous body, the
 29127	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfirst golden limb of the resurgent sun perceptible low on the horizon.
 29128	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29129	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDid he remain?
 29130	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29131	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWith deep inspiration he returned, retraversing the garden, reentering
 29132	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe passage, reclosing the door. With brief suspiration he reassumed the
 29133	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcandle, reascended the stairs, reapproached the door of the front room,
 29134	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thallfloor, and reentered.
 29135	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29136	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat suddenly arrested his ingress?
 29137	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29138	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe right temporal lobe of the hollow sphere of his cranium came into
 29139	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcontact with a solid timber angle where, an infinitesimal but sensible
 29140	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfraction of a second later, a painful sensation was located in
 29141	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconsequence of antecedent sensations transmitted and registered.
 29142	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29143	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDescribe the alterations effected in the disposition of the articles of
 29144	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfurniture.
 29145	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29146	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA sofa upholstered in prune plush had been translocated from opposite
 29147	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe door to the ingleside near the compactly furled Union Jack (an
 29148	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\talteration which he had frequently intended to execute): the blue and
 29149	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhite checker inlaid majolicatopped table had been placed opposite the
 29150	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoor in the place vacated by the prune plush sofa: the walnut sideboard
 29151	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(a projecting angle of which had momentarily arrested his ingress) had
 29152	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeen moved from its position beside the door to a more advantageous but
 29153	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmore perilous position in front of the door: two chairs had been moved
 29154	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfrom right and left of the ingleside to the position originally occupied
 29155	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby the blue and white checker inlaid majolicatopped table.
 29156	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29157	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDescribe them.
 29158	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29159	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOne: a squat stuffed easychair, with stout arms extended and back
 29160	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tslanted to the rere, which, repelled in recoil, had then upturned an
 29161	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tirregular fringe of a rectangular rug and now displayed on its amply
 29162	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tupholstered seat a centralised diffusing and diminishing discolouration.
 29163	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe other: a slender splayfoot chair of glossy cane curves, placed
 29164	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdirectly opposite the former, its frame from top to seat and from seat
 29165	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto base being varnished dark brown, its seat being a bright circle of
 29166	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhite plaited rush.
 29167	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29168	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat significances attached to these two chairs?
 29169	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29170	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSignificances of similitude, of posture, of symbolism, of circumstantial
 29171	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tevidence, of testimonial supermanence.
 29172	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29173	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat occupied the position originally occupied by the sideboard?
 29174	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29175	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA vertical piano (Cadby) with exposed keyboard, its closed coffin
 29176	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsupporting a pair of long yellow ladies’ gloves and an emerald ashtray
 29177	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcontaining four consumed matches, a partly consumed cigarette and two
 29178	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdiscoloured ends of cigarettes, its musicrest supporting the music in
 29179	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe key of G natural for voice and piano of Love’s Old Sweet Song
 29180	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(words by G. Clifton Bingham, composed by J. L. Molloy, sung by Madam
 29181	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAntoinette Sterling) open at the last page with the final indications ad
 29182	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlibitum, forte, pedal, animato, sustained pedal, ritirando, close.
 29183	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29184	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWith what sensations did Bloom contemplate in rotation these objects?
 29185	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29186	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWith strain, elevating a candlestick: with pain, feeling on his right
 29187	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttemple a contused tumescence: with attention, focussing his gaze on
 29188	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta large dull passive and a slender bright active: with solicitation,
 29189	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbending and downturning the upturned rugfringe: with amusement,
 29190	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tremembering Dr Malachi Mulligan’s scheme of colour containing the
 29191	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgradation of green: with pleasure, repeating the words and antecedent
 29192	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tact and perceiving through various channels of internal sensibility
 29193	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe consequent and concomitant tepid pleasant diffusion of gradual
 29194	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdiscolouration.
 29195	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29196	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHis next proceeding?
 29197	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29198	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFrom an open box on the majolicatopped table he extracted a black
 29199	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdiminutive cone, one inch in height, placed it on its circular base on
 29200	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta small tin plate, placed his candlestick on the right corner of the
 29201	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmantelpiece, produced from his waistcoat a folded page of prospectus
 29202	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(illustrated) entitled Agendath Netaim, unfolded the same, examined
 29203	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tit superficially, rolled it into a thin cylinder, ignited it in the
 29204	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcandleflame, applied it when ignited to the apex of the cone till the
 29205	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlatter reached the stage of rutilance, placed the cylinder in the basin
 29206	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the candlestick disposing its unconsumed part in such a manner as to
 29207	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfacilitate total combustion.
 29208	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 29210	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29211	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe truncated conical crater summit of the diminutive volcano emitted a

 29328	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat reflections occupied his mind during the process of reversion of
 29329	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe inverted volumes?
 29330	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29331	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe necessity of order, a place for everything and everything in its
 29332	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplace: the deficient appreciation of literature possessed by females:
 29333	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe incongruity of an apple incuneated in a tumbler and of an umbrella
 29334	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinclined in a closestool: the insecurity of hiding any secret document
 29335	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbehind, beneath or between the pages of a book.
 29336	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29337	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhich volume was the largest in bulk?
 29338	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29339	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHozier’s History of the Russo-Turkish War.
 29340	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29341	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat among other data did the second volume of the work in question
 29342	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcontain?
 29343	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29344	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe name of a decisive battle (forgotten), frequently remembered by a
 29345	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdecisive officer, major Brian Cooper Tweedy (remembered).
 29346	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29347	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhy, firstly and secondly, did he not consult the work in question?
 29348	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29349	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFirstly, in order to exercise mnemotechnic: secondly, because after an
 29350	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinterval of amnesia, when, seated at the central table, about to consult
 29351	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe work in question, he remembered by mnemotechnic the name of the
 29352	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmilitary engagement, Plevna.
 29353	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29354	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat caused him consolation in his sitting posture?
 29355	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29356	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe candour, nudity, pose, tranquility, youth, grace, sex, counsel of a
 29357	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstatue erect in the centre of the table, an image of Narcissus purchased
 29358	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tby auction from P. A. Wren, 9 Bachelor’s Walk.
 29359	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29360	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat caused him irritation in his sitting posture?
 29361	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29362	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tInhibitory pressure of collar (size 17) and waistcoat (5 buttons), two
 29363	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tarticles of clothing superfluous in the costume of mature males and
 29364	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinelastic to alterations of mass by expansion.
 29365	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29366	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHow was the irritation allayed?
 29367	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29368	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe removed his collar, with contained black necktie and collapsible
 29369	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tstud, from his neck to a position on the left of the table. He
 29370	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunbuttoned successively in reversed direction waistcoat, trousers, shirt
 29371	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand vest along the medial line of irregular incrispated black hairs
 29372	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\textending in triangular convergence from the pelvic basin over the
 29373	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcircumference of the abdomen and umbilicular fossicle along the medial
 29374	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tline of nodes to the intersection of the sixth pectoral vertebrae,
 29375	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthence produced both ways at right angles and terminating in circles
 29376	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdescribed about two equidistant points, right and left, on the summits
 29377	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the mammary prominences. He unbraced successively each of six minus
 29378	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tone braced trouser buttons, arranged in pairs, of which one incomplete.
 29379	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29380	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat involuntary actions followed?
 29381	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29382	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe compressed between 2 fingers the flesh circumjacent to a cicatrice in
 29383	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe left infracostal region below the diaphragm resulting from a sting
 29384	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinflicted 2 weeks and 3 days previously (23 May 1904) by a bee.
 29385	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe scratched imprecisely with his right hand, though insensible of
 29386	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprurition, various points and surfaces of his partly exposed, wholly
 29387	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tabluted skin. He inserted his left hand into the left lower pocket of
 29388	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this waistcoat and extracted and replaced a silver coin (1 shilling),
 29389	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tplaced there (presumably) on the occasion (17 October 1903) of the
 29390	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinterment of Mrs Emily Sinico, Sydney Parade.

 29426	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDid the process of divestiture continue?
 29427	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29428	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSensible of a benignant persistent ache in his footsoles he extended
 29429	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this foot to one side and observed the creases, protuberances and salient
 29430	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpoints caused by foot pressure in the course of walking repeatedly in
 29431	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseveral different directions, then, inclined, he disnoded the laceknots,
 29432	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunhooked and loosened the laces, took off each of his two boots for the
 29433	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsecond time, detached the partially moistened right sock through the
 29434	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfore part of which the nail of his great toe had again effracted, raised
 29435	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\this right foot and, having unhooked a purple elastic sock suspender,
 29436	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttook off his right sock, placed his unclothed right foot on the margin
 29437	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the seat of his chair, picked at and gently lacerated the protruding
 29438	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpart of the great toenail, raised the part lacerated to his nostrils and
 29439	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinhaled the odour of the quick, then, with satisfaction, threw away the
 29440	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlacerated ungual fragment.
 29441	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29442	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhy with satisfaction?
 29443	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29444	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBecause the odour inhaled corresponded to other odours inhaled of other
 29445	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tungual fragments, picked and lacerated by Master Bloom, pupil of Mrs
 29446	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEllis’s juvenile school, patiently each night in the act of brief
 29447	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgenuflection and nocturnal prayer and ambitious meditation.
 29448	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29449	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn what ultimate ambition had all concurrent and consecutive ambitions
 29450	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnow coalesced?
 29451	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29452	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNot to inherit by right of primogeniture, gavelkind or borough English,
 29453	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tor possess in perpetuity an extensive demesne of a sufficient number
 29454	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof acres, roods and perches, statute land measure (valuation £ 42), of
 29455	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgrazing turbary surrounding a baronial hall with gatelodge and carriage
 29456	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdrive nor, on the other hand, a terracehouse or semidetached villa,
 29457	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdescribed as Rus in Urbe or Qui si sana, but to purchase by private
 29458	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttreaty in fee simple a thatched bungalowshaped 2 storey dwellinghouse of
 29459	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsoutherly aspect, surmounted by vane and lightning conductor, connected
 29460	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith the earth, with porch covered by parasitic plants (ivy or Virginia
 29461	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcreeper), halldoor, olive green, with smart carriage finish and neat
 29462	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoorbrasses, stucco front with gilt tracery at eaves and gable, rising,
 29463	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tif possible, upon a gentle eminence with agreeable prospect from balcony
 29464	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith stone pillar parapet over unoccupied and unoccupyable interjacent
 29465	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpastures and standing in 5 or 6 acres of its own ground, at such
 29466	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta distance from the nearest public thoroughfare as to render its
 29467	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thouselights visible at night above and through a quickset hornbeam hedge
 29468	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof topiary cutting, situate at a given point not less than 1 statute
 29469	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmile from the periphery of the metropolis, within a time limit of not
 29470	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmore than 15 minutes from tram or train line (e.g., Dundrum, south, or
 29471	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSutton, north, both localities equally reported by trial to resemble the
 29472	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tterrestrial poles in being favourable climates for phthisical subjects),
 29473	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe premises to be held under feefarm grant, lease 999 years, the
 29474	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmessuage to consist of 1 drawingroom with baywindow (2 lancets),
 29475	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthermometer affixed, 1 sittingroom, 4 bedrooms, 2 servants’ rooms, tiled

 29541	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvelocipedes, a chainless freewheel roadster cycle with side basketcar
 29542	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tattached, or draught conveyance, a donkey with wicker trap or smart
 29543	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tphaeton with good working solidungular cob (roan gelding, 14 h).

 29550	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t

 29555	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof newmown hay, ameliorating the soil, multiplying wisdom, achieving
 29556	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlongevity.
 29557	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29558	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat syllabus of intellectual pursuits was simultaneously possible?
 29559	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29560	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSnapshot photography, comparative study of religions, folklore relative
 29561	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto various amatory and superstitious practices, contemplation of the
 29562	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcelestial constellations.
 29563	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29564	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat lighter recreations?
 29565	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29566	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOutdoor: garden and fieldwork, cycling on level macadamised causeways,
 29567	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tascents of moderately high hills, natation in secluded fresh water and
 29568	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunmolested river boating in secure wherry or light curricle with kedge
 29569	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanchor on reaches free from weirs and rapids (period of estivation),
 29570	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvespertinal perambulation or equestrian circumprocession with inspection
 29571	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof sterile landscape and contrastingly agreeable cottagers’ fires of
 29572	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsmoking peat turves (period of hibernation). Indoor: discussion in
 29573	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttepid security of unsolved historical and criminal problems: lecture of
 29574	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunexpurgated exotic erotic masterpieces: house carpentry with toolbox
 29575	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcontaining hammer, awl nails, screws, tintacks, gimlet, tweezers,
 29576	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbullnose plane and turnscrew.
 29577	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29578	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tMight he become a gentleman farmer of field produce and live stock?
 29579	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29580	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNot impossibly, with 1 or 2 stripper cows, 1 pike of upland hay and
 29581	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trequisite farming implements, e.g., an end-to-end churn, a turnip pulper
 29582	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tetc.
 29583	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29584	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat would be his civic functions and social status among the county
 29585	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfamilies and landed gentry?
 29586	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29587	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tArranged successively in ascending powers of hierarchical order, that
 29588	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof gardener, groundsman, cultivator, breeder, and at the zenith of his
 29589	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcareer, resident magistrate or justice of the peace with a family crest
 29590	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand coat of arms and appropriate classical motto (Semper paratus), duly
 29591	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trecorded in the court directory (Bloom, Leopold P., M. P., P. C., K. P.,
 29592	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tL. L. D. (honoris causa), Bloomville, Dundrum) and mentioned in court
 29593	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand fashionable intelligence (Mr and Mrs Leopold Bloom have left
 29594	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tKingstown for England).
 29595	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29596	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat course of action did he outline for himself in such capacity?
 29597	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29598	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA course that lay between undue clemency and excessive rigour:
 29599	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe dispensation in a heterogeneous society of arbitrary classes,
 29600	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tincessantly rearranged in terms of greater and lesser social inequality,
 29601	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof unbiassed homogeneous indisputable justice, tempered with mitigants
 29602	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the widest possible latitude but exactable to the uttermost farthing
 29603	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith confiscation of estate, real and personal, to the crown. Loyal to
 29604	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe highest constituted power in the land, actuated by an innate love of
 29605	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trectitude his aims would be the strict maintenance of public order,
 29606	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe repression of many abuses though not of all simultaneously (every
 29607	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmeasure of reform or retrenchment being a preliminary solution to be
 29608	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcontained by fluxion in the final solution), the upholding of the letter
 29609	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the law (common, statute and law merchant) against all traversers in
 29610	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcovin and trespassers acting in contravention of bylaws and regulations,
 29611	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tall resuscitators (by trespass and petty larceny of kindlings) of
 29612	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tvenville rights, obsolete by desuetude, all orotund instigators
 29613	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof international persecution, all perpetuators of international
 29614	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tanimosities, all menial molestors of domestic conviviality, all
 29615	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trecalcitrant violators of domestic connubiality.
 29616	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29617	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tProve that he had loved rectitude from his earliest youth.
 29618	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 29619	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTo Master Percy Apjohn at High School in 1880 he had divulged his
 29620	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdisbelief in the tenets of the Irish (protestant) church (to which his

 29899	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tformerly of Szombathely in the kingdom of Hungary, hereby give notice
 29900	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat I have assumed and intend henceforth upon all occasions and at all
 29901	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttimes to be known by the name of Rudolph Bloom.

 30034	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tparties, which was impossible.

 30206	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tside in white lettering B. C. T. (Brian Cooper Tweedy).

 30210	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tA commode, one leg fractured, totally covered by square cretonne
 30211	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcutting, apple design, on which rested a lady’s black straw hat.

 30213	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand ironmongery manufacturer, 21, 22, 23 Moore street, disposed

 30216	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t(on the floor, separate).

 30218	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBloom’s acts?
 30219	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30220	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe deposited the articles of clothing on a chair, removed his remaining
 30221	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tarticles of clothing, took from beneath the bolster at the head of the
 30222	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbed a folded long white nightshirt, inserted his head and arms into the
 30223	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tproper apertures of the nightshirt, removed a pillow from the head to
 30224	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe foot of the bed, prepared the bedlinen accordingly and entered the
 30225	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbed.

 30229	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWith circumspection, as invariably when entering an abode (his own or
 30230	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnot his own): with solicitude, the snakespiral springs of the mattress
 30231	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbeing old, the brass quoits and pendent viper radii loose and tremulous
 30232	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunder stress and strain: prudently, as entering a lair or ambush of
 30233	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlust or adders: lightly, the less to disturb: reverently, the bed of
 30234	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconception and of birth, of consummation of marriage and of breach of
 30235	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmarriage, of sleep and of death.
 30236	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30237	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat did his limbs, when gradually extended, encounter?
 30238	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30239	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tNew clean bedlinen, additional odours, the presence of a human form,
 30240	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfemale, hers, the imprint of a human form, male, not his, some crumbs,
 30241	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsome flakes of potted meat, recooked, which he removed.
 30242	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30243	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIf he had smiled why would he have smiled?
 30244	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30245	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tTo reflect that each one who enters imagines himself to be the first to
 30246	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tenter whereas he is always the last term of a preceding series even if
 30247	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe first term of a succeeding one, each imagining himself to be first,
 30248	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlast, only and alone whereas he is neither first nor last nor only nor
 30249	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\talone in a series originating in and repeated to infinity.
 30250	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30251	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat preceding series?

 30253	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAssuming Mulvey to be the first term of his series, Penrose, Bartell

 30261	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tat the General Post Office, Hugh E. (Blazes) Boylan and so each and so
 30262	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton to no last term.
 30263	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30264	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat were his reflections concerning the last member of this series and
 30265	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlate occupant of the bed?
 30266	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30267	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tReflections on his vigour (a bounder), corporal proportion (a
 30268	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbillsticker), commercial ability (a bester), impressionability (a
 30269	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tboaster).
 30270	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30271	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhy for the observer impressionability in addition to vigour, corporal
 30272	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tproportion and commercial ability?
 30273	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30274	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBecause he had observed with augmenting frequency in the preceding
 30275	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmembers of the same series the same concupiscence, inflammably
 30276	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttransmitted, first with alarm, then with understanding, then with
 30277	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdesire, finally with fatigue, with alternating symptoms of epicene
 30278	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcomprehension and apprehension.
 30279	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30280	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWith what antagonistic sentiments were his subsequent reflections
 30281	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taffected?
 30282	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30283	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEnvy, jealousy, abnegation, equanimity.
 30284	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30285	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEnvy?
 30286	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30287	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tOf a bodily and mental male organism specially adapted for the
 30288	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsuperincumbent posture of energetic human copulation and energetic
 30289	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpiston and cylinder movement necessary for the complete satisfaction of
 30290	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta constant but not acute concupiscence resident in a bodily and mental
 30291	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfemale organism, passive but not obtuse.
 30292	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30293	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tJealousy?
 30294	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30295	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBecause a nature full and volatile in its free state, was alternately
 30296	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe agent and reagent of attraction. Because attraction between agent(s)
 30297	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand reagent(s) at all instants varied, with inverse proportion of
 30298	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tincrease and decrease, with incessant circular extension and radial
 30299	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treentrance. Because the controlled contemplation of the fluctuation of
 30300	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tattraction produced, if desired, a fluctuation of pleasure.
 30301	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30302	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAbnegation?
 30303	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30304	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn virtue of a) acquaintance initiated in September 1903 in the
 30305	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\testablishment of George Mesias, merchant tailor and outfitter, 5 Eden
 30306	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tQuay, b) hospitality extended and received in kind, reciprocated and
 30307	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treappropriated in person, c) comparative youth subject to impulses of
 30308	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tambition and magnanimity, colleagual altruism and amorous egoism, d)
 30309	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\textraracial attraction, intraracial inhibition, supraracial prerogative,
 30310	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\te) an imminent provincial musical tour, common current expenses, net
 30311	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tproceeds divided.
 30312	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30313	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tEquanimity?
 30314	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30315	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAs as natural as any and every natural act of a nature expressed or
 30316	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunderstood executed in natured nature by natural creatures in accordance
 30317	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith his, her and their natured natures, of dissimilar similarity.
 30318	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAs not so calamitous as a cataclysmic annihilation of the planet in
 30319	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconsequence of a collision with a dark sun. As less reprehensible than
 30320	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheft, highway robbery, cruelty to children and animals, obtaining money
 30321	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunder false pretences, forgery, embezzlement, misappropriation of public
 30322	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmoney, betrayal of public trust, malingering, mayhem, corruption of
 30323	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tminors, criminal libel, blackmail, contempt of court, arson, treason,
 30324	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfelony, mutiny on the high seas, trespass, burglary, jailbreaking,
 30325	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpractice of unnatural vice, desertion from armed forces in the field,
 30326	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tperjury, poaching, usury, intelligence with the king’s enemies,
 30327	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\timpersonation, criminal assault, manslaughter, wilful and premeditated
 30328	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmurder. As not more abnormal than all other parallel processes of
 30329	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tadaptation to altered conditions of existence, resulting in a reciprocal
 30330	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tequilibrium between the bodily organism and its attendant circumstances,
 30331	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfoods, beverages, acquired habits, indulged inclinations, significant
 30332	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdisease. As more than inevitable, irreparable.
 30333	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30334	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhy more abnegation than jealousy, less envy than equanimity?
 30335	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30336	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tFrom outrage (matrimony) to outrage (adultery) there arose nought but
 30337	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\toutrage (copulation) yet the matrimonial violator of the matrimonially
 30338	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tviolated had not been outraged by the adulterous violator of the
 30339	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tadulterously violated.
 30340	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30341	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tWhat retribution, if any?
 30342	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30343	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAssassination, never, as two wrongs did not make one right. Duel by
 30344	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcombat, no. Divorce, not now. Exposure by mechanical artifice (automatic
 30345	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbed) or individual testimony (concealed ocular witnesses), not yet. Suit
 30346	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor damages by legal influence or simulation of assault with evidence of
 30347	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinjuries sustained (selfinflicted), not impossibly. Hushmoney by moral
 30348	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinfluence, possibly. If any, positively, connivance, introduction of
 30349	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\temulation (material, a prosperous rival agency of publicity: moral,
 30350	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta successful rival agent of intimacy), depreciation, alienation,
 30351	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thumiliation, separation protecting the one separated from the other,
 30352	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprotecting the separator from both.
 30353	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30354	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBy what reflections did he, a conscious reactor against the void of
 30355	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tincertitude, justify to himself his sentiments?
 30356	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30357	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe preordained frangibility of the hymen: the presupposed intangibility
 30358	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the thing in itself: the incongruity and disproportion between
 30359	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe selfprolonging tension of the thing proposed to be done and the
 30360	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tselfabbreviating relaxation of the thing done: the fallaciously inferred
 30361	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdebility of the female: the muscularity of the male: the variations of
 30362	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tethical codes: the natural grammatical transition by inversion involving
 30363	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tno alteration of sense of an aorist preterite proposition (parsed as
 30364	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmasculine subject, monosyllabic onomatopoeic transitive verb with direct
 30365	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfeminine object) from the active voice into its correlative aorist
 30366	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpreterite proposition (parsed as feminine subject, auxiliary verb
 30367	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand quasimonosyllabic onomatopoeic past participle with complementary
 30368	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmasculine agent) in the passive voice: the continued product of
 30369	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseminators by generation: the continual production of semen by
 30370	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdistillation: the futility of triumph or protest or vindication: the
 30371	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinanity of extolled virtue: the lethargy of nescient matter: the apathy
 30372	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof the stars.

 30375	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treflections, reduced to their simplest forms, converge?

 30382	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tseminal warmth, reminiscent of secular families of curves of amplitude,
 30383	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tinsusceptible of moods of impression or of contrarieties of expression,
 30384	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\texpressive of mute immutable mature animality.

 30420	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcourse of a postcenal gymnastic display, the victim (since completely
 30421	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\trecovered) being Stephen Dedalus, professor and author, eldest surviving

 30423	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\texecuted by him (narrator) in the presence of a witness, the professor

 30438	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30439	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBy the listener a limitation of fertility inasmuch as marriage had been
 30440	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcelebrated 1 calendar month after the 18th anniversary of her birth (8
 30441	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSeptember 1870), viz. 8 October, and consummated on the same date with
 30442	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfemale issue born 15 June 1889, having been anticipatorily consummated
 30443	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ton the 10 September of the same year and complete carnal intercourse,
 30444	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twith ejaculation of semen within the natural female organ, having last
 30445	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttaken place 5 weeks previous, viz. 27 November 1893, to the birth on 29
 30446	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDecember 1893 of second (and only male) issue, deceased 9 January 1894,
 30447	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taged 11 days, there remained a period of 10 years, 5 months and 18 days
 30448	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tduring which carnal intercourse had been incomplete, without ejaculation
 30449	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof semen within the natural female organ. By the narrator a limitation
 30450	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tof activity, mental and corporal, inasmuch as complete mental
 30451	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tintercourse between himself and the listener had not taken place since
 30452	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe consummation of puberty, indicated by catamenic hemorrhage, of the
 30453	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfemale issue of narrator and listener, 15 September 1903, there remained
 30454	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta period of 9 months and 1 day during which, in consequence of a
 30455	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tpreestablished natural comprehension in incomprehension between the
 30456	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconsummated females (listener and issue), complete corporal liberty of
 30457	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\taction had been circumscribed.

 30460	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30461	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tBy various reiterated feminine interrogation concerning the masculine
 30462	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdestination whither, the place where, the time at which, the duration
 30463	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfor which, the object with which in the case of temporary absences,
 30464	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tprojected or effected.

 30467	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthoughts?

 30469	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tThe upcast reflection of a lamp and shade, an inconstant series of
 30470	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tconcentric circles of varying gradations of light and shadow.
 30471	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30472	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn what directions did listener and narrator lie?
 30473	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30474	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tListener, S. E. by E.: Narrator, N. W. by W.: on the 53rd parallel of
 30475	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlatitude, N., and 6th meridian of longitude, W.: at an angle of 45° to
 30476	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe terrestrial equator.
 30477	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30478	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn what state of rest or motion?
 30479	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30480	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tAt rest relatively to themselves and to each other. In motion being each
 30481	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tand both carried westward, forward and rereward respectively, by the
 30482	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tproper perpetual motion of the earth through everchanging tracks of
 30483	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tneverchanging space.
 30484	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30485	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIn what posture?
 30486	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\t
 30487	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tListener: reclined semilaterally, left, left hand under head, right
 30488	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tleg extended in a straight line and resting on left leg, flexed, in the
 30489	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tattitude of Gea-Tellus, fulfilled, recumbent, big with seed. Narrator:
 30490	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\treclined laterally, left, with right and left legs flexed, the index
 30491	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tfinger and thumb of the right hand resting on the bridge of the nose, in
 30492	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe attitude depicted in a snapshot photograph made by Percy Apjohn, the
 30493	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tchildman weary, the manchild in the womb.

 32059	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhat harm Dedalus I wonder its like those names in Gibraltar Delapaz
 32060	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tDelagracia they had the devils queer names there father Vilaplana of
 32061	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSanta Maria that gave me the rosary Rosales y OReilly in the Calle las
 32062	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tSiete Revueltas and Pisimbo and Mrs Opisso in Governor street O what a
 32063	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tname Id go and drown myself in the first river if I had a name like
 32064	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ther O my and all the bits of streets Paradise ramp and Bedlam ramp and
 32065	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tRodgers ramp and Crutchetts ramp and the devils gap steps well small
 32066	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tblame to me if I am a harumscarum I know I am a bit I declare to God I
 32067	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdont feel a day older than then I wonder could I get my tongue round
 32068	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tany of the Spanish como esta usted muy bien gracias y usted see I havent
 32069	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tforgotten it all I thought I had only for the grammar a noun is the
 32070	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tname of any person place or thing pity I never tried to read that novel
 32071	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcantankerous Mrs Rubio lent me by Valera with the questions in it all
 32072	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tupside down the two ways I always knew wed go away in the end I can
 32073	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttell him the Spanish and he tell me the Italian then hell see Im not
 32074	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tso ignorant what a pity he didnt stay Im sure the poor fellow was dead
 32075	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttired and wanted a good sleep badly I could have brought him in his
 32076	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbreakfast in bed with a bit of toast so long as I didnt do it on
 32077	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe knife for bad luck or if the woman was going her rounds with the
 32078	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twatercress and something nice and tasty there are a few olives in the
 32079	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tkitchen he might like I never could bear the look of them in Abrines
 32080	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tI could do the criada the room looks all right since I changed it the
 32081	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tother way you see something was telling me all the time Id have to
 32082	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tintroduce myself not knowing me from Adam very funny wouldnt it Im his
 32083	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twife or pretend we were in Spain with him half awake without a Gods
 32084	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnotion where he is dos huevos estrellados senor Lord the cracked things
 32085	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcome into my head sometimes itd be great fun supposing he stayed with us
 32086	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhy not theres the room upstairs empty and Millys bed in the back room
 32087	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\the could do his writing and studies at the table in there for all the
 32088	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tscribbling he does at it and if he wants to read in bed in the morning
 32089	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlike me as hes making the breakfast for 1 he can make it for 2 Im sure
 32090	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIm not going to take in lodgers off the street for him if he takes
 32091	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ta gesabo of a house like this Id love to have a long talk with an
 32092	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tintelligent welleducated person Id have to get a nice pair of red
 32093	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tslippers like those Turks with the fez used to sell or yellow and a
 32094	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnice semitransparent morning gown that I badly want or a peachblossom
 32095	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdressing jacket like the one long ago in Walpoles only 8/6 or 18/6 Ill
 32096	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tjust give him one more chance Ill get up early in the morning Im sick of
 32097	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tCohens old bed in any case I might go over to the markets to see all
 32098	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe vegetables and cabbages and tomatoes and carrots and all kinds of
 32099	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tsplendid fruits all coming in lovely and fresh who knows whod be the 1st
 32100	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tman Id meet theyre out looking for it in the morning Mamy Dillon used
 32101	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto say they are and the night too that was her massgoing Id love a
 32102	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbig juicy pear now to melt in your mouth like when I used to be in the
 32103	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlonging way then Ill throw him up his eggs and tea in the moustachecup
 32104	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshe gave him to make his mouth bigger I suppose hed like my nice cream
 32105	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttoo I know what Ill do Ill go about rather gay not too much singing a
 32106	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbit now and then mi fa pieta Masetto then Ill start dressing myself to
 32107	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tgo out presto non son piu forte Ill put on my best shift and drawers let
 32108	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim have a good eyeful out of that to make his micky stand for him Ill
 32109	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tlet him know if thats what he wanted that his wife is fucked yes and
 32110	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdamn well fucked too up to my neck nearly not by him 5 or 6 times
 32111	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thandrunning theres the mark of his spunk on the clean sheet I wouldnt
 32112	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbother to even iron it out that ought to satisfy him if you dont believe
 32113	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tme feel my belly unless I made him stand there and put him into me Ive a
 32114	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tmind to tell him every scrap and make him do it out in front of me serve
 32115	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thim right its all his own fault if I am an adulteress as the thing in
 32116	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe gallery said O much about it if thats all the harm ever we did in
 32117	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthis vale of tears God knows its not much doesnt everybody only they
 32118	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\thide it I suppose thats what a woman is supposed to be there for or
 32119	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tHe wouldnt have made us the way He did so attractive to men then if he
 32120	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twants to kiss my bottom Ill drag open my drawers and bulge it right out
 32121	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin his face as large as life he can stick his tongue 7 miles up my hole
 32122	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tas hes there my brown part then Ill tell him I want £ 1 or perhaps 30/-
 32123	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tIll tell him I want to buy underclothes then if he gives me that well he
 32124	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twont be too bad I dont want to soak it all out of him like other women
 32125	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdo I could often have written out a fine cheque for myself and write his
 32126	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tname on it for a couple of pounds a few times he forgot to lock it up
 32127	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbesides he wont spend it Ill let him do it off on me behind provided he
 32128	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tdoesnt smear all my good drawers O I suppose that cant be helped Ill do
 32129	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe indifferent 1 or 2 questions Ill know by the answers when hes like
 32130	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthat he cant keep a thing back I know every turn in him Ill tighten my
 32131	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbottom well and let out a few smutty words smellrump or lick my shit or
 32132	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthe first mad thing comes into my head then Ill suggest about yes O wait
 32133	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnow sonny my turn is coming Ill be quite gay and friendly over it O
 32134	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tbut I was forgetting this bloody pest of a thing pfooh you wouldnt know
 32135	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\twhich to laugh or cry were such a mixture of plum and apple no Ill have
 32136	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tto wear the old things so much the better itll be more pointed hell
 32137	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tnever know whether he did it or not there thats good enough for you
 32138	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tany old thing at all then Ill wipe him off me just like a business his
 32139	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tomission then Ill go out Ill have him eying up at the ceiling where is
 32140	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tshe gone now make him want me thats the only way a quarter after what an
 32141	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tunearthly hour I suppose theyre just getting up in China now combing out
 32142	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\ttheir pigtails for the day well soon have the nuns ringing the angelus

 32147	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tin Lombard street was much nicer the apron he gave me was like that

 32167	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tthey go and create something I often asked him atheists or whatever they
 32168	UlyssesbyJamesJoyce.txt\tcall themselves go and wash the cobbles off themselves first then they
